Slide 6: Title: Conclusion  The combination of Mr. Doe's presenting symptoms  history of chronic diseases  and lifestyle all contribute to a high likelihood of acute ischemic stroke. An immediate response is required to limit the potential disability and damage produced by this event.

Title: Patient Presentation: Acute Stroke  Patient Information:  Patient is a 72-year-old African American male named Mr. James Rutherford  retired. He presented at the emergency department accompanied by his daughter who noticed his unusual behavior and symptoms.  Chief Complaint:  The patient's daughter reports that  early this morning  she noticed her father having difficulty speaking  his words were slurred and he seemed to not make sense at times. She also noticed that the right side of his face drooped and he was having difficulty moving his right arm and leg.  Past Medical History: Mr. Rutherford has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both managed with medication. He had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) about 5 years ago.   Habitual History:  The patient has been a smoker for around 50 years  averaging 15 cigarettes a day but has been trying to quit smoking for the past two years without much success.  Family History: Both of his parents had hypertension  and his father died from a stroke at the age of 78. Mr. Rutherford’s older brother was recently diagnosed with early-stage dementia.  Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient appeared drowsy but was responsive to verbal stimuli. His vitals are as follows: BP – 155/95 mmHg  HR – 89 beats/min  RR – 18 breaths/min  Temperature – 98.6F  Oxygen saturation – 96% on room air. Neurological examination revealed right-sided facial droop  slurred speech  right-side hemiparesis (reduced muscle strength)  and reduced tactile sense on the right side of his body. Rest of the physical exam including cardiac  pulmonary  and abdominal were within normal limits.  This clinical presentation raises strong suspicion for an acute ischemic stroke. Immediate CT scan of the head was ordered to rule out a hemorrhagic stroke before starting treatment with thrombolytics.

Title: Presentation of a Patient Presenting with Stroke  Patient Information: Name: Mrs. Alicia Johnson Age: 56 years old Sex: Female Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Retired school teacher Residency: Portland  Oregon Marital status: Widowed Insurance: Medicare  Presenting Concern:  Mrs. Johnson presents with symptoms suggestive of a possible stroke occurring within the past few hours. She was found by her son struggling to speak clearly  a significant drooping of the right side of her face  and difficulty raising her right arm above her head.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Johnson has a history of hypertension over the past 10 years and type II diabetes mellitus for about 8 years. Both conditions are generally well controlled with medications. She also has a history of hypercholesterolemia diagnosed 3 years back. She has no known allergies and does not have a previous history of stroke or transient ischemic attacks. No history of heart disease or other severe illnesses.  Family History:  Her father suffered a stroke at the age of 62. Her mother died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 59. She has one older brother who has been diagnosed with hypertension.  Lifestyle:  She is a non-smoker  rarely drinks alcohol  and follows a balanced diet  though admits to an inconsistent exercise regime. She lives alone since her husband died two years ago.  Medication History:  She has been prescribed Lisinopril for hypertension  Metformin and Glipizide for diabetes management  and Atorvastatin for hypercholesterolemia.  Upon arrival at the emergency department  Mrs. Johnson continues to display unilateral weakness on her right side; she has slurred speech and appears confused. The pending investigations will likely allow us to determine if she has suffered from a stroke  what type  and the course of treatment that may be necessary moving forward depending on the severity of her condition.   It is recommended that Mrs. Johnson’s son or other family members be available for ongoing discussion regarding her health status and care plan upon confirming the diagnosis.

Presentation of Patient with Stroke  Patient Background   The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. Johnson. He is a retired school teacher who lives with his wife in the suburbs. Mr. Johnson has been an active member of his community  regularly engaging in social  intellectual activities. He is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally  and maintains a balanced diet.   Past Medical History  Mr. Johnson has a medical background of well-controlled hypertension for the past 10 years  managed with Lisinopril. He also has a history of type II diabetes  managed with Metformin  diagnosed six years ago. His LDL cholesterol levels have been borderline high and he has been on low-dose Statin.   History of the Present Illness  Mr. Johnson had been found suddenly collapsed in his study room. According to the wife  he had complained of a severe headache and weakness in the morning. A neighbour  a registered nurse  had identified signs of left-sided weakness and slurred speech. EMS was immediately called and patient was brought to the hospital.   Initial Physical Examination  On arrival  his BP was 160/90mmHg  pulse rate 80bpm  and he was breathing at a rate of 20 breaths per minute. His GCS was 13/15. Neurological exam revealed left facial droop  left-sided weakness (grade 3/5 in both upper and lower limbs)  and slurred speech.   These symptoms suggested that Mr. Johnson had suffered a stroke  and he was immediately sent for a CT scan to confirm. The results are pending.  Risk Factors  Primary risk factors include his age  chronic hypertension  type II diabetes  high cholesterol levels and gender. His sedentary lifestyle might have also contributed.   Treatment and Management  His treatment will include immediate measures to restore blood flow to the brain  following which chronic management will involve controlling his hypertension  diabetes and hyperlipidemia. Rehabilitation will likely be an important component of his recovery.   In conclusion  Mr. Johnson’s immediate medical needs are being addressed. However  his chronic conditions and lifestyle will need to be managed to prevent a recurrence of this serious event.

Title: Case Presentation of a Stroke Patient  I. Demographic Information  The patient is a 65-year-old African American female named Mary Smith.   II. Presenting Issue  Mrs. Smith was brought to the emergency department due to sudden onset of weakness in her right arm and speech difficulty. These symptoms started approximately 3 hours before her arrival at the hospital.  III. Past Medical History  Mrs. Smith has a 10-year history of hypertension and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago. Both conditions are under fair control with medications. She was an active smoker until she quit 8 years ago  though she has a 30-pack-year smoking history.  IV. Family History  She has a family history of cerebrovascular diseases. Her father passed away at the age of 73 due to a hemorrhagic stroke while her older sister is surviving with the sequels of an ischemic stroke.  V. Other Pertinent Information  Mrs. Smith lives with her husband  who is her primary caregiver. She is retired and maintains an active lifestyle with regular exercise. She follows a diet recommended for hypertensive and diabetic patients. She adheres to her prescribed medication regimen  which includes amlodipine for hypertension and metformin for diabetes control. However  she does not recall taking any medication on the day of the incident.  VI. Conclusion Given her presenting symptoms  along with her past medical history and lifestyle factors  she is suspected to have suffered an ischemic stroke. She is currently undergoing a brain imaging workup and her treatment protocol will be tailored based on her diagnostic findings and clinical status. Immediate protocols are in place for urgent stroke management  along with addressing her comorbid conditions of hypertension and diabetes  both risk factors for stroke.

Introduction:   Today I will present the case of Mrs. Lona Thompson  a 68-year-old African-American female who was brought to the ER with signs and symptoms consistent with stroke.   Demographics:   Mrs. Thompson is a retired school teacher living in Charleston  South Carolina. She is widowed  a mother of three adult children  and lives alone. As per her information  she is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol sparingly. Prior to retirement  she led a fairly active lifestyle  but currently describes it as sedentary.  Medical History:   She has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which have been managed with medication for the past 10 years. Mrs. Thompson is also a survivor of breast cancer  which was diagnosed and successfully treated 5 years ago. She is currently on Metformin for her diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Tamoxifen for her history of breast cancer. Mrs. Thompson admits to lifestyle inconsistencies that sometimes affect her blood sugar and pressure control.   Presenting Symptoms:   Earlier today  Mrs. Thompson experienced sudden onset weakness on the right side of her body  difficulty speaking and a drooping face on the right side. She also reported a severe headache with no known cause. Her symptoms are indicative of an ischemic stroke. The patient was brought to the ER approximately 1.5 hours after the presentation of symptoms.   In conclusion  given her risk factors of uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  sedentary lifestyle  and advanced age  Mrs. Thompson is at significant risk for a stroke. Her current symptoms match the textbook definition of stroke and immediate medical intervention is warranted.

PRESENTATION OF A PATIENT   Demographics:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named John Smith who reports his occupation as a retired civil engineer. He resides in Sunset Hills  Oklahoma and lives with his wife of 40 years.   Presenting Problem:  Mr. Smith arrived at the Emergency Department (ED) in an ambulance after experiencing sudden onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty in maintaining balance. His wife mentioned that the symptoms began suddenly while they were having breakfast at around 8:30 am today.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a documented history of Hypertension (HTN) and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) which have been managed with medications for the past 10 years. He was also diagnosed with Atrial Fibrillation (AF) 5 years ago  for which he has been on Warfarin therapy. He has no known allergies.  Medication History: He takes Metformin 1000mg twice daily for his T2DM and Losartan 100mg once daily for his HTN. His Coumadin dose for AF has been adjusted to keep his INR between 2.0 and 3.0.  Surgical History:  Mr. Smith had an appendectomy at age 25 and right hip replacement surgery at age 62 with no complications.   Family History:  Both his parents had HTN and his father had a stroke at age 70. His mother died at age 75 due to heart failure. His only sibling  a brother  also has HTN and T2DM.  Social History:  Mr. Smith is a nonsmoker and reports a history of moderate alcohol consumption. He has been retired for five years and enjoys woodworking and bird-watching. He has remained active  with daily walks around his neighborhood.   Assessment: Given Mr. Smith's recent onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and loss of balance in hand with his medical history of HTN  T2DM  and AF  the preliminary diagnosis is that of an Ischemic Stroke. However  further examination with CT imaging  neurological examination  and confirmation of his INR level is necessary before moving forward with treatment interventions.

Title: Patient Presentation and Medical History: Stroke   Patient's Name: Mr. John Doe  Age: 70 years old  Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired from software engineering  Presenting Issue: Acute Stroke  Mr. John Doe  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  renowned software engineer retired from service  presents himself to the emergency having symptoms indicative of an acute left-sided ischemic stroke. The onset of symptoms  including mild confusion  abrupt numbness and weakness in the right side of his body  started approximately two hours prior to admission.   Past Medical History:   1. Hypertension: The patient was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago and is on regular antihypertensive medication (Losartan 50 mg  once daily).   2. Type 2 Diabetes: Diagnosed 10 years ago  controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents (Metformin 500 mg  twice daily). Regular follow-up shows satisfactory glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels.  3. Dyslipidemia: Patient has had high LDL cholesterol levels in the past and is taking a daily dose of Atorvastatin (20 mg).   4. Previous Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA): The patient had one episode of TIA 5 years back. He had fully recovered from the episode without any residual disability.   Social History:  Mr. Doe is a non-smoker and used to consume alcohol socially  which he stopped around the time he was diagnosed with diabetes. He lives with his wife  and they have two adult children. He maintains a good diet  exercises regularly  and is generally compliant with his medications.  In summary  Mr. John Doe is presenting symptoms of an acute stroke  notably on the left brain affecting the right side of his body  with significant past medical history of diabetes  hypertension  dyslipidemia  and a previous TIA. As a healthcare team  we have an urgent situation to mitigate the risk and potential damage from this stroke. Timely intervention can help to control his various risk factors and potentially provide him with a better prognosis.

Presentation of Patient with Stroke  Good day  I will be presenting a patient who was diagnosed with a stroke.  Demographic Information  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who resides at a senior care facility in Madison  Wisconsin. The patient is married  a retired engineer  and is a non-smoker. He lives a relatively sedentary lifestyle and states that he maintains a balanced diet  but has a predisposition to high salt intake.   Presenting Complaint  At 6:30 AM  the patient was found on the floor of his room by a staff member. Reportedly  he was unable to stand and exhibited confusion and an inability to articulate speech clearly. The symptoms were noticed approximately 30 to 45 minutes from the time of discovery.   Past Medical History  The patient has a known history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus which has been managed with antihypertensive medications (Lisinopril 10 mg daily) and oral hypoglycemic agents (Metformin 500 mg twice daily). We also noted from his records that he had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 3 years ago. He does not have any known allergies. He underwent a hip replacement surgery 2 years prior and recovery was uneventful. His last routine checkup was six months ago and all vital parameters were within normal limits except blood pressure which has consistently been at prehypertensive range.   Family History  The patient’s father died at the age of 63 due to Myocardial Infarction and his mother died at 70 due to Alzheimer's Disease  indicating a potential genetic predisposition to cardiovascular disease.   The preliminary assessment has been completed  and the patient was promptly sent to ER for immediate management. The symptoms and past medical history indicate the need to evaluate for possible stroke. Immediate stroke protocol has been activated for the patient. We recommend a neurological evaluation and an immediate CT scan to assess the situation accurately.  Thank you for your attention and I am open to any further questions or suggestions.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 67-years-old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Banker Ethnicity: Caucasian Address: 123 Lincoln St  Springfield  IL   Presenting Complaint:   Mr. John Doe  presented to the emergency room with a sudden onset of weakness in the right side of his body  difficulty with speech  and one-sided facial droop.   History of presenting illness:  The patient complained of awakening with the above symptoms approximately 3 hours prior to presentation to the hospital. He reported no preceding aura or associated symptoms such as headache  seizure  or loss of consciousness. His neurological deficits appeared to persist without any relief or noticeable changes.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a known history of hypertension for the past 15 years  for which he is on hydrochlorothiazide and lisinopril. He is also a type 2 diabetic for the past 10 years  managed on metformin and regular diet control. He had a diagnosis of transient ischemic attack (TIA) about 5 years ago after which he was prescribed aspirin as a secondary preventive measure. There is also a history of hyperlipidemia for which he takes atorvastatin.   Social History:  Mr. Doe has a 40 pack-year history of smoking but he quit 5 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally. He lives with his wife and has three adult children.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  Mr. Doe had a blood pressure of 160/98 mmHg and heart rate of 78 bpm. He appeared conscious but anxious. His speech was slurred and he had difficulty identifying common objects. Facial droop  right side hemiparesis  and decreased power and sensation on the right side of the body were observed.  Based on the clinical presentation  the initial diagnosis is an acute ischemic stroke  possibly due to uncontrolled hypertension and history of TIA. Detailed neurological examination and radiological investigations are being pursued for confirmation of the diagnosis and further management. Considering his medical history and lifestyle  Mr. Doe is at a high risk for such cerebrovascular events. Prompt management and further control of modifiable risk factors are imperative.  **Disclaimer: The above text is fictional and is created for illustrative purposes. Real-world use should consider all factors in a patient's medical history and current health status. Always follow local and national guidelines when treating patients.

Patient Presentation:  Introduction: Today  I will present a patient identified as Mr. Roger Mitchell. He is a 68-year-old Caucasian male patient who has had the recent onset of stroke symptoms.  Demographic information: Mr. Mitchell resides in Brooklyn  New York. He lives with his wife in their home. He is a retired engineer and enjoys spending his free time with his grandchildren.  Past Medical History: Mr. Mitchell has a notable history of hypertension and Type-2 diabetes mellitus  which he has managed for the past ten years. Earlier this year  he was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation but was adamant about not taking the prescribed medication because of potential side effects. He is currently on Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. He is not a smoker and maintains a moderate consumption of alcohol.  Presentation: Mr. Mitchell was brought to the emergency department by his wife  who noticed sudden-onset unresponsiveness and slurred speech while they were having lunch. This was accompanied by a drooping face on the right side  weakness in the right arm  and difficulty walking.   The stroke symptoms had a clear onset  which is likely suggestive of an ischemic stroke. Narrowing or blockage of arteries due to his medical conditions might have played a role in this. Immediate initiation of stroke protocol including neuroimaging  clinical examination  and laboratory investigations are very crucial to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of stroke.   I further advise initiating thrombolytic therapy as soon as clinically feasible considering his risk factors  particularly atrial fibrillation not on anticoagulants and other comorbidities. As he has arrived within 3 hours of symptom initiation  reperfusion therapies can be considered if appropriate. In the long term  effective diabetes and hypertension management  initiation of anticoagulant for atrial fibrillation  and lifestyle modifications need to be addressed and implemented.  This concludes the briefing on Mr. Mitchell. We shall continue to monitor his progress and prioritize his immediate health needs.

Subject: Presentation of a Patient Presenting with Stroke  Patient Information: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John Smith  who resides in Pittsburgh  PA. He is a retired civil engineer and lives with his wife at home. He is a former smoker  with a 40 pack-year history but quit smoking ten years ago. He does not consume alcohol and leads a sedentary lifestyle. Mr. Smith was brought to the emergency department by his wife this morning due to sudden speech difficulty and weakness on his right side.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a known history of chronic conditions that include hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which have been managed with medication for the past fifteen years. He also has hyperlipidemia controlled by a statin. He was treated for prostate cancer two years ago  with no recent signs of recurrence. He has no known allergies but has a family history of strokes and heart disease  with his father having passed away from a myocardial infarction at age 72  and his older brother experiencing a stroke at age 65.   Recent Health Developments: The patient's wife reported that Mr. Smith has been feeling fatigued for the past week and complained about a headache yesterday evening. This morning  around 7:30 AM  while having breakfast  Mr. Smith was noted to have slurred speech and drooping on the right side of his face. His wife also noticed that he was having difficulty moving his right arm and leg.  Summary: In summary  Mr. Smith is a 67-year-old male presenting with the sudden onset of right-sided weakness and speech difficulty  consistent with a stroke. Given Mr. Smith's underlying medical conditions (hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia)  alongside his family history  he is at a higher risk for a stroke. His condition requires immediate attention and further testing to confirm the diagnosis and commence appropriate treatment promptly.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Stroke  Patient's Profile: Mr. Ted Richards  a 64-year-old Caucasian male  hailing from Springfield  Massachusetts  was brought to the emergency department on Monday. He is a retired serviceman and lives with his wife. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack year history before quitting 10 years ago. He has a moderate alcohol intake  drinking about 100g of alcohol per week  but denies any illicit drug use.   Past Medical History: Mr. Richards has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes mellitus type 2 which are all well-managed with medication. Additionally  he suffered a myocardial infarction eight years ago for which he underwent stent placement. Unfortunately  he has not been compliant with the prescribed cardiovascular exercise program due to chronic low back pain.  Clinical Manifestations: Upon arrival at the hospital  Mr. Richards presented with sudden-onset left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking  which started about 90 minutes prior. His family noticed these changes while he was watching television. His speech was slurred and he was unable to lift his left arm. There is no reported loss of consciousness or seizures. He also denied headache  visual changes  or dizziness.  On examination  vital signs were stable. Neurological examination noted significant weakness in the left upper and lower extremities with the power of 2/5. He had left facial droop and slurred speech  with no significant comprehension or naming difficulty observed. Both pupils were equal and reactive. In addition to this  no signs of neglect  visual field deficits  or sensory-level changes were noted.  Given Mr. Richard's age  history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and current presentation  a stroke is highly suspected. The stroke team has been activated  and the patient is being further evaluated via necessary investigations including CT scan of the brain  blood work  and potential thrombolytic options are being explored.   An early diagnosis and immediate intervention are crucial in addressing Mr. Richards's condition and minimizing potential long-term neurological damage. His attending physician will be monitoring his progress closely and updating his family as appropriate.   This case underlines the importance of patient education regarding the recognition of stroke symptoms and the urgency of seeking timely medical intervention to maximize recovery potential and limit disability.

Slide 1: Introduction   Patient's Initial: Mr. T.J  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with acute onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech.  Slide 2: Demographics   Mr. T.J. is a retired engineer who lives with his wife. He is living in Boston  Massachusetts. He is a non-smoker  drinks socially  and lives an active lifestyle.   Slide 3: Previous Medical History   The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  for which he has been taking Lisinopril  Atorvastatin  and Metformin respectively. He has no known allergies.  Slide 4: Recent Healthcare Interactions  Mr. T.J. has been seen regularly every 3 months for control of diabetic and hypertensive status by his primary care physician. His blood pressure and glucose control have been reported to be fairly controlled.  Slide 5: Presentation of the Complaint   This morning  while having breakfast with his wife  Mr. T.J. suddenly started experiencing weakness on his right side. He found himself unable to lift his coffee cup or speak clearly. He denied any headache  vision changes  balance issues  or loss of consciousness.   Slide 6: Neurological Examination and Diagnosis   Upon examination  Mr. T.J. showed features of right-sided hemiparesis and dysarthria  indicative of a left hemispheric stroke event. An emergent CT scan of the brain confirmed the initial diagnosis of ischemic stroke.  Slide 7: Risk Factors and Management   Mr. T.J’s risk factors for stroke include advanced age  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 Diabetes. The management plan for Mr. T.J focused on immediate medical intervention in the emergency department to minimize cerebral damage  followed by aggressive secondary prevention measures to control his risk factors and prevent future strokes.   Slide 8: Discharge Plan  Upon discharge  Mr. T.J. was referred to a neurologist  cardiologist  and rehabilitation therapist for management of stroke sequelae  improvement of cardiovascular health and physical therapy. Appropriate adjustments were made to his current medications  aspirin  and a statin were added and he was supplied with lifestyle modifications information.   Slide 9: Follow-up Plan  Mr. T.J. was advised to follow up with his primary care physician within 1 week of discharge and with the relevant specialists as recommended. He was educated about the signs and symptoms of stroke and advised to visit the emergency department immediately should these or any worrying signs appear in the future.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 72-year-old African-American male presenting with signs and symptoms suggestive of an acute stroke. He arrived at the emergency department accompanied by his older sister  who noticed that he was having difficulty moving his right arm and leg  and was experiencing speech difficulties.  The patient's medical history includes type 2 diabetes which is currently managed with metformin and dietary restrictions. He also has a history of hypertension  for which he is regularly taking Lisinopril. There is no history of any previous cerebrovascular accident  transient ischemic attack or known heart disease. His only surgical history is an appendectomy at the age of 20. He has no known allergies.   According to his sister  the family history reveals a paternal uncle who had a stroke in his 70s and his parents both lived into their 80s and died of non-stroke-related causes.   As per the patient’s lifestyle  he is a non-smoker  does not drink alcohol regularly  and maintains an active lifestyle promoting daily walking for around 30 minutes.   Patient is a retired school teacher who lives with his wife and has 3 children. Currently he has moderate disability needing some help  but able to walk without assistance.   Given his demographic data  medical history and current presentation  a thorough neurologic examination and appropriate diagnostic tests are urgently needed to confirm the stroke diagnosis and determine the optimal therapeutic strategies.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information: The patient is a 74-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Timothy James. He is a retired construction foreman  currently living with his wife and occasionally visited by their adult children.  Presenting Issue: Mr. James' wife called the ambulance upon finding him semi-conscious on the bathroom floor early in the morning. Upon examination  he presents with right-side hemiparesis  partial facial droop  and expressive aphasia. Emergent CT imaging confirmed the presence of a recent left hemisphere ischemic stroke.  Medical History: Mr. James has a significant past medical history involving Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hyperlipidemia  and Hypertension  all of which have been managed for the past 15 years with diet  exercise  and a combination of oral antihyperglycemics  statins  and antihypertensives  including metformin 500mg twice a day  Atorvastatin 20mg once daily and Lisinopril-hydrochlorothiazide 20-12.5 mg per day. He also has a 40 pack-year smoking history  having quit twenty years ago.  Family History: The patient's family history is significant as his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 69  his mother had a history of hypertension  and one brother had a stroke in his early 70s.   Medications & Allergies: On top of his prescribed medications  Mr. Timothy James takes a daily multivitamin. He has a known allergy to penicillin  which induces hives.  Social History: On a social level  Mr. James does not consume alcohol  he lives a relatively sedentary lifestyle since his retirement and frequently complains about his diet restrictions. He is a retired construction foreman  and now his days are occupied mostly by light gardening and spending time with his wife and grandchildren during visits. He has been married for just over 50 years  and his wife is his primary caregiver.   At the current presentation  lovenox was initiated due to the nature of his stroke  glycaemic control evaluated and its treatment intensified  vital signs were monitored and control of hypertension was optimized. The team has initiated dysphagia screening and diet modification  he is being frequently repositioned to avoid pressure ulcers and physiotherapy initiated for the palsy. The patient was referred to a neurologist and the necessary rehabilitation services are being organized alongside dietary consultation to help Mr. James manage his diet better.   Mr. James and his family were informed about the severity of the situation  the management planned  the prognosis explained  and comforted as they navigate this catastrophic event.

Presentation Title: Case Study: Stroke Patient Presentation  Slide 1:  Patient Introduction - Name: Mr. James Smith - Age: 67 Years Old - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Engineer  Slide 2: Reason for Presentation - Mr. Smith reported experiencing sudden weakness on the left side of his body  difficulty with speech  and a sensation of his face drooping on one side.   Slide 3: Patient’s Medical History - Hypertension: Diagnosed at age 58  inconsistently controlled with medication - Type 2 Diabetes: Diagnosed at age 60  suboptimally controlled - Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed at age 60  controlled via statin therapy - 20 pack-years smoking history  quit at age 60  Slide 4: Family Medical History  - Father: Deceased at age 72  due to myocardial infarction - Mother: Deceased at age 69  cause unknown  - Brother has a history of hypertension - Two daughters  one with a history of hypertension  the other with no known medical issues  Slide 5: Current Presentation - Described sudden onset weakness on his left side  affecting arm and leg - Reports difficulties in speech and mild facial drooping  - No currently reported issues with vision  headache  or dizziness. - Observed symptoms suggest a possible stroke occurrence.  Slide 6: Conclusion & Next Steps - Given Mr. Smith's medical and lifestyle history as well as current symptoms  further diagnostic studies will be required to confirm the presence and type of stroke. - Immediate coordination with a stroke team  a neurologist  and/or a neurosurgeon will be initiated. - Treatment will be determined based on the diagnostic findings.   Slide 7:  Recommendations - Referral to a stroke specialist  - Regular follow-up and intensive therapy such as physical therapy may likely be needed.  - Lifestyle modification and stricter control of hypertension and diabetes.

Presentation of Patient:   The patient is a 72-year-old Asian male named Mr. Lee  a retired school teacher experiencing symptoms consistent with stroke. Mr. Lee was brought to the emergency room as he experienced sudden weakness on his right side  slurred speech  and difficulty maintaining balance. These symptoms started about two hours prior to his arrival at the hospital. He resides in Queens  New York with his wife and his daughter lives close by. Mr. Lee is a non-smoker and he drinks alcohol occasionally.  Past Medical History: Mr. Lee has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension  for which he is prescribed antihypertensive medication. Despite having a hypertension diagnosis  information suggests that his medication compliance has been inconsistent due to forgetfulness as he juggles multiple medications for other conditions. Other prevailing medical conditions include Type 2 diabetes mellitus  under control with oral hypoglycemic agents  and hyperlipidemia managed with statins. He has no known drug allergies. He suffered an episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) about five years ago  but no residual deficits were reported after that event. He has not had any surgical history or known genetic disorders.   Family History: His father died of stroke at 80  and his mother had a heart attack at age 74. He has two siblings; one brother is hypertensive and diabetic  while the other is healthy.  Lifestyle: Mr. Lee used to be a moderately active person but with recent retirement has become sedentary. His diet is predominantly high in sodium and is currently under dietary counseling for the same.  Summary: The patient's uncontrolled hypertensive status combined with other prevailing conditions like diabetes and hyperlipidemia puts him under the high-risk category for stroke. The previous TIA status indicates cerebrovascular pathologies that might have escalated to the current state. The familial disposition further supports the gravity. Patient needs immediate attention for acute stroke management in the emergency setting followed by rigorous control over his hypertension  diabetes  and lipid status for future prevention.

Patient Presentation:  We have a 63-year-old African American female  Mrs. JN  presenting with acute onset of right-side weakness and slurred speech  reported by her family. The patient was last noted to be well approximately 2 hours prior to presentation.   Past Medical History:  Mrs. JN has a significant history of uncontrolled hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. She is also a smoker  with a 30-year history  and has a BMI of 31  which classifies her as being obese. She admitted to having a poor diet  limited physical activity  and non-compliance towards her antihypertensive and hypoglycemic medications. She also has a family history of stroke  with her father having suffered a cerebrovascular accident in his sixties.   Mrs. JN has received regular health care over the years but unfortunately  has had poor adherence to her antihypertensive and hypoglycemic regimes. She is currently on Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes. She is also on Aspirin for stroke prevention.   She denies any history of cardiac issues  renal diseases  coagulopathies  and neurological disorders  but admits she has not been proactive about her health. She has had limited engagement with health promotion activities and has made sporadic attempts at smoking cessation in the past.  Summary:  Considering Mrs. JN's high-risk demographic factors (race  age  gender)  coupled with her considerable burden of modifiable (hypertension  diabetes mellitus  obesity  smoking) and genetic risk factors  there's a high probability of an ischemic stroke. An immediate stroke code should be activated and stroke management protocol should be followed to prevent further neurological deficit and morbidity.

Patient Presentation:  We have a 65-year-old African American female  Mrs. J. Thompson  who was brought in by her daughter due to abrupt onset of neurological changes.  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of severe headache  slurred speech  and right-sided weakness that started approximately 2 hours ago.  Past Medical History: History of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the last ten years. Her blood pressure and cholesterol levels have been relatively controlled with medication. She has been non-compliant with her anti-hypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medications due to financial constraints. She reports a smoking history of 20 years but quit 10 years ago. She also has a family history of stroke with her father suffering a stroke at the age of 70. No history of diabetes  heart disease  or other chronic illnesses.   Allergies: She has a known allergy to penicillin  which causes a rash.  Medications: Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  although she has not taken them consistently due to financial constraints.  Social History: She lives with her daughter and is a retired school teacher. She does not drink alcohol. She has a 20-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago.   Her daughter noticed her mother's speech became slurred during a conversation  and she developed right-sided weakness. She wasn't able to lift her right hand and lost her balance attempting to stand up. Understanding the potential implication of these symptoms  her daughter immediately called 911.  Summary:  Mrs. Thompson is a 65-year-old female patient with a significant medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presenting with signs and symptoms suggestive of a stroke. These symptoms include severe headache  slurred speech  and right-sided weakness. Given her history  non-compliance with medications  and current presentation  Mrs. Thompson’s clinical picture is of a high concern for a stroke. Immediate medical attention  including a neurological examination and imaging  is required. Proper management and intervention need to be implemented promptly to prevent further damage.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Stroke  Patient Information: Mr. Paul Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith was brought to the emergency department by his wife after he developed sudden weakness in his right upper and lower extremity  facial drooping  and mild difficulty in talking noticed around 8 am today. His wife also mentioned he became confused and disoriented which led her to seek immediate medical attention.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith is a retired teacher and a known case of hypertension for the last 15 years  type 2 diabetes for the past 8 years  and was found to have atrial fibrillation during a routine check-up 5 years ago.  Medication History: He is on metformin  lisinopril  and warfarin with a generally good adherence to his medication regimen.  Family History: His father died of myocardial infarction at an early age and his mother had a stroke in her seventies.   Social History: He reports that he quit smoking about 20 years ago and is a moderate alcohol drinker. He is not involved in any regular physical activity and follows a diet that can be high in salty foods.  Summary: Given the sudden onset of signs and symptoms and past medical history  we suspect an acute ischemic stroke which could be a complication from his long-standing hypertension  atrial fibrillation  or diabetes. His other risk factors include advanced age  history of smoking  lack of physical activity  and family history of cardiovascular diseases. prompt diagnostic measures and treatment should be initiated given the time-sensitive nature of the stroke.

[Slide 1: Introduction]  Good morning/afternoon. Our case presentation today is about Mr. Johan Peterson  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  who has presented with symptoms suggestive of a stroke.  [Slide 2: Background]  Mr. Peterson lives in Stockholm  Sweden  where he is a retired engineer. He has been a non-smoker and non-alcohol drinker for the past 10 years. He has been living with his wife in their suburban home. He has a family history of stroke; his father had a stroke at the age of 75.  [Slide 3: Past Medical History]  Mr. Peterson has Type II diabetes mellitus  diagnosed 8 years ago on a routine health check. He is on oral hypoglycemics to control his blood sugar and has a reasonable diet. He was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia 12 years ago and has been on antihypertensives and statins since then. There is also a history of atrial fibrillation  which was managed successfully with oral anticoagulants.  [Slide 4: Presumptive Stroke]  Two days ago  Mr. Peterson experienced sudden numbness in the right side of his body  difficulty speaking  and coordination problems. His wife immediately recognized these as possible stroke symptoms and summoned help.  [Slide 5: Current Examination]  Currently  Mr. Peterson has a blood pressure of 165/95mmHg  pulse 88bpm  irregular. The initial neurological examination revealed right hemiparesis  dysarthria  and facial droop on the right side. His blood glucose level is controlled at a measurement of 7.8mmol/l.  [Slide 6: Conclusion]  In summary  we are dealing with a male senior citizen who  in the context of significant vascular risk factors like hypertension  diabetes and hyperlipidemia  and a family history of stroke  has presented with clinical features highly suggestive of an acute stroke. The next steps would entail appropriate imaging investigations and immediate initiation of ischemic stroke management protocols.  [Slide Last: Questions]  This concludes Mr. Peterson's presentation. If there are any questions  feel free to ask.

Patient Presentation:  I am presenting Mr. John Dawson  a 67-year-old Caucasian male who is currently experiencing symptoms suggesting a possible cerebrovascular accident (CVA)  often referred to as a stroke.   Mr. Dawson came in today after recognizing signs of a stroke using the FAST mnemonic (face drooping  arm weakness  speech difficulties  and time to call for help) when he experienced his left face droop and left arm numbness. Mr. Dawson mentions that he experienced a similar situation three years ago  which was determined to be a transient ischemic attack (TIA).   In terms of his past medical history  Mr. Dawson has long-standing hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which have been managed with oral medications. He was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation two years ago and is on warfarin for stroke prevention. He also has a 40-pack per year smoking history but quit smoking last year. However  he drinks alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use.   The rest of his family history is also significant for cardiovascular illness  with his father dying from myocardial infarction at the age of 72  and his brother recently suffered a stroke at 65.   In view of these details  it's apparent that Mr. Dawson has multiple risk factors for cerebrovascular disorders  including his age  sex  hypertension  type 2 diabetes  atrial fibrillation  and extensive smoking history  which necessitates immediate medical attention and further investigation.   This presentation emphasizes the need for rigorous control of cardiovascular risk factors  including blood pressure management and anticoagulation in atrial fibrillation  particularly in older adults with multiple risk factors for stroke.

Patient Presentation   Name: Mr. Robert Smith Age: 74 years old Sex: Male  Occupation: Retired musician  Ethnicity: Caucasian   Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith presents with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty understanding language that began approximately two hours ago when he was having breakfast with his wife who noticed these changes.  Past Medical History: Previously diagnosed with Hypertension and type II diabetes  which he manages with medication (enalapril and metformin if taken regularly). Additionally  Mr. Smith has a 40-year history of smoking  although he quit about 5 years ago. He also reports drinking alcohol socially  but not excessively. He has a BMI of 28. He is otherwise generally in good health for his age  with no other known metabolic or systemic disorders.   In terms of surgical history  he has undergone appendectomy at the age of 30. He has not had any previous strokes or heart attacks. His mother had a stroke in her eighties.  On physical examination: Mr. Smith shows signs of dysarthria (difficulty articulating words) and facial drooping on the right side. His right arm shows significant weakness  scoring 2 on the Medical Research Council (MRC) scale for muscle power. His comprehension of language is also mildly affected. His blood pressure is elevated at 170/100 mmHg.  Conclusion: Given his symptoms and history  a stroke is highly suspected. Immediate neuroimaging should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and treatment should be instituted immediately especially considering the time-dependent nature of stroke treatments. A vasculature evaluation may also determine potential areas of occlusion. Ongoing control of Mr. Smith's blood pressure and diabetes will be imperative  and he will require referral to smoking cessation service as secondary prevention measures. When stable  physical  and possibly speech  therapy should be arranged to guide recovery.

Patient Presentation:  We have a 68-year-old African American male patient  Mr. John Smith  presenting with signs and symptoms suggestive of a stroke. He was brought to the emergency department by his wife after she noticed he was having difficulty speaking and was showing weakness on his right side. Patient is a resident of Brooklyn  New York. His social history reveals that he's a retired teacher and a non-smoker but has a habit of moderate alcohol consumption.  His past medical history is significant with chronic conditions such as Hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes  and Hyperlipidemia. His family history suggests a strong predisposition to cardiovascular diseases with his father having succumbed to a stroke and his brother diagnosed with an Ischemic heart disease. The patient is under medication for his existing conditions which includes antihypertensives (Lisinopril)  oral hypoglycemic agent (Metformin)  and a statin (Atorvastatin).  His neurological examination revealed moderate dysarthria  right facial droop  and right-sided hemiplegia. The patient was alert and oriented to time  person  and place. He had noticeably slurred speech  as well.   Based on the presenting symptoms  previous medical and family history  the patient is likely to have suffered an ischemic stroke. He had a high score on the NIH Stroke Scale emphasizing the severity of his condition. Given his rapid presentation to the emergency department  a computerized tomographic (CT) scan of the brain without contrast will be recommended to rule out any intracranial hemorrhage and further decisions about thrombolytic therapy will be made accordingly.  A multidisciplinary approach will be taken to manage the patient’s condition  including consultation with a neurologist for further management. Nutritional support  physical therapy  and counseling will be integral to his recovery. It would also be important to monitor the progress of his existing conditions in light of the recent event. He will be counseled regarding the importance of lifestyle modification  medication adherence  and regular follow-ups to prevent the recurrence of stroke as well as to manage his diabetes and hypertension.

PRESENTATION OF A STROKE PATIENT  [SECTION I - DEMOGRAPHICS]   The patient under discussion is Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  resident of California  with an occupation of business management. He is non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumer  with no illicit drug history. John is of average height and weight with a Body Mass Index that indicates he is slightly overweight.  [SECTION II - PAST MEDICAL HISTORY]  His past medical history is noteworthy for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been on medications  including Amlodipine 5mg for hypertension and Rosuvastatin 20mg for hyperlipidemia  for the past ten years. He has been compliant with his medication and has been regularly followed up by his primary care physician.  He has also been diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus (DM) for the past five years. He is on Metformin 500mg twice a day for his DM.   John has a paternal family history of stroke and heart disease  with both his father and elder brother having experienced ischemic strokes.  [SECTION III - PRESENTING COMPLAINT]  He presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden loss of strength and numbness in the right side of his body  which began an hour before admission. He also reported difficulty speaking and brief loss of consciousness.  [SECTION IV - PHYSICAL EXAM]  Upon physical examination  John was conscious but disoriented to time and place  with slurred speech. His blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg  pulse 90 beats per minute  and his oxygen saturation level was 97% on room air. Physical examination also revealed right-sided hemiplegia and facial droop on the right side.   In conclusion  this is a case of an elderly male patient with high-risk factors (hypertension  hyperlipidemia  Type-2 diabetes  and family history of stroke) for a cerebrovascular accident  who presented with features highly suggestive of an acute onset ischemic stroke.  Imaging and appropriate interventions will be initiated immediately to confirm the diagnosis and potentially ameliorate the condition.

Title: Presentation of a Stroke Patient  Introduction:  The patient is Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  residing in Naperville  Illinois. He is a retired teacher and likes to garden. Mr. Doe lives with his wife  and they have two adult children. The patient is a non-smoker. He drinks alcohol in moderation and has no known allergies. The patient  however  mentioned moderate physical activity and a diet moderately rich in fatty foods.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a significant past medical history including hypertension which has been managed by medication for the last ten years. He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease  as his father passed away from myocardial infarction at the age of 72 and his elder brother was diagnosed with ischemic heart disease five years ago. The patient was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia five years ago and has been on statins. Despite taking medication  his control of both the conditions has been inconsistent.  He had an episode of Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) two years ago  from which he recovered completely without any residual deficits. The patient has been under regular follow-ups with a neurologist and cardiologist. His medication compliance  however  has been questionable. Unfortunately  he has not been regular with his follow-up appointments due to COVID concerns.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe presented to the hospital with a sudden onset of left-sided weakness and slurred speech starting about 2 hours prior to admission. His wife noticed that his face was drooping on the left side  prompting them to immediately go to the hospital.  Examination & Investigations:  On examination  he was conscious but his speech was slurred. His blood pressure was high at 162/95 mmHg. Pulse was 98/min  regular and all peripheral pulses were palpable. His neurological examination revealed weakened motor function in the left upper and lower limbs with a power of 3/5 and a decrease in sensation. His speech was slurred and he had facial drooping on one side  all suggestive of a stroke.  Immediate CT scan of his head has been ordered to confirm the diagnosis and MRI will be done subsequently for further evaluations. Blood investigations and ECG have also been ordered.  This case presentation was intended to illustrate a common  yet grave healthcare concern - a stroke  showcasing the need for regular health checks  medication compliance  healthy lifestyle to effectively manage chronic conditions like hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and to potentially avoid severe complications like stroke.  The next steps would be promptly initiating treatment based on the imaging and investigation reports.

Patient Presentation:  We are here to discuss Mr. David Smith  a 67-year-old Caucasian male presenting with symptoms of stroke. Mr. Smith is a retired teacher from New York. He experienced sudden numbness on the right side of his body and difficulty in speech.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith has a known history of hypertension for the past seven years and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past three years. He has been on appropriate medication and managing his conditions reasonably well. Detailed review revealed no previous cerebrovascular events. However  there is a family history of stroke; his mother had a stroke at the age of 75.   Mr. Smith admits being a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago. He denies any significant alcohol consumption. His medication regimen includes Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. Additionally  he is physically active and follows a balanced diet.  Recent events:   Mr. Smith was watching television when he suddenly experienced difficulty speaking and moving his right arm and leg. His wife noticed his face drooping on the right side and immediately called an ambulance. The patient denies experiencing confusion  severe headache  or loss of consciousness. Currently  the patient is conscious but demonstrating clear signs of expressive aphasia.  In conclusion  Mr. Smith  given his age  past medical history  and current presenting symptoms  falls into a high-risk category for ischemic stroke. Further diagnostics must be performed promptly to determine the area affected and to decide the most effective treatment plan. Time is of the essence in managing stroke patients.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Details: Name: Joseph Scott Age: 62 years old Sex: Male Race: African American Occupation: Retired engineer Residence: San Francisco  California  Presenting issue:  Mr. Scott was brought to the ER with sudden-onset confusion and weakness on the right side of his body. He also has difficulty speaking and has slurred speech. His symptoms started while he was having breakfast with his wife  who noticed his sudden altered behaviour and immediately sought medical help.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Scott was previously diagnosed with hypertension (high blood pressure) and hyperlipidemia (high cholesterol levels) about 10 years ago. Both conditions are currently managed with amlodipine and atorvastatin  respectively. Despite his condition  his doctor's records indicate that he still smokes about ten cigarettes a day.  Family History:  His father died of a heart attack at the age of 66 and his mother died from complications related to Alzheimer's disease at the age of 75. His older brother suffered a stroke at the age of 60.  Lifestyle Factors:  Despite the patient's efforts to maintain an active lifestyle with regular walking and light exercise  he failed to quit smoking and still consumes alcohol moderately. His diet notably includes red meats and processed foods.  Observations:  The physical examination revealed that he has difficulty moving his right arm and leg and has drooping on the right side of his face. Speaking is difficult for him and his speech is not as articulate as before.  The presented symptoms accompanied by Mr. Scott's high blood pressure and cholesterol level  smoking habit  family history of stroke  and personal history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia contribute to a higher risk for stroke. Immediate attention is required to prevent further damage and complications.   This patient presentation suggests an acute stroke  possibly an ischemic stroke according to the localization of the symptoms. The patient needs to undergo diagnostic imaging as soon as possible to confirm the diagnosis and determine the best course of treatment.

Title: Stroke Patient Presentation   Patient Information: Patient: Mr. Allan Green Gender: Male Age: 65 Years Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Chief Complaint: Patient was brought in by the Emergency Medical Service (EMS) with chief complaints of sudden onset weakness on the right side of his body and difficulty with expressive speech which started an hour prior to his presentation to the emergency room.  Vital Signs: Patient presents with a blood pressure of 170/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 78 bpm  respiration rate of 18 breaths per minute  temperature of 98.6°F  and an oxygen saturation level of 98%.  Past Medical History (PMH): Mr. Green has a past medical history positive for hypertension for which he's been taking Lisinopril 10mg daily for the past 16 years. He is also known to have type 2 diabetes mellitus under good control with Metformin. In addition  the patient has a history of hyperlipidemia managed with Atorvastatin. He does not have a history of previous stroke or transient ischemic attack. He denies smoking or alcohol use.   Family history: His father died from a heart attack at age 70 and his mother had a history of stroke.  Physical Exam: On physical examination  he appears to be in moderate distress. He is usually alert and oriented but currently is experiencing dysarthria. His speech is slurred and he has impaired comprehension. Motor examination shows notable weakness on the right side of the body including the right face  arm  and leg with a strength score of 3/5. His reflexes are 2+ throughout. Sensation is intact.   Impression: The patient’s history and physical examination suggest an acute ischemic stroke with a potential location involving the left hemisphere. He is within a candidate for thrombolytic therapy  but further evaluations including brain imaging are needed for definitive diagnosis. The patient’s hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia form a significant risk factor triad for stroke and should continue to be managed carefully  with potential adjustment needed in the management plan.   Plan: The patient was immediately sent for a CT scan of the head to determine the type and location of the stroke. His blood sugar was monitored regularly. He was further evaluated by the neurologist team  and his eligibility for IV thrombolytic therapy was assessed. A dietitian was consulted for diabetic diet recommendations. The patient and family will be educated about stroke prevention and control of risk factors.   This case illustrates the importance of early recognition and intervention in the management of stroke and the importance of managing patient’s underlying risk factors.

Subject Name: John Doe Age: 75 Sex: Male  Residence: New York  United States Ethnicity: Caucasian   Presentation:  Mr. Doe came in today with a chief complaint of sudden weakness in his right arm  leg  and face. He also reports experiencing blurred vision  difficulty speaking  sudden and severe headache  dizziness and loss of balance. The onset of these symptoms was two hours prior to his emergency room arrival.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a significant past medical history which includes hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypercholesterolemia  and ischemic heart disease. He is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago. He maintains a moderate alcohol intake and reports no known drug allergies. His medications include both Metformin and Lisinopril  which he has been on for more than 10 years. He suffered a previous stroke 5 years ago but recovered most of his function after intensive rehabilitation therapy.  Mr. Doe's family history is significant for cardiovascular disease and stroke with his father dying from a heart attack at age 70. The patient’s diet and physical activity levels are relatively poor and he is overweight with a BMI of 28. He has persistent stress due to the loss of his wife last year. These factors place Mr. Doe at high risk for another stroke.  In summary  Mr. Doe is a 75-year-old man who has presented with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  blurred vision  difficulty in speech  severe headache  and dizziness - strong symptoms indicative of a stroke. His previous medical history and overall lifestyle show that he is at high risk for recurrent strokes. A CT scan would be needed for further diagnosis and determining treatment plans.

Patient Information:  Name: Mrs. Susan Adams Sex: Female Age: 68 Race: White Address: 324 Park Street  Denver  Colorado Occupation: Retired school teacher Marital Status: Widowed with two adult children Insurance: Medicare  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of right side weakness  difficulty with speech  dizziness  and blurred vision.  History of Present Illness:   The patient's symptoms were first noted two hours ago when she attempted to get out of bed and found she could neither maintain balance nor adequately move her right arm and leg. The patient's daughter noticed her mother's slurred speech and called an ambulance.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Adams has a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Both conditions have been relatively under control; hypertension maintained with Lisinopril 10 mg daily and diabetes controlled with Metformin 500 mg twice daily. Her last recorded HbA1c was 7.3  three months ago. She also has a history of hyperlipidemia which is currently being treated with Atorvastatin 20 mg at bedtime. Other significant history includes an episode of Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) about five years ago  since which she has been on Aspirin 81 mg for secondary prevention. Her adherence to medication and regular follow-ups have mostly been inconsistent  as reported by her daughter.   Family History:  Both parents passed away due to cardiac complications. Her younger brother suffers from type II diabetes and hypertension.   Social History:  Mrs. Adams is a former smoker (15 pack-years) and quit smoking twenty-five years ago. She occasionally drinks red wine with dinner. She lives alone. She is supported by her daughter who lives nearby.  Summary:  Considering the above factors  in particular her past medical history with hypertension  diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and previous TIA  Mrs. Adams' risk factors for stroke are significant. She is a retired woman  living with a combination of controlled vascular conditions and is currently presenting with signs of a stroke. Further diagnostic investigations are required to confirm a diagnosis and determine the precise location and severity of the stroke.

Slide 1: Introduction  Patient Information: Mrs. Laurie Smith  a 74-year-old African-American female  has been admitted following the sudden onset of stroke-like symptoms. She lives with her husband in downtown Brooklyn  New York. Her main support system is her husband and two adult kids who live nearby. Mrs. Smith is a retired teacher and is socially active in her local community. She is non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially  seldom.  Slide 2: Past Medical History  Mrs. Smith has a relevant past medical history:  1. Hypertension (high blood pressure) - diagnosed 10 years ago. 2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus - diagnosed 7 years ago. 3. Hyperlipidemia (high cholesterol) - diagnosed 5 years ago. 4. Osteoarthritis - diagnosed 3 years ago.  Mrs. Smith has been fairly compliant with her medications which include Metformin for diabetes  Amlodipine for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for high cholesterol levels.  Slide 3: Current Presentation  Today  Mrs. Smith presented with sudden onset of symptoms: severe headache  weakness and numbness on the left side of her body  difficulty talking and understanding speech  difficulty walking and loss of balance. She also reported blurred vision in one eye. Her husband  Mr. Smith noticed her symptoms and immediately called an ambulance. From the onset of her symptoms to her arrival at the hospital was approximately 90 minutes.  Slide 4: Initial Assessment  On arrival  Mrs. Smith's vital signs were stable; however  her Glasgow Coma Scale was 12 which indicate moderate brain injury. An urgent non-contrast CT brain scan was carried out and confirmed ischemic stroke.  Slide 5: Emergency Management   She was immediately administered intravenous thrombolytic therapy (IV rtPA) as per protocol for acute ischemic stroke. She was admitted to the Stroke Unit for 24-hour monitoring and further management.  Slide 6: Plan for further treatment  Consideration to start her on secondary prevention medications including aspirin  statin and further blood pressure control is being made by her healthcare team. Rehabilitation services has been consulted for physical therapy and speech therapy to aid in recovery and reduce disability.    Just as a reminder  stroke is an emergency and time-sensitive condition. Immediate intervention and access to medical care can significantly influence the patient’s outcome in terms of recovery and prognosis.

Title: Presentation of a Stroke Patient  Patient Profile:   Mr. Robert Johnson is a 72-year- old  Caucasian male who presented at our facility today. He is a resident of Heartley County  Texas and lives with his wife who is his primary caregiver. He identifies himself as a retired Army officer and a non-smoker  although he does drink alcohol moderately.   Presenting Problem:   Robert was brought in today with complaints of sudden weakness on the right side of his body and difficulty speaking  which he noticed upon waking up this morning. His wife states that he was normal and in good spirits when they both retired last night. This morning  upon hearing him stammer and struggle to collect his words  she immediately suspected a serious problem.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a documented history of hypertension and dyslipidemia. He was on antihypertensives (Lisinopril 10mg daily) and lipid-lowering drugs (Rosuvastatin 10mg daily)  but his compliance with medications and regular follow-up visits have been sporadic. He mostly relied on a home remedy for his health problems  which his wife reports have been more ""miss"" than ""hit"". His medical records also reveal a previous transient ischemic attack (TIA) 7 years ago.   Family History:  His family history is significant for stroke and heart disease – both his parents succented to cardiovascular complications. His father had his first stroke at age 65 and died of a heart attack at age 72  while his mother died of a stroke at age 70.  Summary:  In summary  Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old male presenting with sudden hemiparesis and speech disturbance  with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a previous TIA. Given his present symptoms and medical history  there lies a high suspicion for an acute ischemic stroke  which necessitates immediate diagnostic interventions and therapeutic management.

No previous strokes or myocardial infarctions. 5. No known allergies.  IV. Family History: 1. Her mother and father both had hypertension. 2. Her father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 72. 3. No family history of stroke or diabetes.  V. Medication List: 1. Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg daily.  2. Metformin 500mg twice a day. 3. Atorvastatin 20mg daily.  VI. Social History: 1. She quit smoking 10 years ago. 2. Alcohol: Occasionally drinks a glass of wine with dinner. 3.
