Current Examination: Physical examination reveals an alert and oriented patient with obvious right-sided weakness and expressive aphasia. Her blood pressure is 165/90 mmHg. Remainder of the vital signs are normal. Neurological examination reveals right-sided hemiparesis and facial droop. A CT scan has been ordered to determine the type and location of the stroke.  This presentation is for acute stroke management discussions. Further diagnostic studies and therapeutic interventions will be decided upon after evaluation of the CT scan results.

Presentation of the Patient:   Here is a brief presentation of Mr. John Doe  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  who has presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of weakness in his left side  slurred speech  and diminished vision in his left eye which started two hours before arrival.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Doe has an extensive past medical history  including hypertension for the past 10 years  managed with Lisinopril. He also has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes  which is controlled with Metformin. He has been relatively compliant with his medications and follow-ups with his GP. The patient quit smoking 10 years ago after being a smoker for 30 years and states he rarely drinks alcohol. He has hypercholesterolemia and has been taking statins for this  his last LDL reading was at a moderate level. Further  Mr. Doe has no known history of atrial fibrillation or other cardiac conditions nor any previous strokes or episodes of transient ischemic attack. He says he has not been having symptoms of depression or anxiety.   Family History: He lost his father and an older brother to myocardial infarction  while his mother is still alive  living with Alzheimer’s disease.   In summary  Mr. Doe is a high-risk patient for a stroke due to his age  sex  longstanding hypertension  diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia  and a family history of heart disease. However  his non-compliance to smoking and adequate management of diabetes and hypertension helps in reducing his risk. The symptoms he has presented with align closely with a diagnosis of stroke. Further examination and investigation are required to confirm this hypothesis and determine the path forward for his care.

Patient Presentation:  Good day  everyone. Today we are focusing on a patient who presents with a recent stroke.   Patient's Demographics:  Our patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. James Kingsley. He is a retired police officer who lives with his wife in the suburbs. He is a non-smoker and only drinks alcohol occasionally.  Past Medical History: Mr. Kingsley has been hypertensive for the last 10 years. He is also diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  managing his condition through oral hypoglycemic agents for the past 5 years. He has a history of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) with two episodes in the last 3 years. His father also had a history of stroke which he suffered at the age of 75.  Recently  Mr. Kingsley experienced a sudden onset of left-sided weakness and speech difficulties. These symptoms persisted  which prompted their visit to the emergency room. His wife stated that he was fine when they went to bed  but in the morning  he was not able to get up and his speech was slurred.   The initial CT Scan has revealed a large right MCA (middle cerebral artery) infarction. At the moment Mr. Kingsley is conscious and stable  but with pronounced left-sided hemiparesis. Appropriate interventions have been initiated as per acute stroke protocol.  In conclusion  Mr. Kingsley’s hypertension  diabetes  history of TIAs  and family history have all contributed significantly to his risk of suffering a major stroke. Moving forward we anticipate the need for a multidisciplinary approach to his rehabilitation and secondary prevention measure.   Thank you for your attention.

Title: Acute Presentation of a Female Patient with Stroke  Good morning colleagues   I'm here to discuss the case of a 60-year-old African-American female patient who has been admitted to our unit with symptoms appearing to be significant for a stroke.   Her symptoms started suddenly today morning when she experienced difficulty in speaking  alongside noticeable face drooping on the right side. Her husband also stated that she had difficulty in understanding simple commands and appeared to be unsteady on her feet. This prompted immediate transportation to our hospital where her symptoms were typical of a stroke.  Relevant Demographics Information: She is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. She has been a resident of Washington D.C. for the past 16 years and works as an elementary school teacher.  Chronic Medical History: Our patient has a documented history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  which she has been managing for the past 15 years. In addition  she suffers from obesity with a BMI of 29. Unfortunately  her compliance with medication and regular follow-ups has been sub-optimal.  Acute Medical History: Upon admission  her blood pressure was recorded at 170/95 mmHg  and her blood sugar was high at 207 mg/dL. A neurological examination further revealed right-sided weakness  with a NIH Stroke Scale score of 12.  Emergency Intervention: She was immediately administered with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)  and an urgent CT scan was ordered to rule out any hemorrhage.  Conclusion: This case presents an instance of a possible ischemic stroke in a patient with significant risk factors  including hypertension  diabetes  obesity  and advancing age. It underscores the importance of prompt intervention and the need for regular follow-up and adherence to medications in patients with underlying chronic conditions. Our aim will be to carefully manage her condition  ensure appropriate rehabilitation  and reinforce her need for an effective home care plan to manage her chronic illnesses post recovery.

Patient Presentation:  We are currently managing a 59-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John Smith  who presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in speech. Mr. Smith  a resident of Springfield  was brought in by his wife  who reported that he had no prior complains or symptoms prior to the incident. The symptoms started about one and a half hours ago.  Mr. Smith has a known past medical history of well-controlled type II Diabetes Mellitus for the last ten years  which he has been managing with regular medication and lifestyle modifications. He also has a documented history of hypertension  which was diagnosed around eight years ago and has been kept under control with regular antihypertensive medications. He is a former cigar smoker but quit smoking about five years ago  after having smoked approximately 1 cigar a day for 20 years. There is no family history of stroke.  He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  headaches  nausea or numbness. His BP on admission was 152/90 mmHg  heart rate was 80 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 19 per minute  and temperature was 37.1 degrees Celsius.  Based on the clinical picture and temporal profile of the symptoms  as well as initial examination  there is a high clinical suspicion of stroke. We have requested emergency neuroimaging (CT brain scan) to confirm the diagnosis and its type  which will guide in initiating the most appropriate management plan for Mr. Smith.  Please note  time is of the essence when managing patients with stroke  thus ensuring a timely therapeutic intervention is key to optimizing recovery.

Title: Patient Presentation: Acute Stroke  Patient Information: Name: James Smith Age: 68 years old Sex: Male Occupation: Retired schoolteacher Ethnicity: Caucasian Residential location: Suburban environment  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith presents with sudden-onset weakness in the right side of his body  associated with slurred speech and difficulty in understanding spoken language. His symptoms began approximately 3 hours ago.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a known history of hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus for the last 10 years  both of which have been managed with regular medication. He also experienced a mild myocardial infarction 5 years ago. He used to smoke a pack of cigarettes a day for 40 years but quit smoking immediately after his myocardial infarction. His paternal side has a history of cardiovascular diseases.   Current Medications: He is currently on Lisinopril 10mg for hypertension and Metformin 500mg for Type II diabetes mellitus. After his myocardial infarction  he was prescribed daily low-dose aspirin 75mg.  Social History: He lives with his wife in a one-story house. He has two adult children living out of town. He is retired and engages in mild physical activity like gardening.  Nutritional History: Mr. Smith follows a balanced diet as recommended by his dietician but admits to occasionally indulging in fried food and desserts. He stopped alcohol consumption after his myocardial infarction.  In summary  Mr. Smith  a 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension  Type II diabetes  and previous myocardial infarction  presents with symptoms that likely indicate an acute ischemic stroke. Non-modifiable risk factors include his age  male gender  and family history of cardiovascular disease  while the modifiable risk factors are his hypertension  diabetes  and former smoking habit. His symptoms necessitate immediate medical intervention to minimize potential brain damage and to manage resultant disability.

Title: A Case Presentation on Stroke  Patient Profile: Patient Name: Mrs. Carla Thompson Age: 65 years old Sex: Female Ethnicity: African-American Occupation: Retired school teacher Location: Chicago  Illinois  Presenting Issue: Mrs. Thompson was brought to the Emergency department at around 9 AM this morning by her neighbor who discovered Mrs. Thompson slurred in speech and weak on one side of the body. Symptoms were reported to have appeared suddenly.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Thompson has a documented medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes for the past decade  and irregularly takes her prescribed medications due to the perceived side effects. She does not engage in regular exercise and has a noted preference for a high-sodium diet. She also has a 5-year history of hyperlipidemia. Mrs. Thompson used to smoke  but she quit 10 years ago.  Family History: Her father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 68 and her mother suffered from a stroke at the age of 72. Her older brother  aged 70  is also hypertensive.   Additional Background Information: Mrs. Thompson lives alone and her two children live in different cities. She follows up sporadically with her primary care physician and sometimes misses her regular check-ups.  Diagnosis: Based on her symptoms of sudden onset unilateral weakness and slurred speech  as well as her cardiovascular risk factors including hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and family history  Mrs. Thompson has been diagnosed with an acute ischemic stroke.  The patient is now stable and we are awaiting further neuroimaging results to confirm the nature and extent of her stroke. The case has been discussed with the neurology team who recommend immediate initiation of stroke protocol therapy. Further discussion regarding management and rehabilitation options will be undertaken in the coming days.    This case serves as a cautionary example to improve our efforts in managing modifiable risk factors and improving follow up care for patients with chronic diseases.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. James Black  a 65-year-old African-American male  presented to the emergency department with acute onset of right-sided weakness and speech difficulty. His wife  who accompanied him  reported that his symptoms began abruptly about 3 hours ago while he was reading the morning newspaper. Her quick decision to contact emergency services was prompted by prior awareness of stroke symptoms. The patient has lived in Tampa Bay  Florida for the last 30 years  has a 45-year history of hypertension  and a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  both conditions have been managed on medication. He has a known allergy to Penicillin.  In addition  he has a history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 35 years  but quit 10 years ago. His alcohol consumption is minimal  restricting to occasional social drinking. He denied any illicit drug use. He has been on Aspirin 81mg daily for primary prevention of heart disease for the past 5 years.  Family history revealed that his father suffered a stroke at the age of 60. No history of similar episodes of neurological deficits  seizures  or migraines have been recorded for Mr. Black in the past. He has been largely independent with his daily activities. He retired from his job as a high school teacher 5 years ago  lives with his wife and is an active participant in his local community's senior citizen services.    In summary  Mr. Black  with a significant past medical history of hypertension  diabetes  and family history of stroke  along with a prior long-term smoking habit  is at an increased risk for a stroke. His acute onset right-sided weakness and speech difficulty suggest the possibility of a stroke. Prompt evaluation with imaging is warranted to determine the type and extent of stroke and to guide immediate treatment.

Title: Patient Presentation: Stroke Incident   Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Johnson. He is a retired engineer  married  non-smoker  and a social drinker. He resides in Brooklyn  New York  with his wife. He has been under consistent treatment for hypertension for the past 12 years.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Johnson was brought into the Emergency Department by his wife complaining of sudden weakness on the right side of his body. Onset was approximately 2 hours ago while they were having breakfast.   Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia  under medication for both. He also underwent elective cholecystectomy about 15 years back. He has had no known allergies. Family history reveals that his father had an Ischemic Stroke at the age of 72.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with acute symptoms which include right-sided hemiparesis  facial droop on the right side  slurred speech  and mild confusion. He also complained of a mild headache but denied any chest pain  palpitations  or change in vision. No history of trauma or falls. He has not experienced similar symptoms before.  Physical Findings: On examination  the patient is anxious  blood pressure is 185/95 mm Hg  pulse is regular at 90 beats per minute. Neurological examination reveals right-sided motor and sensory deficit  and dysarthria. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Summary: This presentation fits with a likely Acute Left Hemispheric Stroke  given Mr. Johnson's acute neurological deficits  his cardiovascular risk profile  and the absence of a trauma history. Immediate neurological consultation  along with urgent neuroimaging  is warranted in this case.   Mr. Johnson’s case reiterates the importance of blood pressure control in chronic hypertensive patients to reduce the risk of stroke  particularly in those also having other cardiovascular disease risks like hyperlipidemia.

Presentation of the Patient:  Our patient is a 75-year-old African-American woman named Mrs. Susan Thompson. Mrs. Thompson is a current resident of Tampa  Florida  originally from Louisiana  currently a retired primary school teacher  living with her husband of 50 years. She is a non-smoker and has a very moderate alcohol intake on rare occasions.  Chief Complaint:   She was brought to the emergency department this morning presenting with slurred speech  facial drooping on the left side  and weakness in her left arm that began roughly two hours prior to her arrival. She denies experiencing any headache  dizziness  or vision changes at the onset of the symptoms.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Thompson has a robust medical history. She has been diagnosed with high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which have been managed with medications (Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes) for the past 15 years. Additionally  she was treated for breast cancer  stage II  five years being cancer-free now  and is undergoing her annual cancer screenings. She also has a history of high cholesterol for which she takes Simvastatin.   She has no allergies and no previous surgeries apart from a single lumpectomy. She is compliant with her medications and follows up regularly with her primary care physician. Previously  she had no neurological symptoms  and there is no family history of cerebrovascular accidents.  Summary:  Given her age  medical history  especially the history of hypertension and diabetes  the sudden onset of her symptoms  and the findings from a physical examination  she seems to be experiencing a stroke. Prompt diagnosis with neuroimaging and treatment is crucial to minimize any potential long-term disability.   This case highlights the importance of periodic preventive health checkups in elderly patients with risk factors like hypertension  diabetes  and high cholesterol levels to prevent severe adverse events like a stroke.

Title: A Case Presentation on Stroke  Patient Profile: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female named Mrs. Gladys Thompson who resides at 789 Anderson Street  Pittsburgh  Pennsylvania. She is a retired teacher  married with four children. Mrs. Thompson has been a non-smoker throughout her life and has a moderate alcohol intake. She isn't involved in any strenuous activity but maintains an active lifestyle  with gardening as her primary hobby.  Presenting Complaint: Mrs. Thompson presented to the Emergency Department on January 19  2022  with complaints of sudden onset weakness on the right side of her body along with slurring of speech. She noted that these symptoms started about three hours earlier while she was gardening at home.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Thompson has a history of Chronic Hypertension for the past ten years  for which she has been taking Lisinopril. She was also diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus five years ago and has been managing it with Metformin. She had a previous Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) about two years ago. Unfortunately  Mrs. Thompson has been inconsistent with her medication adherence. Besides  her family history is significant with her father having suffered a stroke at the age of 75.  Recent Medical Investigations: Upon physical examination  it was noted that her blood pressure was 170/90 mm Hg  heart rate was 85 beats per minute  and her random blood glucose level was elevated at 200 mg/dL. A neurological examination showed right-sided hemiparesis and expressive aphasia indicative of a possible stroke.   The patient was immediately sent for a head CT scan which showed a thrombus in the left middle cerebral artery  confirming an ischemic stroke.   Management and Prognosis: Mrs. Thompson was promptly started on intravenous Alteplase (tPA)  an emergency clot-busting treatment. After initial therapy  a comprehensive  multidisciplinary stroke rehabilitation program is planned. The family has been counseled about the seriousness of her condition  the importance of medication adherence  and lifestyle modifications.  This case poses a substantial challenge due to her multiple health complications  including Chronic Hypertension  Type II Diabetes  and previous TIA  which potentially increased her risk for the ischemic stroke.

Title: Patient Presentation: An Acute Ischemic Stroke Case  Patient Demographics: - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 65 years - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Engineer - Marital Status: Married - Location: Urban  - Primary Language: English  Medical History: Mr. John Doe has a known history of preventative health care avoidance and an inconsistent medication regimen. He has been managed for several comorbidities  to include: 1. Long-standing Hypertension for the past 10 years which has been poorly controlled. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 8 years ago. He is non-compliant with diet and medication. 3. Hyperlipidemia diagnosed 10 years ago. 4. History of Atrial Fibrillation diagnosed 6 years ago  for which he was placed on Warfarin  but the adherence has been inconsistent. 5. He has a 45 pack-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. 6. No known drug allergies are reported.  Family History: Patient's family history is significant with both parents dying in their late 60s due to heart disease.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Doe presents to the ER with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in speech which started approximately 2 hours ago while having breakfast. He denies experiencing any headaches  seizures  loss of consciousness  or trauma.   This clinical picture is highly suspicious of an acute ischemic stroke and requires immediate attention for rule out of hemorrhagic stroke  followed by the initiation of thrombolytic therapy if indicated.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Douglas is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presented at the hospital on October 14th complaining of sudden weakness in the right side of his body and difficulty speaking. He resides in Rochester  New York  and is a retired engineer living with his wife. According to his wife  these symptoms started approximately two hours prior to coming to the hospital.   Patient History:  His past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus which have been relatively well controlled with medications  namely Hydrochlorothiazide for his BP and Metformin for his diabetes. He was diagnosed with these conditions 15 years ago. He also has a family history of stroke  with his father passing away from a stroke at the age of 72. Mr. Douglas has been a non-smoker for the past ten years  but it is worth noting that he was a heavy smoker (1 pack/day) for almost 30 years prior to that.  Recent Developments:  Despite a regular follow up with his primary care provider  Mr. Douglas admitted that he had forgotten to take his regular medications for the past couple days due to a recent stressful event in the family.   Vitals and Symptoms on Presentation:  On arrival  his vitals were unstable with a blood pressure of 172/94 mmHg  pulse 92 beats/min  respiratory rate 20 breaths/min  temperature 98.2°F  and oxygen saturation at 96% on room air. The physical examination revealed right-sided facial droop  right arm weakness  and dysarthria. His blood glucose level was also higher than normal.   The severity and sudden onset of symptoms are highly indicative of a possible stroke  making immediate medical intervention crucial. Therefore  he was quickly stabilized and was taken for a brain scan to confirm the diagnosis and decide on the further line of treatment.

Presentation of Patient:  Ladies and Gentlemen  today I would like to present a case of a 72-year-old African American male patient named Mr. James Smith who has come to our hospital presenting with the symptoms of an acute stroke.   Demographic Information: Mr. Smith is a retired teacher who lives in downtown Chicago  Illinois. He was brought in by his wife and reports experiencing sudden loss of balance  difficulty speaking  and weakness on the right side of his body since morning. He is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol.  Past Medical History: Upon obtaining his past medical history  we found that Mr. Smith has been diagnosed with several substantial conditions in the past. He has a known medical history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus and has been on medication for the same. Moreover  he was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia five years back and is periodically undergoing treatment for it. Yet  the records suggest that his body mass index (BMI) is consistently over the higher normal limit despite regular consultation with a dietician. In addition to this  he survived a myocardial infarction two years back and has a stent in situ. There is a notable family history  both his father and elder brother died due to stroke.   As such  Mr. Smith’s combination of advanced age  hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  obesity and a history of cardiac disease significantly increases his risk for a stroke. Currently  the plan is to stabilize him  begin medication to prevent further clotting  and then further proceed with diagnostic imaging to determine the extent and type of his stroke. At the same time  the team is also looking to manage his comorbid conditions to prevent another occurrence in the future.  Mr. Smith's case emphasizes the importance of inter-professional collaboration among health professionals to manage and treat patients effectively.

Title: A Case Presentation of Acute Ischemic Stroke   Background  Patient: Sarah Wright  73-year-old Caucasian female.  Patient's Address: #345 Autumn Park  Denver  Colorado.  Presenting Problem: Sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty in speaking.  Medical History  Ms. Wright has an extensive medical history that includes hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia for which she is on oral medication. She was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation two years ago and has been on anticoagulation treatment.  She quit smoking 15 years ago and leads a sedentary lifestyle due to her joint pain secondary to osteoarthritis.   Past Surgical History: Undergone appendectomy at age 23.  Family History: Both parents had heart disease. Her father died of MI at age 60  and her mother died of stroke at age 70. She has a brother who has been diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Presenting Symptoms  Ms. Wright was doing her usual activities at home when she experienced sudden weakness on the left side of her body that was associated with difficulty in speaking and facial droop.  Examination and Findings  On examination  Ms. Wright has altered speech and signs of left-sided hemiparesis. Her National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score was 12 at initial assessment indicating moderate severity stroke. Her Blood Pressure was 160/85 mmHg and her Heart rate was regular at 78 bpm.  Investigations  Immediate brain imaging (CT-scan) confirmed an acute ischemic stroke.   EKG showed an irregular rhythm consistent with atrial fibrillation. Patients’ blood works showed elevated blood sugar levels  elevated LDL and HbA1c was 7.8%.  Update Post- Emergency Department  Ms. Wright was admitted to the stroke unit and she was given intravenous thrombolysis (rtPA). Antihypertensives and blood glucose-lowering drugs were adjusted.   This holistic care and approach have helped Ms. Wright to achieve a modest recovery over days. An interdisciplinary team of rehab specialists  nutritionists  and mental health professionals were involved in her care.   In conclusion  despite the limitation of her comorbidity  she has shown promising recovery with an integrated stroke management plan.

Title: Presentation of First Time Stroke Patient  Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male known as Mr. John Connor. He is retired  widowed and lives alone. His main caregiver is his daughter who visits 3 times a week. He is an ex-smoker  having quit smoking 35 years ago  and drinks alcohol occasionally.   Presenting Problem: Mr. Connor was brought in by his daughter when he developed a sudden difficulty with speech and weakness on his right side that persisted for a couple of hours on November 11  2022. The daughter increased her visits when she noticed that her father had become slightly more forgetful in past few weeks but didn't associate the memory issues with a sign of a worsening health condition.   Past Medical History: Mr. Connor has a history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. Both conditions have been relatively well-managed with medication. He has also been treated for elevated cholesterol levels in the past but currently not on statins. Five years ago  he was diagnosed with benign prostate hyperplasia but has since undergone a successful TURP procedure. No known allergies have been reported.  Evaluation and Assessment: He was immediately administered a NIH Stroke Scale evaluation in which he scored 12  indicating a moderate stroke. An urgent brain CT scan showed an ischemic stroke in the left middle cerebral artery territory. The blood sugar level was normal; however  the blood pressure was significantly elevated at 180/90 mmHg.  In conclusion  the patient is presenting with symptoms of stroke that are suspected to be as a result of long standing hypertension  high cholesterol  and diabetes. Immediate treatment and rehabilitation plan is necessary to prevent further complications and improve quality of life. Given his history of diabetes and hypertension  post-stroke management should also aim at gaining control of these conditions to reduce chances of recurrent stroke.

Title: Clinical Presentation of a Patient Presenting with Stroke  Patient Profile: --------------- Name: Mr. Ian Thompson Age: 67 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Engineer Nationality: Caucasian American Marital Status: Married   Presenting Complaint: --------------- Mr. Thompson presented with sudden onset of weakness on the right side of his body  accompanied by slurred speech and facial droop that started approximately 3 hours prior to arriving in the emergency department.  Past Medical History: --------------- 1. Hypertension: Mr. Thompson was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago; he takes a daily dose of Lisinopril. 2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus: He was diagnosed with T2DM 8 years ago and is under Metformin therapy. 3. Ischemic Heart Disease: He underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery 5 years prior due to significant coronary artery disease. 4. Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed alongside his T2DM and managed with regular intake of Simvastatin. 5. Previous Stroke: Mr. Thompson suffered a mild stroke 2 years ago with no residual symptoms or deficits  so he is on aspirin for secondary prevention.   Family History: --------------- Mr. Thompson's father experienced a stroke at the age of 70. His mother had hypertension. He has two younger sisters - one of them has T2DM while the other is healthy. He has no children.   Social History: --------------- Mr. Thompson is a retired engineer  married for 35 years. He is a former smoker  having quit 6 years ago and was a moderate alcohol drinker  but quit after his CABG surgery. Mr. Thompson enjoys reading and gardening.  Clinical Assessment: --------------- The clinical picture paired with the sudden onset of symptoms strongly suggests an evolving stroke. Given his past medical history  Mr. Thompson is at a high risk for stroke occurrence. An urgent neurological evaluation  along with a CT scan of the brain  is recommended.   Patient Management: --------------- Initiating stroke protocol measures  strategies for thrombolysis or thrombectomy should be considered depending on the results of the further examination and imaging. His current medications for hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and previous stroke will continue  with possible adjustments based on his new clinical findings.

Title: Clinical Presentation of A Patient with Stroke  Patient Information:  Mr. John Doe  a 68-year old African-American male born in 1953 and a resident of Richmond  Virginia  was brought to the hospital because of sudden onset right sided weakness and slurred speech.  Past Medical History: Our patient on review has a significant history of hyperlipidemia and hypertension diagnosed 8 years ago along with type 2 diabetes mellitus which was diagnosed 5 years ago. He is a smoker with a 20-pack year history and consumes alcohol occasionally. Unfortunately  Mr. Doe is not compliant with medication and lifestyle modifications as advised. His prescriptions include metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. He doesn't have any known allergies to any medications. There is a family history of stroke  as his father had a stroke at the age of 72.  Clinical Presentation: Mr. Doe was brought to the emergency department roughly two hours post symptom onset. He presents with difficulty in talking  understanding  confusion  sudden severe headache  dizziness  loss of balance  but no loss of consciousness. A physical exam revealed right-sided hemiparesis  facial drooping on the right side  and dysarthria.  Initial impression points towards a left hemisphere cerebrovascular accident  most likely ischemic in nature  given the clinical presentation and risk factors. Further investigations including CT scan/MRI  blood tests  a cerebral angiogram  carotid ultrasound  and an echocardiogram are scheduled to confirm the diagnosis and map the future course of treatment.   This case serves as a reminder of the importance of addressing modifiable risk factors like smoking  poor diet  sedentary lifestyle  and poor management of hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. Early recognition of symptoms and prompt treatment can significantly improve the outcome of a stroke patient.

Patient Presentation  Patient's Identity: Mr. Gavin Peterson Age: 68 years Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired military officer   Mr. Gavin Peterson  a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2  presented with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in speech  which he noticed when he woke up this morning. He has been managing his chronic illnesses with medication  but admits inconsistent compliance to his treatment regimen. Mr. Peterson lives alone and is a retired military officer. He denies any smoking or illicit drug usage but admits to moderate regular alcohol use. He has a paternal family history of cardiovascular disease with his father who had a fatal heart attack at the age of 62.  Upon physical examination  Mr. Peterson showed signs of dysarthria  right facial droop  and right-sided hemiparesis. These symptoms along with his medical history strongly indicate a suspected ischemic stroke. Further diagnostic imaging and stroke protocol should be established urgently to confirm the diagnosis and begin appropriate management. Furthermore  close attention should be given to his chronic conditions and lifestyle changes should be discussed as part of long-term care. Despite living alone  it’s encouraging that Mr. Peterson managed to seek medical attention promptly  but coordinating potential post-hospital care might need to be addressed  given the uncertainty of potential motor function loss.   This is a clear medical emergency requiring immediate attention and multidisciplinary management. The goal now is not only treating the current stroke but also to prevent future cardiovascular and cerebrovascular events  improve the management of his chronic conditions  and enhance Mr. Peterson's overall quality of life.

Title: Patient Presentation: Mr. Smith with a Suspected Stroke   I am presenting a case of Mr. John Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  living in San Jose  California. He is a non-smoker with a known medical history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension for the past 10 years—both well-controlled with medication. The patient has been compliant with Metformin for his diabetes and Lisinopril-Hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension. He has also been on Low-Dose Aspirin as a prophylaxis for cardiovascular disease. His vaccination status is up-to-date. He has no known allergies.  On June 6  2023  Mr. Smith reported sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking coherently after waking up from his afternoon nap. His wife noticed that his face seemed to droop on the left side and he was unable to hold his cup of tea with his left hand. There was no reported seizure activity or loss of consciousness. The patient reported no headache  vertigo  or vision changes prior to these symptoms.  Family history is significant for a paternal grandfather who suffered a stroke at 72 and a maternal uncle who suffered a myocardial infarction at 65. Mr. Smith reported to the emergency department within 45 minutes of symptom onset.   Initial physical examination showed a conscious but anxious man. He was able to follow commands but had difficulty in forming words (expressive aphasia). His vitals were stable but demonstrated elevated blood pressure at 160/90 mmHg. Motor examination revealed 2/5 power in the left upper and lower limbs and mild left facial droop with normal sensory examination. There were no cerebellar signs or any signs of meningeal irritation.  Subsequently  an urgent Non-contrast CT of the brain was ordered to establish whether the stroke was ischemic where a blood clot stops the blood supply to the brain or hemorrhagic where a blood vessel in the brain bursts.

Title: Stroke Patient Presentation  Demographic Information: Patient's Name: Mr. David Brown Age: 68 years Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Professor Living Situation: Lives alone in a bungalow Smoking Status: Non-smoker Alcohol Intake: Occasionally socially  Chief Complaint: Mr. Brown reported experiencing symptoms of severe headache  sudden weakness  and numbness on the right side of his body  confusion  blurred vision  dizziness  and slurring of speech. These symptoms started suddenly while he was having lunch at home.   Past Medical History: Mr. Brown has known hypertension and Type-2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 6 years ago. Both are generally well-controlled with regular medication. He had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) three years back  from which he recovered fully. He had quit smoking post-TIA.   His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease; his father died of a heart attack  and his mother had a stroke.   Current Medication:  He takes Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes and Amlodipine 5mg once daily for hypertension. No known drug allergies.  Social History: Mr. Brown leads an active lifestyle  keeping himself engaged in gardening and social work. He adheres to a balanced diet mostly but admits having a sweet tooth.  Overall: Given the sudden onset of symptoms - specifically unilateral bodily weakness and slurred speech  along with his hypertension  reported TIA  diabetes  and positive family history - we consider an acute ischemic stroke as the top differential. He sits within the therapeutic window for thrombolytic therapy  if further supported by neuroimaging findings.

Subject: Patient Introduction and Medical History Report  Patient Information: Name: Mrs. Joan Smith Age: 65 years Gender: Female Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired School Teacher Living Conditions: Lives with her husband in a suburban environment Smoking Status: Non-smoker Alcohol Use: Occasionally  in moderation  Presenting Complaint: Mrs. Joan Smith has presented with the primary symptoms suggestive of a stroke. These symptoms include sudden weakness on the right side of her body  difficulty in speaking  loss of balance  and dizziness.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Smith has a known past medical history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are being managed through medication and lifestyle modifications. Her blood pressure and glucose levels have been mostly under control  with occasional spikes.  She had previously experienced a Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) 7 years ago  but there were no subsequent episodes or significant residuals. She is also a survivor of breast cancer from 10 years ago  and she has been in full remission since completing her treatment.  Family History: There is a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases. Her father died at the age of 68 due to a massive stroke  and her brother  aged 70  has coronary artery disease.  Medications: She is on Metformin for her diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Tamoxifen as a preventive measure regarding her breast cancer.   Review: In light of her symptoms and past medical history  there is a high suspicion of her having experienced a stroke. Immediate diagnostics  including neurological evaluation and imaging  are warranted to confirm the diagnosis and commence appropriate treatment. Her known risk factors include her age  hypertension  diabetes  previous TIA  and family history of stroke. Timely intervention is crucial due to the potentially severe consequences of a stroke.   End of Report.

Title: Case Presentation of Acute Stroke  Patient Profile: The patient is a 71-year-old African American male named Mr. John Peterson who resides at 4467 Westwood Avenue  New York. He is a retired banker  living with his wife. He does not have any known hereditary diseases. He stopped smoking 25 years ago and consumes alcohol occasionally  mostly during social events.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Peterson was brought to the emergency department on May 16  2021  after his wife noticed sudden onset of slurred speech  right facial drooping  and weakness in the right limb. Upon questioning  signs started about 1 hour prior to presenting to the ER.   Past Medical History: Mr. Peterson has a documented medical history of hypertension for the past 20 years  currently under the control of Lisinopril 20mg daily. He had also been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 10 years ago  managed by Metformin 1000mg twice daily. No records of previous strokes or transient ischemic attacks. There is also no family history of cerebrovascular accidents. Mr. Peterson is not allergic to any known medications.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  his blood pressure recorded was 172/96 mmHg  pulse 98 beats per minute  and body temperature at 98.2°F. Neurological examination confirmed the presence of right-sided facial drooping  right arm drift  and slightly garbled speech suggestive of aphasia. No signs of meningeal irritation or focal sensory loss.   Conclusion: The clinical features are indicative of a possible acute stroke  likely ischemic  affecting the left side of the brain. Further investigations such as CT scan/MRI of the brain  carotid Doppler ultrasound  and complete blood count are recommended. Urgent stroke team referral has been made for potential thrombolytic therapy  considering the symptom onset within the therapeutic window. The patient would also benefit from closer control of blood pressure and blood sugar levels. A multidisciplinary approach  involving neurology  physiotherapy  and speech and language therapy  would be beneficial in managing and preventing further stroke episodes in Mr. Peterson.

Title: Clinical Presentation of a Stroke Patient  Patient Profile: Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented at the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of weakness on the right side of his body  difficulty in speaking  and vision changes that began earlier in the day.  Past Medical History (PMH): The PMH includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed seven years ago. He also has a 10-year history of tobacco use and elevated cholesterol levels. He is currently under medication for the aforesaid conditions (ACE-inhibitors for hypertension  Metformin for diabetes  and Statins for hypercholesterolemia). There is no history of prior cerebrovascular events or other neurological abnormalities.  Family History: There is a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father succumbed to coronary artery disease  and his elder sister suffered a stroke at the age of 70.   Social and Lifestyle Characteristics: Mr. Doe is a retiree living with his wife. He has a 30 pack-year smoking history  and his alcohol consumption is moderate. His diet predominantly includes processed and fast food.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient has increased blood pressure (160/100mm Hg)  and his BMI is within the overweight range. Neurological examination reveals right hemiparesis  facial droop  and dysarthria. A comprehensive stroke examination by the NIH Stroke Scale rates his stroke at 15.  Given the PMH  family history  and lifestyle choices like uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  unhealthy diet  and persistent smoking  Mr. Doe is already at high risk for a vascular event. The sudden onset neurological deficits strongly suggest an acute ischemic stroke.   Further diagnostic measures such as CT scan or MRI  blood tests  carotid ultrasound or cerebral angiogram should be initiated immediately. Based on his risk factors  lifestyle modification  adherence to medication  and potentially antithrombotic therapy will be critical in managing his condition and preventing further cerebrovascular events.   Above all  the importance of prompt diagnosis and treatment cannot be overstated in cases of stroke  as ‘Time is Brain’.

Patient Presentation:  We are presenting Mr. Thomas Owens  a 70-year-old Caucasian male who has presented with symptoms suggestive of a stroke. Mr. Owens is currently living with his wife in Brooklyn  New York and is recently retired from his work as an accountant. He is of average build  weighing around 165 lbs with a height of 5'11"". He is a non-smoker and reports moderate alcohol consumption.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Owens has an extensive past medical history of high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes for which he has been on medication for the past ten years including beta-blockers and oral hypoglycemics. He had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago  and had a coronary artery bypass graft a week later. He had been maintaining his cholesterol levels with statins since his bypass surgery. Additionally  he suffers from asymptomatic osteoarthritis. He has no known allergies and reports being compliant with his medication.   Presenting Symptoms:  According to his wife  Mr. Owens started to experience sudden onset of severe headache  confusion  trouble speaking and understanding  and difficulty walking approximately 3 hours before presenting to the Emergency Department. He has no fever  chest pain  difficulty breathing  or any other associated symptoms.   Based on these symptoms and history  we strongly suspect a cerebrovascular accident  or in other words  a stroke. An immediate full neurological examination and brain scan is warranted to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity and type of stroke  which will guide the urgent medical intervention. The health care team is concerned about the potential effects of the stroke given his past medical history of heart disease and diabetes.

Patient Presentation:  Good afternoon everyone   Today  we are presenting a case of a 65-year-old African American male named Mr. John Doe  who comes to the emergency room with signs of an acute stroke.  Mr. Doe resides in the urban city of Boston  Massachusetts  and lives with his wife. He is a retired mechanical engineer  does not smoke  and drinks alcohol occasionally. He has a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 28  indicating that he is overweight.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension diagnosed five years ago and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed three years ago. Both conditions have been reasonably controlled with medications; however  his compliance to medication and routine check-ups has been irregular. He has no known allergies.  About 2 hours ago  he started experiencing a sudden onset of right-sided weakness with slurred speech. His wife confirms that he appeared confused and had difficulty understanding her. There were no reported seizures  loss of consciousness  or headaches.  Upon further examination  his blood pressure was found to be slightly elevated. The preliminary neurological evaluation has revealed right hemiparesis  facial droop  and dysarthria  arousing the suspicion of an ischemic stroke. Mr. Doe's condition is currently stabilized  and he has been sent for further imaging and investigations to confirm the diagnosis.  In summary  we are examining a case of a 65-year-old male presenting with acute stroke symptoms who has other predisposing factors like age  ethnicity  hypertension  and diabetes. This asserts the importance of regular monitoring and control of the underlying conditions to prevent such drastic outcomes in the future.

Title: Clinical Presentation of a 68-Year-old Female with Stroke  Good day everyone   The purpose of my presentation today is to detail the clinical case of a 68-year-old Caucasian female  Mrs. Anderson  who has recently presented with a stroke.  Mrs. Anderson is a retired teacher who lives in rural Kentucky with her husband. She is a former smoker  having smoked a pack per day for 30 years before quitting 10 years ago. Her daily alcohol consumption is in the low-risk category  and she denies any current drug use. She maintains a borderline body mass index  leaning towards overweight  and records limited physical activity.  Mrs. Anderson's past medical history is significant for controlled hypertension for 20 years  taking Lisinopril-Hydrochlorothiazide. She is also a type 2 diabetic  controlled using Metformin for the past 10 years.  Mrs. Anderson arrived at the emergency department this morning brought in by her husband after noticing right-sided weakness and slurred speech upon waking up from sleep. The onset of symptoms was sudden. She was afebrile  not in apparent distress  but showed diminished strength and coordination on her right side. Her speech was slow  and she had difficulty finding words. She was alert and oriented to name and place but was not entirely sure of the current date  indicating possible confusion.  Neurological examination suggested the presence of a left hemisphere cerebrovascular accident. She underwent an immediate CT scan that revealed an acute left middle cerebral artery ischemic stroke. Treatment was promptly initiated according to the stroke protocol with intravenous tissue plasminogen activator  given within the recommended window from the onset of symptoms.  The importance of strict control of her hypertension and diabetes was reiterated  recommending lifestyle changes  including exercise and diet modification. She has been transferred to the stroke unit for a close monitor of her condition  and further management.  Thank you.

Patient Presentation  The patient is a 57-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John Smith. He is a long-term resident of Chicago  Illinois. Mr. Smith has an extensive medical history which includes hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and high cholesterol.   He was brought into the emergency department by his wife who reported witnessing sudden onset of right-sided facial drooping  speech difficulties and right-sided weakness about 3 hours prior. According her  these symptoms were completely new and she also stated that her husband was complaining about a severe headache.   Mr. Smith is a former smoker with a history of 20-pack years but quit smoking around 10 years ago on the advice of his physician. He consumes alcohol in moderate amounts only during social gatherings and does not have any known illicit drug use.  His family history is also remarkable with his father and older brother both having suffered from strokes at relatively early ages  thus making him genetically predisposed to cerebrovascular accidents. His regular medications include Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for cholesterol management.  In summary  Mr. Smith is a 57-year-old man with significant cardiovascular risk factors including hypertension  diabetes mellitus  high cholesterol and strong family history  presenting with new concerning symptoms suggestive of acute Cerebrovascular Accident (Stroke). It is highly recommended that he undergo immediate investigation and treatment to minimize any potential risks and complications.

Title: Stroke Presentation of A 68-Year-Old Male Patient  Good Day! The patient in discussion is Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old Caucasian male residing in downtown Chicago. He was brought in presenting classical stroke symptoms. Mr. Doe is a retired banker who lives with his wife. Mr. Doe's current presentation was sudden in onset  characterized by severe headache  slurred speech  and right-sided weakness.  The patient has an extensive past medical history of chronic hypertension  uncontrolled type-2 diabetes  and is a former smoker with a 40 pack-year smoking history. His hypertension and diabetes have been managed with oral medications for over 15 years. Hypertension is under control; however  his glycemic index has been fluctuating over the years. His family history reveals similar problems with hypertension and diabetes  but with no records of stroke.  In the past  Mr. Doe has presented with no symptoms of neurological disorders. However  over the last year  Mrs. Doe has noticed moments of forgetfulness with occasional difficulty finding correct words  but these incidents were sporadic and not alarming enough to seek medical attention.   Currently  he presents with aphasia and hemiparesis  common symptoms related to stroke. Immediately upon admission  CT and MRI scans were performed  revealing an ischemic stroke in the left hemisphere of his brain  causing his right-sided weakness.  The patient's condition was immediately addressed by following the standard stroke protocol. His blood pressure and glucose levels were monitored and managed. Measures were taken to prevent complications including deep vein thrombosis and to initiate early rehabilitation.  In summary  Mr. Doe  a 68-year-old man with a significant past medical history of hypertension and type-2 diabetes  presented with a sudden onset of severe headache  slurred speech  and right-sided weakness  indicative of a stroke. His history and symptoms  along with the results of imaging studies  helped confirm the diagnosis of an ischemic stroke.

Patient Presentation  I am presenting a 65-year-old Caucasian male named David Smith who appears to be experiencing symptoms of a stroke. He does not have any known drug allergies.  Regarding his medications  he takes Metformin 500mg BID for diabetes and Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension. He is not on any kind of blood thinner.   He was in his usual state of health until this morning when the symptoms began. His wife reported that he had a headache last night which improved after he took acetaminophen. Mr. Smith has been informed about the seriousness of his condition and the importance of immediate intervention  including the possibility of thrombolytic therapy. Presentation Title: Stroke and Subsequent Complications: A Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction The presentation outlines a case study of a patient presenting with a stroke. The patient’s demographics  medical history  current symptoms  and the potential therapeutic approach will be discussed.   Slide 2: Personal Information Patient X is a 68-year-old male  of African-American descent  currently residing in Houston  Texas. He is a retired engineer  non-smoker with a moderate alcohol consumption pattern. His BMI is within a healthy range  and he lives with his wife who noticed his acute symptoms.   Slide 3: Past Medical History Mr. X has a history of hypertension and Type II diabetes  which have been controlled with medication for the past 10 years. He also suffers from atherosclerosis. He has no history of previous strokes or transient ischemic attacks (TIAs)  no allergies  no family history of strokes but his father had heart disease.  Slide 4: Current Symptoms The patient was presented to the emergency department with classic stroke symptoms. He suddenly experienced weakness on the left side of the body  slurred speech and confusion. He also states that he lost balance and coordination.   Slide 5: Clinical Findings Neurologically  he was awake and alert  but oriented to person only. Cranial nerve examination revealed left facial droop and left-sided neglect. Motor examination confirmed the significant left-sided weakness. His blood pressure was found to be elevated and blood glucose was in the higher range than usual.   Slide 6: Assessment and Plan Based on his medical history  current symptoms and physical examination  it supports the diagnosis of an acute ischemic stroke. He was quickly given a CT scan which confirmed the diagnosis.   Slide 7: Treatment and Management The patient was indeed experiencing an ischemic stroke  and was promptly treated with intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). He will also undergo rehabilitation to address the resultant motor weaknesses. Further  continuous management of his diabetes and hypertension will be essential in lowering his risk of future incidents. Lifestyle modifications will also be suggested  including a healthy diet  physical activity  stress management  and limited alcohol intake.   Slide 8: Conclusion This case represents the acute presentation and management of a stroke. It highlights the importance of quick intervention and the use of tPA for favorable outcomes. Furthermore  it acknowledges the necessity for adequate control of prevalent conditions such as hypertension and diabetes  that contribute to stroke incidents.

Patient Presentation  I am presenting a 65-year-old African American male  Mr. X  who has reported to our emergency department with signs indicative of stroke. Prior to this event  he had noted occasional episodes of weakness which he attributed to his diabetes and ageing process.   In terms of medication  the patient is on Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  a statin for his hyperlipidemia  and Aspirin as prophylaxis against heart disease; he is compliant with his medications. Patient Presentation:  Good morning team. Today  I would like to present a case regarding a 68-year-old African American male named Mr. Williams. He hails from downtown Queens  New York  where he lives with his wife. He was a construction worker  but he is currently retired.   Mr. Williams arrived at the emergency room last night with symptoms of right-sided weakness  difficulty in speech  facial droop  and disorientation. These symptoms emerged suddenly while he was watching television with his wife who then immediately drove him to our hospital.  In terms of medical history  Mr. Williams has been hypertensive for the past 20 years and is on a low sodium diet along with 25mg of Hydrochlorothiazide once daily. Five years ago  he had a myocardial infarction and had two stents implanted. He is on aspirin (75mg once daily) and a statin (atorvastatin 20mg once daily) for this. There is also a history of type II diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years  which he controls with metformin (500mg twice daily) and lifestyle modifications.   Mr. Williams is a non-smoker but admits to having a 20-year history of pack-a-day smoking until his MI 5 years ago. He denies illicit drug use and drinks alcohol occasionally  noting maybe one or two beers on the weekend. His mother died of stroke at the age of 72 which suggests a family history of cardiovascular disease.   His last recorded health care visit was just 6 months ago  where he was noted to be relatively stable and blood tests suggested adequate diabetic control.   Given his symptoms and background  our current clinical suspicion is a possible ischemic stroke. We have conducted an immediate neurological exam  obtained a head CT  and are awaiting the results. In the meantime  pertinent interventions such as administration of tPA  if the CT scan suggests no hemorrhage and within the window period  will be prepared. We will also manage his care based on current stroke guidelines and are aiming for swift rehabilitation and secondary prevention measures.

Patient Presentation  We are discussing a 69-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. John Davidson  who presented with acute onset neurological deficits  suggestive of a stroke. Mr. Davidson is a retired engineer  a non-smoker  and a moderate drinker. Mr. Davidson was found at his home by his wife in a state of confusion  slurred speech  and weakness on the right side of his body.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension which was diagnosed approximately 10 years ago  and he is following antihypertensive medication regimen. He also suffers from hyperlipidemia and Type II diabetes mellitus which are relatively well-managed with medication. Additionally  he had a Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) about 3 years ago.  His family medical history is relevant for strokes  with both his father and paternal grandmother suffering from strokes at around 70 years of age. His father also had a history of heart disease.  Upon arrival to the emergency department  he presented with a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate at 95 beats per minute  temperature at 37°C  respiratory rate at 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. His physical examination showed decreased muscle strength of 2/5 in his right upper and lower extremities  and he had clear signs of facial droop on the right side. His speech was slurred  and he was experiencing difficulty understanding verbal commands  indicative of receptive aphasia.  On the basis of his symptoms  past medical and family history  and the initial physical examination  a stroke was highly suspected. Further neuroimaging tests were immediately ordered to confirm the diagnosis and to accurately determine the extent and location of the stroke  which will guide the treatment plan.  Mr. Davidson's case emphasizes the importance of early detection and prompt intervention in stroke management  given his rapid progression of symptoms within a short period and the significant risk factors including age  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and his previous TIA.

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: Case Presentation: Stroke Patient Profile   Slide 2: Patient's Demographic Information  - Name: Jane Smith - Age: 64 years old  - Sex: Female - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired School Teacher - Family Background: Mother suffered a stroke at age 68.  Slide 3: Medical History   - Hypertension: Diagnosed 12 years ago - Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 8 years ago - Smoking history: Smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years; quit smoking 10 years ago. - Alcohol Intake: Patient reports occasional alcohol intake - Hereditary Risk: Stroke history from the maternal side.  Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms  - Date of Presentation: January 15  2022 - Symptoms: Suddenly developed weakness and numbness on the right side of body and slurred speech. - Time Frame: Symptoms appeared around 9 am on day of presentation.  Slide 5: Conclusion  Proper treatment and management planning will be carried out based on diagnostic test results. The patient will possibly require a multidisciplinary team approach consisting of a neurologist  physiotherapist  dietician  psychologist and stroke nurse specialist to manage her health issue and mitigate the risk of future occurrence. A post-discharge plan will also be prepared to ensure healthy lifestyle modifications and compliance to medication regimens.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old African American male by the name of Mr. George Smith who presented to the Emergency Department on August 15  2022 with symptoms suggestive of an acute stroke.   Mr. Smith was watching television at home with his wife when she noticed a sudden change in his behavior. His speech became slurred and he started showing difficulty while walking  appearing clumsy. He also had a sudden weakness on his right side  most prominent in the arm and leg.  His past medical history is significant. Mr. Smith is known to have hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he takes Lisinopril and Metformin respectively. He is also a smoker with a 30 pack-year history. His mother had a stroke in her late 60s.  He has no known allergies. He retired 5 years ago from a bank where he worked as a manager. He drinks socially and denies any illicit drug use. His body mass index is 28  suggestive of being overweight.  Mr. Smith's clinical presentation along with his risk factors  including age  race  hypertension  diabetes  smoking status  and family history of stroke  strongly suggest that he is presently suffering an acute stroke. Timely intervention and management in the form of intravenous thrombolysis or endovascular therapy would be crucial in Mr. Smith's case to limit the extent of irreversible neurological damage.

Presentation of Patient with Stroke   Demographic Information:  Patient's Name: Mr. John Doe Gender: Male Age: 68 years Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer Marital Status: Married Next of Kin: Mrs. Jane Doe (wife) No known drug allergies  Medical History:  Mr. Doe presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking which started about three hours prior to arriving to the hospital. These symptoms were noted by his wife who immediately called 911.   Mr. Doe has a significant past medical history which includes hypertension  hypercholesterolemia and type two diabetes mellitus. He has been taking medication consistently for these conditions which include Metformin for his diabetes  Lisinopril for his hypertension  and Atorvastatin for his high cholesterol.   Mr. Doe quit smoking ten years ago but had a 30 pack-year history. He does not consume alcohol or use any illicit drugs. He denies any recent travel or trauma.   His family history adds to his risk as his mother suffered a stroke in her late sixties and his father had a heart attack early in his sixties.   Upon physical examination  Mr. Doe was conscious but showing expressive aphasia. He exhibits right-sided facial droop and has 2/5 strength in his right upper and lower extremities. He's experiencing difficulty maintaining balance when sitting up. His blood pressure on admission was 155/90 mmHg  heart rate of 88 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air.   A CT scan and MRI were ordered to confirm the type and location of the stroke. Upon confirmation of an ischemic stroke  an intravenous thrombolytic was administered to reestablish blood flow in the blocked artery.  In summary  Mr. Doe's significant cardiac risk factors  hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  along with his family history places him at high risk for stroke. It's strongly recommended upon stabilization and recovery  Mr. Doe undergo further assessment and management  with possible medication adjustments  to mitigate future stroke risk.

Title: Case Presentation of Stroke in a Geriatric Patient  I. Introduction:  Presenting the case of Mrs. Y  a 72-year-old Caucasian female residing in Chicago  Illinois  diagnosed with an acute ischemic stroke.  II. Demographics and Background:  Mrs. Y is a retired school teacher whose primary language is English. She is a widow with three adult children and seven grandchildren. Her primary health insurer is Medicare and she has secondary insurance through a commercial health plan.   III. Past Medical History:  Mrs. Y has a significant medical history that includes: 1. Hypertension controlled with Losartan  2. Type II Diabetes managed with Metformin 3. Hyperlipidemia controlled with Atorvastatin 4. A prior transient ischemic attack (TIA) approximately 4 years ago 5. No known drug allergies  She does not smoke or consume alcohol. Her eating habits are relatively healthy but she does not engage in regular exercise due to arthritis in the knees.   IV. Presenting Complaint:  Mrs. Y visited the ER after experiencing sudden numbness and weakness on the left side of her body  impaired speech  and difficulty walking starting about 3 hours before her arrival at the hospital. These symptoms were all new for Mrs. Y. Her son mentioned she had recently complained of intermittent episodes of throbbing headache for the past 3 days.  V. Stroke Diagnosis:  Physical examination confirmed left-sided weakness  facial droop  and speech difficulties. An emergent non-contrast CT scan of the head revealed a thrombotic occlusion in the right middle cerebral artery with edema but no evidence of hemorrhage—consistent with an acute ischemic stroke. Carotid ultrasound showed stenosis of the right carotid artery.   Early identification and immediate medical attention have hopefully minimized potential long-term complications for Mrs. Y. She has been started on appropriate stroke treatment  including anticoagulant therapy with intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA).   VI. Plan and Follow-up:  Multidisciplinary involvement from neurology  physiotherapy  and dietetics is warranted in the management of Mrs. Y’s condition. A follow-up is planned after 1 month for a full neurological assessment and to evaluate her response to the stroke therapy. In the meantime  she will be overseen by the stroke nursing team.   Her family members have been counselled on her condition  possible complications  the importance of medication adherence  and lifestyle modifications including regular physical activity as her condition allows  a heart-healthy diet  and maintaining a healthy weight. Their engagement in her aftercare will be a crucial component of her recovery process and her long-term health outcomes.   In conclusion  Mrs. Y's case highlights the importance of prompt recognition and treatment of stroke symptoms  as well as the role of lifestyle modification and adherence to long-term medical management in preserving health.  Thank you.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old African-American male presenting with sudden-onset right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and facial droop noticed by his wife at home. She reports that he was in his usual state of good health until approximately 30 minutes prior to arrival at the ER. The weakness was sudden with no preceding falls or injuries. He has struggled to form words and cannot move the right side of his body. His wife also mentioned that he appeared confused when she tried to talk to him.  Vital signs on arrival are stable except for a blood pressure of 190/100 mmHg. The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker but quit 5 years ago after a 30 pack-year history. He also has a family history of stroke with his father having had a stroke at the age of 70. His medications include lisinopril  metformin  and atorvastatin. No known drug allergies.   On physical examination  the patient is conscious but appears anxious. Speech is slurred but he is able to follow commands. His right upper and lower extremities are weak and he has a right-sided facial droop. Pupils equal  round  and reactive to light. The rest of the physical exam is unremarkable.  Mr. Johnson is on a regular diet but lately has been non-compliant with his diet and medication which his wife attributes to stress at work. His alcohol consumption is moderate with occasional drinks over weekends and he denies any illicit drug use. He lives with his wife  has two adult children and is currently employed as an engineer.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes. He was brought in by his wife who noted sudden onset of slurred speech  confusion and drooping of the right side of his face and right arm weakness while they were having breakfast this morning. This is the first time he has experienced such symptoms. The patient denies experiencing any trauma. He confirmed that he had been adhering to his regular medication schedule for his chronic conditions. He is a former smoker but quit 10 years ago and drinks alcohol occasionally. He has no known drug allergies.  Family history reveals that his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age 75 and his mother has a history of stroke. The patient is a retired banker and lives with his wife; their two children are grown and live out of state.   Objective examination reveals blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg  heart rate of 75 bpm regular in rhythm  oxygen saturation of 95% on room air  and temperature of 98.6°F. Neurologically  his Glasgow Coma Scale score is 13/15 with motor response score of 5  and expressive and receptive aphasia present. Right-sided facial droop and weakness  and 3/5 power in the right upper and lower limbs were noted.  A stroke code was immediately activated and the patient was sent for an emergent CT scan.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J. is a 63-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of slurred speech  right-sided weakness  and difficulty walking. These symptoms were noticed by his wife around 30 minutes ago  and they arrived at the hospital promptly. Mr. J. is a retired school teacher who lives with his wife. He denies substance abuse but admits to 30 pack-years of smoking  although he quit 5 years ago. He consumes alcohol socially  but not excessively.  Past Medical History:  Mr. J. was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago and dyslipidemia 7 years ago  for which he takes Ramipril 10mg and Atorvastatin 40mg once daily  respectively. He has no other known allergies or drug intolerances. The family history is positive for cerebrovascular accidents  his father passed away due to a hemorrhagic stroke at the age of 72.   He had a transurethral prostatectomy two years ago for benign prostatic hyperplasia and made a good postoperative recovery. He does not report any history of heart disease  diabetes mellitus  or any other serious medical conditions.   Physical Examination:  On examination  he is alert and oriented but has difficulty speaking. His speech is slurred but he appears to understand what is being said to him. His pulse is regular but fast at 110 bpm. Blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg  temperature is 98.6°F and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Focused neurological examination reveals right-sided hemiparesis and right facial droop. He is unable to lift his right arm against gravity and drifts towards the right when sitting with no support. His gait could not be examined due to his difficulties with mobility. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. These symptoms suggest a potential left hemisphere ischemic stroke. Immediate stroke protocol and management will be undertaken.

Patient Information: Mrs. Anna Johnson  a 67-year-old Caucasian retired school teacher  resident of Brooklyn  NY.  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset right-sided weakness and difficulty in speaking since the past 2 hours.  History of Present Illness: The patient was in her usual state of health  watching television when suddenly she felt her right arm becoming weak. She attempted to call for help but found that she was unable to speak clearly. As she tried to get up  she noticed that her right leg was not supporting her and she fell to the ground. She was brought to the emergency department by her husband.  Past Medical History: She has a history of hypertension for 15 years  diabetes Mellitus Type 2 for 10 years  and hyperlipidemia for 7 years. She had a transient ischemic attack about 5 years ago. Both conditions are controlled with medications.  Personal/Social History: The patient is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol. She lives with her husband and follows up regularly with her primary care physician.  Review of Systems: Notable for dysarthria and right-sided hemiparesis. Denied any headache  seizure  loss of consciousness  or incontinence.  Physical Exam: Patient appeared anxious. Vital signs were stable. Neurologic examination revealed right side facial droop  decreased strength of 2/5 in right upper limb and 3/5 in right lower limb. Sensation was intact. Speech was slurred but she was able to understand instructions.   Impression: The sudden onset of her symptoms  coupled with her known history  and findings on physical examination leads to the impression of an acute ischemic stroke. (Note: Images such as a CT scan or an MRI would be necessary for further confirmation.)

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Charles  a 72-year-old Caucasian retired teacher  presents to the emergency department after experiencing sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech for the past 3 hours. His wife also noticed that he had difficulty understanding her and initially dismissed it as tiredness before realizing he could be having a stroke.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Both of these conditions are controlled with medications (Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension and Atorvastatin 20mg daily for hyperlipidemia). He quit smoking 20 years ago but has a 30 pack-year history of smoking prior to quitting. He also has a family history of ischemic strokes – both his father and elder brother experienced strokes in their 70s.  His current symptoms includes difficulty speaking  understanding speech  drooping on one side of his face and arm weakness. No report of headaches  chest pain  or shortness of breath. No recent trauma  fever  headache  vision changes  seizure activity  difficulty swallowing or loss of consciousness.  Vital signs are within normal limits except for elevated blood pressure of 160/92 mmHg. Body Mass Index is 29  indicating overweight. Random blood glucose is 126 mg/dL.   Based on his symptoms and past medical history  the patient appears to be having an acute ischemic stroke  which warrants immediate neurological evaluation and intervention.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired teacher  presents to the emergency department accompanied by his wife. The patient complains of sudden onset of weakness on the right side of his body  slurred speech  and difficulty walking that started about 90 minutes ago.  Demographic Details:  Mr. Doe lives with his wife in the local area. He is a non-smoker and reports only occasional alcohol use. His BMI is calculated to be 28 and he has a sedentary lifestyle.   Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He was diagnosed with Type II diabetes 10 years ago  which has been managed with diet and Metformin. His father had a stroke at 68. He admits being non-compliant with his prescribed antihypertensive medications (Lisinopril and Amlodipine) and his last blood pressure measurement was 180/100 mmHg during a routine check-up 2 weeks ago. He is not on any anticoagulant medication  and denies any previous stroke or TIA symptoms. He is allergic to Penicillin.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Jennifer Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian female  presenting with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking for the past 30 minutes. She states that she was having breakfast when she suddenly dropped a glass she was holding in her right hand and slurred speech. She denies headache  dizziness  loss of consciousness  or bowel or bladder incontiness.   Past Medical History:  She has a 10-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are well-managed with medications (Lisinopril and Metformin respectively). She quit smoking 5 years ago but had a 40-year history of pack-a-day smoking prior to quitting. She has a history of transient ischemic attack (TIA) about 2 years ago. She denies history of heart disease  peripheral vascular disease or hypercoagulable disorder.  Family history includes a mother and older brother with stroke in their late 60s. She lives alone but has supportive neighbors who check on her everyday. She denies alcohol or illicit drug use.  Relevant findings on examination include a Blood Pressure of 165/95 mmHg  pulse 98/min  normal temperature and respiratory rate. Neurologic exam reveals significant right-sided facial droop  arm drift and leg weakness with a score of 3/5 on muscle strength testing.
