She has slurred speech but is alert  oriented and comprehends well. Rest of the examination is within normal limit.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Brown  a 75-year-old African American male  presents to the Emergency Department experiencing acute onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking  which started approximately 2 hours ago. He was found slumped in his chair by his caregiver who promptly brought him to the hospital.  Demographic Details: Mr. Brown is a retired engineer  widowed  and now lives under the care of a home health aide but maintains some degree of independence. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol moderately. He has no known drug allergies.  Past Medical History: His relevant medical history includes a diagnosis of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus (both diagnosed approximately 10 years ago)  for which he takes antihypertensive medications and metformin respectively. Mr. Brown also had a previous transient ischemic attack (TIA) 5 years ago  but no residual deficits were noted after that episode. He has no history of surgeries  cardiovascular disease or cancer. His father had a stroke at age 70 and died of subsequent complications. His mother passed away due to cardiac failure at age 74.  His baseline functional status prior to this symptom onset was independent for all activities of daily living. His swallowing function was normal and he maintained a normal diet. His caregiver reports that he has been compliant with his medications and regular follow-ups.  In light of his symptoms and pertinent medical history  a stroke is strongly suspected  and immediate medical intervention is warranted.

Patient Information:   Mr. James Henderson  a 67-year-old black male  presents to the emergency department accompanied by his daughter.  Chief Complaint:   Sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty with speech of about 3 hours duration.  History of Present Illness:  The patient was in his usual state of health until he suddenly experienced weakness of his right arm and leg while having lunch with his daughter. He also reported having trouble speaking and understanding words spoken to him. No reported headache  dizziness  or changes in vision. Symptoms persisted and the patient was brought in to the emergency department.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known diagnosis of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. He had been previously diagnosed with atrial fibrillation but was non-compliant to anticoagulant therapy. He had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 5 years back.  Review of Systems:  The patient has been taking his prescribed antihypertensive and oral hypoglycemic agents. He denies any chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  or recent sick contacts. No reports of bowel or urinary incontinence.  Family History:  There is a family history of cardiovascular disease. The patient’s father died at age 69 from a myocardial infarction and his mother suffered from stroke at age 77.  Social History:  The patient is a retired teacher  lives with his wife in a nearby community. He has a 30-year pack history of smoking but quit 2 weeks ago. He admits to consuming alcohol socially but denies any illicit drug use.  Physician's Notes:  On physical examination  the patient appeared alert but anxious. His temperature was 98.6 F  pulse of 76 beats/min and irregular  blood pressure of 165/90 mm Hg  respiratory rate of 18 breaths/minute  with an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Cardiovascular exam revealed an irregularly irregular rhythm. Neurological examination revealed right-sided facial droop  motor strength of 2/5 in the right upper and lower extremities  slurred speech  and normal sensation. Investigations  including non-contrast head CT and various blood tests  have been ordered. The patient has a high-risk profile for ischemic stroke. Management will be decided based on the results of the investigations.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Janet Riley  a 72-year-old Caucasian female  comes in with sudden onset of left-sided weakness  difficulty speaking  and difficulty maintaining balance. These symptoms started just over an hour ago. Patient denies experiencing any current headache  nausea  or recent trauma.   She has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her medications include metformin and lisinopril. She denies alcohol  tobacco  and illicit drug use. She lives alone but has two children who live within a few miles. She denies any known drug allergies.  She has no past surgical history but has a family history of stroke as her father experienced one at the age of 74. She is retired  previously working as an executive assistant. She is widowed  her husband passed away from a heart attack 5 years ago. There appear to be no significant travel or occupational exposures that would contribute to her current symptoms.   Her vital signs upon presentation are: Blood Pressure: 160/90 mmHg  Heart Rate: 85bpm  Respiratory Rate: 18 rpm  Oxygen Saturation: 96% in room air  and Temperature: 37.2 degrees Celsius.  Given the clinical history and the presentation  evaluation for an acute ischemic stroke was initiated.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old African-American male  presents to the emergency department with symptoms of left-sided weakness and slurred speech that started roughly 2 hours ago. The patient's wife  who accompanied him  reported that he seemed confused and had difficulty moving his left arm and leg. She denies any known history of trauma or recent falls.  Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are under fair control with Lisinopril 10 mg daily and Metformin 500 mg twice daily respectively. He is a former smoker with a 40 pack-year smoking history  who quit 10 years ago. His last routine check-up was approximately 4 months ago and  at that time  his blood pressure and glycemic control were within acceptable limits. He does not have any known drug allergies.   The patient's familial history is significant for cerebrovascular illness with both his mother and older sister having experienced strokes over the age of 65. He socially drinks alcohol in moderation and denies illicit drug use.   Mr. Smith is retired and lives with his wife. He was independently mobile and functional before today's episode. As far as his wife knows  he had no previous episodes of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) or strokes.   His calculated NIH stroke scale score is 8  suggestive of a moderate stroke. His vitals on presentation: BP 185/100 mmHg  Pulse 86 beats/min  Respiratory rate 18 breaths per min  Temp 99℉  and SpO2 97% on room air. The patient is immediately sent for a non-contrast CT scan of his head per stroke protocol.    Given Mr. Smith’s age  race  and history of hypertension and diabetes  as well as his symptoms of unilateral weakness  confusion  and speech difficulties  he is suspected of having an acute ischemic stroke.

Mr. Kenneth Johnson  an 71-year old African American male  walked into the emergency department. He presents with sudden onset right-sided weakness  difficulty speaking  and drooping on the right side of his face that started about 2 hours ago. He also mentions a headache and blurred vision. Mr. Johnson has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient is a retired elementary school teacher  who lives alone. He reports compliance with his regimen of metformin and lisinopril. He doesn't smoke and drinks occasionally. He is not on any anticoagulant medications and has not undergone any recent surgeries. His father died of stroke at age 67. He was worried as the same symptoms were shown by his father before death.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Smith  attends the emergency department with a sudden onset of weakness on his right side  including facial drooping  right arm weakness  and difficulty speaking. These symptoms started around an hour ago while having breakfast.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith is a former smoker  quitting about ten years ago  and a history of mild hypertension controlled with medication. He was diagnosed with type II diabetes five years ago  which he controls with lifestyle modifications and metformin. A year ago  he was diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia  for which he regularly takes statins. No allergies have been documented. No previous history of stroke or transient ischemic attack. He lives with his wife and is retired.  Family History: There is a positive family history of stroke  with his father having a stroke in his late sixties. His mother has diabetes  and his older brother passed away from a heart attack in his early seventies.   Social History: He consumes alcohol moderately on weekends and denies any illicit drug use. He is a retired engineer  has two adult children  and is quite active playing golf twice a week.   Review of Symptoms: He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations. No recent history of trauma or injuries. No previous similar episodes. Symptoms have not been experienced before. No recent illness or travel history.   This kind of presentation is suggestive of an acute ischemic stroke  which needs immediate attention and management.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with symptoms that began approximately one hour ago. He reports sudden onset of weakness in his right arm and an inability to speak clearly. His wife  who accompanied him  mentions that the corners of his mouth appear to be drooping and he seems to be having trouble understanding her.  The patient has a known medical history of hypertension and type-2 diabetes  both of which have been controlled with medication. He quit smoking ten years ago but has a 30 pack year history. He does not have any known allergies. He doesn’t report any recent surgeries or trauma. He does not have a personal or family history of stroke  but his father had coronary artery disease.  On examination  the patient presents with altered mental status  with difficulty in speaking and understanding commands. Neurological examination reveals a right-sided facial droop  right-sided weakness which is more evident in the upper limb  and speech deficits  thus for the patient was ranked 3 points on the NIH stroke scale score list.  The patient’s blood glucose level is within normal limits  as are basic metabolic  complete blood count  prothrombin time  and INR (International Normalized Ratio) tests. Blood pressure on admission was recorded as 155/85 mmHg. An urgent non-contrast CT head has been ordered for further evaluation.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 76-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty with speech. Onset was 6 hours ago while he was eating breakfast. His family reports no known trauma or other symptoms prior to onset. Patient has difficulty in maintaining balance while walking  expresses confusion  and occasional dizziness.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a significant past medical history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  diabetes mellitus type 2  and a 30-year history of pack-a-day smoking. He suffered a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 5 years ago. His medications include aspirin  metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. His family history is significant for heart disease and stroke.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking that started around an hour ago. The patient also has a blurring vision in his left eye. He has a history of hypertension  type II diabetes  and a 20-pack year smoking history. Past medical history also reveals recurrent atrial fibrillation for which he's on anticoagulation therapy. He is non-compliant with his medication  which includes metformin  lisinopril  and warfarin. He denies any drug or alcohol abuse. His family history includes stroke in his mother at a similar age. He denies any prior surgeries or allergies. There are no significant environmental factors. His diet is high is sodium and fat  and he has a sedentary lifestyle. He is retired  lives with his wife  and has two grown-up kids. No known drug allergies. His vital signs reveal blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg and irregular heart rate. He is alert  but has some difficulty in expressing his thoughts and understanding language. The physical examination shows right-sided facial droop  reduced muscle strength on the right side of the body  and impaired coordination.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Perkins  a 63-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department via ambulance with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty finding words  symptoms that started an estimated 2 hours prior to arrival.   Mr. Perkins is a retired civil servant  does not consume alcohol  and was a former smoker  having quit about ten years ago. However  he is obese with a BMI of 31 and has poorly controlled hypertension which he has had for more than 15 years. He states that he takes antihypertensive medications irregularly. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago  but admittedly  his glycemic control has not been optimal  with a last HbA1c documented as 8.2% six months ago.   No history of previous similar episodes  head injuries  or recent surgeries. He also denies tick bites or recent travel. There is a family history of stroke with his father suffering from a stroke at an elderly age.  On presentation  he is alert and oriented  but clearly struggling with his speech. A neurological examination reveals a right-sided homonymous hemianopia  right-sided facial droop  dysarthria  and right-sided hemiplegia. Gait and coordination couldn't be assessed due to his weakness.  The rest of his physical examination including cardiovascular  respiratory  and gastrointestinal systems is essentially unremarkable. The patient has no apparent physical injuries.

Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  63-year-old male  presenting to the emergency department.   Chief Complaint: ""I woke up this morning and I couldn't move the right side of my body.""  History of Present Illness: Mr. Doe woke up this morning with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  difficulty speaking  drooling  and a severe headache which he rates as an 8 on a scale of 10. The symptoms have been persistent over the last 5 hours which prompted his wife to bring him to the hospital. He denies any trauma  fever  recent surgery  alcohol or drug usage.  Past Medical History: The patient has a 5-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and high cholesterol levels. He has a history of a transient ischemic attack (TIA) approximately a year ago  for which he was given aspirin. Patient states he has not been compliant with daily aspirin or taking his antihypertensives and statins for the last 6 months. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. There is a family history of strokes (both parents).  Review of Systems: Right-sided weakness  difficulty in speaking  severe headache  no changes in vision or hearing  no chest pain  shortness of breath  or dizziness.  Physical Exam: Pupils equal  round and reactive to light. Right facial droop is noted. Muscle strength in the right upper extremity is 2/5 and lower extremity is 3/5 as compared to 5/5 on the left upper and lower extremities  respectively. Slurred speech is appreciated. Rest of the examination is unremarkable.  Social History: Married  retired  with no history of smoking or illicit drug use. Moderate alcohol use. Lives with his wife who works full-time.  Possible/Working Diagnosis: Acute ischemic stroke

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Anna Smith is a 73-year-old Caucasian female who presented to the emergency room with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. These symptoms were noticed by her daughter who lives with her when she woke up in the morning. She also observed some facial drooping on the same side. Mrs. Smith denies having any chest pain  shortness of breath  headache or vision changes but has been feeling dizzy and unsteady since the symptoms occurred.  Broad review of systems was unremarkable except for a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. Her blood pressure is currently well managed using Amlodipine 5mg once daily  and she has been adhering to her medication regimen. Her diabetes is managed by Metformin 500mg twice daily and the most recent Hemoglobin A1C level from 2 months ago was 6.5%. She takes Simvastatin 20mg at bedtime for hyperlipidemia. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially and occasionally.  Family history is significant for cerebrovascular disease - both her father and elder sister suffered from stroke. She lives with her daughter  is widowed  and worked as an elementary school teacher before retiring.   Given the abrupt onset of her symptoms  her hypoglycemia  hypertension  and family history of cerebrovascular disease  a stroke is suspected.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Smith is a 68-year-old African-American male presenting with sudden-onset numbness and weakness of the left side of his face  arm  and leg that started about 45 minutes before his arrival in the emergency department. He also has some difficulty in speaking  garbled speech  and a moderate headache with no associated nausea or vomiting.   Demographic Details:   Mr. Smith is a retired bank manager  who smokes a pack of cigarettes daily (40 pack-years) and drinks alcohol occasionally. He lives with his wife in the suburbs. He does not use illicit drugs. He has no known allergies.   Relevant Past Medical History:  His medical history is significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. He had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago and follows up regularly with his cardiologist. He has been non-compliant with his prescribed medications: Metformin  Atorvastatin  and Lisinopril  often missing doses due to forgetfulness. There is a family history of stroke; his mother had an ischemic stroke in her late 70s.

Patient Information: A 79-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with his wife. He is retired and lives with his wife in the suburbs.  Chief Complaint:  ""Wife noticed sudden onset of difficulty speaking and right-sided weakness that started approximately 3 hours ago.""  History of Present Illness: Patient's symptoms began while having breakfast  characterized by sudden slurring of speech  difficulty finding words  and right-sided arm and leg weakness. There were no associated symptoms such as headache  seizure  loss of consciousness or incontinence. The symptoms have persisted.  Past Medical History:  He has a history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and coronary artery disease. He underwent a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) 5 years ago. He quit smoking 10 years ago.  Medications: He takes aspirin  metformin  lisinopril  and simvastatin.  Family History: His father had a stroke at the age of 82.  Review of Systems: Non-contributory besides difficulty speaking and right-sided weakness.  Physical Exam:  On examination  he is awake  alert  oriented to time  place  and person. His speech is slurred. He exhibits right sided facial droop  weakness in the right upper and lower extremities  normal strength in the left upper and lower extremities  and has difficulty finding words. His cardiovascular  respiratory  and gastrointestinal examinations are unremarkable.  Impression: These clinical findings suggest a possible left hemispheric ischemic stroke  necessitating prompt neuroimaging and potential intervention.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department after experiencing sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech for two hours. He describes the symptoms as starting suddenly while he was reading a book at home. He denies experiencing any severe headache  seizures  loss of consciousness  or vision changes. However  he noticed difficulty with right hand coordination  slurred speech  and difficulty walking due to right leg weakness. There was no reported history of trauma.   Past Medical History (PMH): The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a former smoker with a 40-pack year history. He quit smoking 10 years ago. He has a known history of a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 5 years ago  but was non-compliant with his prescribed antiplatelet medication.   Family History (FH): His father had a stroke at age 75 and his sister has a history of heart disease.   Social History (SH): He is retired and lives with his wife. He reports a moderate daily consumption of alcohol. He denies the use of illicit drugs.  Medications: Hydrochlorothiazide  Metformin  Atorvastatin. He was previously prescribed aspirin post his TIA  which he admits to not taking regularly.   On arrival  patient’s vitals are: BP 160/90 mm Hg  Pulse 78 bpm  Temp 98.7°F  RR 16 and oxygen saturation 96% on room air.  Given the patient's sudden onset of symptoms  history  vitals  and physical examination findings  an urgent stroke protocol was initiated. A non-contrast CT of the head was ordered immediately per protocol to rule out intracranial hemorrhage and to confirm a possible acute ischemic stroke.

Patient Information:   Mr. Bruce Williams  a 68-year-old African American male  retired auto mechanic.   Chief Complaint:  Patient presents to the ER with sudden onset weakness on the right side of his body and difficulty speaking which progressed to slurred speech over the past two hours.   History of Present Illness:  According to the patient's wife  Mr. Williams was watching television when he suddenly complained of not being able to move his right arm and leg with significant difficulty in articulating words. He had a sudden inability to express himself and could not understand when spoken to. Upon noticing these symptoms  his wife immediately called for an ambulance.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Williams has a history of hypertension  high cholesterol  coronary artery disease  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been a smoker for about 40 years  consuming a pack per day. He is on medication for his hypertension (amlodipine 5mg daily) and type 2 diabetes mellitus (metformin 2000mg daily)  and takes 81mg aspirin daily.  Family History:  His family history includes a father who passed away from a myocardial infarction  and a younger sister who survived a stroke at 55.  Social History:  Mr. Williams is a retired mechanic  used to drink alcohol moderately but has quit alcohol two years ago. He continues to be a heavy smoker. He lives with his wife and they have two grown-up children.   This such presentation is suggestive of an ischemic CVA (Cerebro-Vascular Accident) or Stroke  which would require immediate medical attention  a neurological examination  and neuroimaging to confirm the diagnosis and to plan subsequent management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 72-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department via ambulance with his wife. He was at home when he suddenly developed right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty finding words. His symptoms began two hours prior to presentation.   Mr. Doe has a significant past medical history for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He also has a 30-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. He reports adherence to his prescribed medications which include Metformin and Lisinopril. He denies any use of alcohol or illicit substances. There are previous clinic notes indicating that his blood pressure and diabetes have been well controlled on his current regimen.   His family history is significant for an elder brother who had a stroke at the age of 75. There is no known history of other thromboembolic events or bleeding disorders in the family.  On examination  Mr. Doe is awake and alert but appears somewhat anxious. His speech is slurred. His vitals show blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse 78 bpm  the temperature of 37°C  and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. Neurologic examination demonstrates a right-sided facial droop  right upper and lower limb weakness  and word-finding difficulties. The remaining examination  including cardiovascular and respiratory examinations  is normal.  An immediate CT scan of his head showed no bleeding  and a diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke was made based on his symptoms and radiological findings.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 72-year-old African-American male  presents to the emergency room alongside his wife  on the evening of October 20th. He has a chief complaint of sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech  which started about an hour ago while they were having dinner.   Past Medical History (PMH): Mr. Smith was diagnosed with hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He's been on antihypertensives  statins  and oral hypoglycemic agents respectively. He has a 45-pack-year history of smoking but quit smoking 10 years ago. His father died of stroke at age 80.  Social History (SH):  He is retired but works part-time as a consultant. His spouse is his primary caregiver.    Family History (FH):  His father died from a stroke at the age of 80. His mother died at the age of 85 from a pulmonary embolism. His brother  75  is alive and has coronary artery disease.  Review of Systems (ROS): Negative for chest pain  shortness of breath  and headache.  Physical Examination: On examination  John appears alert but is vocally dysarthric. His vital signs are stable with blood pressure of 180/95 mm Hg  pulse rate of 85 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and temperature of 37.2 degrees Celsius. The right side of his face is drooping. His speech is slurred  and he has difficulty in understanding simple commands. His right upper and lower extremities show a marked decrease in strength compared to his left side.  Initial Assessment/Diagnosis: Based on the patient's clinical presentation  initial assessment points towards an acute ischemic stroke  typical of middle cerebral artery occlusion. Immediate brain imaging and further neurologic assessment are necessary.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Wilson is a 72-year-old male who presents to the emergency department. His wife reports that approximately 1 hour ago  he suddenly started deteriorating. Mrs. Wilson noticed speech difficulties  right-sided facial drooping  and uncoordinated movements in his right arm and leg. The condition made him stumble while walking which prompted their immediate arrival to hospital.   Past Medical History:  He has a 10-year history of hypertension and type II diabetes which are managed with Metformin and Lisinopril. He's non-compliant with his medications at times. No history of strokes or transient ischemic attacks in the past. He quit smoking 5 years back but has a 30 pack-year smoking history. His father had a stroke at the age of 75. He is retired and lives with his wife in the city. His alcohol intake is described as minimal.   Review of Systems:  No recent history of fever  weight loss  headache or visual disturbances. Mrs. Wilson reported that her husband had been complaining of occasional dizziness for the past few weeks but they didn't think much about it. No recent travel history or unusual activities were reported.    Physical Assessment:  On exam  his vital signs are: BP 170/90 mmHg  HR 88/min  RR 18/min  O2 saturation 96% on room air  Temp 36.7°C. His Glasgow Coma Scale Score is 14 and NIH Stroke Scale Score is 10. He's awake  alert and oriented to person  place  and time but having difficulty in speech with negligible movement on his right side. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. J is a 67-year-old African-American woman who presents via ambulance to the emergency department. She was found by her daughter on the bathroom floor at home this morning  noted to have a droopy face on the right side  difficulty speaking  and unable to move her right arm and leg. The first signs began approximately two hours ago  with no witnessed seizure activity or loss of consciousness.   Relevant Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. She is a former smoker  having quit smoking 10 years ago  and enjoys consuming red wine. She lives alone. She takes medications including amlodipine  metformin  and simvastatin regularly. She is adherence to her medication regimen and follows her primary care appointments. She denies any illicit drug use. She has no known drug allergies. Her father had a stroke at the age of 60. Her last known well is approximately two hours before the onset of symptoms.   On presentation  her blood pressure was high at 190/100  heart rate regular at 85  the respirations of 20 and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. The patient was immediately sent for a non-contrast CT scan to rule out a hemorrhagic stroke. The NIH stroke scale was used to categorize the severity of the stroke which came out to 17 out of 42  indicative of a moderate to severe stroke.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Joseph Peterson  a 71-year-old Caucasian male  presents in the Emergency Department brought in by EMS with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and slurred speech. The symptoms were first noticed by his wife about two hours ago. She reports he was having difficulty with balance  and one side of his face appears drooping. No changes in level of consciousness or confusion is reported.  Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Peterson has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been managed with medication for the past ten years. However  his blood pressure and cholesterol levels are occasionally slightly above the desired range. He quit smoking 5 years ago but has a 30 pack-year history of cigarette smoking. There is no known history of diabetes or heart diseases. There is no prior history of stroke or TIA but there is a family history of stroke; his father suffered a stroke at the age of 75. Mr. Peterson does not take any anticoagulants or antiplatelets.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Juan Mendoza is a 68-year-old  right-handed Mexican-American male who has been brought to the emergency department by his wife around 11:30 AM. Patient's wife reported that he had an abrupt onset of difficulty speaking and right-sided weakness while they were having breakfast at around 10:00 AM. On examination  he presents with dysarthria  right facial droop  and an inability to move his right arm and right leg effectively. He also seems unaware of this condition  possibly suggestive of neglect. His comportment is cooperative  but his memory seems affected as he struggles to recall the current date and his age.   Past Medical History (PMH): He has a history of hypertension for which he takes Lisinopril 10 mg daily  and type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with Glipizide 5mg daily. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack year history  having quit 10 years ago  and occasionally drinks alcohol. He does not have any known drug allergies.  Family History (FH): Both of Mr. Mendoza's parents suffered from hypertension and his father had a history of myocardial infarction at the age of 72.  Social History (SH): He lives at home with his wife and is retired. His son lives nearby and visits regularly. Prior to retirement  he worked as a school janitor.  Review of Systems (ROS): Patient's wife denies any recent headaches  visual disturbances  chest pain  dizziness  or light-headedness prior to this episode. She also reports no history of seizures or convulsions  no history of trauma or fall  and no loss of consciousness. She mentions that he has been more forgetful recently  but she assumed it was just normal aging.   This case highlights the cardinal signs of stroke  noted to be sudden in onset: severe headache  visual disturbances  unilateral weakness/numbness  difficulty with speech  or sudden confusion. Because these symptoms are severe and are affecting a patient with known risk factors (hypertension  diabetes  old age  prior smoking history)  it is prudent to conduct further confirmatory tests (CT  MRI) and begin management for acute ischemic stroke while considering differential diagnoses.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. D. is a 75-year-old African-American man who presented to the emergency room with complaints of sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech that started approximately one hour ago while he was having breakfast. He was aware of these symptoms and was immediately brought to the hospital by his wife.  Demographics: Sex: Male  Age: 75 years Race: African-American Occupation: Retired stone mason Residence: Lives with his wife in a single-storey house.  Relevant Past Medical History: Mr. D. has a known history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and hyperlipidemia. He is on medication (metformin  lisinopril  atorvastatin) for his conditions. He is also a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago after a 30-year pack history. Mr. D. had a myocardial infarction approximately 5 years ago for which he underwent angioplasty. His family history reveals that his father had a stroke at the age of 71. His compliance with medication and regular follow-ups had been good. There is no history of any previous stroke  transient ischemic attack  or any neurological deficit. He does not consume alcohol and does not have any known drug allergies.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Briggs is a 68-year-old African American male who presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in speaking. On examination  Mr. Briggs has facial drooping on the right side and slurred speech. His wife states that he was perfectly alright approximately 4 hours ago until the aforementioned symptoms appeared all of sudden while they were having dinner.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Briggs has a known history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medications include Metformin 500mg twice a day and Lisinopril 10mg once daily. He also has hyperlipidemia for which he has been advised dietary modifications. He is a smoker with a 30-pack year history. There is no known family history of stroke. He has a history of poor medication compliance as per his wife.  Social History:  The patient is a retired bank manager and lives with his wife. He has been a smoker for the last 30 years. He is not known to consume alcohol or illegal substances. He has been non-ambulatory primarily due to joint pain.  This presentation of sudden hemiparesis and speech difficulty is highly suggestive of a stroke  and immediate neurological evaluation is indicated. Given his history of hypertension  diabetes  and smoking  his risk of a cerebrovascular event is substantial.

Patient Presentation:   A 70-year-old right-handed Caucasian male presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with his wife. He is experiencing sudden-onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech and difficulty swallowing since about three hours ago.   He reports no headache  vision changes  loss of consciousness  chest pain or shortness of breath. No history of head injury or recent surgeries is reported. He hasn't taken any medication today except for his routine hypertension pills.   The patient has past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes  managed with Lisinopril and Metformin respectively. He is a 30-pack-year former smoker  having quit 5 years ago. He continues to consume alcohol occasionally. There is history of stroke in the family (his mother at age of 67).   Upon physical examination  the patient is found to have a BP of 177/94 mm Hg  heart rate 88 bpm  respiratory rate 16 breaths/min  oxygen saturation 99% in room air and temperature 37.1 C. Neurological examination reveals expressive aphasia  facial droop on the right side and significant motor weakness in right upper and lower extremities consistent with a left hemiparesis. NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) on admission was 12.   A secondary search reveals no signs of trauma  skin changes  infections  or other acute issues.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Margaret Williams is a 67-year-old African-American female presenting in the Emergency Department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech since 7:30 this morning. The symptoms had been ongoing for approximately 2 hours. She has associated symptoms of headache and difficulty swallowing. She denies any chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  loss of vision  or seizure activity. She has no history of trauma or fall. Ms. Williams reports she has never experienced such symptoms before.   Relevant Past Medical History:  Ms. Williams has a history of hypertension for the past 20 years  Type II Diabetes Mellitus for 10 years  and Hyperlipidemia for 7 years. She has been previously non-compliant with her medication  frequently missing doses of her prescribed lisinopril  metformin  and atorvastatin. There is no past history of cardiac disease  thromboembolic events  or strokes. There is no known family history of strokes  although her mother had a myocardial infarction at the age of 72.   Social/Behavioral History:  Ms. Williams is a retired schoolteacher who lives with her husband. She is a non-smoker and reports that she drinks alcohol occasionally  one glass of red wine twice a week. She has not been active lately due to COVID-19 related restrictions. She admits that she does not follow a specific diet and tends to make unhealthy food choices.  This patient's age  past medical history including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and non-compliance with medication  her sedentary lifestyle and poor diet make her a high-risk candidate for ischemic stroke. Prompt assessment and intervention are needed.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. X is a 68-year-old African American male presenting to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty swallowing since the last 2 hours. He has been known to be a nonsmoker and consumes alcohol occasionally.   Past Medical History:   Reveals that he is a known case of hypertension for the last ten years and type II diabetes mellitus for the past six years. Both conditions are fairly well controlled - with his most recent readings showing blood pressure of 140/90mmHg under antihypertensive medications and HbA1c of 8.0 despite oral hypoglycemic agents. Also  he underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery five years ago and has been on aspirin since then. He had a right hip replacement two years ago due to osteoarthritis. There is also a family history of ischemic stroke in his late father and grandmother.  On examination  his blood pressure was 159/95mmHg  heart rate was 92 beats per minute (regular)  his O2 sat was 99% at room air  and his random blood sugar was 195mg/dl.   Neurological examination revealed a right-sided facial droop  decreased power (3/5 MRC Scale) in the right upper and lower limbs  and speech was dysarthric. His Glasgow Coma Scale was E4V4M6.   Summary: Mr. X is a 68-year-old male  with a background of hypertension  diabetes  and ischemic heart disease  presenting with a likely acute left-sided ischemic stroke.

Patient Profile:  - Name: Mrs. Barbara Johnson - Age: 72 years - Gender: Female - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired school teacher  Chief Complaint:  Sudden onset of weakness on right side of body  difficulty speaking  History of Present Illness:  Mrs. Johnson was found by her daughter in the morning when she came by for a visit  not being able to get up from her chair. She states that she felt completely fine when she woke up  but then noticed that she was having trouble moving her right arm and leg when getting up from the breakfast table. She also noticed that she was having trouble forming words and called her daughter for help  which alarmed her. The symptoms started abruptly and have not improved or worsened since the onset.  Past Medical History: - High blood pressure for 10 years  on medication (Lisinopril 20 mg daily) - Type 2 diabetes for 20 years  moderately controlled (Metformin 1000mg twice daily  A1C 8%) - Prior transient ischemic attack (TIA  mini-stroke) 3 years ago - Hyperlipidemia (statin therapy - Atorvastatin 40mg daily) - No history of heart disease or kidney disease  Family History:  - Father died of stroke at 65 - Mother had diabetes and died of complications related to diabetes  Social History:  - Smoked half a pack a day for 30 years  quit 15 years ago - Drinks alcohol socially  about 2-3 times per month - Lives alone in a single story home  no disability  Review of systems:  - Reports a morning headache  denies chest pain  shortness of breath  changes in vision  difficulty swallowing or change in bowel and bladder habits.  - She states she has not had any falls or loss of consciousness - Otherwise her systems review is unremarkable  Current Medications:  - Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension - Metformin 1000 mg twice daily for type 2 diabetes - Atorvastatin 40 mg daily for hyperlipidemia  Allergies: None reported

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old right-handed African-American male  presents to the Emergency Department via EMS. He was found by his wife this morning with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in speech. This episode occurred approximately 2 hours ago  with no history of preceding trauma.   He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and a 40 pack-year smoking history. He takes medication for his hypertension and diabetes but admits to occasional non-compliance.  On examination  he is alert and oriented to person  place  and time but has noticeable facial droop on the right side. He reports difficulty in speaking and is observed to have slurred speech. He has right-sided hemiparesis with a power of 3/5 in both upper and lower limbs. His vitals are stable except for a high blood pressure reading at 160/90mmHg.  Family history reveals that his mother had a stroke at the age of 72. There is no history of alcohol or illicit drug use.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Ahmed  a 65-year-old Arab male  presented to the emergency department with acute onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking which started around one hour back. The weakness was suddenly noticed when he was trying to stand up from a chair and felt his right arm and leg were quite weak. He also reported that he was having trouble formulating his words  which was noticed by his wife. He denies any pain  headache  or loss of consciousness.   He has a significant past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and non-insulin dependent diabetes. He is a former smoker with a history of about 30 pack years  quit 10 years ago. He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease with his father passing from a myocardial infarction at 70 years old and a brother with a history of stroke at 72 years old.  On physical examination  he had facial droop on right side  expressive aphasia  right-sided hemiparesis  with strength of 2 out of 5 in right upper and lower extremities. He displayed no sensory losses  and reflexes were normal bilaterally. His vitals: Pulse- 88 beats per minute  Blood pressure- 170/96 mmHg  Respiratory rate- 18 breaths per minute  Oxygen saturation- 97% on room air  and Temperature- 98.6 F.   The remaining general physical examination and systemic examination were unremarkable. Cardiovascular and respiratory examination revealed normal heart sounds and clear lung fields. There is no carotid bruit noted on examination.

Patient Presentation:   Ms. Johnson is a 67-year-old African American female who presents with sudden-onset right-side weakness and facial drooping which she noticed upon waking up around two hours ago. She reports associated nausea  dizziness  and a mild headache. She denies any chest pain  dyspnea  loss of consciousness  or any other neurological symptoms.  Complete Demographic Details:  Ms. Johnson lives alone and reported the symptoms over a phone call to her daughter  who immediately drove her to the emergency department. She is a retired school teacher with a Bachelor's degree education  is economically stable  and is a non-smoker.  Relevant Past Medical History:  Ms. Johnson is known to have hypertension and type II diabetes  both of which have been well-controlled with medications for the last 10 years. She does not have a history of dyslipidemia or any cardiac disorders. She reported having a mini-stroke or Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) five years ago with similar symptoms  which resolved within a few hours. There is no reported history of surgeries or allergies. Her medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Aspirin (81 mg/day).  Summary:  Ms. Johnson is a 67-year-old hypertensive and diabetic female who recently developed acute right-sided weakness and facial drooping  likely suggestive of a stroke. She requires immediate evaluation using a CT scan and potential treatment with thrombolytic therapy depending on the findings. Given her past history of a mini-stroke or TIA  she is at much risk and needs aggressive management of her risk factors and possibly secondary stroke prevention strategies.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Sarah Johnson  a 67-year-old African American female  presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. The symptoms started approximately two hours ago when she was gardening. She has also noticed a droop on the right side of her face.  Mrs. Johnson is accompanied by her daughter  who mentions that her mother has seemed more confused than normal for the past couple of hours. The patient's medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which have been managed with medication for the past ten years. She also has a history of hypercholesterolemia and is a former smoker who quit 15 years ago. Her medication regime includes Metformin  Lisinopril  and Lipitor. There is a family history of strokes on her father's side.  On examination  Mrs. Johnson has difficulty articulating words and shows signs of confusion. She is unable to lift her right arm  and her right facial droop is consistent with a stroke. Her blood pressure is currently 185/95 mm Hg  which is significantly higher than her usual readings.  Mrs. Johnson is quickly ushered for urgent imaging to confirm a suspected stroke and initiate appropriate treatment with consideration for her medical history.

Patient Information: Mr. Jones  a 65-year-old African-American male  retired engineer  comes with his wife from their suburban home.  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking that started 1 hour ago.  History of Present Illness: The patient was in his usual state of health until this morning when upon waking  he experienced sudden onset of weakness in his right arm and leg. He stumbled while trying to get up from his bed. His wife also noticed he was slurring his words and his mouth was drooping on the right side. The symptoms have persisted and motivated the ER visit. He denies experiencing any headache  vertigo  seizure  unconsciousness  chest pain  or shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: Hypertension for the last 20 years  controlled with lisinopril. Diabetes Mellitus type 2 diagnosed 5 years ago  maintained with metformin. History of smoking 1 pack/day for 40 years but quit 10 years ago. No known allergy.  Family History: Father had a fatal heart attack at 68. Mother had a stroke at 73. A brother with hypertension and diabetes.  Social History: Retired engineer  married with three adult children. Denies alcohol usage. Has a history of smoking  1 pack/day for 40 years quit 10 years ago. No illicit drug use.  Review of Systems: Negative for fever  weight change  GI symptoms  urinary symptoms  and recent trauma. Positive for difficulty in articulation and right-sided weakness.  Physical Exam: Vital signs within normal limits. Cranial nerve examination reveals facial droop on the right side with an intact sensation. Motor exam shows right-sided hemiparesis. Reflexes are normal on the left side  reduced on the right side. Speech is slurred. The rest of the physical examination is normal.  This presentation alerts to the possibility of a left-hemispheric ischemic stroke  a neuroimaging study (like a CT or MRI) will be ordered to confirm diagnosis and appropriate management started promptly.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J. Anderson is a 65-year-old African-American male presenting to the Emergency Department with complaints of sudden onset of right-sided weakness  difficulty speaking  and difficulty maintaining balance that has been ongoing for the past two hours.   He denies any associated symptoms such as headache  trauma  or loss of consciousness. He also reports no previous similar episodes. His wife  who has accompanied him  reports that she noticed him 'slurring his words' and 'dragging his foot' while they were having breakfast.  Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes. He has been taking Lisinopril and Metformin for the last ten years. He also has a 20-year history of smoking  although he quit 5 years ago. There is no family history of stroke or other neurological disorders.   Mr. Anderson currently lives with his wife. He is retired and denies any alcohol or illegal substance use. His last routine check-up was six months ago  and according to his available records  his blood pressure and diabetes were under control.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with acute symptoms of left-sided weakness and slurred speech onset approximately 1 hour prior to presentation. The patient's wife confirms that he was fine when they woke up in the morning  but during breakfast  he suddenly dropped his cup and he couldn't speak clearly. He also took some time to comprehend her questions.  Demographic Details:  Name : Mr. John Doe Age : 67 Years  Sex : Male Race: Caucasian Occupation : Retired School Teacher Marital Status: Married Insurance: Medicare   Relevant Past Medical History:  The patient's medical history is significant for uncontrolled hypertension and he was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus 5 years prior. He has also suffered from hyperlipidemia for the past 10 years and has been on statin therapy. He is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history and stopped smoking 7 years ago. There is no known history of previous stroke  transient ischemic attack  or any other neurologic disorder. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 72. He occasionally drinks alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Johnson is a 68-year-old African-American woman presenting to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of weakness in the right upper and lower extremities  difficulty with speech  and facial droop which began approximately 2 hours ago while she was gardening at home. She has a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. She is a non-smoker with occasional alcohol use. She lives with her husband  who was the one to notice the changes and bring her to the hospital.   In terms of medications  she is currently on Lisinopril  Metformin and Simvastatin. She has no known allergies. Her family history is significant for stroke in her father. She is an active woman with good adherence to her medications and regularly follows up with her primary care provider. Her last set of labs from approximately 6 months ago showed fair control of her blood glucose and lipid profile.   On physical examination  she is alert but is having some difficulties with her speech. She has a right facial droop  her right upper and lower extremity strength is 2/5 with an absence of sensation on the right side of her body. The rest of her cranial nerves are intact  and she is moving all other extremities with normal and symmetrical reflexes. Her blood pressure is 165/90 mmHg. Her heart rate is regular  without any murmurs. She is afebrile and her other vital signs are stable.   This patient’s presentation is concerning for an acute left-hemispheric ischemic stroke.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Brown is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with sudden onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech that commenced approximately 2 hours ago. Mr. Brown's wife  who brought him into the hospital  noticed his face seemed droopy on the right side.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus  all of which are fairly well managed with medications (Lisinopril  Simvastatin  and Metformin respectively). He denies any history of heart disease or migraines. His family history is significant for stroke  with his father having suffered a stroke at 72. The patient is a former smoker who quit 10 years ago after a 30-year history of smoking one pack a day. He admits to mild alcohol use and denies the use of illicit drugs.   Current Medications:  1. Lisinopril 20 mg daily  2. Simvastatin 40 mg once daily 3. Metformin 500 mg twice daily   Allergies:  He is allergic to penicillin  that causes a rash.   Social and Lifestyle History:  He is a retired civil engineer. He lives with his wife in a suburban community and they have two adult children. He is mostly sedentary and his diet is high in saturated fats and salts. He denies any recent travel.   The significant findings  along with the patient's other risk factors for cerebrovascular disease  make the diagnosis of stroke highly likely.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Lucy  a 72-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency room with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech. She woke up from her sleep with these symptoms and had trouble walking to the bathroom. Her daughter  who lives with her  found her confused and immediately brought her to the hospital. The patient also complained of mild headache  but denied any trauma  recent illness  chest pain  palpitation or shortness of breath.   Past medical history is notable for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia for which she has been prescribed lisinopril  metformin  and atorvastatin respectively. No known history of stroke  transient ischemic attacks  atrial fibrillation  cardiac diseases or bleeding disorders. She is a non-smoker and has a history of moderate alcohol use in her younger years. She lives with her daughter and maintains a reasonably active lifestyle.   Family history reveals her father suffered a stroke at the age of 75. Further  her mother  who passed away at 80  had hypertension and diabetes.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency room with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech starting about 2 hours ago. He also reports a severe headache and one episode of vomiting. He denies any recent trauma  chest pain  or shortness of breath. His wife reports noticing some facial droop on the right side.   Past Medical History:  Hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypercholesterolemia. He also had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 2 years ago. Currently on Metformin  Lisinopril  and atorvastatin. He is a former smoker with a 30-year pack history but quit approximately 5 years ago  and admits to occasional alcohol use. He is not physically active and admits to a generally poor diet.   Family History:   Father had a history of stroke at age 70  mother has hypertension and diabetes. His younger brother has hypercholesterolemia.   Social History:   Worked as a truck driver and is married with two children.   Physical Examination:   On exam  his vitals are BP 185/95 mmHg  HR 85 beats per minute  RR 16 breaths per minute  Temp 98.7 F  and SpO2 97% on room air. Neurological examination reveals a power of 2/5 in the right upper and lower limbs  expressive aphasia  and facial drooping on the right side. No meningeal signs or cranial nerve abnormalities are observed. Rest of the examination is unremarkable.   Given the history and clinical presentation  an acute ischemic stroke is suspected. Immediate management is initiated and neurology team is consulted for further management.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the Emergency Department with complaints of sudden onset of left-sided weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty maintaining balance which began approximately two hours ago. The patient's wife  who is his primary caretaker  noticed these changes and brought him promptly to the hospital. Mr. Doe has a known 10-year history of poorly controlled hypertension (last recorded BP 160/95 mmHg two months ago) and obesity (BMI 32)  but is non-compliant with his anti-hypertensive medications. He is an ex-smoker and quit smoking 5 years ago  after 40 years of a pack/day history. He denies alcohol or illicit drug use. No known drug allergies. He lives with his wife and is retired  previously he was a truck driver. Family history is significant for a father who died of a stroke at the age of 70.   On physical examination  he appears anxious  there's mild difficulty in communicating  but he's oriented to time  place and person. Vitals are stable. Neurological examination reveals weakness in left upper and lower extremities (power 2/5)  slurred speech  and left-sided facial droop. There is no noted vision changes.   This clinical picture suggests the possibility of an Acute Ischemic Stroke  probably on the right side of the brain  potentially secondary to his uncontrolled hypertension. In terms of management  the primary focus is to confirm the diagnosis with a non-contrast CT scan  ruling out hemorrhage  initiate thrombolytic therapy if the patient is within the therapeutic window and no contraindications  and control his blood pressure. The patient should be admitted to a stroke unit for further monitoring and care.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Joseph Miller is a 67-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech which began about two hours ago while watching TV at home. He states he tried to get up from his chair but noticed he couldn't use his right arm and leg properly. Also  his wife noticed that his speech sounded strange.  His PMH is significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and coronary artery disease with a past MI about three years ago. He had a PTCA and a stent placement done at that time. He is a former smoker  quit about 10 years back but he has history of moderate alcohol intake. He lives with his wife  who is his primary caregiver.  Medications: Amlodipine 5 mg QD  Metformin 500mg BID  Simvastatin 20 mg QHS  and Aspirin 81 mg QD. He denies any recent changes in his medication regimen and is fairly compliant taking his medications.  Family history is significant with his father had a stroke at age 75 and his mother had diabetes and HTN.  He denies any drug allergies. He denies any recent illnesses  fever  neck pain  weight loss or gain  headaches  or any subsequent or pre-occurring traumas. He also denies any recent travel or surgery.  On examination  his BP is 175/95 mmHg  pulse 82 beats/min  resp rate 18/min  and temp 98.6 F. Physical exam reveals a well-nourished male in moderate distress. Neurologic exam reveals right-sided face  arm and leg weakness  and slurred speech. His MMSE score was 22/30.  All of these clinical findings hint towards a possible ischemic stroke  so urgent neuroimaging is arranged to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate management.

Patient Presentation:   A 67-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency department with his wife  who reports that  beginning about an hour ago  her husband started to show signs of confusion  could not move his right arm  and was having difficulty speaking. The patient's wife also mentions that the left side of his face seemingly ""dropped"" out of nowhere. The patient is visibly frustrated and anxious  making attempts to speak but producing only mumbled  unintelligible speech. The wife reports no complained or observed headache  visual changes  or seizures.  Past medical history is significant for hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2 and hyperlipidemia  all of which are managed with medications including Lisinopril  Metformin  and Atorvastatin. The patient's father died of a stroke at age 70. The patient has a 40-pack year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He admits to consuming alcohol socially but denies any use of illicit drugs.  Upon physical examination  the patient’s blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  pulse is 78 beats/min and regular  and respiratory rate is 16 breaths/min. Neurological examination reveals right-sided hemiparesis  expressive aphasia  and facial droop.  The patient's clinical picture and risk factors point towards a potential ischemic stroke  with further diagnostic evaluation needed. Prompt action is needed to define the subtype of stroke and apply the corresponding therapeutic measures.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old female patient was brought into the emergency department by her son  who reported that he found her in the kitchen this morning with slurred speech and an inability to hold a cup of coffee in her right hand. The patient is a retired school teacher  living alone with a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and a 45 pack-year smoking history. She is on medication  including an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor  metformin  and a statin. She reports adhering to her medication regimens but admits difficulty with diet control and smoking cessation. She has no known allergies. There is a family history of stroke in her father who passed away in his early 70s.  Over the last 3 hours  her symptoms have worsened with the patient experiencing right-sided weakness  numbness  and difficulty speaking. She denies any headache  dizziness  nausea  or visual changes. No history of previous transient ischemic attacks  strokes  or known heart disease.  On vital signs  her BP was 160/95 mmHg  heart rate was 88 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute  temperature was 36.7-degree celsius  and her oxygen saturation was 96% on room air. Her fasted blood glucose was reported as high as 200 mg/dl.   This presentation is consistent with an acute ischemic stroke and requires immediate medical intervention.

Patient Presentation:   A 67-year-old  left-handed Caucasian male  Mr. Martin Wells  presents to the Emergency Department brought in by his wife who noticed that he suddenly started experiencing severe headache and weakness on the right side of his body while they were having breakfast together. She also noticed that her husband was having speech difficulties. These symptoms occurred approximately 2 hours before their arrival.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Wells has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are managed with medications  Lisinopril and Simvastatin respectively. However  he often forgets to take his medications regularly. He has a 35-pack year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He drinks socially on occasions and denies using any recreational or illicit drugs. His father suffered a stroke at the age of 72.   He has no known allergies. He is retired and lives with his wife in a two-story suburban house.

Patient Information: Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old  African-American male.  Chief Complaint: Sudden weakness on right side of the body and difficulty with speech.  History of Present Illness: Mr. Johnson noticed sudden onset of right-sided weakness of his face  arm  and leg and slurred speech while having breakfast this morning. The symptoms lasted for about an hour and then he gradually regained strength. He has no associated symptoms like headache  seizure  loss of consciousness  fever or confusion.  Past Medical History: Hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years. He also has a 40-pack-year history of smoking and moderate drinking.  Current Medications: Metformin 850mg BID  Lisinopril 10mg OD and aspirin 81mg OD.  Physical Examination: On examination  his blood pressure is 170/90mmHg  pulse rate-75/min  temperature-98.6°F  respiratory rate-16/min. Neurological examination reveals mild facial droop and weakness in right upper and lower limbs with power 4/5. He is alert and oriented but shows dysarthria.  Investigations Recommended: Complete Blood Count  blood sugar  lipid profile  ECG  CT or MRI scan of the brain  carotid ultrasound.  Impression: TIA (Transient Ischemic Attack) or Stroke. Referral to a neurologist for further management is recommended.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset weakness on the right side of his body  difficulty speaking  and facial droop for an estimated 2 hours duration. He denies any form of trauma.  Past Medical History:  John has a medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which have been poorly controlled due to inconsistent medication use. He has a 45 pack-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. His mother had a stroke at the age of 75  and his father died from a heart attack at 70. He was hospitalized three years ago due to a transient ischemic attack (TIA) and discharged with aspirin  lisinopril  and metformin  but has not been compliant with the regimen. He denies any history of heart disease and is not known to have atrial fibrillation. His routine medications include metformin for diabetes and lisinopril for hypertension.  Social History:  John is a retired school teacher and lives alone  though his daughter checks on him regularly. He is a widower and admits to consuming alcohol but denies any illicit drug use. He has a poor diet and leads a sedentary lifestyle.  Physical Exam:  On examination  BP is 160/95 mmHg  heart rate is 88 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 18 breaths/minute  and temperature is 98.6°F. Neurological examination reveals right-sided weakness (motor strength 3/5 on the right side)  facial droop on the right side  and slurring of speech. Rest of his examination including cardiovascular and respiratory system is unremarkable. There are no signs of trauma or injury.  Summary:  In summary  this is a 68-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  previous TIA  and smoking  presenting with classic symptoms of a stroke. The patient's demographic details  past medical history  lifestyle habits  and family history significantly increase his risk for cerebrovascular accidents. Immediate intervention is necessary to limit the degree of neurological damage.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 68-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of slurred speech  right-sided weakness  and drooping on the right side of his face which started around 3 hours prior to hospital arrival. The patient also reports issues with vision and a sudden severe headache. Mr. Smith's wife states that he has had some memory issues over the past year but no formal diagnosis of dementia has been made. Mr. Smith is a former smoker and drinks alcohol on social occasions. He is currently on a medication regime of Metformin and Lisinopril. Family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Hispanic female presents to the emergency room with sudden onset of left sided weakness and slurred speech that began approximately 2 hours prior to arrival. Stating that she was in her usual state of health engaged in household chores when she suddenly felt weakness in her left arm and then noticed she was having difficulty speaking. There was no associated headache  confusion  or loss of consciousness.  Family members verified these complaints and noted a slight facial droop. Family history is significant for hypertension and stroke. She is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic.   Past Medical History:  Patient has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years. She is compliant with her prescribed antihypertensive and diabetic medications. Her most recent HbA1c was 7.2%. There was no previously documented cerebrovascular accident. She has no known allergies to medications.

Patient Information: Mr. Albert Kirkland  a 65-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department at around 09:30 AM.   Chief Complaint: Woke up with a severe headache and sudden weakness in his right arm and leg. His speech was slightly slurred. His wife  who brought him to the ED  reported that these symptoms started suddenly when he woke up in the morning.  Past Medical History: Known case of Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  both being managed through combination therapy of ACE inhibitors and Metformin  respectively  for the past ten years. He also has Hyperlipidemia and a smoking history of 20 pack years. He does not consume alcohol and has no known drug allergies.  Family History: His father passed away due to stroke at the age of 72 and mother due to heart disease at the age of 70. His older brother was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus in his 60s.  Review of Systems: The patient denied any nausea  vomiting  vision changes or loss of consciousness. His wife mentioned that Mr. Kirkland has been feeling more fatigue than usual for the past few weeks but they assumed it was related to his diabetes.  Social History: Lives with his wife in their own home. He's a retired teacher who has picked up gardening as a hobby.  Physical Exam: BP 160/90 mm Hg  HR 110 bpm  RR 14 breaths per minute  O2 saturation 98% on room air  temperature 98.7°F. Patient had partial facial droop on his right side  speech articulation was difficult  right upper and lower extremity showed significant weakness and the patient was unable to lift arm against gravity. Left side showed normal motor and sensory responses.   Based on initial clinical presentation and NIH stroke scale assessment  a working diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke is made. CT head scan ordered to confirm.   Pending the scans  IV-thrombolysis might be considered based on time window of symptom onset  stroke severity  contraindications and risk vs benefit discussion with the patient and family.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old African American male presenting with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in speaking for the last 6 hours. He was found on the floor by his wife this morning  unable to get up.   He is a known patient of hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus  for which he is taking medication. He has a 30-year history of smoking two packs/day. He has no known allergies.  Vital signs include a blood pressure of 168/94 mmHg and a pulse of 80 beats per minutes. His family history includes a father who died of coronary artery disease and a mother who suffered from stroke  both in their late eighties.  On physical examination  the patient showed right-sided facial droop  dysphasia  and right-sided hemiparesis  all consistent with an acute ischemic stroke. His GCS score is 12/15. ECG shows a Sinus rhythm with no acute ST changes. His lab results show hyperglycemia and elevated cholesterol levels.  The patient's wife stated that Mr. Johnson was functioning well until today  living independently without any cognitive impairment. Now he is unable to lift his right arm or leg and is having trouble speaking and swallowing. He is right-handed and is concerned about his ability to care for himself. He is taken to the emergency department for neuroimaging to confirm the type and location of the stroke  and decisions regarding acute treatment options are under consideration.

Patient Presentation: A 65-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking  which started an hour ago. The patient's symptoms include difficulty in understanding language  vision problem in one eye  and inability to walk. He lives alone and was found by his neighbor in the early morning in a confused state.  Past Medical History: Patient's relevant medical history includes hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  which are well managed with medication for the past 10 years. He has a history of smoking and alcohol consumption but quit drinking and smoking 5 years back. He was on aspirin for a suspected transient ischemic attack 2 years ago. His father and grandfather had also suffered from stroke in their late sixties. No known drug allergies are reported. No prior surgical history is recorded.    Medication History: The medications the patient is currently taking include Metformin 850mg twice daily for diabetes  Losartan 50mg daily for hypertension  and Aspirin 75mg daily as secondary prevention post TIA.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 68 year-old African-American male who presents to the emergency room with right-sided weakness  difficulty speaking and sudden confusion that started about 3 hours ago. He expresses that his symptoms started while he was having breakfast with his wife who immediately noticed his difficulty in holding his mug and his slurred speech.   Patient Demographic Details: Mr. Johnson is a retired truck driver who lives with his wife. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking  however he quit 5 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. He is originally from Texas but has been living in Colorado for the past 30 years.  Patient's Relevant Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a past medical history significant for hypertension  type-2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia for the past 20 years. Medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. However  he is non-compliant with his medications due to financial constraints. He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease with his father having had a myocardial infarction at age 60 and his mother suffering a stroke at age 70.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Johnson  presents to the ER via ambulance with sudden onset of left-sided weakness  difficulty speaking  and right-sided facial droop that started approximately an hour ago. He was watching television when these symptoms started suddenly. He denies headache  vision changes  confusion  or loss of consciousness.   Past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes  all of which have been managed with medication over the past 10 years. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history but has quit five years back. He admits to a poor diet and sedentary lifestyle. Family history reveals that his father had a stroke at the age of 70.   Upon initial examination  his blood pressure is 180/95 mm Hg  heart rate is 92 beats per minute  and respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute. His Glasgow Coma Scale score is 13. Neurological examination shows left upper and lower limb power of 2/5 and expressive aphasia. Other systems examination is unremarkable. His blood glucose level is high  at 200 mg/dl. He appears overweight with a BMI of 28.   His regular medications include Lisinopril  Metformin  and Atorvastatin. He reports no known drug allergies.

Patient Presentation:   Patient is an 65-year-old right-handed Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulties in speaking which were noticed by his wife at home. The onset began approximately two hours prior to presentation according to the wife  with no previous similar episodes. The symptoms have remained persistent with no episode of unconsciousness reported.   Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension as well as hyperlipidemia but has been noncompliant with medications due to their side effects. He smokes a pack of cigarettes every day and has been doing so for the past 40 years. His father had a stroke at age 70. The patient denies any chronic alcohol consumption. He has never had any surgical interventions.  Medication History:   The patient was previously prescribed Ramipril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  however  he's been noncompliant lately.  Social History:   Retired civil engineer  40 pack-year smoking history  no known drug abuse  Consumes alcohol socially  Married with two adult children.  Family History:   Father suffered a stroke at the age of 70 and died due to complications. His mother is alive and has type 2 diabetes. Sibling details unknown.  Review of Systems:  General: Alert and oriented  denies fever or chills Neurological: Reports left sided weakness and speech difficulties.  Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain  palpitations. Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath or cough Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain  vomiting  diarrhea or constipation Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain  muscle pain.  Skin: Denies rash  itching or bruises. Psychiatric: Denies depression  anxiety or sleep disturbances.   Physical Exam:   General Appearance: Awake  alert  in no acute distress HEENT: Pupils equal  round  reactive to light. Mucus membranes moist. CNS: Speech slur  left-sided facial droop  left-sided hemiparesis  heightened DTR on the left side. Heart: Rhythm regular  no murmurs Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.  Skin: Warm  dry  no rashes.   Workup: Would suggest immediate head CT  ECG and neurological evaluation for possible thrombolytic therapy given the onset of symptoms and history of significant vascular risk factors.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Paul Stevens is a 67-year-old African-American male presenting with sudden onset left-sided weakness and slurred speech that began approximately 2 hours ago while he was having breakfast with his wife. He denies any recent trauma or injury. There is no history of headache  blurred vision  facial droop  or loss of consciousness. The patient exhibits a severely uncoordinated gait and he is unable to lift his left arm.  Demographic and Social History:   Mr. Stevens is a retired school teacher who lives with his wife in the suburbs. He is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally  and denies illicit drug use. He is allergic to penicillin which causes him to develop a skin rash.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Stevens has been diagnosed with hypertension which is poorly controlled. He is also a known diabetic patient and has been on oral hypoglycemics for the last 10 years. He had a myocardial infarction (heart attack) 3 years ago and received angioplasty treatment. His father died from a stroke in his 70s and his sister is a diabetic.  Medication History:  He is currently on Metformin 500 mg twice daily  Lisinopril 10 mg daily  and Aspirin 75 mg daily.  Initial Assessment:  The physical examination reveals blood pressure of 175/95 mmHg  heart rate of 78 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Neurological examination revealed left-sided hemiparesis  dysarthria  and positive Babinski's sign on the left.
