An emergent head CT scan is ordered to evaluate for possible ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke. His symptoms fulfill the FAST (face  arm  speech  and time) criteria for stroke.

Patient Information: Mr. Ahmed Khan  a 65-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and a 20-pack year smoking history presents to the emergency department (ED).  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset difficulty in speaking  right-sided weakness  and decreased sensation of right arm and leg.  History of Present Illness: The patient's symptoms began approximately 4 hours ago when he woke up from sleep. His wife noted that his speech was slurred and he was not able to move his right arm and right leg. Also  he had difficulty swallowing his breakfast and almost choked. No complaints of headache  dizziness  or loss of consciousness. No history of a similar event in the past.  Medication and Allergies: The patient is currently on Metformin and Lisinopril. No history of medication allergies.  Family History: There is a family history of heart disease (Father died of a heart attack at age 60).  Social History: The patient is a retired engineer  married with 3 children. He is a current smoker with a 20-pack year history and drinks alcohol socially. He denies any history of recreational drug use.   Physical Examination: Vital signs: Temperature 98.5 F  Pulse-90 beats per minute  Respiratory rate-16 breaths per minute  Blood Pressure- 165/95 mm Hg. On neurological examination  he has expressive aphasia  right hemiparesis and right side hemisensory loss. His pupils are equal  round and reactive.  Summary: Mr. Khan is a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and smoking who has presented with symptoms that are suggestive of an acute left-sided hemispheric cerebrovascular accident  likely an ischemic stroke. Immediate neurologic evaluation and potentially thrombolytic therapy is indicated.

Patient Information: Mr. Davis  a 68-year-old African-American male  married with two grown children.  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty in speaking   History of Present Illness: Mr. Davis was in his usual state of health until about two hours ago when his wife noticed that he developed sudden difficulty in speech and weakness on the left side of his body. He did not complain of any headache  seizure  loss of consciousness or involuntary movements. There were no reports of any recent trauma  fever or infections.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension for 10 years  2. Type 2 Diabetes for 8 years  3. Hyperlipidemia for 7 years  4. Smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years  quit smoking 5 years ago   Family History: Father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 62  Mother is hypertensive and diabetic. Older brother has a history of stroke at the age of 64.  Social History: Lives with his wife in their own house. Retired as a school teacher. Non-alcoholic.  Review of Systems: Negative  except as stated in the HPI.  Physical Examination: Blood Pressure – 170/95 mmHg  Pulse Rate - 88 beats per minute  Respiratory Rate - 18 breaths per minute  Temperature - 98.6°F  O2 saturation - 98% on room air.  Neurologic exam showed dysarthria and left-sided hemiparesis with a power of 2/5 on the left upper and lower limbs. Sensory system was intact  reflexes were brisk on the left side. Rest of the physical examination including heart  lung and abdomen were within normal limits.  Summary: This is a case of a 68-year-old male patient who has presented with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and speaking difficulty. The patient has notable medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes. Given his symptoms and past medical history  he is suspected to have had a stroke.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old African American female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of numbness and weakness in her right arm  difficulty speaking  and confusion for the past two hours. She has a prior medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She is a non-smoker. Her only medications are lisinopril and metformin. She lives alone and is not currently under any home care. Her vital signs on admission: BP 170/100 mm Hg  temperature 36.7°C  HR 89 beats per minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute. Her NIH Stroke Scale score on arrival is 12  indicating moderate severity. Her initial glucose was 7.8 mmol/L  ECG showed normal sinus rhythm  and a non-contrast CT scan of her brain showed no intracranial hemorrhage.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Smith is a 65-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department via ambulance with sudden onset slurred speech  right facial droop  and right-sided weakness that occurred approximately 2 hours prior to arrival. He has a known medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and states that he smokes a half pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years. He reports adhering to his medication regimen of lisinopril and atorvastatin. His family history is significant for cerebrovascular disease  with his mother having suffered a stroke at the age of 68. John does not have any known allergies.  Upon examination  his blood pressure is found to be 180/95 mmHg  heart rate is 92 bpm  temperature is 97.9 F  respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. His neurologic examination reveals slurred speech  facial droop on the right side and weakness in the right upper and lower extremities (motor strength 3/5)  consistent with a left hemispheric stroke syndrome. NIH Stroke Scale score is calculated to be 12  indicating a moderate stroke.

Patient Information: Mr. Jackson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presented at the emergency department.  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of severe headache  right-sided weakness and impaired speech.  History of Present Illness: Symptoms started approximately 2 hours ago while watching television at home. He also noticed his right side of the face drooping. He does not report any preceding trauma or unusual activity.  Past Medical History: Mr. Jackson has a history of hypertension  dyslipidemia  and tobacco use. He admits to a 40 pack-year smoking history and currently smokes half a pack a day. He underwent angioplasty 5 years ago following a myocardial infarction. He is compliant with prescribed medication including aspirin  statins  and ACE inhibitors.  Review of Systems: Positive for headache  nausea  and dizziness. Negative for fever  chest pain  shortness of breath  lower extremity swelling  seizure  visual disturbances or history of similar episodes.  Physical examination: Mr. Jackson was found to have a blood pressure of 165/95 mmHg  pulse rate of 88 beats/min  and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min. Neurologically  he has right facial droop  dysarthria  and right-sided hemiparesis. Rest of the examination is unremarkable.  Impression: Given the acute onset of Mr. Jackson's symptoms and his risk factors  a stroke is suspected. Due to the symptoms onset time and his history  need to rule out hemorrhagic stroke. Emergency measures and investigations were initiated immediately.   Follow-up Plans: CT brain scan as soon as possible to rule out hemorrhage. Neurology is consulted  and the patient is moved to tracking for tPA administration considering the presentations and directives.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Smith is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presenting to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in speaking that started 3 hours ago. His wife  who accompanies him today  also noticed that his face seemed to droop on the right side when he tried to smile. He denies any headache  seizure  nausea  or vomiting. He has no history of trauma.   Demographic Details:   Mr. Smith is a retired engineer  lives with his wife in their own home  and has 3 grown-up children. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking  and quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. His diet is high in salt and fat  and he is not regularly physically active.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith was diagnosed with hypertension 20 years ago and type II diabetes mellitus 10 years ago. He has been taking Amlodipine 10mg daily for his hypertension and Metformin 1000mg twice a day for his diabetes. Despite these treatments  he often misses his medications and has a poor follow-up. He had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago and underwent angioplasty. He also has a 6-year history of high cholesterol  for which he is prescribed Atorvastatin 20mg daily. There is no known drug allergy. Family history is positive for stroke in his mother.   Therefore  the suspected diagnosis is acute ischemic stroke due to his glaring symptoms and significant cardiovascular risk factors. Expanded assessment and emergent intervention are necessary.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with symptoms of sudden-onset confusion  expressive aphasia  right-sided weakness  and acute visual loss in the right field of vision. He was having breakfast with his wife when the symptoms started  his wife noticed his slurred speech and immediately brought him to the ED.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a known history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and dyslipidemia. He takes medication for these conditions: Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension  Metformin 500mg twice daily for type II diabetes  and Atorvastatin 20mg nightly for dyslipidemia. He had undergone angioplasty 3 years ago following an ST-elevation myocardial infarction.   Social History:  He is a retired construction worker  has a 40-pack-year smoking history  but had quit smoking about a decade ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies any recreational drug use. He lives with his wife who is his primary caregiver.  Family History:   His father had a fatal stroke at the age of 75  and his mother died of breast cancer in her sixties. He has an older brother with coronary artery disease.  Review of Systems:   Prior to this event  patient had no recent sick contacts  weight changes  fevers  or other constitutional symptoms. No recent travel history. No history of falls  dizziness or seizures.   Despite his past medical history and family history  Mr. Smith had been relatively independent and had no issues with ADLs (activities of daily living) prior to this event. However  his sudden-onset neurological symptoms strongly suggest a stroke  most likely ischemic in nature given his vascular risk factors and family history. He will require immediate stroke protocol including brain imaging and potential thrombolytic treatment.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Richard Thompson  a 65-year-old African-American male  presents to the emergency department with his wife who reports that he suddenly developed difficulty in speaking and was unable to move the right side of his body earlier this morning. It is noticed that his mouth drooped on the right side when he tried to talk. His symptoms had progressively worsened over 1 hour and they decided to bring him in.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Thompson has a known case of hypertension for the past 10 years and type II diabetes mellitus for about 5 years. He has not been regular with his medication and has poor control over his diet  frequently indulging in high-sugar and high-sodium food. He reports a history of smoking around 10 cigarettes a day for last 40 years. He has a family history of heart disease and stroke; his father passed away due to stroke at the age of 70. Mr. Thompson has no known drug allergies. He denied any history of head injury  seizures  illicit drug use  or alcoholism.

A 75-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Smith  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided hemiparesis and expressive aphasia that began 2 hours earlier. He denies any confusion  headache  visual changes or loss of balance. His vital signs upon arrival are blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  heart rate of 80 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and temperature of 37.1°C.  Mr. Smith has a medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been taking lisinopril  hydrochlorothiazide  and metformin for years. He quit smoking 10 years ago  but has a 30 pack-year history. His social history reveals he lives alone but his adult daughter visits regularly. He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. He has no known drug allergies. His family history is notable for paternal grandfather who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65 and a brother with an ischemic stroke aged 70.  Given the abrupt onset of symptoms  timeline  and the fact that he presents within thrombolytic window  he is suspected to have an ischemic stroke and is sent immediately for a CT scan of the brain. His examination reveals a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score of 4.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired accountant  currently living with his wife.  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of left-sided weakness and speech difficulties  History of Present Illness: Mr. Smith woke up from a nap two hours ago  noticing a sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty forming sentences. His symptoms have persisted and still ongoing without improvement. He denies having accompanying symptoms such as headache  dizziness  loss of consciousness  or vision changes. Mr. Smith’s wife noticed him slurring his words and his face appeared droopy on one side  so she called the ambulance.  Past Medical History: The patient has a five-year history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are controlled by Metoprolol and Simvastatin  respectively. He is also a former smoker who quit 10 years ago but smoked a total of thirty pack years. He does not have any known allergies. He does not have any previous history of stroke or TIA. He does not have a family history of stroke.   Review of Systems: Denies chest pain  difficulty breathing  abdominal pain  diarrhea or visual changes.  Physical Examination: The patient appeared slightly anxious  was conscious  oriented to person  place  and time. Cardiac and pulmonary auscultation were unremarkable  blood pressure was slightly elevated. Neurological exam revealed left-sided hemiparesis including the face  arm  and leg. Slurred but fair comprehension of spoken language  Impression: The history  along with the physical examination is suggestive of an acute ischemic stroke on the right side of the brain. The exact type and extent of stroke and further management plan will be determined based on imaging results and consultation with the neurology team. Patient needs to be managed urgently in a stroke unit. Fast-track stroke protocol activated.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year old Caucasian male  Mr. John  presents to the emergency department reporting a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. He is accompanied by his wife who reports that he was fine one hour prior but suddenly developed difficulty in speech and right arm movement. She denies any recent trauma  medications  or substance abuse.   Past Medical History:  Mr. John has a significant past medical history of hypertension for the last ten years and Type 2 diabetes for the past 7 years. He is a former smoker and quit 5 years ago. He also has a familial history of strokes  with his deceased father having suffered two strokes in his 70s. He is currently on Lisinopril 10mg for hypertension and Metformin 500mg BD for diabetes and takes his medications regularly. He does not have any known drug allergies. His latest HbA1c was 7.5% and blood pressure was last recorded to be 135/85 mmHg.   Patient Denies:  History of chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  headache  seizures  loss of consciousness  vision changes  difficulty swallowing  or loss of balance. No recent travel  recent surgeries or uncontrolled bleeding.   The current examination reveals a conscious but anxious patient  with slurred speech and a noticeable droop on the right side of his face. More specifically  he is unable to lift his right arm or stand up from a seated position due to perceived weakness in his right leg.   This clinical presentation and history are strongly suggestive of a possible left-hemispheric ischemic stroke. He will need immediate further assessment including a CT scan and potential thrombolytic therapy depending on the results. The patient's diabetes and hypertension  both risk factors for stroke  along with his family history  add to this suspicion. Serial monitoring of neurological status  vital signs  and blood glucose levels will also be important.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Smith is a 68-year-old Caucasian female presenting to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness  difficulty speaking  and facial droop that started roughly 90 minutes ago. The symptoms began while she was having breakfast and have progressively worsened.   Ms. Smith has a significant past medical history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type II  hyperlipidemia  and a 20-year tobacco use history  for which she quit 5 years prior to this incidence. She is currently on Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes  Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension  and Simvastatin 20mg at night for hyperlipidemia. She has no known drug allergies.  She lives alone and was brought to the hospital by her neighbor who noticed the sudden change in her speech. She has a family history of cardiovascular diseases: her father passed away from myocardial infarction at 72 years and her older brother has a history of ischemic stroke.   On examination  Ms. Smith is conscious  oriented but displays noticeable speech difficulty (dysarthria) and a drooping right side of her face. Her vitals show blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg  heart rate of 88 bpm  respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute  an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air  and a random blood glucose level of 190 mg/dL.  A quick neurological examination reveals a strength of 2/5 in her right upper and lower extremities compared with a strength of 5/5 on her left side. The rest of the physical examination is largely unremarkable.   These findings are suggestive of an acute ischemic stroke  pending further confirmatory diagnostic procedures including a CT brain scan without contrast.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 73-year-old male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a non-smoker and reports moderates alcohol consumption. His medications include lisinopril  metformin  and atorvastatin.  He presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech which began approximately 2 hours before arrival. He also reports experiencing a headache and dizziness. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  the patient is alert but has difficulty in expressing himself though he can understand what is being said. The patient displays right-sided facial droop. He has reduced motor strength (3/5) on the right upper and lower limb but normal strength (5/5) on the left side. Vital signs are stable with BP of 150/90 mmHg. Examination of the cardiovascular  respiratory  and gastrointestinal systems is unremarkable. Neurological exam of the cranial nerves shows loss of function in the upper and lower facial branches of the facial nerve on the right. He's unable to raise his right eyebrow and has trouble closing his right eye.  Given this presentation  as well as his risk factors of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes  there is a high clinical suspicion of ischemic stroke. He is immediately sent for a CT scan of the head to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the extent of cerebral involvement.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Jane Doe is a 66-year-old Caucasian female presenting with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking  which started while eating breakfast this morning.   Past Medical History is notable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are being actively controlled with Lisinopril and Metformin  respectively. She quit smoking 10 years ago and doesn't consume alcohol. Relatives have a history of stroke and heart disease.  On examination  it was noted that she had right sided facial weakness  right sided hemiparesis and expressive aphasia.   The onset of symptoms  the patient’s history of hypertension and diabetes  her age  and her family history all strongly suggest a possible stroke. An immediate neurology consult and brain imaging has been advised.

Patient Presentation:  A 57-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and speech problems. The symptoms began approximately 90 minutes prior to arrival at the hospital. HIS wife  who called the ambulance  reported that he had a difficulty speaking and understanding language. Also  he fell when he tried to stand up due to the weakness in the right side.   He has a documented history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which are both controlled using oral anti-hypertensives and anti-diabetic medications. He is otherwise in good health  does not smoke  drinks alcohol socially  and performs regular physical activity. He reported no allergies to medications  and his immunizations are up to date.   His family history is notable for hypertension on the paternal side and a brother who had an ischemic stroke at the age of 54. His father also had a stroke and died in his late 60s. No family history of heart diseases or other chronic diseases reported.  On physical examination  the patient is alert and oriented to person  place and time. His vital signs show a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate of 80 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Neurological examination reveals expressive aphasia with an understanding of speech and intact cranial nerves. Power is 1/5 in the right upper and lower limbs. He has a brisk deep tendon reflex in the right biceps and patellar  with a right facial droop and slight dysarthria. No other abnormalities are noted on physical examination.  Given this presentation  there is a high suspicion for an acute ischemic stroke. Immediate CT scan and blood work including complete blood count  electrolytes  and coagulation parameters are ordered. The patient is being considered for intravenous thrombolysis. His family and next of kin are informed about his health status and ongoing treatment planning.

Mr. John Anderson  a 69-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with symptoms consistent with a possible stroke. Mr. Anderson's symptoms began roughly 2 hours ago when his wife noticed his face drooped on one side  and he was unable to lift his right arm. He also showed signs of difficulty speaking and comprehending speech.   He has a significant medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes mellitus type 2 which he reports are managed with daily medications. Additionally  he has a 15-year history of smoking one pack per day and admits to be a moderate drinker.  He has no known allergies to medication or food. He is currently taking Lisinopril for hypertension  Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  and Metformin for diabetes.  On examination  he has right-sided facial droop  pronator-drift in the right arm  and slightly slurred speech. Initial assessment reveals a blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg  pulse rate 80 bpm  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 95%.  His recent lab results within the last week show Hemoglobin A1c at 9.2%. The last lipid profile from two months ago showed an LDL of 145 mg/dl. The rest of the results are normal. He denies any known family history of stroke. This preliminary presentation strongly suggests a possible acute ischemic stroke  for which he requires immediate evaluation and management.

Subject: A 70-year-old African American male  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset left-side weakness and slurred speech   History of Present Illness:  Mr. Smith is a 70-year-old retired teacher who was brought in by his wife due to sudden onset of left-side weakness  left facial droop  and slurred speech which started two hours before arriving at the emergency department. He also reports a mild headache. He has no complaints of chest pain  shortness of breath  altered vision or dizziness. No recent head trauma was noted. There is no evidence of seizure at the onset of his symptoms.  Past Medical History:  He has a known history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He has no history of previous stroke or transient ischemic attacks. There are no known allergies. He has a 30-pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use.   Current Medications: Metformin 500mg BID  Lisinopril 20mg once daily  and Atorvastatin 20 mg at bedtime.  Family History: Father had a history of stroke at age 72 and mother has type 2 diabetes. He is married with two children who are in good health.   Physical Examination:  On examination  he is alert and oriented to person  place and time. His vital signs are as follows: Blood pressure: 165/90 mm Hg  Heart rate: 78 beats per minute  Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute  Oxygen Saturation: 98% on room air  and Temperature: 37.1° C (98.8° F).   Neurological examination reveals left-sided facial droop  left-sided weakness in both upper and lower limbs (power 2/5) and dysarthria. Sensation is intact on both sides. Coordination could not be tested due to weakness.   The rest of the physical exam including cardiorespiratory and abdominal examination is unremarkable.  The presentation and symptoms suggest a diagnosis of stroke; patient is immediately sent for a CT scan of the head.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Johnson is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who was brought in to the Emergency Department today by her daughter  who discovered Ms. Johnson this morning with symptoms of acute onset slurred speech  right side facial droop and weakness of the right arm. The symptoms were first noticed 2 hours prior. This event was accompanied by a mild headache  but no instances of loss of consciousness  seizure  or trauma were reported. Ms. Johnson denies experiencing any similar issues in the past.   On further questioning  the patient is also a known case of hypertension for 15 years  controlled on hydrochlorothiazide and asthma on inhaled corticosteroids. Her father reportedly died following a stroke in his early 70s  and her mother suffers from diabetes and hypertension. She admits to smoking a half pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years and denies alcohol or illicit drug use. Her last meal was consumed 12 hours ago without any complications  and she reports no changes in her dietary habits recently.   Upon physical examination  she is alert and oriented  though her speech is understandably slurred. A notable asymmetry in the smile is evident  with drooping of the right eye and mouth. She also displays an inability to lift her right arm against gravity. Strength on the left side appears normal. Her vitals show a blood pressure of 155/95mmHg  heart rate of 82 bpm  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  a temperature of 37.0°C and SpO2 of 96%.  The clinical picture  along with her pre-existing condition  raises the suspicion of an acute ischemic stroke. The patient has been stabilized  and imaging studies have been ordered to confirm findings and guide treatment.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Whiteside  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and facial droop that began approximately 2 hours ago. He denies any headache  seizure  trauma  or loss of consciousness. His wife  who accompanied him  reported that he has seemed increasingly confused over the past hour.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Whiteside has a 10-year history of well-controlled hypertension and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago. He had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 2 years ago  without any residual deficits. He is a former smoker  having quit 8 years ago but had a 30 pack-year smoking history prior. His mother suffered a stroke at the age of 72.   Current Medications:  Mr. Whiteside is currently on metformin for his diabetes  a daily low-dose aspirin  and lisinopril for his hypertension.  Social History:  He lives with his wife and is a retired engineer. He does not consume alcohol and quit smoking 8 years ago. He is moderately active  walking around their neighborhood daily.  Review of Systems:  No complaints of chest pain  shortness of breath  or disturbances in vision. No complaints of numbness or tingling in the extremities apart from the presenting issue. No recent illnesses or injuries. His wife reports that he seemed in his usual state of health up until the sudden onset of the current symptoms.  Examination:  On examination  he has a blood pressure of 155/90 mmHg  heart rate of 80 bpm  and an oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Neurological examination revealed a clear speech deficit  noticeable right-sided facial droop  and significant right-sided upper and lower limb weakness with a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score of 8. Examination of the cardiopulmonary system and abdomen was unremarkable.  This case warrants immediate stroke protocol activation  including urgently a CT scan of the brain.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Mary Lancaster is a 72-year-old Caucasian female who presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. The symptoms began approximately two hours ago while she was having breakfast with her husband  who noticed her slurred speech and brought her in immediately.   Past Medical History:  Ms. Lancaster has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus both of which have been controlled with medication. She also has a history of hyperlipidemia and was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation three years ago for which she takes daily anticoagulation therapy. She suffered a minor stroke seven years ago with complete recovery and no residual deficits. She has been a non-smoker for the past 15 years after quitting a 30-year  pack-a-day habit.  Ms. Lancaster lives with her husband and she is generally quite active in her daily activities and retired as a school teacher 8 years ago. The couple have three adult children who live nearby.  Family History:  Her father died from coronary artery disease at the age of 75  and her mother suffered from cerebrovascular disease and passed away at the age of 82. Her oldest sibling  a brother  had a stroke at the age of 68.  Review of systems is otherwise normal. She takes metformin for her diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension  statin for her hyperlipidemia  and apixaban for stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jensen  a 75-year-old African-American male  presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset right-sided weakness affecting both his right arm and leg  facial drooping on the right side  and slurred speech. His wife  who brought him  stated these symptoms occurred abruptly during breakfast about 2 hours ago. Besides these changes  she also reports that he seemed confused and his right eye did not seem to close properly.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Jensen has a history of hypertension for which he takes Amlodipine  past smoker who quit smoking 10 years ago. He also has high cholesterol and he is diabetic type II for which he takes Metformin. He had been non-compliant with his medication for the past week due to pharmacy refill issues. He does not have any history of heart diseases or strokes. He does not consume alcohol. He lives with his wife and is a retired engineer. His father died of a stroke at the age of 80 and his mother had diabetes and died of complications of diabetes at the age of 85.  Recently  he has not reported any headaches  migraines  changes in vision or dizziness. He denies any history of illicit drug use or recent surgeries. He has not had any fever or signs of infection.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting with acute neurologic deficits suggestive of stroke. He was brought to the hospital by his wife after he suddenly slumped over in their living room and exhibited slurred speech and unilateral weakness.   The patient's symptoms started approximately 2 hours prior to arrival. He was watching television when he suddenly complained of a severe headache. Shortly thereafter  his wife noticed that his smile was lopsided and that he was having difficulty speaking coherently. He also complained of weakness on his right side and had trouble moving his right arm and leg. She dialed 911 immediately.   Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he takes medication regularly. He is a smoker with a 40-pack-year history. The patient had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) five years ago. He does not have diabetes or any known heart disease. There is no family history of stroke  but plenty of heart disease in his family  making him more susceptible to cardiovascular events.  The patient's medications include daily Aspirin  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.   He denies any recent trauma  heavy alcohol consumption  drug use  or travelling. He denies a change in medication  medication non-compliance or recent sickness.   His vitals on arrival are; blood pressure 175/95 mmHg  pulse 80/min  respiratory rate 14/min  and temperature of 99.1°F.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker named Mr. Williams  who is presenting with sudden-onset right-sided weakness  difficulty speaking and loss of balance. He was reportedly fine when he went to bed last night. This morning his wife found him on the floor beside their bed  unable to get up.   Patient’s past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 40-pack-year smoking history. He admits non-compliance with his prescribed medication regimen which includes Lisinopril  Atorvastatin  and Metformin.  Family history reveals a father who died of a myocardial infarction at age 65 and a brother with a history of an ischemic stroke.  Physical Examination shows a BP of 190/110 mmHg  HR of 95 bpm  and patient is afebrile. Neurologic examination reveals right-sided hemiparesis  right-sided facial droop  dysarthria  and neglect of the right visual field. He is alert and oriented to person  not to time or place.    Based on the history and clinical presentation  an acute ischemic stroke is suspected. Urgent investigations including brain imaging and full stroke workup have been arranged.

Patient Presentation :  A 65-year-old African American male patient presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking  which started approximately 2 hours ago. He was at home watching television with his wife when he suddenly got up and started to walk towards the kitchen but faltered and fell against the wall. He complained of a sudden loss of strength in his right side. His wife  noticing his speech was slurred  immediately called for an ambulance.   Past medical history reveals that the patient is a long-standing hypertensive and diabetic on daily medication. He also has high cholesterol levels. He suffered a TIA (transient ischemic attack) 5 years ago with full recovery. He is a former 30-pack year smoker and quit smoking 10 years ago. He also has a history of heavy drinking but quit 6 months ago. He denies any history of head injury or recent trauma. His father had a stroke in his late sixties.   The patient is currently taking daily medications including Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Simvastatin for cholesterol. His vital signs upon arrival include a blood pressure of 190/105 mmHg  a pulse rate of 80 beats per minute  a respiration rate of 18 breaths per minute  and a temperature of 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit.   This presentation is suggestive of an Acute ischemic stroke  and the patient should be rushed for immediate care and further evaluation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. David Steele  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with sudden onset unilateral weakness and slurred speech. Reports that symptoms started approximately two hours ago during breakfast. No documented history of similar episodes.  He is a resident of New York  he lives alone and was brought in by his neighbor who observed the acute change in his condition.   Mr. Steele is a retired mechanic and his only daughter lives out of state. He is a widower and uses a walking stick for support due to osteoarthritis.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension for 15 years  treated with Lisinopril 2. Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 for 10 years  managed with Metformin and regular exercise 3. Previous admission for myocardial infarction 5 years ago  managed with aspirin and statins since then 4. Osteoarthritis in the left knee for the last 7 years  managed conservatively.  Social History:  He has a 20 pack-year history of smoking but quit two years ago. He reports moderate alcohol consumption (1-2 drinks per week) but no illicit drug use.   The triage nurse has obtained this history and now awaits further assessment and treatment.

A 65-year-old African-American man  Mr. Jackson  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty with speech for the past hour. He works as a construction worker and lives with his wife. He is a current smoker with a 40-pack-year history and has a daily alcohol consumption of 2 drinks. His weight is 210 lbs with a BMI of 30  indicating obesity. Mr. Jackson has a documented history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both of which are poorly controlled  with most recent readings 1 week ago showing blood glucose at 220 mg/dL and blood pressure at 160/95 mmHg. He has been non-compliant with his diabetes and hypertension medications. He has no history of strokes  but his father had a stroke at age 72. He admits to not having regular health check-ups due to lack of health insurance.

Patient Presentation: A 65-year-old African American male presents to the Emergency Department with sudden left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking that began approximately two hours ago. He also reports a severe  throbbing headache and a sense of numbness on the left side of his face.  Vital Signs: Blood-pressure – 180/95; heart rate – 110 bpm; respiratory rate – 25 breaths per minute; oxygen saturation – 95% on room air; temperature - 98.6 F.  Past Medical History: Patient is a known hypertensive for last 15 years  Type-II diabetic for 10 years  and also has a history of Hyperlipidemia. Patient reports he was compliant with medications including Metformin  Atorvastatin  and Lisinopril. He had a prior ischemic stroke 5 years back with full recovery. He also mentions a family history of stroke and heart diseases. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years and drinks alcohol occasionally. No known drug allergies.  Clinical Physical Exam: Patient is alert but anxious  speech deficit is noted with left facial droop. Mild left-sided neglect is noticed. Motor strength is 2/5 in the left upper and lower limbs and 5/5 in the right limbs. Sensory loss noted on the left side. Rest of the systems examination is unremarkable.  Imaging: Urgent non-contrast CT brain was ordered  which suggests a new infarct in the right MCA territory.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thompson is a 68-year-old African-American male who presents to the Emergency Department brought in by his wife due to sudden onset of slurred speech  right-side facial droop  and right arm weakness. The symptoms started approximately 2 hours ago while he was watching television. Mr. Thompson is a non-smoker. He has a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with oral medication  as well as hypertension controlled with lisinopril  which he has been taking for the past 10 years. He was recently started on simvastatin for hyperlipidemia. There is no family history of early cardiovascular disease or stroke. He denies accompanying headache  seizure  recent trauma  or loss of consciousness.  Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 165/90 mmHg  pulse 78 beats per minute  respiration 16 breaths per minute  and an oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. His speech is slurred  he has pronounced right nasolabial fold  and a right upper extremity drift is noted. The National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) is determined to be 5.   Workup and diagnosis confirm he is having an ischemic stroke. His wife reports Mr. Thompson has been compliant with his medication and his last HbA1c was 6.4% suggesting good control of his diabetes. Further management and decision for interventions such as thrombolysis are decided upon after a detailed discussion with the stroke team.

Patient Profile:  Name: Margaret Anderson Age: 73  Sex: Female Race: Caucasian  Presenting Complaint:   Margaret was brought in by her daughter who noticed sudden onset of right-sided weakness  facial droop  and slurring of speech when she visited her earlier today. These symptoms were not present the previous night when Margaret was put to bed.  Past Medical History:  Margaret has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both well-managed with medications including lisinopril  amlodipine and metformin for over 15 years. She also has a history of hyperlipidemia and has been on atorvastatin and daily aspirin therapy for the past 14 years. No known allergies to any medications. She does not drink alcohol or smoke tobacco. She also has atrial fibrillation  controlled with warfarin. She had a transient ischemic attack five years ago but had no residual effects post that event.  Family History:   Her parents both had hypertension. Her father also had a stroke at the age of 77.  Review of Systems:   Positive for sudden onset of unilateral weakness  facial droop  speech difficulty. Negative for any changes in vision  dizziness/loss of balance  headache  chest pain  or any other cardiorespiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms.   Physical Examination:   Margaret appears alert but anxious. Vitals are stable. She is afebrile with a blood pressure of 150/90 mm of Hg  heart rate of 85 beats/min and respiratory rate of 18 breaths/min. Oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Cardiovascular exam reveals irregularly irregular heart rhythm. Neurological exam confirms right-sided hemiparesis  right lower facial droop and slurring of speech on talking.  All the clinical findings and history are suggestive of a possible stroke. CT scan brain and other neuroimaging tests are advised to confirm ischemic stroke and evaluate further. Immediate neurological intervention is necessary.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Johnson  a 68-year-old Caucasian woman  presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. The patient's daughter  who was with her at the time  reported the symptoms started about 1.5 hours prior to arrival. Ms. Johnson has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking history. She has been compliant with her antihypertensive and anticholesterol medications  but she continues to smoke half a pack of cigarettes per day. She has no known drug allergies. She has no prior history of stroke or transient ischemic attack. Her mother and brother both had strokes in their 70s. She denies any recent trauma  severe headache  or loss of consciousness  but has experienced dizziness and instability while walking in the last month. There is also a noticeable facial droop on her right side. On examination  she shows right-sided hemiparesis and expressive aphasia. She is on a regular diet and is independent for her activities of daily living. Her vaccinations are up-to-date. She lives with her daughter and is a widow with three children. Her other family history details are unremarkable. The patient has not travelled recently and does not consume alcohol.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Smith is a 67-year-old African American male who was brought in by his wife due to the sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking which started about 2 hours prior to arrival at the emergency department. He reports that while he was having breakfast  he suddenly felt a weakness in his left arm and leg  and his wife noticed he was slurring his words. His symptoms have remained constant since onset. There is no report of loss of consciousness  seizure activity  or trauma.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are moderately controlled with medication. He also has a 20-year history of smoking  although he quit 5 years ago. The patient denies any previous stroke  but reports that his mother had a stroke at the age of 73. He has no history of myocardial infarction  depression  dementia  or atrial fibrillation.  Current Medications:  Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for type 2 Diabetes. He also takes a daily aspirin as directed by his primary care physician.  Social History: He used to work as an accountant but is now retired. Lives with his wife. He quit smoking 5 years ago but used to smoke a pack of cigarettes a day for about 20 years. He drinks alcohol socially  denying any history of substance abuse.   Physical Exam: On examination  his BP is 160/90 mmHg  heart rate is 88 beats per minute  and respirations are 20 per minute. He is alert and oriented to person  place  and time. His speech is slurred. Neurologically  he demonstrates a left-sided facial droop  3/5 strength in the left upper and lower extremities  and has slight trouble maintaining balance. The remaining examination is unremarkable.  Based on the history and physical examination findings  acute ischemic stroke is highly suspected and urgent brain imaging (CT scan) is planned.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Jones is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presenting to the emergency department with acute onset of left-sided weakness and slurred speech. The symptoms started approximately 2 hours prior to arrival  with no improvement. He denies previous similar episodes  recent trauma  or loss of consciousness.  Mr. Jones has a past medical history indicative of significant cardiovascular risk factors including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 40-pack year history of smoking which he quit 5 years ago. He is currently maintained on medication for his three chronic conditions - Metformin for diabetes  Atenolol for hypertension and Simvastatin for hyperlipidemia.   He appears pale and speaks with some difficulty due to dysarthria. His vital signs on admission are a blood pressure of 180/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  temperature of 98.6°F (37°C)  and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air.   He lives with his wife who is a retired teacher  and they have two adult children living close by  prepared to provide additional support. The wife remarks that over the past few weeks  Mr. Jones had mentioned experiencing brief episodes of dizziness  but they had not sought medical advice at the time. This is his first evident neurological deficit.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 66-year-old Caucasian male presenting at the emergency department. He was brought in by his wife who reported that he had sudden onset of difficulties while speaking and weakness on the right side of his body. This began approximately two hours ago when they were having breakfast. Apart from feeling a bit tired in the early morning  he has not complained of any other symptoms like headache  nausea  dizziness  or loss of consciousness.  Past medical history reveals that Mr. Smith has been treated for hypertension and hyperlipidemia for over a decade  managing these conditions with regular medication of Lisinopril and Simvastatin respectively. He has also been a smoker for nearly 20 years  though he quit five years ago. He also has a family history of stroke as his mother experienced one at the age of 70. Mr. Smith's alcohol intake is reportedly moderate and he retired from his job as a school principal last year.  On physical examination  he is alert but with notable difficulty in finding words. Anterior circulation stroke is suspected related to activity in the left cerebral hemisphere. Weighing at 85 Kg with a BMI of 28.4  he appears overweight.  Given the clinical presentation  past medical history  and initial physical examination  the leading differential diagnosis is an ischemic stroke. Immediate attention to ensure appropriate management  including potential thrombolytic therapy needs to be evaluated urgently to prevent further neurological damage.

Patient Information: A 68-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired truck driver.  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of slurred speech  weakness on the right side of the body  and difficulty seeing out of his right eye.  Present History: Mr. Smith was having breakfast this morning when his wife noticed he started speaking incoherently and couldn’t grip his glass of water. His wife called 911. He has had no previous episodes like this.  Past Medical History: Known hypertensive for 10 years  Type II Diabetes Mellitus for 8 years  and history of tobacco use (1 pack/day for 30 years  quit 5 years ago). No previous history of stroke or transient ischemic attacks.  Family History: Father died from stroke at age 72. Mother died of breast cancer at age 76.  Current Medication: Metformin 500 mg twice/day and Lisinopril 10 mg/day. No known drug allergies.  Vital Signs: Blood Pressure: 155/90 mmHg  Heart rate: 88bpm  Respiratory rate: 20 breaths/min  body temperature: 98.6°F  Oxygen saturation: 96% on room air.  Physical Examination: Cranial nerve examination revealed a partial right-sided facial droop  speech was slurred but he was orientated to time  place  and person. Right arm and leg showed mild weakness (4/5) with normal tone  and reflexes were symmetrical.  On cardiovascular examination  heart rhythm was normal and no murmurs were heard. No notable abnormalities on respiratory and abdominal examination.  Neurological examination: Right homonymous hemianopia was present. No sensory loss detected.   Investigation: Immediate non-contrast CT Brain taken. Awaiting results.  Conclusion: The patient’s history and physical examination are indicative of a possible left hemisphere ischemic stroke. Currently awaiting imaging results to confirm diagnosis and appropriate thrombolytic therapy will be initiated depending on the results.  Plan: Admit to stroke unit  neurology consultation  control blood sugar and blood pressure  manage medical needs and risk factors.  Education: Educate patient and family on signs of stroke (FAST: Face drooping  Arm weakness  Speech difficulty  Time to call 911) and stroke prevention methods.

Patient Information: A 67-year-old African American male.  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of speech difficulty and weakness on the right side of the body lasting for about an hour.  History of Present Illness: Patient was fine when he went to bed last night. Upon awakening  he noticed he was unable to speak in his usual manner and felt weakness when trying to grip his coffee cup. He also reported feeling a numbness on the right side of his face.  Past Medical History: Hypertension  Type 2 diabetes  Hyperlipidemia  past smoker with a 40 pack-year history but quit smoking 10 years ago.  Family History: Father died of a stroke at the age of 73.  Review of Systems: Denies headache  dizziness  loss of consciousness  or loss of balance. Admits to intermittent chest discomfort over the past year.   Physical Examination: Conscious  alert  and favorable nutritional status. Observation of speech confirmed slurring and difficulty finding words. Right-sided facial droop present. Motor exam showed weakness of the right upper and lower extremities with power 3/5 as compared to the left side power 5/5. Deep tendon reflexes were symmetric. No sensory deficit was detected.  Impression: The patient's presentation suggests that he may have had a stroke. Will need neuroimaging to further assess.

Patient Presentation:  A 67-year-old African American male is brought into the Emergency Department (ED) by his daughter who noticed a sudden change in her father’s ability to speak  and weakness in his right arm starting approximately 2 hours ago. He denies headache  chest pain  or shortness of breath. He vomited once after the symptoms started. The patient has a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes  all of which are treated with medication (Lisinopril  Atorvastatin  and Metformin respectively). He quit smoking 10 years ago after having smoked a pack a day for about 35 years.  In the ED  his blood pressure is noted to be elevated (180/95 mmHg)  heart rate is 78 bpm  and he appears to be in no acute distress. On neurological examination  he had difficulty speaking  facial drooping on the right side  and significant weakness in his right upper and lower limbs consistent with a left-sided stroke. Urgent CT scan of the head is obtained which shows an early ischemic stroke in the left middle cerebral artery territory.  Immediate management includes initiating treatment with IV thrombolytic therapy within the therapeutic time window. He is also started on aspirin  his blood pressure is cautiously managed  and he is admitted to the stroke unit for close monitoring and further management.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 72-year-old African American male brought to the emergency room (ER) by his wife who is his primary caregiver. She reported that he has been experiencing weakness on the right side of his body  difficulty speaking  and drooping on the right side of his face for the past hour.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He is known to be non-compliant with his medications and has poor glucose control. He had a prior myocardial infarction five years ago for which he was given thrombolytic therapy. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease with the patient's father having had a stroke and his mother with a history of coronary artery disease.   Lifestyle:  The patient is a life-long smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. He worked as a long-distance truck driver until his retirement. He is overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 32. He follows a diet high in carbohydrates and fats  and does not engage in physical activity as he settles into his retirement years.  Allergies:  The patient reports an allergy to penicillin; he experiences rashes upon use.   Current Medications:  He is prescribed Metformin for his diabetes  Lisinopril for his high blood pressure  and Simvastatin for his high cholesterol. However  he is regularly non-compliant with his medication regimen.  Review of Systems:  He denies headache  nausea or vomiting. No bowel or bladder incontinence observed. Neurologic testing was limited in the ER  but suggests right-sided hemiparesis  right facial droop  and dysarthria.  Given his sudden neurologic deficit  the presence of multiple risk factors for cerebral vascular disease  and the patient's non-compliance with medication  the clinician should be highly suspicious of stroke in this patient. The recommended next step is urgent neuroimaging  ideally with a non-contrast CT scan of the head to assess for the presence of hemorrhage.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old Caucasian male presented to the Emergency Department (ED) accompanied by his daughter. He was found at home with difficulty speaking and weakness on the right side of his body. The onset was sudden  occurring about two hours prior to arrival at the ED. The patient is conscious but aphasic  with an altered level of comprehension.   Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and persistent atrial fibrillation. He had a myocardial infarction approximately ten years ago. He is a former smoker who quit two years ago  having had a 30-pack year history prior. The patient's medications include lisinopril  metformin  atorvastatin  and warfarin. His INR on arrival is subtherapeutic at 1.5.  Social History: The patient is a widower who lives alone but is checked on regularly by his daughter. He used to work as a banker  has been retired for eight years  and is generally independent in his activities of daily living. He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use.  The patient's daughter mentioned that her father had some memory problems but was not previously diagnosed with any cognitive disorder and was managing his own medications. Stroke was suspected and a brain CT was ordered immediately.  Given this presentation  assessment  and history  it supports the suspicion of an ischemic stroke  possibly due to his atrial fibrillation combined with the subtherapeutic INR providing an opportunity for thrombus formation and embolization. His other comorbidities also place him at an increased risk.

Title: Stroke Presentation in a 57-Year-Old Male  Slide 1: Introduction - Definition of the stroke - Importance of early recognition - Elements of thorough evaluation  Slide 2: Patient Bio and Demographics - Patient: Mr. John Doe  57-year-old male - Occupation: Accountant - Lives alone  non-smoker  and occasionally drinks alcohol  Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms - Acute onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking - Complaints of sudden  severe headache  Slide 4: Past Medical History - Hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both managed with medications - No history of surgeries or hospitalizations - No known allergies - Family history of stroke   Slide 5: Physical Examination - Right-sided facial droop - Right-sided weakness in the arm and leg - Slurred speech - Vital signs: BP 170/95 mm Hg  HR 95 bpm  RR 16 breaths per min  Temp 37.2 C  SpO2 98% RA  Slide 6: Diagnostic Evaluation - Immediate CT scan of the head showed an ischemic stroke - Lab work: hyperglycemia  high cholesterol levels  Slide 7: Management and Treatment - Admitted to the stroke unit - Establishment of IV access and administration of recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) within the golden hour - Blood pressure management - Blood sugar control - Physiotherapy initiated for right-sided weakness  Slide 8: Prognosis - Importance of early recognition and treatment - Possible outcomes and recovery - Role of lifestyle modifications and secondary prevention  Slide 9: Stroke Prevention - Controlling blood pressure and diabetes - Healthy diet and exercise - Quitting smoking  limiting alcohol intake - Regular check-ups to monitor health status  Slide 10: Conclusion and Questions  - Recap of Mr. John Doe's stroke management - Importance of multidisciplinary care in stroke treatment - Open forum for discussion and questions.

Title: Case Study - Management of an Ischaemic Stroke Patient  Slide 1: Introduction In this presentation  we will walk you through an illustrative case involving an elderly patient with an Ischaemic Stroke. Each slide details key aspects  including her demographics  past medical history  diagnosis  management  prognosis  and rehabilitation.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Patient: Ms. Jane Doe  a 72-year-old African American female  recently retired teacher  lives with her husband  a non-smoker  with occasional alcohol consumption.  Slide 3: Past Medical History Ms. Doe presents a history of Hypertension and Type-2 diabetes for the past 6 years  both well-managed with medication. Her mother recovered from a stroke at the age of 78 and both her parents succumbed to heart disease.  Slide 4: Current Presentation Ms. Doe was admitted to the ER after her husband noticed a sudden slurring of her speech  confusion  and weakness in her right arm and face. These symptoms occurred approximately 1 hour ago.  Slide 5: Physical Examination & Diagnosis Upon physical examination  Ms. Doe presented with expressive aphasia  right-sided facial droop  hemiparesis on the right side. An emergent CT scan confirmed the diagnosis of an acute Ischaemic Stroke.  Slide 6: Stroke Management Given the time of onset  she was eligible for thrombolytic therapy and was promptly given intravenous rtPA. Patient’s blood pressure and blood sugar levels were routinely monitored and maintained within the normal range.  Slide 7: Post-Stroke Rehabilitation Ms. Doe's stroke affected her motor abilities and speech. She was referred to physiotherapy for restoring motor function and a speech-language pathologist to improve her speech and swallowing.  Slide 8: Prognosis Considering her prompt diagnosis and treatment  coupled with her participation in rehabilitative therapy  Ms. Doe has a favourable prognosis. However  lifestyle modifications and strict control of hypertension and diabetes are advised to prevent future strokes.  Slide 9: Conclusion  Stroke patients require a multi-disciplinary and prompt approach for successful treatment outcomes. Educating patients and their families about stroke risk factors and the importance of timely treatment is crucial to reduce the incidence and recurrence of strokes.   Slide 10: Reflection Finally  questions and discussions are welcome. Let’s reflect on this case  and discuss further improvements in care for similar patients.

Title: A Case Study of Stroke in an Elderly Patient  Slide 1: *Introduction*  Mr. John Doe  an 82-year-old male with an established diagnosis of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  presents with acute onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in speaking  suggestive of a stroke.  Slide 2: *Patient Demographics and Lifestyle*  John is a former high school teacher  now retired and living with his wife and caregivers. He has a 30 years history of smoking and excessive alcohol intake. His ethnicity is Caucasian.  Slide 3: *Past Medical History*  John has battled type 2 diabetes mellitus for over 20 years and has been managing his condition through a combination of medications and diet. For approximately ten years  John has also been diagnosed as suffering from hypertension  which he's been controlling with the aid of prescribed medicines.  Slide 4: *Recent Symptoms Indicating Possible Stroke*  John awoke from his afternoon nap unable to use his right arm and leg and had difficulty in constructing coherent sentences. His wife called for an ambulance immediately. There was no symptom of fever  headache  trauma  or any other alarming symptoms.  Slide 5: *Physical Examination*  Upon hospital presentation  he had a BP of 155/96 mmHg and pulse of 98/min. Neurological exam revealed right-sided hemiplegia and expressive aphasia. His face was also drooping on the right side. The other systems examination was unremarkable.  Slide 6: *Diagnosis*  With his symptoms and physical examination  a tentative diagnosis of Acute Ischemic Stroke was made.  Slide 7: *Clinical Investigations*  A CT scan of the brain was conducted which showed a loss of the left middle cerebral artery territory indicative of an ischaemic stroke. His glucose levels and lipid profile were abnormal  and EKG showed signs of left ventricular hypertrophy.  Slide 8: *Treatment and Rehabilitation*  John was treated with tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA)  as he arrived within the therapeutic window of this treatment. He was also started on aspirin therapy. Given the expressivity of the symptoms  he was referred to speech therapy and physical rehabilitation to aid his recovery.  Slide 9: *Prognosis and Patient Education*  John's prognosis largely depends on his response to therapy and efforts in rehabilitation. Aspects related to lifestyle modification  including smoking cessation  moderation in alcohol intake  diabetes management  regular monitoring of blood pressure  and a healthy diet  were discussed extensively with both John and his wife to prevent a recurrent incident.  Slide 10: *Conclusion*  This case underlines the importance of managing chronic conditions  such as hypertension and diabetes  the role of lifestyle factors in stroke risk  and the value of swift diagnosis and treatment for stroke prognosis.

Title: Case Presentation on a Stroke Patient  Slide 1: Introduction Today we will be discussing a case of a 68-year-old male patient diagnosed with Ischemic Stroke.   Slide 2: Demographics Our patient  Mr. X  is a 68-year-old African American male  who is a retired teacher and a resident of downtown Chicago. He lives with his wife and reports no tobacco or illicit substance use. He is a social drinker and maintains a relatively active lifestyle.  Slide 3: Past Medical History Mr. X has a history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes  managed by medication and diet. His family history is notable for stroke and heart disease. He experienced a transient ischemic attack (TIA) five years ago.  Slide 4: Symptoms Mr. X was brought to the ER presenting with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  difficulty in speech  and drooping on the right side of his face. He also exhibited signs of confusion and coordination issues.  Slide 5: Physical Examination  Upon arrival  his vitals were: Respiration - 18  Pulse - 68  Blood pressure - 150/88  Temperature - 98.6F. Neurological evaluation demonstrated right-sided hemiparesis and facial drooping.   Slide 6: Laboratory Testing & Imaging Blood glucose level and lipid profile were found to be marginally high. CT scan of the head revealed a lack of blood flow to the left side of the brain  confirming the diagnosis of ischemic stroke.  Slide 7: Management Mr. X was immediately given IV thrombolytics followed by antiplatelet therapy. His care plan includes physical and speech therapy for post-stroke rehabilitation. Lifestyle modifications and enhanced control of diabetes and hypertension are also advised.  Slide 8: Prognosis Early intervention  compliant diet  medication management  and regular follow-up are crucial for minimizing future stroke risk and increasing overall quality of life for Mr. X.   Slide 9: Conclusion This case presentation has reflected stroke management in a patient with diabetes and hypertension. The timely response  multidisciplinary approach  and patient compliance are key factors in successful stroke recovery.   Slide 10: Questions & Discussion Open for clarifications  questions  and discussion.

Title: A Case Study Presentation on Stroke  Slide 1: Introduction  Today  we will dissect the case study of a stroke patient  shedding light on the patient’s demographics  medical history  symptoms  diagnosis  treatment  and follow-up care.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  Our patient  Mr. John Doe  is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired  widowed  and living alone in the urban area of New York. He’s a former chain smoker and a heavy drinker till his late 50s.   Slide 3: Past Medical History  John's medical history is significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and high cholesterol level. Unfortunately  his compliance with his medications has been inconsistent. He suffered a mild heart attack five years ago  but no lasting damage was reported.  Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms  Mr. Doe was found unconscious by his neighbor. Upon admission  he exhibited left-sided weakness  slurred speech  visual disturbances  and a confusion state. He scored 20 on the NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS)  indicating moderate to severe stroke.  Slide 5: Diagnosis  Considering his symptoms and NIHSS score  a CT scan was performed  confirming a right Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) ischemic stroke. Emergency blood tests showed irregularly high blood sugar levels and mildly elevated blood pressure.  Slide 6: Treatment  John was started immediately on a thrombolytic therapy  as he reached the hospital within the therapeutic window. He was also treated for hyperglycemia  dyslipidemia  and hypertension. His medications were adjusted and closely monitored.  Slide 7: Rehabilitation and Follow-Up  Post-stroke rehabilitation included physical  occupational  and speech therapy. His inability to consistently take his prescribed medications necessitated the intervention of a social worker to ensure his compliance. He was also given lifestyle modification counseling to manage his diabetes and reduce the risk of another stroke.  Slide 8: Summary  John’s case emphasizes the importance of monitoring and properly managing chronic diseases  timely therapeutic intervention during stroke  and consistent medication compliance in preventing stroke recurrence. Strengthening the healthcare support system for elderly living alone can play a significant role in ongoing disease management and post-stroke recovery.  Slide 9: Questions  Time to clarify any doubts  understand more about stroke pathophysiology  treatment  and prevention strategies.

Presentation Title: Stroke Management and Recovery: A Patient Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction - The subject for today's case study analysis is Mr. James Thompson  a 65-year-old African-American male  who experienced a stroke. We will discuss his journey from diagnosis to rehabilitation  examining the impact of his prior medical history on his condition.  Slide 2: Demographics and Past Medical History - Mr. Thompson hails from a lower socio-economic area in an urban setting. He has been married for 45 years and has two adult children. - His medical history comprises of uncontrolled hypertension for ten years  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed five years ago  and moderate obesity. He is also reported to smoke about a pack of cigarettes a day for the past 40 years.  Slide 3: The onset of Stroke - Mr. Thompson presented to the hospital with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and speech difficulties. His symptoms started around four hours earlier on a leisurely Sunday morning.  Slide 4: Diagnosis - An urgent brain CT scan confirmed an ischemic stroke. The area affected was on the left side of the brain  correlating with his right sided symptoms.  Slide 5: Management - Mr. Thompson was immediately started on recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA)  considering the timeframe from symptom onset. - His blood pressure was brought under control  and blood glucose levels managed meticulously. All his medications were re-evaluated.  Slide 6: Post-Stroke Rehabilitation - Mr. Thompson spent two weeks in the hospital undergoing physical and speech therapy. - He was discharged with a comprehensive home rehabilitation plan involving physiotherapy  lifestyle changes  diet  and smoking cessation counseling.  Slide 7: Follow Up and Future Care - Mr. Thompson will be monitored closely for improvements and any complications. His health team will include his primary physician  a neurologist  a physiotherapist  and a dietitian to manage his hypertension  diabetes  and obesity. Regular family involvement was encouraged for his emotional well-being.  Slide 8: Key Learning Outcomes - This case underlines the importance of controlling predisposing factors like hypertension  diabetes  obesity  and smoking for stroke prevention. - Timely diagnosis and management of stroke can considerably improve patient outcomes. - Multi-disciplinary team involvement is crucial in post-stroke rehabilitation  combining medical management and lifestyle modifications.  Slide 9: Conclusion  - Our journey with Mr. Thompson has re-emphasized the importance of primary prevention  swift response in acute stroke situation  and the significance of a personalized approach to post-stroke rehabilitation.    Slide 10: Discussion & Questions - Open the floor for discussion and any questions about the case.

Title: Acute Stroke in an Elderly Patient: A Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction Mrs. Alice  a 72-year-old Caucasian woman  presented to the emergency department with clinically diagnosed acute stroke. A retired school teacher  she continues to be community-active despite her age.  Slide 2: Past Medical History Previous medical records show that Mrs. Alice is hypertensive and has been managing type II diabetes for a decade. Her medications include Metformin and Lisinopril. She also has a history of transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) and occasional atrial fibrillation for which she takes aspirin.  Slide 3: Presenting Complaints Mrs. Alice was found by her neighbor having trouble speaking and moving her right-side limbs. Prior to the incident  she reportedly experienced acute onset of severe headache.  Slide 4: Clinical Presentation Upon arrival  Mrs. Alice had a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 14  demonstrating mild confusion and disorientation. Physical examination revealed right-side facial droop  motor weakness  and slurred speech. Her blood pressure was significantly elevated at 180/100 mmHg.  Slide 5: Clinical Investigation  A CT scan displayed a left hemispheric ischemic stroke. Lab results showed elevated glucose levels and raised HbA1c  indicating poor diabetic control. ECG showed occasional atrial fibrillation.   Slide 6: Diagnosis  Based on clinical findings and imaging  diagnosis of acute ischemic left hemispheric stroke was made.  Slide 7: Management Immediate administration of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) was done  and Mrs. Alice was shifted to the stroke unit. Her medical therapy was adjusted to improve blood pressure and glucose control. Antiplatelets were continued  and a statin was introduced.   Slide 8: Rehabilitation and Follow-up She was referred to therapies for stroke rehabilitation and her social circumstances assessed for potential needs post-discharge. Regular follow-up is scheduled for monitoring her signs  symptoms  and progress in management.  Slide 9: Conclusion This case highlights the importance of early recognition  prompt management of acute stroke  and the key role of optimizing control of underlying conditions (like hypertension and diabetes) to prevent future episodes.   Slide 10: References (To be added based on the source of specific researches referred for patient care)

Title: A Case Study on Cerebral Stroke   Slide 1: Introduction - Subject: An overview of the case focusing on a 63-year-old Caucasian female exhibiting clinical symptoms of cerebral stroke.
