Patient is a 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  type II diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. He presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness  expressive aphasia and facial droop which started approximately 2 hours prior to arrival. The patient's wife reports that he was normal at breakfast and the symptoms occurred suddenly while he was reading a newspaper. He denies headache  chest pain  or shortness of breath. He has no past surgical history or allergies. He is on Olmesartan for hypertension  Metformin for diabetes  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. There is no family history of stroke or other neurological diseases. He quit smoking 10 years ago and drinks alcohol socially. There is no history of illicit drug use. The patient’s wife reports meticulous medication adherence and regular follow ups with his primary care physician. The patient does not have any travel history. His diet is a balanced one  except he prefers foods high in salt. He works as an accountant and engages in light physical activities such as short walks in the park.

Patient is a 75-year-old right-handed Caucasian female with a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presenting to the emergency department with abrupt onset of left-sided weakness and facial droop. She noticed these symptoms upon waking up this morning  approximately 4 hours ago. Additionally  she reports mild confusion and difficulty with her speech. She denies headache  change in vision  chest pain  shortness of breath or dizziness. She confirms medication adherence with her usual antihypertensive and antidiabetic regimens. She denies recent trauma  fever  or infectious symptoms. She has no known drug allergies and her only surgical history is a hip replacement 10 years ago. She is a non-smoker  consumes alcohol moderately  and denies recreational drug use. Her family history is significant for stroke in her father at age 82. Physical exam reveals a Blood Pressure of 160/95 mm Hg  heart rate of 90 bpm  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  temperature of 98.6°F. Neurological examination confirms left-sided upper and lower extremity weakness  dysarthria  left-sided facial droop  and a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale score of 10. The patient appears mildly confused but oriented to time  place  and person. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.

A 68-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for poorly controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus arrives at the Emergency Department via an ambulance. The patient's wife reported that he abruptly developed right-sided weakness while eating breakfast an hour before arrival. She also noticed that he suddenly slurred his words and was unable to maintain balance. According to her  these symptoms were all new and sudden in onset. Although blood pressure readings were noted to be high at home  the patient had been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medication. He has no known history of any neurological deficits or prior cerebrovascular accidents. He also denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or any other complaints. On examination  patient appeared disoriented with right side facial droop  flaccid paralysis of right arm and right leg  and was having difficulty with speech.

Patient Information: A 67-year-old African-American male  Chief Complaint: New onset weakness on the right side of the body and slurred speech  History of Present Illness: The patient reports that he woke up from his nap with a noticeable difficulty in moving his right arm and leg. He has also developed slurred speech  but denies any facial droop or visual changes. The initial symptoms started approximately 3 hours ago with no signs of improvement.  Past Medical History: Hypertension  Type II Diabetes Mellitus  Hyperlipidemia  previous transient ischemic attack (TIA) four years ago  and cigarette smoking for the past 45 years.  Medications: Lisinopril  Metformin  Simvastatin  and Aspirin.  Physical Examination: Blood pressure 180/90 mmHg  heart rate 84 bpm  temperature 37.3º C  and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. Neurological examination reveals dysarthria  right hemiparesis with power of 3/5 in the upper and lower extremities  normal sensation  and no facial asymmetry. Rest of physical exam is unremarkable.  Relevant Labs/Imaging: CT scan of the brain is pending.   Problem Representation: This is a 67-year-old male with a history of hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and previous TIA  presenting with acute right-sided weakness and slurred speech consistent with acute onset cerebral vascular accident  notably an ischemic stroke.

A 72-year-old African-American male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with acute right-sided weakness and an inability to speak. Symptoms started one hour ago when he was at home  and he was brought to the hospital within a framework of stroke-alert. On examination  he has a blood pressure of 180/95mmHg  heart rate of 90bpm  right-sided facial droop  dysarthria  and right-sided hemiparesis. He does not have a history of strokes or TIAs  and his daily medications include metformin  atorvastatin  and hydrochlorothiazide  but he admits he has not been compliant with his antihypertensive medication. His mother had a stroke when she was 65 years old.

Patient Information: 67-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History: Previous diagnosis of hypertension and type 2 diabetes; former smoker with a 30-pack-year smoking history; father died of stroke at age 73  Presenting Complaint: Acute onset of left-sided weakness and slurred speech  History of Present Illness: Patient was at home when he experienced sudden left-sided weakness along with difficulty speaking. These symptoms persisted and prompted his visit to the ED. The symptoms started approximately 2 hours before his arrival.  Physical Examination: Vital signs are normal. Neurological exam indicates left-sided hemiparesis  facial droop  and dysarthria.  Summary: This patient with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes who presents with acute onset left-sided weakness and impaired speech raises concern for an ischemic stroke. Factors contributing to his elevated risk include his age  male sex  hypertension  diabetes  smoking history  and family history of stroke.

Problem Representation:  Mr. O'Brien  a 60-year-old right-handed Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presented to the emergency department with acute onset of left-sided weakness and speech difficulties. He has been compliant to his regular medications  which include lisinopril and atorvastatin. He denies any drug allergies. The patient is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. His symptoms started approximately 4 hours prior to present. Specifically  he describes slurred speech  sudden numbness  and loss of strength in the left arm and leg. He also reports a paroxysm of headache with no vision changes  seizures  or loss of consciousness. His mother suffered a stroke at an age of 65. Neurological examination confirms left-sided hemiparesis with dysarthria. Emergency head CT scan didn't reveal any signs of intracranial bleeding.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male  known hypertensive and smoker  presents with a sudden onset of severe headache followed by slurred speech  right-sided facial droop  and right-sided weakness for the past 2 hours. Upon assessment  he has altered consciousness  dysarthria and right-sided hemiplegia. His blood pressure is elevated at 180/100 mmHg. There is no past history of diabetes or previous stroke. This clinical scenario suggests an acute ischemic stroke possibly related to uncontrolled hypertension and thromboembolic event from smoking.

Problem Representation:  A 62-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking for the past two hours. The patient’s wife  who accompanied him  mentions her initial observation of his facial droop and the inability to hold onto objects with his right hand  causing frequent drops. The patient also reports experiencing a severe  sudden headache and blurred vision throughout the day. He denies any chest pain  difficulty in breathing or loss of consciousness. He admits to non-compliance with his antihypertensive and antidiabetic medication regimen for the past week. His blood pressure at presentation is 180/110 mmHg  other vitals are stable. No significant family history of stroke or heart disease. His social history includes moderate alcohol consumption and a 30-pack-per-year smoking history. A cursory neurologic examination reveals expressive aphasia  right facial droop and right hemiparesis. Immediate CT scan of the head is ordered to rule out hemorrhagic stroke. This patient's symptoms  risk factors  and clinical findings are highly suggestive of acute ischemic stroke.

Patient is a 68-year-old  right-handed  African-American male  retired teacher  with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  presenting with sudden onset left-sided weakness and slurred speech. He was at his usual state of health until this morning when his wife noticed that he could barely lift his coffee mug with his left hand and was having difficulty articulating his words. There was no preceding headache  seizure  loss of consciousness  or trauma. His wife also reports that he seems confused and having trouble understanding her. These symptoms have been constant since onset. There are no associated symptoms of chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  nausea  or vision changes. He has been adherent to his medications including lisinopril  metformin  and atorvastatin  and has no known drug allergies. He has no previous history of stroke  transient ischemic attacks (TIAs)  or atrial fibrillation. He is a lifelong non-smoker with rare alcohol consumption. Family history is remarkable for a father with a stroke at age 75.

A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a poorly adhered to smoking cessation presents with an acute onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and facial droop that began approximately 2 hours ago. His wife noticed that he suddenly dropped his coffee mug and was unable to get up from his chair. His symptoms are consistent with an acute ischemic stroke  notably he has clear facial asymmetry and right-sided hemiparesis; National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale score is 10. Urgent neuroimaging would be required to confirm the diagnosis and to assess for potential thrombolytic treatment. His poorly controlled blood pressure  diabetes  and continued smoking habit have significantly increased his risk for cerebrovascular diseases. He denies any other associated symptoms such as headache  seizure  or recent trauma. His medications include Lisinopril and Metformin. He has no known allergy.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia presents to the hospital with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in speech for the past 2 hours. The patient's family reports he was seen normal the previous evening but woke up this morning with expressive aphasia. He has a 20-year history of poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension for which he is on medication but has been non-compliant in the last month. He is a former smoker  quit 5 years ago but has a 30 pack-year history. His father suffered a stroke at the age of 65. The patient denies headache  dizziness  fever  or neck stiffness. Physical examination reveals blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg  right-sided facial droop  reduced power of 2/5 in the right upper and lower limbs and expressive aphasia but consciousness is intact. Rest of the systemic examination is unremarkable. An urgent brain imaging is planned to clarify the diagnosis.

A 67-year-old African American male with a medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  is brought to the ER with new onset acute left-sided facial droop  dysarthria  and right arm weakness. Symptoms began approximately 2 hours from presentation when he was found unresponsive by his wife. He denies headache  but admits to a sudden onset of dizziness. His diabetes and hypertension have been poorly controlled due to non-compliance with medicines. He has no history of smoking or alcohol abuse. No previous instances of similar presentation. On physical examination  BP was 190/110 mmHg  decreased sensation  and power on the right side of the face and right upper limb. Rest of fields are normal. These symptoms raise the concern for an acute stroke  most likely ischemic secondary to the patient's significant risk factors.

Problem Representation:  A 70-year-old African-American male with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  presents with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech. He was last seen normal 3 hours prior to his arrival at the hospital. Further physical examination reveals right facial droop and neglect  visual field loss  and reduced sensation to touch on the right side of the body. He denies experiencing any head trauma  seizures  headache or changes in consciousness. There is no history of prior transient ischemic attacks or strokes. He is a non-smoker and lives alone. His medication regimen includes Metformin and Lisinopril  though he admits to non-adherence often. His father died of stroke at the age of 75 years. His blood pressure on presentation is 180/105 mmHg and random blood glucose is 459 mg/dL - indicative of his poorly controlled hypertension and diabetes. Clinical findings are suggestive of an acute left hemispheric ischemic stroke.

A 70-year-old African-American female with a 15-year history of hypertension and dyslipidaemia presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and speech difficulties that started 2 hours prior to her arrival. The patient experienced dizziness  accompanied by severe headache. She denies changes in vision  and loss of consciousness. She has been non-compliant with her antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medications due to financial concerns. She is a former smoker with 30 pack years of smoking history. She consumes alcohol socially and there is a family history of stroke. On examination  she is conscious with a blood pressure of 190/100 mmHg. Neurological examination reveals severe dysarthria  right homonymous hemianopsia  right-sided hemiplegia  and right-sided sensory loss. Her NIH Stroke Scale score is 13  which suggests moderate to severe stroke.

A 65-year-old African American male  known hypertensive and smoker for the last 30 years  presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness  difficulty speaking  and drooping of the right side of the face for the last two hours. There's a notable absence of headache or loss of consciousness. He also has a relevant medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia  both managed with long-term medication. His father had a similar attack at the age of 70. His current symptoms are consistent with sudden neurological loss suggestive of left-sided ischemic stroke.

Patient is a 68-year-old African-American male with past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes mellitus  who presents with new onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech. Patient's symptoms started abruptly 2 hours prior to presentation and was brought in to hospital by his wife who first noticed the symptoms. Symptom developed while the patient was watching TV and did not get better with time. On presentation  the patient's Glasgow Coma Scale score is 15  pupil examination revealed equal and reactive pupils  heart sounds were normal  but the right upper and lower extremity showed noticeable weakness with a NIH stroke scale score of 10. There is no prior history of similar episodes or known allergies. Patient is compliant with his antihypertensive and hypoglycemic medications. He is a non-smoker and doesn't consume alcohol.

A 68-year-old  right-handed  African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus presents with an acute onset of aphasia and right sided hemiparesis (weakness on the right side of the body). He was last seen normal by his wife about 2 hours ago. He does not have a history of any surgical procedures or allergies. He is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol or take illicit substances. His mother had a stroke at the age of 72. On presentation  he is found to have blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg  pulse of 70 bpm  and blood glucose of 150 mg/dL. He appears anxious but is not in acute distress. Neurological exam reveals expressive and receptive aphasia and reduced power in the right upper and lower limbs (3/5) with normal sensation. His gait cannot be assessed due to weakness. Cranial nerves examination is difficult due to aphasia but shows no obvious unilateral facial weakness. Other systemic examination findings are within normal limits. There is an ongoing need to further evaluate these symptoms with an aim towards the diagnosis of an acute ischemic stroke.

Problem Representation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and smoking presents with sudden onset of right-sided body weakness  slurred speech  and facial drooping. She noticed these symptoms on awakening  5 hours prior to presentation. She also reports experiencing a severe  sudden headache. She denies any trauma  fever  vision changes  difficulty swallowing  numbness  or confusion. Her blood pressure on presentation is 185/102 mmHg and glucose level is elevated at 220 mg/dL. Her other vitals are stable. She has B-type natriuretic peptide levels above normal and troponin levels within the normal range. She has no known drug allergies  but her medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Simvastatin. The patient lives alone and is a retired school teacher. Her gait is impaired on physical examination due to right-sided weakness.

Patient is a 72-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes presenting with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and speech impairment. The patient noticed the symptoms upon waking up this morning. He denies headache  visual changes  or any loss of consciousness. He also mentions being noncompliant with his hypertension and diabetes medications for the past few weeks. Vital signs on presentation: Blood Pressure 185/98 mmHg  Heart Rate 88 bpm  Respiratory Rate 18 breaths per minute  Temperature 98.6°F  Oxygen Saturation 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals decreased motor strength (3/5) in the right upper and lower extremities  facial droop on the right side  and slurred speech. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. His baseline functional status prior to today was fully independent in all daily activities. The patient lives with his wife and is a smoker with a 40 pack-year history. He denies alcohol or illicit drug use.

A 65-year-old African American male with a medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 20-year smoking history  presents with a sudden onset of aphasia  right-sided weakness  and facial drooping that started two hours ago. The patient denies any headache  seizure  or trauma. His blood pressure on presentation is 180/95 mmHg  glucose is 250mg/dL and his weight is 100 kg. The patient is currently not on any antiplatelet or anticoagulant therapy.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical model of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with acute onset right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking that began approximately 3 hours ago. The patient also reports a sudden headache  blurred vision  and confusion. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness. He does not smoke  consumes alcohol socially  and has a family history of stroke in his mother. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. He has no known drug allergies. On examination  right-sided facial droop  slurred speech  and hemiparesis are observed  suggesting left hemisphere involvement. His blood pressure is elevated (160/95 mmHg)  blood glucose is 180 mg/dL  and heart rhythm is regular without murmur.

A 68-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes presents with acute onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. He was reportedly normal one hour prior to arrival according to his wife  who also noticed a droop on the right side of his face. He denies headache  chest pain  or shortness of breath. On examination  he has expressive aphasia  right facial droop  and right hemiparesis. His blood pressure is elevated at 160/90 mmHg and blood glucose level is 250 mg/dL. The remaining physical examination findings are normal.

A 72-year-old African-American male presents with an acute onset of right-sided upper and lower limb weakness and facial drooping  with expressive aphasia. He has a medical history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 20-year history of smoking. He reports a sudden onset of symptoms while having breakfast an hour ago. He denies headache  confusion  vision disturbances  or loss of consciousness. He is not on any blood thinners but takes Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin for his chronic conditions. Physical examination shows a blood pressure of 188/94 mmHg  reduced muscle strength (3/5) in right limbs  and positive right facial droop. The sensory system and gait could not be tested due to the patient's condition. There is no pronounced nystagmus  dysmetria  or past-pointing on the left upper limb. The remaining neurological examination is non-contributory.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old  right-handed Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with acute onset of left-sided weakness and slurred speech. She has a significant past medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  both of which are poorly controlled. Smoker of 20 pack-years. The patient's symptoms started suddenly while she was having breakfast. Her family noticed she was having difficulty lifting her left arm and the left side of her mouth was drooping. She also complained of a severe headache and was having pronounced difficulty speaking. The patient denies any trauma  fever  or history of a similar event. Her medications include metformin and lisinopril. She is not allergic to any known drug. On examination  she has a left-sided facial droop  dysarthria  and significant left-sided hemiparesis. Her blood pressure on arrival was elevated. No other immediate neurologic  cardiorespiratory  or abdominal abnormalities were identified. A CT scan of her brain was immediately ordered.

Patient is a 68-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and smoking who presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  difficulty in speech  and facial drooping that started about 2 hours ago while he was watching television at home. Patient also complains of a mild headache but denies chest pain  nausea  vomiting  or loss of consciousness. Patient’s wife confirms that he has been compliant with his antihypertensive medication and oral hypoglycemics  has been smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for past 30 years and has a family history of stroke. The patient's vital signs on arrival are stable with blood pressure slightly elevated. Physical examination reveals a right-sided facial droop  reduced power in the right upper and lower limbs  and slurred speech but is otherwise normal.

A 68-year-old African-American male with a medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in speaking  which his wife noticed approximately 2 hours ago. He denies any associated symptoms such as headache or dizziness but reports a mild intermittent headache for the past week. Upon physical examination  the patient displays drooping of the right side of the face  severe right-sided weakness  and dysarthria. His blood pressure is 160/98 mmHg and his blood sugar level is 180 mg/dL. He has no known allergies and takes lisinopril  metformin and atorvastatin. He quit smoking 5 years ago but has a 20-pack year history. The patient has no previous history of strokes  transient ischemic attacks  or known congenital heart abnormalities.

Patient Information:   Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old right-handed white male  retired engineer.  Medical History:   The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and coronary artery disease. Surgical history includes a coronary artery bypass graft 7 years ago. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years and maintains a sedentary lifestyle. Mr. Doe is adhering to his medicines including Metformin  Atorvastatin  and Lisinopril.  Presenting Complaints:  His primary complaints include sudden onset weakness and numbness on his left side that started approximately 2 hours ago. He experienced sudden difficulty speaking and slurred speech. There is no headache  no visual changes  no difficulty swallowing  no loss of consciousness or seizures. He also noted facial droop on the left side. There is no chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations.   Physical Exam:   On examination  Mr. Doe is alert but shows noticeable facial asymmetry with drooping of his left mouth corner. His speech is slurred but he is oriented to time  place and person. Neurological exam reveals motor power of 2/5 in his left arm and 3/5 in his left leg. Sensation is reduced on his left side. Reflexes are brisk on the affected side. He has a pronounced left-sided neglect. His cardiovascular and respiratory systems are stable and other system examinations are normal.  Summary:  65-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and coronary artery disease presents with acute onset left-sided weakness  numbness  facial droop  and slurred speech suggestive of a cerebrovascular accident/stroke.

A 66-year-old African American male  hypertensive  non-smoker  living an active lifestyle is admitted with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  difficulty in articulating words and a severe headache for the past 6 hours. PMH significant for poorly controlled hypertension and a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation one year ago for which he did not take any prescribed anticoagulant therapy. No other known cardiovascular risk factors or family history of stroke. On presentation  the patient has a blood pressure of 170/100 mmHg. Neurological examination exhibits expressive aphasia  right-sided facial droop  and right-sided hemiparesis (4/5 motor strength). Initial NIH Stroke Scale score of 8. CT brain done instantly shows no signs of intracranial hemorrhage.

A 68-year-old African American male patient with a known history of chronic hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  difficulty speaking  one-sided facial drooping  and severe headache for the preceding two hours. The patient also reports experiencing visual disturbances in his left eye a week prior that quickly resolved on their own. He has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medication for several months. He has no history of stroke or transient ischemic attack. He has no known allergies. Family history is significant for stroke and heart disease. He is a non-smoker and social drinker. The patient's symptoms indicate a potential left hemisphere ischemic stroke.

A 68-year-old African American male with a known medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and facial droop that started approximately 2 hours ago. Besides  he also mentions a sudden severe headache with no known cause. He has been adherent to his antihypertensive and diabetic medications. He has a 10-year history of smoking and significant alcohol consumption. There is no prior history of strokes  transient ischemic attacks  or similar symptoms. His family history is significant for cerebrovascular diseases with his father passing away from a stroke. On examination  he is currently oriented times three  but with expressive aphasia making it difficult to communicate.

A 62-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus presents with an acute onset left-side weakness and speech difficulties. The patient's wife reports that he was normal this morning  but she found him in bed unable to get up and his speech appeared slurred. The patient also complained of headache and severe confusion. He denies history of previous stroke or any cardiopulmonary symptoms. He has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive and insulin therapy for the last few months as per his wife. Vital signs upon arrival show blood pressure of 190/105 mm Hg and a blood glucose level of 330 mg/dL. Neurological examination reveals a moderate left-sided hemiparesis  left-sided facial droop  sensory loss  and dysarthria. He scores a 15 on the NIH Stroke Scale.

Patient is a 68-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  presenting with acute onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech. Symptoms started about 6 hours prior to presentation. The patient also describes a headache of moderate intensity that is persistent since the onset of symptoms. There is no history of trauma  seizure  or loss of consciousness. He has smoked one pack a day for the past 20 years and consumes alcohol occasionally. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide  metformin  and atorvastatin. On physical examination  there is notable right facial droop  motor strength is 2/5 in right upper and lower extremities  and speech is dysarthric. No sensory deficit is found. Neurological exam reveals an NIH stroke scale score of 7. He is afebrile  blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate of 78 beats per minute  and other vitals are stable. No additional abnormal findings are observed in cardiovascular and respiratory examination. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.

Patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  presenting with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech. He was alert and oriented to time  place  and person  but showed signs of right facial droop and motor weakness in his right arm and leg. He reported mild headache but denied any dizziness  confusion  vision changes  seizure activity  or loss of consciousness. His blood glucose on admission was 238 mg/dL. Rest of the system examination was unremarkable. Rapid stroke protocol was initiated due to suspicion of an acute ischemic stroke.

Problem Representation:  Patient: A 68-year-old female   Relevant Medical History: Patient has a 10-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which have been managed with lisinopril and metformin respectively. She is also a smoker with a 30 pack-year history of cigarette use.  Chief Complaint: She presents to the Emergency Department with 3 hours of left-sided weakness and inability to speak clearly.  Examination: On presentation  she appears uncomfortable  aphasic  and frustrated. Her vital signs are normal apart from slight hypertension at 147/88 mmHg. Neurological examination shows expressive aphasia  facial droop  left arm and leg weakness  and impaired fine touch and proprioception on the left side of the body. Balance and coordination are also impaired on the left side.  Summary: The combination of abrupt onset unilateral weakness  expressive aphasia  and hypertension suggests a probable hyperacute ischaemic stroke. The patient’s history of hypertension  diabetes  and smoking promotes her as high risk. Immediate imaging and stroke unit attention are necessary to confirm diagnosis and initiate suitable management.

Problem Representation:  A 67-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  Type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia presents with an acute onset of left-sided face  arm and leg weakness. He also reports associated symptoms of slurred speech  dysphagia  and altered balance over the last 2 hours. The patient's wife  who was his historian  mentioned that he has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive and diabetic medications over the past several weeks. The stroke scale assessment on presentation is consistent with severe symptoms. There is no report of recent trauma  drug use or an ongoing infection. He doesn't smoke or drink alcohol. Urgent neurology consult is sought.

Patient Profile: Mr. Johnson  a 70-year-old African American male  retired civil engineer.  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of left-sided weakness and speech problems.   History of Present Illness: Mr. Johnson's symptoms started 2 hours ago while watching television at home. He has expressive aphasia and reports that he is unable to use his left arm or leg. He also reports mild headache and some visual disturbance.  Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker (quit 10 years ago)  and consumes alcohol in moderation. His medications are Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin.  Family History: His father suffered a stroke at age 75  and his mother has hypertension and diabetes. Siblings are healthy.   Physical Examination: His vital signs are as follows: temperature 98.6°F  heart rate 88 bpm  respiratory rate 16/min  and blood pressure 165/100 mmHg. Neurological exam reveals a right gaze preference  left sided facial droop  decreased sensation on the left side  muscular strength is 2/5 in the left upper and lower extremities  and aphasia. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Brief Assessment: Mr. Johnson  a 70-year-old man with risk factors of hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia presents with sudden onset left-sided weakness  expressive aphasia  and visual disturbance indicative of an acute right-sided ischemic stroke.

Patient is a 72-year-old African American male with a past medical history of poorly controlled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presents with acute onset of right-sided weakness  facial droop  and difficulty speaking which started two hours ago. His wife also noticed a change in his behavior and confusion this morning. On examination  he had a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score of 12. CT scan without contrast of the head showed no acute hemorrhage.

Problem Representation:  Patient Information: A 65-year-old African American male.  Medical History: The patient has a ten-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and Type 2 diabetes. He also has a 20-pack-year smoking history.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with sudden onset of right side weakness and difficulty in speaking  which started two hours ago. His family noticed that he also had a facial droop on the right side. No complaints of headache  dizziness  or vertigo.  Physical examination: Upon examination  the patient has a blood pressure of 165/95 mmHg  and a blood sugar level of 220mg/dl. He demonstrates significant motor weakness of the right upper and lower limbs (power 2/5) and mild dysarthria. A right lower facial droop is also noticeable. Patient does not have any sensory deficits  cerebellar signs  or changes in the level of consciousness.  Given the patient's medical history and presenting complaints  these are symptoms suggestive of an Acute Ischemic Stroke. Immediate medical evaluation including neuroimaging is warranted.

Patient is a 68-year-old African American male presenting with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking noted an hour before  which are new symptoms. His past medical history is notable for well-controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a nonsmoker and takes oral Metformin for his diabetes and Lisinopril for his hypertension. He denies headache  seizures  prior strokes  heart disease  or family history of strokes. On examination  his blood pressure is elevated (160/95 mm Hg)  NIH Stroke Scale is 12. He has right hemiplegia and expressive aphasia  but preserved consciousness. Furthermore  his blood sugar is slightly elevated at 200 mg/dL. His electrocardiogram (EKG) is normal  but initial computed tomography (CT) scan showed evidence of a left middle cerebral artery (MCA) ischemic stroke. The patient's symptoms suggest an acute cerebrovascular accident  likely precipitated by his hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus despite their current treatment.

A 68-year-old African American male with a medical history significant for hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  high cholesterol  and a 20-year pack history of smoking presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and facial dropping noticed by his wife at home. The patient cannot recall when his symptoms commenced. He denies headache  seizures  loss of consciousness  or any other associated symptoms. On physical examination  the patient has noticeable facial asymmetry with drooping of the right side of his face  dysarthria  and significant motor weakness in the right upper and lower extremities. He is currently oriented to person  time  and place and has a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15.

A 68-year old Caucasian male  retired architect with significant medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  presents with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  speech difficulty  and imbalance. He reports he was fine 2 hours ago and upon waking up from a nap  noticed the symptoms. He denies any headache  loss of consciousness  seizures  trauma  fever  and recent infections. Review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. His medication list includes amlodipine  metformin  and atorvastatin. He has a 30-pack year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago  and drinks alcohol occasionally. There is a family history of stroke on his mother's side. Physical examination reveals facial droop on the right side  expressive aphasia  right upper and lower limb weakness  and ataxia. His blood pressure is 170/100 mmHg  pulse is regular  and blood glucose is 210 mg/dL. Currently  the patient is within the window for thrombolytic therapy.

Patient Profile: Mr. Williams  a 68-year-old African American male  retired warehouse worker  married  with two adult children.  Medical History: Patient has a known history of hypertension  for which he has been non-compliant with medication. He also has a 20-year history of smoking  moderate alcohol use  and unhealthy diet  with high cholesterol and obesity. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease - his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Williams presented to the emergency department with sudden onset right-sided weakness  slurred speech and facial droop that started about 2 hours ago whilst watching television. He also reported a headache and dizziness but no loss of consciousness  headache  seizures  or memory loss.  Physical Examination: Examination revealed that he has right-sided hemiparesis (grade 3/5 power)  right facial droop. He is conscious but has expressive aphasia. His BMI is 32. Blood pressure is significantly elevated at 190/100 mmHg.  Conclusion: Mr. Williams' risk factors including age  race  hypertension  smoking  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  family history of cardiovascular disease  and his non-compliance with medication  along with his sudden onset of symptoms suggest a probable ischemic stroke.

Patient Profile: Mr. Clark  a 75-year-old male  retired teacher  nonsmoker  and resident of Omaha  Nebraska.  Medical History: Mr. Clark is hypertensive  been managing it for the last ten years. He also has a history of atrial fibrillation and was prescribed oral anticoagulation. However  there has been inconsistency in medication adherence mainly due to his forgetfulness. His father had a stroke at the age of 80.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Clark was brought to ER by his wife. From the onset  he exhibited a sudden abruptness in speech  weakness and numbness on the right half of his body. His wife informed that he had a severe headache and began to lose balance earlier in the day. Mr. Clark also complained about feeling confused and disoriented.   Additional Information: His BP is 160/95 mmHg on presentation. His Glasgow Coma Scale score is 14  and according to NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS)  he scores an 18  indicating severe stroke. His blood tests show a normal Complete Blood Count (CBC) but an elevated INR. A non-contrast CT scan of his head was obtained immediately  which showed areas of hypodensity in the left middle cerebral artery distribution indicative of an acute ischemic event. The patient's presentation of symptoms  clinical and radiological findings support a diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke.   Plan: Mr. Clark was not a candidate for thrombolysis due to delayed presentation (beyond the 4.5 hours window). The neurology team was consulted for further management including considering endovascular procedures. His anticoagulation medication is held  and neuro checks every hour has been ordered. Physical and occupational therapists will evaluate him for appropriate therapies. Stroke education has been provided to the patient's wife  including the signs and symptoms of stroke and the need for immediate medical attention. Additionally  measures to improve medication adherence have been discussed with the patient's wife. The wife has been advised that a referral to Social Work might be beneficial to explore resources that assist with medication reminding systems and caregiver support programs.

A 72-year-old African-American male with a past medical history notable for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  atrial fibrillation (on warfarin)  and previous transient ischemic attack (TIA) presents to the emergency department with the acute onset of right sided weakness  slurred speech  and facial droop noted by his daughter approximately 2 hours prior to arrival. The patient is a non-smoker  but drinks alcohol socially. He has been taking his medications as per prescription  without any medication change recently. He denies having any chest pain  shortness of breath  or severe headaches. He has no history of stroke in his family. On examination  he is conscious with Glasgow Coma Scale 15/15  blood pressure 170/90 mmHg  pulse regular at 80 beats per minute. Neurologic examination reveals right facial droop  dysarthria  right-sided hemiparesis (motor power: 2/5) and neglect  consistent with a left hemispheric syndrome. No signs of meningeal irritation or hemorrhagic features were present. The patient has no other pertinent physical exam findings. A stat non-contrast head CT is pending.

Patient is an 82-year-old female with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and previous transient ischemic attack (TIA). She is a non-smoker and has a family history of ischemic stroke. Today  the patient presents with sudden onset of left-sided weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty swallowing which occurred around 2 hours prior to arrival at the emergency department. The patient also reports associated symptoms including a sudden severe headache  dizziness and loss of balance. She denies any changes in vision  chest pain  difficulty breathing  or recent trauma or infection. Her home medications include hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. Physical examination shows left-sided facial droop  hemiparesis  and dysarthria. NIHSS score on presentation is 15.

A 67-year-old Hispanic male with a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of left-sided weakness  slurred speech  and facial droop. The patient reported having experienced a severe headache before debilitation. Also  his wife noticed that he was not able to lift his left arm and drag his left foot while walking. He denies any recent trauma  headache  or loss of consciousness. He is currently on lisinopril for hypertension and metformin for diabetes. He admits being noncompliant with his medication for the last two months. He has no known drug allergies. His family history is notable for stroke in his mother at age 72. On examination  he's afebrile  with blood pressure of 180/95 mmHg  heart rate of 95 bpm  and oxygen saturation of 98% in room air. Neurological examination reveals left-sided hemiparesis  left-sided facial droop  and slurred speech. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.

A 66-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  presents with acute onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech lasting for about an hour. Patient also mentions intermittent dizziness  severe headache and trouble walking. Family history is pertinent for stroke in his father. Review of patient’s medication shows he is non-compliant with his hypertensive and diabetic medications. He denies tobacco  alcohol  or drug use. The patient has an established sedentary lifestyle  with a body mass index of 32 which is classified as obesity. Systolic blood pressure on presentation is 180 mmHg. Neurological examination reveals expressive aphasia with right facial droop  right-sided hemiparesis and sensory loss on the right side. JVP is not raised and cardiovascular examination is normal with regular rhythm  no murmurs or abnormal heart sounds. Patient's blood glucose on presentation is 220 mg/dl. All these findings suggest a presumptive diagnosis of left hemispheric cerebrovascular accident  also known as stroke.

A 72-year-old African American man with a past medical history of poorly controlled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and prior tobacco use  presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and facial drooping. He denies experiencing any headache  fever  or recent trauma. On physical examination  he is found to have weakness and decreased sensation on his right side  dysarthria  and rightward gaze preference. His blood pressure is 190/90 mmHg  pulses are regular  and other vitals are within normal limits. An immediate non-contrast CT head is ordered for further assessment.

A 72-year-old Asian female patient presents with acute onset of right-sided weakness and facial droop. She has a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and atrial fibrillation  for which she has been non-compliant with her anticoagulant medication. On examination  she has aphasia  her blood pressure is 180/95 mmHg  a right side facial droop  with right-sided hemiparesis and dysarthria. She has had symptoms for approximately 3 hours without any cessation of symptoms. No history of trauma  headache  or seizure is reported. Her Glasgow Coma Scale score is 14/15. Her current medications include antihypertensives and statins for hyperlipidemia. She reports no known drug allergies  has a 40-year pack history of smoking  and denies alcohol usage.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 30-pack-year smoking history  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and facial drooping for the past two hours. The patient also reports experiencing a severe headache  dizziness  and blurred vision commencing approximately at the same time as the other symptoms. He denies experiencing any similar episodes in the past. The neurological examination reveals decreased motor strength (3/5) on the right side of his body and mild dysarthria. No cognitive deficits were observed. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. The patient's blood pressure was elevated at 165/100 mmHg and blood glucose was 185 mg/dL  fasting. His last normal physical state was reported to be approximately 3 hours ago  based on information from his spouse.

Problem Representation:  A 68-year-old African-American male with medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and an elevated body mass index (BMI)  presents with sudden onset of right-sided facial drooping and right-arm weakness that began in the last two hours. His HR is 78 bpm and his oxygen saturation is 94% on room air.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and type II diabetes presents with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in verbal expression. His medications include Amlodipine for blood pressure control and Metformin for diabetes management. He has 15 pack years of smoking history. Family history is notable for his father  who had a stroke in his 70s.

A 65-year-old African American male presents with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  facial drooping  and slurred speech. His symptoms started around an hour ago. Patient is a 78-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia  presenting with acute onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech that started two hours ago. A 68-year-old African American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia presents with acute onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech. A 67-year-old right-handed African American male with a medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and smoking presents with a sudden onset of speaking difficulties  right side facial droop  and weakness in his right arm for the past 2 hours. Problem Representation:  A 70-year-old African American male with a medical history significant for poorly controlled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset weakness in his right arm and leg  accompanied by difficulty speaking  which started approximately two hours ago. He also reports associated headache and mild confusion. He denies any recent trauma  fever  or eye symptoms. He admits to occasional noncompliance with his antihypertensive medications but insists he regularly takes his antidiabetic medications. His vitals on presentation include BP of 180/100 mmHg  heart rate of 90 bpm  and blood glucose of 250 mg/dL. Neurological examination reveals right-sided hemiparesis with facial droop  dysarthria  and impaired comprehension suggesting a potential left-sided prefrontal cortex stroke.

A 64-year-old African American male with a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-pack-year smoking habit  presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. The patient’s wife  who accompanied him  reported that these symptoms started approximately 2 hours prior to their arrival. His hypertension and hyperlipidemia have been relatively well-controlled on these medications. No known drug allergies. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 170/100 mmHg and a NIH Stroke Scale score of 12. Neurologic examination shows moderate right-sided facial droop  and motor examination reveals moderate right-sided hemiparesis. Speech is slightly slurred but he is still able to follow commands and answer questions accurately.

A 70-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with sudden onset left-sided weakness and slurred speech starting 2 hours ago. He was found with decreased strength in his left arm and leg and reduced sensation to light touch. His speech was garbled and he was unable to correctly name objects presented to him. The onset was sudden and he denies any other symptoms such as confusion  seizure  headache  or loss of consciousness. His vitals were stable with BP of 175/90 mm Hg but a blood sugar level of 300mg/dL. He has not been compliant with his antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications. No history of similar episodes or strokes in the past. The patient has a 40 pack-year smoking history and is a chronic alcohol consumer.

Patient is a 65-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and tobacco use (smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years) who presents with acute onset left-sided weakness  slurring of words and facial droop of 2 hours duration. He has no known history of similar symptoms. He has not used any medications regularly for his hypertension or high cholesterol. There is no family history of stroke or other neurological conditions. His symptoms are consistent with an acute ischemic stroke  possibly secondary to untreated hypertension and history of smoking.

A 72-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes presents with new onset of left-sided hemiplegia  facial drooping  and aphasia. There is no family history of stroke  but there is a history of cardiovascular disease. As per patient's wife  he has been compliant with his medications. On physical examination  he exhibits left upper extremity and lower extremity weakness  left facial droop  and difficulty communicating effectively. Rest of systemic examination is unremarkable. His blood pressure on arrival is elevated (160/90 mmHg). He is currently on oral anti-hypertensives (Lisinopril)  statin (Atorvastatin)  and oral hypoglycemic agent (Metformin). He denies any tobacco use  occasional alcohol consumption  and no illicit drug use. His last normal (baseline) physical status was yesterday evening before he went to sleep. His quick NIH Stroke Scale score is 12.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 67-year-old Caucasian male  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes  for which he has been taking medication.  Presenting Complaint and Relevant Symptoms: The patient presented with a one-hour history of sudden-onset  right-sided weakness  difficulties with coordination  speech slurring  and unilateral facial drooping. Family members also noticed that he has been having problems with understanding their words. He denies any chest pain  palpitations or shortness of breath. The patient has never experienced these symptoms before. He has been consistently adhering to his antihypertensive and diabetes medications. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.  This clinical presentation suggests a possible ischemic stroke  making it necessary to conduct appropriate investigations  including brain imaging  immediately. Due to the patient's known risk factors (hypertension and diabetes)  it is critical to check his blood pressure and glucose levels. Immediate treatment initiation is crucial to limit the extent of brain tissue damage.

A 68-year-old African American female patient with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents at the emergency room with symptoms which started 3 hours prior to presentation. A 65-year-old African-American male with a medical history of long-standing hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking presenting with sudden left-sided weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty walking that started an hour before his arrival to the emergency department. Patient is a 68-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 40-pack-year smoking history who presents with sudden onset of left-sided weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty swallowing. A 72-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  Type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia presents with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and facial droop for last four hours. A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and long-term tobacco use presents with an abrupt onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech that started 2 hours ago. A 75-year-old African American male  hypertensive for the past 20 years with irregular medication compliance and a 30-year history of smoking  presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in speaking that started an hour ago. A 68-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  atrial fibrillation  and hyperlipidemia presents with acute onset of right-sided weakness and expressive aphasia. A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and atrial fibrillation  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. Problem Representation:  A 67-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with an acute onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech. A 65-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension and type II diabetes presents with sudden onset of left-sided weakness  difficulty speaking and facial drooping since the last 2 hours. A 67-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with sudden onset of weakness in the right arm and leg  slurred speech  and drooping of the right side of the face. A 72-year-old African-American male  with a known medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 20-pack-year smoking history  presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech starting an hour prior to arrival. His blood pressure on arrival is 180/95 mmHg. There is no evidence of infection or other systemic illnesses. His EKG  blood glucose  and other routine labs are within normal limits. A 65-year-old  Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with acute onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech. Upon presentation  she experienced a sudden inability to move her right arm and leg coupled with loss of speech  which occurred about two hours ago. Her blood pressure is elevated at 165/100 mmHg and she also has an irregular pulse. She has no known history of similar symptoms. Evaluation with a stroke scale indicated severe symptoms. Her blood glucose level is elevated at 250 mg/dL. She has no allergies and her family history reveals her mother had a stroke at the age of 70. In addition  she is a former smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. This presentation is consistent with acute ischemic stroke.

A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and tobacco use  presents with sudden right-sided facial droop  weakness in right upper and lower limbs  aphasia  and headache which he first noticed upon waking up this morning. He lives alone and doesn't know the exact time of symptom onset. He has no known priors of similar symptoms or any neurological disorders. His BP is 190/110 mmHg  pulse rate is 88 per minute and regular  and random blood sugar level is 300mg/dl. His speech is slurred  and cranial nerve  motor  sensory  and cerebellar testing reveals deficits suggestive of a left acute middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 68-year-old African-American male.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in speech which began about 2 hours prior to presentation.  Medical History: Known hypertensive for the past 10 years  poorly controlled on medication. History of smoking for the past 30 years amounting to 40 pack-years. There is no prior history of similar episodes.  Review of Systems: On thorough questioning  he reported a transient episode of right arm weakness one week back which resolved within a few minutes. No complaints of headache  seizure  facial droop  or vision changes.   Physical Examination: Observed dysarthria and right-sided hemiparesis. Visual fields intact. No facial droop noticed.   Impression: The recent development of acute onset right-sided weakness  difficulty speaking (dysarthria)  and previous transient episode suggests the possibility of acute left-sided ischemic stroke. Further neuroimaging would be necessary to confirm the diagnosis. The history of poorly controlled hypertension and smoking places the patient at risk for this diagnosis.

Patient is a 72-year-old African-American male with a background history of untreated hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and atrial fibrillation  who presented to the ED with acute onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech. Symptoms initiated approximately 3 hours prior to the arrival. The patient also complained of loss of balance and blurred vision. He is a former smoker and has been non-compliant with prescribed oral anticoagulants and blood pressure medications. There is no reported history of similar episodes  head trauma or recent surgeries. Family history includes a father with ischemic stroke. The patient denies headache  fever  neck pain  or seizure-like activity. On examination  he is alert but demonstrates expressive aphasia  right facial droop  right arm drift  and impaired right-sided sensation. His blood pressure is elevated at 186/98 mmHg. The remaining of the examination is unremarkable.

A 62-year-old African-American male  known hypertensive and diabetic but non-compliant with medication  presents with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and facial droop noticed by his family. No history of trauma  headache  or seizures. No history of similar episodes or any genetic history of stroke. His blood pressure is noted to be elevated  and his blood glucose levels are uncontrolled. On neurological examination  large motor deficits in the right upper and lower extremities  sensory deficits in right side  dysarthria  and a right-sided lower facial droop were observed. Given the symptomatology and presentation  patient is suspected of having a left-sided ischemic stroke.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  who presents with acute onset of right-sided weakness  difficulty speaking  and facial drooping. The symptoms started approximately 2 hours ago while the patient was watching television. The patient's wife  who witnessed the onset of symptoms  mentions that the patient was otherwise his usual self earlier that day. On arrival in the emergency department  the blood pressure was noted to be significantly raised on two readings. There is no record of previous stroke or transient ischemic attacks. He is a retired teacher  does not smoke and only drinks alcohol occasionally. He is currently on amlodipine and metformin. Family history reveals both his parents died of stroke in their 70s. Neurological examination confirms the right-sided weakness and aphasia. Brain imaging will be the next step to distinguish between ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke and inform appropriate treatment strategies.

A 68-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension and smoking presents with acute onset of left-sided weakness and slurred speech that started 1.5 hours ago. He has no known allergies but is non-compliant with his prescribed antihypertensive medications due to side affects experienced. On examination  the patient appears conscious but struggles to articulate words. His blood pressure on presentation is 190/100 mmHg  and there is noticeable facial drooping on his left side. He displays considerable weakness in his left arm and leg accompanied by a lack of sensation. He also has difficulty swallowing. No previous stroke episodes or similar neurological deficit episodes were noted in his medical history. The patient denies headache  vision changes  dizziness  chest pain or shortness of breath. The problem is likely an acute ischemic stroke.

Problem Representation:   Patient is a 72-year-old  obese  African American male with a known medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  who presents with acute onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty in maintain balance. His blood pressure on presentation was 180/100 mm Hg  blood sugar 250 mg/dl  has an irregular heartbeat (atrial fibrillation) discerned by physical examination with right-sided facial droop  and National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score was 14  indicating moderate to severe stroke.

Patient Information: A 72-year-old African American male.  Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both poorly controlled. He is a former smoker who quit 15 years ago but has a 25-year smoking history. His father died from a stroke at the age of 78 and his mother was diagnosed with hypertension.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient was found by his daughter lying on the floor  confused  with slurred speech and right-sided weakness. His blood pressure upon arrival was 186/98 mmHg  blood glucose was 189 mg/dL  and his pulse was 88 beats per minute. He denies any headache  dizziness  chest discomfort  or palpitations prior to the event.   Physical Examination: Right side facial droop  right side upper and lower extremity weakness  aphasia.   Assessment: These symptoms suggest an acute left hemisphere ischemic stroke. Given his history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and his family history of stroke  this patient is at an elevated risk for a cerebrovascular event.

A 67-year-old Hispanic male presents himself with acute onset of right-sided weakness and troubles speaking  started around two hours ago. There are no signs of any injuries or trauma. His latest regular medications include Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes. No known allergies are reported.

A 68-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech. He has not been adhering to his blood pressure and diabetes medication for the past few weeks. He denies any history of smoking  excessive alcohol use  or illicit drug use. Blood pressure is elevated at 180/95 mmHg. His blood glucose levels are also elevated. The remainder of his physical examination is unremarkable. His current symptoms of uncontrolled hypertension  uncontrolled diabetes  severe headache  dizziness  right-sided weakness  and dysarthria suggest a possible left-sided ischemic stroke.

A 65-year-old Hispanic female with a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech. She noticed these symptoms when waking up from sleep. She also describes difficulty swallowing  a slight headache  and dizziness. The patient denies any chest pain  palpitations  or shortness of breath. She has a 30 pack year smoking history. Her blood pressure on arrival is 150/90 mmHg  heart rate is 82 bpm  and she has a regular rhythm. Rest of her exam  including cardiac and respiratory findings  are unremarkable. Lordscheince of immediate neuroimaging is requested to confirm suspected left-hemispheric cerebrovascular accident (stroke).

Patient is a 65-year-old Hispanic male with a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus  and a 20-pack year smoking history. He presents with a sudden onset of left-sided weakness  difficulty speaking and facial droop that started earlier this morning. He also reports having blurred vision and a severe headache. Patient Information: A 72-year-old African American male patient.   Medical History: Departed smoker for the past 20 years with a history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia. Patient is adherent to regular anti-hypertensive medication  statin therapy and metformin. No known drug allergies.   Presenting Complaint: Sudden onset of right sided weakness and facial drooping that started two hours prior to presentation.   Symptoms: Patient reports difficulty in speaking and swallowing  loss of balance during an attempt to walk causing a fall with no loss of consciousness  and a severe sudden headache. No reported chest pain  palpitations or dyspnea. His vital signs on presentation are: blood pressure - 200/110 mmHg  heart rate is regular at 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air.   Physical Examination: On examination  patient is found to have right sided facial droop  decreased power in the right upper and lower extremities. No sensory deficit. Right reflexes are diminished with downgoing plantars.  Assessment: The aforementioned clinical findings indicate an acute ischemic stroke  most likely due to uncontrolled hypertension and other existing co-morbidities. An urgent neurology consultation  CT scan for head  and blood tests including complete blood count  blood glucose  were recommended.

A 62-year-old African American male with a significant past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 diabetes presents to the ER with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech and facial droop that started approximately 2 hours ago. The patient's daughter noticed these symptoms when she visited him this morning. Upon evaluation  the patient's speech was noted to be garbled  and he had difficulty comprehending spoken language. He has a substantial decrease in force when moving his right-sided limbs. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness before these symptoms appeared. He also reports a long term smoking history of 20 years. No history of similar symptoms or stroke in his family. Patient's vital signs on presentation are stable but he has slightly elevated blood pressure. His current medications include Metformin  Lisinopril and Atorvastatin.

A 72-year-old African American male with a medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with acute onset of right-side weakness and difficulty in speaking. He also reports a sudden severe headache with no known cause. His wife  who accompanied him  mentioned that he had a brief episode of confusion and agitated behavior earlier this morning. On examination  he has right-sided facial droop  speech is slurred and comprehensible  and his right arm drift is noted. This clinical scenario is suggestive of a cerebrovascular accident  or stroke.

Patient is an 82-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  ex-smoker  with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes. Today  he presents to the emergency department with sudden onset right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking  which started 4 hours ago while he was having dinner. His wife noted he had right facial droop and became increasingly confused. The patient also reported a sudden severe headache. He denied any chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope. The patient does not conform to alcohol or illicit drug use. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. His vitals on arrival show blood pressure of 162/95 mmHg  heart rate of 85 per minute  respiratory rate of 16 per minute  and a temperature of 98.4 degrees Fahrenheit. On physical examination  there is profound motor weakness on the right side of his body and he is unable to repeat a sentence.

A 68-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness  difficulty speaking and facial droop that started 2 hours ago. The patient's family reports that he has not been adherent to his anti-hypertensive and anti-diabetic medications. He has a 40-pack year smoking history and consumes alcohol socially. On physical examination  he demonstrates a right-sided hemiparesis with a National Institutes of Health Stroke Score (NIHSS) of 12. His speech is slurred and he has difficulty finding words. His blood pressure on presentation is 190/110 mmHg and random blood sugar is 250 mg/dl. He has no allergies to medications. The patient is right-handed and retired from his job as a school teacher. There is no family history of stroke.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old African-American male with past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia presents with sudden onset of slurred speech  right-sided facial droop  and right-sided weakness. The patient's wife  who is the primary caregiver  noticed the symptoms approximately 2 hours ago. He denies experiencing headache  nausea  or vomiting. He has been adherent to his prescribed medications: Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. However  he admits to recent poor dietary choices and decreased physical activity. On examination  he shows signs of expressive aphasia. Also noted is a right-sided hemiparesis and a slight drift of the right arm. His blood pressure is slightly elevated at 145/90 mm Hg and blood glucose is 180 mg/dl. He has no prior history of stroke or transient ischemic attack. He is a non-smoker and moderately consumes alcohol. His father died from an ischemic stroke. CT scan shows no hemorrhage. Given the time of onset and clinical presentation  he is possibly suffering from an acute left hemisphere ischemic stroke.

Patient Profile: A 67-year-old African-American male.  Medical History: History of uncontrolled hypertension for 20 years  smoker for 40 years  occasional alcohol drinker  and non-compliant to antihypertensive medications. No other known medical conditions.  Presenting Symptoms: Presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty in swallowing that started an hour ago. No headache  seizure or loss of consciousness reported. He noticed difficulties in buttoning his shirt because of his weak right hand  and his family noticed his slurred speech during a meal.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  patient was confused with speech impairment. Drift of the right arm and decreased strength in right leg was noted. Decreased sensation of the right side of his face and body were noted as well. Rest of the physical exam was unremarkable.  This is suggestive of an Acute Ischemic Stroke  likely due to small vessel disease secondary to longstanding  uncontrolled hypertension. The patient needs immediate stabilization  definitive diagnosis through neuroimaging  and initiation of reperfusion or anticoagulant therapy as appropriate. Regular follow-up and better control of his hypertension are crucial steps in preventing further cerebrovascular events.

Patient is a 65-year-old African-American male  diagnosed with uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia and Type II diabetes  presents with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  difficulty speaking and trouble with balance for the past 2 hours. He denies any recent trauma  travels  chest discomfort  shortness of breath  or any other symptoms. He has a family history of stroke and cardiovascular disease in his father. On physical examination  patient has right facial droop  expressive aphasia  decreased motor strength in the right upper and lower extremity and difficulty in maintaining balance while walking. He showed no signs of fever or tachycardia. His blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg and he had a blood glucose of 225 mg/dL on presentation. A stroke is highly suspected.

A 68-year-old African American male  known hypertensive and diabetic  presents with sudden onset right-sided bodily weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty understanding language for the past 2 hours. He denies experiencing any headache  nausea  or any other neurological symptoms. His past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus (type 2) for the past 10 years  poorly controlled  hypertension for 15 years and past smoking history. He is on metformin  sitagliptin  and lisinopril. His family history reveals a father who died of stroke in his 70s. On physical exam  he exhibits right hemiparesis  facial droop on the right side  and aphasia. No other abnormalities were detected on a comprehensive neurological examination. The rapid onset of these focal neurological symptoms and signs are suggestive of an acute ischemic stroke.

Patient Representation:  A 66-year-old African American male with a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and previous tobacco use presents to the emergency department with altered mental status and unilateral weakness. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  A 68-year-old right-handed Caucasian male  retired engineer  residing in suburbia  presenting with stroke symptoms.  Current Condition:  The patient was brought into the emergency department with sudden onset of slurred speech  right facial droop  and confusion. His son noticed his condition two hours prior to arriving at the hospital  and there was no report of trauma or loss of consciousness.  Medical History:  The patient has a history of high blood pressure  type II diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia with inconsistent medication adherence. He quit smoking 3 years ago after a 30-pack year history  and his alcohol consumption is limited to occasional social drinking. The patient's father died of stroke at the age of 70 and his mother has Alzheimer's disease. His medication list includes metformin  lisinopril  and simvastatin.  The patient had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 5 years ago  from which he completely recovered. He has gained 10 kg in the past year  and his last HbA1c level  six months ago  was 7.8%. On physical examination  the patient is obese (BMI 32.5) with a BP reading of 155/90mm Hg. Lab results show increased levels of LDL and triglycerides. Patient is generally sedentary and follows no specific diet plan.  Psychosocial History:  The patient lives with his wife and reports a happy marriage. His son  who lives nearby  regularly visits them. The patient loves painting landscapes but has lately been neglecting his hobby due to fatigue. His main source of stress is his mother’s declining health.  This representation of a typical patient presenting with a stroke takes into account demographic information  current presentation  medical history  and psychosocial factors that could impact the patient's health. The patient's cardiovascular risk factors and family history suggest a possible genetic predisposition and lifestyle contributors to the strokes. Prompt and effective treatment  followed by aggressive management of these risk factors  may be crucial in preventing further strokes.
