Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: Mr. X is a 68-year-old African-American male who presented to the emergency department in need of immediate medical attention. He lives alone at his residence and has retired from a construction job.  Presenting Problem: The patient is presenting with sudden onset left-sided weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty walking that started 2 hours ago. He has had multiple episodes of confusion and memory loss within this time. There also seems to be a mild degree of facial drooping on the left side.  Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with hypertension 8 years ago and has been managing his high blood pressure with medication. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus for the past five years  which he manages via dietary control and oral hypoglycemic agents  respectively. Mr. X is a former smoker  having stopped 15 years ago  and alcohol consumption is limited to occasional social drinking. He suffered a minor heart attack five years ago for which he underwent coronary angioplasty  and he continues to take daily low-dose aspirin and a statin as per his cardiologist's recommendations. His family history includes his father succumbing to stroke in his early 70s and a brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease.   Lifestyle Factors: Mr. X maintains a sedentary lifestyle. His diet usually includes fast food and he has a high intake of sodium. He reports having irregularly used his home blood pressure monitor  but admits that he has struggled with adherence to his prescribed medication regimen due to perceived side effects. He is socially active with a good support system  but lives alone.   This patient is at high risk for cerebrovascular disease  and the sudden onset of left-sided weakness  slurred speech  and impaired coordination suggests the possibility of an acute ischemic stroke.

His dietary habits have been historically poor  with a high intake of fast food and low intake of fruits and vegetables.  Family History: There is a family history of cardiovascular disease; the patient's father died of a stroke at the age of 75. His mother died of heart disease at the age of 78. He has been previously prescribed medication for both  including a daily regimen of Metformin and Lisinopril. Also  he underwent an appendectomy in his thirties.  Medications: The patient is on ACE inhibitors for hypertension  Metformin for diabetes  and aspirin for the prevention of cardiovascular events. Often  he does not comply with his medication regimen.  Allergies: Patient has a known allergy to Penicillin- skin rash.  Social History: He is a retired engineer  living with his wife  in moderate socioeconomic conditions. He has health insurance. He was a smoker but quit about ten years ago. He drinks alcohol socially  once a week approximately. He does not follow regular exercise habits. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea/vomiting  or loss of consciousness. Lab Findings: No lab tests have been done yet. The patient’s medical history of hypertension and diabetes  known risk factors for stroke  along with his symptoms  support this working diagnosis.  Further Steps: Immediate neuroimaging (CT or MRI) test to confirm type  location  and extent of stroke  followed by appropriate medical or surgical intervention as per the findings. Establish a therapeutic plan to manage the patient's hypertension and diabetes more effectively  including reinforcement on medication adherence and lifestyle modifications.     Notes: The patient’s poor compliance with his hypertension and diabetes medication regime  in conjunction with his poor diet and lifestyle factors  are likely contributing to his current presentation. Problem Representation:  Patient Description:  A 68-year-old African American male  retired construction worker  presents with sudden-onset weakness on the right side of the body  facial droop  slurred speech  headache  and confusion.  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  non-adherence to diabetic medication  chronic untreated hypertension  and 15 pack-years of smoking but quit smoking ten years ago. No previous history of stroke or transient ischemic attacks (TIAs)  but has mild to moderate peripheral artery disease. History of occasional excessive alcohol use.  Family History: Father had a stroke at 71 and mother had hypertension and type 2 diabetes. All three of his siblings have hypertension and one of his two sisters has type 2 diabetes.  Operating factors: Patient reports non-compliance to his prescribed antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications due to financial constraints and occasionally self-medicates with over-the-counter pain medications for chronic arthritis pain. He also has a poor diet high in sodium and fats  and his exercise is limited due to arthritis.  Social and Living Conditions: Lives with his wife in their own home. Has two adult children who live nearby. His wife handles the cooking  but the diet is primarily high in carbohydrates  processed food  and sodium. He drinks socially and has bouts of heavy drinking.  Summary: The above case represents a typical patient with stroke who is a 68-year-old African American male with a significant past medical history of poorly managed type 2 diabetes  hypertension and peripheral artery disease. He is a former smoker  and he occasionally drinks excessively. He is non-compliant with his medications due to financial constraints and has high risk factors such as a poor diet and limited physical activity. His family history of strokes  hypertension and diabetes further increases his risk. This patient’s case includes potentially modifiable risk factors such as adherence to medication  diet  exercise  and alcohol consumption. The non-modifiable risk factors include age  race  gender  and family history.

Physical Examination Findings  - Vital signs: BP 160/90 mmHg  HR 88 bpm  RR 16 bpm  Temp 98.6 F - Alert and oriented  but has difficulty with speech. - Cranial Nerve Examination: Right facial droop  dysarthria. - Motor Examination: Right upper and lower extremity weakness (4/5 power) - Sensory Examination: Intact sensory function bilaterally. - No cardiac murmurs or abnormal lung sounds.  X. Probable Diagnosis - Acute ischemic stroke  XI. Plan of Action  - Immediate CT head without contrast. - Possible thrombolytic therapy pending imaging results. - Consult neurologist and admission to stroke unit. - Optimization of blood pressure control and other related comorbidities.   This data was analyzed  collected  and used to determine the likely diagnosis and plan of action. Management of acute stroke is time-sensitive and requires quick and appropriate management.

Problem Representation:  Patient's Demographics:  - A 65-year-old right-handed male non-smoker  - Retired construction worker - Living alone  two adult offspring  carrier of 2 sickle cell trait  - Insured by Medicare  Presenting Complaint:  - The patient was found at home with slurred speech  right-sided weakness  and difficulty maintaining balance.  Relevant History:  - Has hypertension  poorly controlled with a recent blood pressure recording of 150/90 mmHg. - Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago  controlled with Metformin  recent HbA1c measured at 7%. - History of transient ischemic attack (TIA) approximately 3 years ago  Medication History:  - The patient is on Lisinopril and Metformin.  Family history:  - His father died in his early 60s from an unknown type of stroke. - His mother is alive with well-controlled hypertension.  Clinically:  - On examination  the patient is conscious  mildly aphasic with a National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score of 8. - His right facial droop  right arm weakness  and right leg paralysis are in line with his described symptoms.   Investigation / Lab Findings:  - Glucose is 140 mg/dL (preprandial) - Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows atrial fibrillation. - CT scan of the brain shows a hypodense area within the territory of the left middle cerebral artery - suggesting a recent infarction.  Summary:  An elderly male with a previous history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and a transient ischemic attack who presents with signs of acute onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and a drop in blood pressure is highly suggestive of an acute left middle cerebral artery stroke. His long-term poorly managed hypertension and diabetes  together with his family history of stroke  all contribute to his risk factor profile.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Information: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith. Patient Problem Representation:  A 72-year-old right-handed Caucasian male from an urban city presents with a sudden onset of left-sided weakness and slurred speech. The symptoms started two hours prior to arrival at the emergency department.   Patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus (on metformin)  and hyperlipidemia (on statin therapy). He has been a heavy smoker for the past 30 years and has an occasional alcohol intake. He lives alone and is independent in his activities of daily living. There is no family history of stroke.   On further scrutiny  the patient denies experiencing any similar episodes  vision changes  confusion  chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  or recent history of trauma. He admits to not being compliant with his hypertensive and diabetic medications for the past few weeks.   On physical examination  the patient is afebrile with a blood pressure of 180/95 mmHg and a pulse rate of 90 bpm. Neurological examination reveals left-sided hemiparesis with decreased motor power (3/5) and diminished sensory perception. The rest of the physical examination including cranial nerves  coordination  and gait are normal.   Based on the initial clinical presentation  patient's advanced age  significant past medical history  and lifestyle habits  this clinical scenario is suggestive of an acute ischemic stroke until proven otherwise. The next steps would include confirming the diagnosis with imaging studies such as a CT scan or an MRI and starting the first-line treatment promptly.   Inferring upon the risk factors  it's possible that his non-compliance with antihypertensive and diabetic medications  along with a long history of smoking may be significant contributions to his current presentation.

Problem representation:   A 68-year-old African American male with a known history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 40 pack-year smoking history. The patient has stopped the regular use of antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications for the past few months and has a lack of regular follow-up due to financial constraints. This scenario involves the interplay of multiple factors such as non-compliant with medications  poor diet control  persistent smoking  the absence of regular follow-ups  and a positive family history that could have predisposed the patient to develop stroke symptoms.

Demographic Characterization:  The patient is a 68-year-old male named John Smith. He is Caucasian and lives in the rural Midwest of the United States  specifically in Iowa. He lives with his wife of 40 years and has 3 grown-up children. John is a retired engineer and spends most of his time gardening and fishing. His BMI is elevated at 28.4  and he is a former smoker who quit 10 years ago. He reports moderate alcohol consumption  about 2-3 drinks per week.  Relevant Past Medical History:  1) Hypertension: John has a 10-year history of hypertension  initially diagnosed at age 58. He has been on antihypertensive medications - including an ACE inhibitor and a beta-blocker. His blood pressure has been relatively well-controlled on his current regimen.  2) Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed at age 60  John has type 2 diabetes for which he takes a regimen of metformin. His diabetes is fairly controlled with HbA1C of 7.1%.  3) Hyperlipidemia: He was diagnosed with high cholesterol levels at 56 and has been on statin therapy (atorvastatin 40 mg daily) since then. His lipid profile improved on this therapy  although high-density lipoprotein (HDL) still remains a bit too low.  4) Mild Congestive Heart Failure: John has a history of congestive heart failure diagnosed at 65 years old after he presented with shortness of breath  bilateral foot swelling  and fatigue.  5) Previous TIA: At age 67  John suffered a transient ischemic attack (TIA) but recovered without any permanent neurologic damage.  6) Family History: John's father had a stroke at an early age of 60  and his mother was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.  Current Presentation:  John was brought to the emergency department by his wife after he suddenly developed speech difficulties and weakness on his right side. He also complained of unusually severe headache. These symptoms started about 90 minutes prior to his arrival at the hospital. The clinical suspicion for a stroke is high  therefore he is immediately evaluated by the physician and sent for relevant tests.   This problem representation serves to highlight the key features of John's case and history that can influence his current presentation and likely diagnosis  as well as guide further management steps.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Gender: Male Age: 78 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  former teacher Residence: Lives with his wife in suburban area  Presenting Complaint: Sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in speech. He subscribed to a healthy lifestyle post-retirement with regular walks and a balanced diet.  Clinical Assessment: From his history  it is likely that John has had a stroke. It's especially likely because of his age  his personal history (such as his hypertension  atrial fibrillation  former smoking habit)  and his family history. The symptoms mentioned by him strongly suggest that he has had an ischemic stroke.   Plan: 1. Immediate hospital admission for a comprehensive clinical evaluation. 2. Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history notable for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and tobacco use.  Chief Complaint: The patient arrived at the emergency department presenting with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking that began approximately 2 hours prior.   Medical History:  The patient has had hypertension for the past 20 years that is controlled with medication (Lisinopril). He also has hyperlipidemia for which he takes a statin (Atorvastatin). He has been a half-a-pack per day smoker for the past 40 years. The patient has no known allergies to medications.   Family History:  The patient's father had a stroke at the age of 70 and hypertension. The patient's mother had diabetes and died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 78.  Social History:  The patient is a retired truck driver  who lives with his wife. He is a current smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. He also reports having a sedentary lifestyle.  Review of Systems:  Negative for chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  double vision  difficulty swallowing. Positive for right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking.  Physical Examination:  Alert and oriented x3  but appears anxious. Vital signs are stable. Cranial nerves II-XII are intact. Right upper and lower extremity strength is 3/5; left upper and lower extremity strength is 5/5. Speech is slurred.  Diagnostic Evaluation: The patient will need an urgent CT scan of the head without contrast to evaluate for the possibility of acute ischemic stroke.   Working Diagnosis: Based on the history and physical examination findings  an acute ischemic stroke is suspected. Other differential diagnoses include transient ischemic attack  intracranial hemorrhage  and brain tumor.   Treatment Plan: The patient will be managed with intravenous thrombolytic therapy if CT scan results confirm an ischemic stroke and patient is within the therapeutic window. If the time of onset of symptoms is beyond the therapeutic window  only supportive care and secondary prevention measures will be offered.  Patient Education: Inform patient about factors that increase the risk of stroke  including hypertension  smoking  high cholesterol  lack of physical activity and poor diet. Advise him on necessary lifestyle modifications  such as quitting smoking  reducing alcohol intake  adopting a healthy Diet and engaging in regular physical exercises.

Problem Representation:  Patient Information: The patient is a 67-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Continued follow-up with primary care and neurology specialists will be necessary for appropriate adjustments in his management plan.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 65-year-old  African-American male who is retired  a former smoker  and leads a sedentary lifestyle.   Past Medical History: Hypertension for 15 years  managed with Lisinopril 20mg daily Type II Diabetes Mellitus for 10 years  managed with Metformin 500mg BID Hypercholesterolemia for 15 years  managed with Atorvastatin 20mg daily Previous transient ischemic attack (TIA) 3 years ago  Present Issue: Presented to the hospital with complaints of sudden onset weakness on the right side of the body  slurred speech  and difficulty understanding verbal communications over the past 2 hours. The patient also reported a headache and dizziness.  Risk Factors: Non-modifiable - Age  Race  Male  Previous TIA  Family history of stroke Modifiable - Hypertension  Diabetes type II  Hypercholesterolemia  Sedentary lifestyle  former smoker  Possible Diagnosis: Given the patient's background and the symptoms  the medical provider should consider an ischemic stroke as the primary differential diagnosis. Immediate medical attention with imaging (brain CT or MRI) and specialists input should be sought to confirm diagnosis and determine the appropriate treatment plan. Other differential diagnoses to consider include TIA  migraine  hypoglycemia  and seizure.   Role of Past Medical History: The past medical history of hypertension  diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia contribute to the development of atherosclerosis  which in turn increases the risk of ischemic stroke. His history of previous TIA also makes him more susceptible to future strokes. His former smoking habit  as well as a sedentary lifestyle  further increases his risk. All these comorbid conditions and lifestyle factors need to be taken into account in the overall management plan  both for immediate treatment and for prevention of future strokes.

These symptoms started approximately 2 hours ago.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has had no previous strokes or transient ischemic attacks. He also has a history of chronic smoking for the past 40 years. There is no known allergy history.   Medication History: 1. For hypertension: He's taking Lisinopril 10mg daily. 2. For hyperlipidemia: He's on Simvastatin 40mg daily. 3. For diabetes: He takes Metformin 500mg twice daily. 4. For secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease  he is on Aspirin 81mg once daily.  Familial History: His father had a stroke at age 74 and his mother had hypertension  both are deceased. Problem representation:  A 68-year-old African American male presents to the ER with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty understanding speech which started three hours ago while he was watching TV. He admits to having a headache but denies vision changes  seizures  loss of consciousness  chest pain  dyspnea  or any other symptoms. He also reports having dizziness occasionally in the past but never to this extent.   Patient's medical history reveals a diagnosis of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both being treated with medications for over six years. He is a non-smoker and denies any recreational drug use. His family history is significant for a mother who died from a stroke  and a father who had coronary artery disease. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and low-dose aspirin. He admits to being non-complaint with his medications recently  but he cannot recall the last time he missed the doses.  His blood pressure (BP) is 190/98 on arrival. Neurologic examination reveals expressive aphasia  right facial droop  and decreased strength in the right upper and lower extremities. Sensory examination is intact. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Given his sudden onset of symptoms and risk factors (hypertension  diabetes  family history of stroke  and medication non-compliance)  the most likely diagnosis is acute ischemic stroke. Time since onset of symptoms is critical for this patient's management  and a CT scan should be done immediately to confirm the diagnosis before considering thrombolytic therapy.   This man should be counselled on the importance of lifestyle modification and medication adherence to manage his condition and prevent future strokes  given the strong impact of his modifiable risk factors.

Emergent situation: The patient's symptoms of confusion  headache  difficulty speaking and numbness strongly suggest that he may be experiencing a stroke. Given his past medical history and current symptoms  immediate medical attention is crucial.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: - Demographic Characteristics: A 62-year-old African American male. - Socioeconomic Status: Retired  living alone in a middle-class neighborhood. - Lifestyle: Former smoker  moderate alcohol consumption  no regular exercise. - Diet: High in processed foods and low in fresh fruits and vegetables.  Presenting Complaint: - Primary Complaint: Sudden numbness on the right side of his body  difficulty speaking  and loss of balance.  - Duration of Complaint: Symptoms started approximately 3 hours before presentation to the emergency department.  Relevant Past Medical History: - Diagnosed with high blood pressure at age 52  taking anti-hypertensive medication regularly - History of transient ischemic attack (TIA) at 58 years old - Type II diabetes diagnosed at 55 years old  attempting diet control with limited success - Diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia at 50  on statin therapy - Has a family history of cardiovascular disease; both parents and an older sibling died from heart attacks in their 60s.  Recent Investigations/Tests: - Two years prior  an EKG showed minor abnormalities but nothing impactful according to his cardiologist. - Last lab results from 5 months ago showed elevated blood glucose levels and moderately high cholesterol. - Recent blood pressure checks at home often show readings of 140/90.  Current Medications: - Lisinopril for hypertension - Atorvastatin for hypercholesterolemia - Metformin for type II diabetes   Psychological Factors: - Reported moderate anxiety levels surrounding health  feared another TIA event.  The current symptoms and past medical history suggest that the patient could be experiencing an ischemic stroke  potentially resulting from a combination of uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  hypercholesterolemia  and his history of TIA. Swift diagnosis and prompt treatment are essential in such cases to prevent severe damage and disability.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 68-year-old African-American male patient named Mr. Johnson has presented in the emergency department with acute onset of right-sided weakness  speech problems  and difficulty maintaining balance which started approximately an hour ago.   Demographic Characterization: Mr. Johnson is retired and lives in a suburban area with his wife. Economic status is middle-class and is a non-smoker. His diet mainly consists of southern comfort foods. He is not very physically active and enjoys sitting and watching television.   Relevant Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a significant past medical history which includes type 2 diabetes mellitus that is relatively uncontrolled  hypertension  prior transient ischemic attack (TIA) 5 years ago and hypercholesterolemia. He has a positive family history of stroke as his father had a stroke at the age of 72. He is currently on metformin for diabetes  hydrochlorothiazide and amlodipine for hypertension  and atorvastatin for hypercholesterolemia. He is compliant with his medications.  Problem: The sudden onset of right-sided weakness  speech problems and difficulty maintaining balance are highly suggestive of an acute stroke  specifically given that the past medical history reveal serious risk factors for stroke including poorly controlled diabetes  hypertension  previous TIA  hypercholesterolemia  and family history. Mr. Johnson urgently needs medical intervention corroborated with a clinical examination which typically includes physical and neurological examination  laboratory tests  and imaging for formal diagnosis and treatment planning. Prompt action is pivotal to limit neurological damage and enhance recovery. The patient’s lifestyle  including diet and physical inactivity  should also be addressed as part of long-term management strategy to reduce stroke recurrence.

Patient Information: - Age: 65 years old - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Engineer   Presenting Problems: The patient presents with sudden weakness on the left side of his body  slurred speech  and difficulty in understanding conversation. The onset was sudden and occurred today while he was having breakfast.   Medical History: - Hypertension: The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past ten years and has been on regular medication (amlodipine). - Hyperlipidemia: Patient is on statins for high cholesterol. - Diabetes Type 2: Controlled with the help of oral hypoglycemic agents. - Smoker: The patient has a history of smoking - 10 cigarettes per day for the past 30 years. He quit smoking 2 years ago. - Alcohol: He reports moderate alcohol intake (2-3 drinks during the weekends).    Family History: - His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 72. - His mother had a stroke at the age of 68.  Social History: - He lives with his wife in a suburban area.  - He is a retired engineer and stays mostly sedentary with occasional walks in the neighborhood.  Review of Systems: - Negative for fevers  chills  recent weight change. - Positive for episodes of dizziness and blurred vision over the past week.    On Physical Examination: - BP: 155/90 mmHg  Pulse: 88 bpm  irregular - Neurologic examination reveals: left-sided facial droop  decreased motor strength of the left upper and lower extremities  slurred speech  and orientation to person and place  but not time.   These symptoms suggest that the patient may be suffering from an ischemic stroke  but further diagnostic tests like a CT scan or MRI would be necessary to confirm the diagnosis.

Case Report - Stroke in an Elderly Caucasian Female with Pre-existing Medical Conditions  I. Identifying Information and Demographics  The patient is a 76-year-old Caucasian female  residing in a senior living community in Hartford  Connecticut. She has been living independently post-retirement and is widowed with 2 adult children.  II. Chief Complaint  The patient was brought to the emergency department due to sudden onset of difficulty in speaking  weakness on the right side of her body  and loss of balance with subsequent collapse.  III. Past Medical History  Her medical history includes hypertension for which she has been on antihypertensive medications for the past 15 years  type II diabetes mellitus on oral hypoglycemic agents for 10 years  and hypercholesterolemia treated with statins. She has not had previous strokes  transient ischemic attacks  or heart disease. She does not smoke and her alcohol intake is limited to occasional red wine with dinners. Her maternal grandfather and father both had stroke in their 70s.  IV. Examination and Investigations  Upon arrival  she was conscious but confused  had slurred speech  and right hemiparesis. The Glasgow Coma Scale was 13/15. Her blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg and blood glucose was 286 mg/dl. Other investigations like kidney function  liver function  and electrolytes were within normal limits except mildly raised cholesterol. An immediate CT scan of the brain showed an area of infarction in the left middle cerebral artery territory.  V. Diagnosis  Considering the acute onset of her symptoms  clinical findings  and CT scan results  she was diagnosed with Acute Ischemic Stroke.  VI. Treatment  She was started on intravenous alteplase  as she was within the therapeutic window of 4.5 hours for thrombolysis. Her blood pressure was aggressively managed and her blood glucose was controlled. The patient was started on aspirin after 24 hours of alteplase administration.  VII. Outcome and Follow-Up  The patient showed signs of improvement  with her speech becoming clearer and gaining some power in her right arm and leg. She was referred to a multidisciplinary team for neurorehabilitation. Further modifications to her antihypertensive and diabetic medications were done and she was counselled about adhering to medication  diet control and regular exercise. She was discharged after ten days  by which time she was able to walk with assistance. Long term physiotherapy and regular follow-ups have been scheduled.

Title: Acute Ischemic Stroke in a Diabetic Patient with Prior Hypertension: A Case Report  Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department with symptoms consistent with acute ischemic stroke.  Background: The patient has a known medical history of diabetes and hypertension  which were both diagnosed a decade ago. She is a non-smoker but has an inconsistent exercise regime. The patient is under medications for her diabetes (Metformin 1000mg twice daily) and hypertension (Lisinopril 20mg once daily). The patient also has a family history of stroke  with her mother having had an ischemic stroke at the age of 70.  Clinical Findings: The patient presented with sudden onset of right-sided hemiparesis and slurred speech  which she noticed upon waking from sleep. She had a blood pressure of 159/95 mmHg  pulse of 92 beats/min  and respiratory rate of 20 breaths/min. Her blood glucose levels were elevated at 192 mg/dL. Physical examination found increased muscle tone and decreased strength in her right upper and lower extremities  with a power of 3/5. Her Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was 13 out of 15  losing points for slurred speech and confusion.  Timeline: The patient was admitted to the stroke unit immediately upon arrival at the hospital  given her symptoms and medical history. An emergent CT scan of the head was performed within 60 minutes of arrival  which suggested an acute infarction in the area supplied by the left middle cerebral artery.  Diagnostic Assessment: Necessary laboratory tests were performed including a complete blood count  lipids profile  coagulation profile  renal and liver function tests which showed no co-existing abnormalities. A 12-lead ECG showed left ventricular hypertrophy which is consistent with her long-standing hypertension. A Transthoracic echocardiogram showed no intracardiac thrombus or valvular defects. The patient's NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score was 15  indicating moderate to severe stroke.  Therapeutic Intervention: Upon confirmation of ischemic stroke  the patient was administered intravenous thrombolytic therapy with Alteplase within the golden period of 4.5 hours of onset of symptoms. She was also started on Aspirin 325mg  Atorvastatin 80mg  and her antihypertensive was switched to Amlodipine to ensure better blood pressure control.  Follow up and outcome: With aggressive therapy  her NIHSS score improved to 10 after 24 hours and was down to 5 at 7-day follow-up. She was then considered for a comprehensive rehabilitation programme  and her medications were adjusted before discharge. The patient was counseled on the importance of medication compliance and regular exercise. She was referred to Neurology for outpatient follow-up and to a nutritionist to further optimize her diabetic management.  Patient Perspective: “I never thought it could happen to me. I now recognize the importance of proper control of my sugar levels and blood pressure and am determined to take better care of my health.”  Informed Consent: The patient provided written informed consent for publication of this case.

Patient Profile:  Demographic Information: Name: Edward Richardson Age: 73 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher Address: Somewhere in Arizona  USA  Medical History:  Mr. Richardson has a known medical history of hypertension and was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus five years ago. His records indicate that he has been non-compliant to diet restrictions and medication for these health conditions. Furthermore  it is recorded that he is a former smoker  stating to have quit some 10 years ago. There is no history of alcohol abuse. His family history includes a brother who suffered from a stroke at the age of 70.  Present Condition:  The patient was presented to the Emergency Department after he was found unconscious by his wife at home. Upon examination  the patient was confused and exhibited slurred speech. He also had right-sided hemiparesis and his face appeared to be drooping on the right side.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An immediate CT scan of the brain was ordered which revealed an infarct within the left middle cerebral artery territory. The EKG was normal. Full blood work came back with an HbA1c of 8.5% and an elevated cholesterol level of 230 mg/dL. His blood pressure was recorded as 165/95 mmHg on arrival to the ER.  Treatment and Progress:  Mr. Richardson was immediately treated with intravenous thrombolysis  after which  he was shifted to the Stroke Unit. His blood pressure and blood sugar levels were managed with the necessary medication and he also began a course of statins. Given his dysphagia  initially  a nasogastric tube was used for feeding. He received physiotherapy while at the hospital to help with his hemiparesis.  After 3 weeks of hospitalization  the patient started to show significant improvement. His speech improved  he began to regain strength on the right side of his body  and was able to swallow food normally. His HbA1c was reduced to 7% and his blood pressure was within the normal range. Upon discharge  he was advised to follow a diet recommended by a dietician and to engage in moderate exercise daily. He was prescribed oral antihyperglycemics  antihypertensives  statins  and a daily low-dose aspirin.  Preventative measures against further strokes were discussed with the patient and his wife  including compliance with prescribed medication  diet  exercise  regular check-ups  and to stop smoking completely.    Prognosis:  It is hoped that with strict adherence to lifestyle modifications and medication compliance recommended  the patient's risk of recurrent stroke can be significantly reduced. However  given his age and previous medical history  he remains at a higher risk of another stroke. Regular follow-up visits will be necessary.   This case illustrates the importance of lifestyle changes and the correct management of pre-existing conditions to minimize the risk of stroke.

Patient Information:  Mr. R. Johnson  72 years old Caucasian male  retired engineer  from Elmwood Park  Illinois.  Chief Complaint: Patient was brought to ER via ambulance following a sudden loss of strength in the right half of body and slurring of speech while at home.   Time of Onset: The notable changes in the patient's health were first observed by his wife at around 8.30am on 15th May.  Medical History: The patient has a medical history of hypertension  controlled with medication for the last 10 years. He was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus (DM) 5 years ago which is lipid-controlled. Additionally  he has been on medication for atrial fibrillation for the past 6 years. He had a minor heart attack 2 years ago and has since been on an aspirin regimen. He ceased smoking 20 years ago and consumes alcohol socially. He has an allergy to penicillin; the reaction was a rash. His father passed away due to an unknown cause at 72 and his mother at the age of 82 due to myocardial infarction.  Present Medical Condition: Mr. Johnson presented in the ER with symptoms of right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and confusion. His vitals at the time of admission were: blood pressure - 160/100 mmHg  heart rate - 105 bpm (irregular)  respiratory rate - 18 breaths per minute  temperature - 98.6°F  Body mass index - 29  indicating obesity. A minor abrasion was observed on his right forearm possibly due to falling over after the onset of symptoms. His Glasgow coma scale was 14/15 (E4V4M6).  Diagnostic Assessment: Emergency CT scan of the brain showed signs of an acute left middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke. Blood reports showed elevated glucose levels and HbA1c was 7.5% indicating poor glycemic control. EKG showed atrial fibrillation. Aside from blood glucose  other lab results including lipid profile  kidney function tests  and complete blood count were all within acceptable ranges considering the patient's age and medical history.  Treatment Plan: Initially  treatment with intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) was administered within the appropriate window period. Blood pressure was promptly managed with antihypertensives and blood sugar levels were controlled. The patient was also started on anticoagulants considering his atrial fibrillation. Neurologist consultation was done and a multidisciplinary approach including physiotherapy and occupational therapy was planned for his neurorehabilitation.  Prognosis: His condition remained stable for admission to the Stroke Unit. Prognosis and recovery largely depend on the extent of rehabilitation and management of risk factors  especially his DM and hypertension.  Conclusion: This case report highlights the connection between stroke and common risk factors: age  hypertension  atrial fibrillation  and DM. It underscores the need for effective control of these illnesses to prevent debilitating complications such as strokes. It also underscores the need for emergency medical intervention and early administration of medication in case of acute stroke to improve outcomes.

Patient A.D: An Unusual Presentation of Stroke   Introduction  This case report discusses a 67-year-old Caucasian female who presented with an uncommon manifestation of a stroke.   Patient Information and Clinical Findings  The patient  referred to as Mrs. A.D  is a retired school teacher residing in a suburb of Florida who was previously in good health condition for her age  with a past medical history of controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. There was no history of smoking  alcohol consumption  or illicit drug use. The patient had no known allergies and has been compliant with her medications  which includes daily intake of Hydrochlorothiazide and Atorvastatin.  Mrs. A.D presented to the emergency room with a chief complaint of sudden onset slurred speech  confusion  and noticeable weakness on the right side of her body. The symptoms began while she was gardening that afternoon. Upon her arrival  she was fully conscious but seemed disoriented with slight aphasia.  Diagnostic Assessment   The patient's vitals were within the normal range  apart from mild hypertension with a blood pressure reading of 147/92 mmHg. Laboratory studies showed normal complete blood count  liver function tests  and kidney function tests. Her lipid profile indicated controlled hyperlipidemia. A neurological examination illustrated right-sided hemiparesis and dysarthria. Her National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score was seven at the initial examination.  Computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain was conducted  which revealed an acute ischemic stroke in the left middle cerebral artery territory. Echocardiogram showed no unusual findings or signs of cardiac embolism. Carotid ultrasound reported no significant stenosis in the carotid arteries.  Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was immediately started on an intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA) upon diagnosis confirmation. She was also given a loading dose of aspirin (325mg). She was subsequently admitted to the Stroke Unit for close monitoring.  Follow-Up and Outcomes  The patient showed substantial improvement within 48 hours of admission  with her aphasia and right-sided weakness demonstrating marked reduction. Her NIHSS score reduced to 2 at 48 hours. The coordinated interdisciplinary stroke rehabilitation therapy was initiated  which included physiotherapy and speech therapy.  Mrs. A.D was discharged one week later on aspirin  a statin  and an adjusted antihypertensive medication regime. She was advised to maintain regular follow-ups at a stroke clinic and adhere strictly to her medications.  Conclusion  This case highlights the importance of early recognition and swift treatment of stroke symptoms  even in patients with well-controlled risk factors. Regular follow-ups and adherence to the prescribed medication regimen are vital to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke  and enhance recovery and quality of life after a stroke.

Patient Information:  Mr. Richards is a 64-year-old Caucasian male who resides in the suburban areas of Orlando  Florida. He's a retired mechanical engineer and lives with his wife  who's a retired school teacher. They have two adult children residing in different states.   Chief Complaint:  Mr. Richards presented to the hospital emergency department complaining of an abrupt onset of weakness in the left side of his body  slurred speech  and difficulty swallowing which he noticed when he woke up that morning.  History of Present Illness:  According to his wife  Mr. Richards had been in his usual state of health until recently when they noticed subtle changes in his speech and memory. When they woke up that morning  Mr. Richards was unable to get out of bed on his own and was found drooling with slurred speech. There was no history of trauma  headache  vomiting  loss of consciousness  visual disturbances  or fever.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Richards has a history of hypertension for the past ten years  controlled with Losartan 50mg daily. He has high cholesterol levels for which he is taking Atorvastatin 20mg daily. Furthermore  Mr. Richards was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus five years ago and is managed on Metformin 500mg twice daily. He quit smoking ten years ago and has a 30 pack-year smoking history. He also enjoys a glass of red wine every evening and has no history of drug use.   Family History:  Mr. Richards' father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 72  and his mother had hypertension. His older brother has been diagnosed with Peripheral Artery Disease and his younger sister is a healthy individual.   Physical Examination:  Upon examination  Mr. Richards had a blood pressure reading of 170/100 mmHg  pulse rate of 88 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. He was alert and oriented but had difficulties with his speech. His pupils were equal and reactive. No carotid bruits were noticed.  Neurological examination revealed a facial droop on the left side  with a significant decrease in power (2/5) in the left upper and lower limbs. His gait couldn't be assessed due to weakness. He also exhibited dysarthria and dysphagia with no sensory loss.  Investigations:  Promptly  computed tomography (CT) of his head was done which revealed an infarct in the right middle cerebral artery territory. His blood sugar levels were high  standing at 250mg/dL. Other lab studies  including complete blood count  liver function tests  creatinine  and electrolytes  were all within normal limits.  Diagnosis:  Based on his symptoms  history  physical exam  and the results of his diagnostics  Mr. Richards was diagnosed with an acute ischemic stroke.  Treatment:  Mr. Richards was admitted to the stroke unit and intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator was commenced immediately as per hospital protocol and guidelines. He was started on antiplatelet therapy and his current antihypertensive and diabetes medications were continued.  Prognosis:  Mr. Richards' recovery would depend on the size and location of the stroke  his resilience  and the rehabilitation services he receives.   This case highlights the importance of recognizing the warning signs of stroke immediately and the critical need for efficient and rapid management of this life-threatening emergency. Regular medical monitoring and medication adherence is essential to manage comorbid conditions such as hypertension  diabetes  and high cholesterol levels which put individuals at a higher risk of developing a stroke.

Patient Information:   Mr. Edwards  a 72-year-old Caucasian male patient  presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden-onset severe headache  dizzy spells  and confusion  speaking with slurred speech.  Clinical Presentation:  Patient's initial diagnosis was noted to be a possible stroke. He explained experiencing these troubling symptoms first when he was trying to read a book at his home. His son quickly noticed that the left side of his face was drooping and rushed him to the hospital immediately.   Medical History:  Mr. Edwards is a retired school principal  leading a significantly sedentary lifestyle. He has an established history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which have been managed with medication (metformin for diabetes and lisinopril for hypertension) for the past ten years. He has a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for almost 35 years before quitting 9 years ago. His BMI score upon physical examination was 28  thus classified as overweight. Additionally  he is known to have hypercholesterolemia and atrial fibrillation but has been irregular with his visits to the cardiologist lately.  Family History:  He reported that his parents had longer lifespans with coronary heart disease in his paternal side and maternal side having a history of stroke. His elder brother had suffered from a stroke at the age of 75.   Clinical Findings:  Upon admission to the emergency department  the patient had a blood pressure of 169/95 mmHg  heart rate was irregular at 98 beats per minute  temperature was 37.1 degrees Celsius  and he had an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. The Glasgow Coma Scale rating was 15. A neurological examination discovered a slight dysarthria and left-sided hemiplegia.   Diagnosis:  The patient's symptoms  medical history  clinical examination results  and subsequent computed tomography (CT) scan showing evidence of an infarct in the right middle cerebral artery territory established the diagnosis of an acute ischemic stroke.  Treatment and Outcomes:  Mr. Edwards was managed with thrombolytic therapy promptly after the CT scan confirmed the diagnosis  within the appropriate window period for using such treatment. His diabetes and hypertension were controlled with adjustments to his previous medication regime. He was referred to physiotherapy for early mobilization and rehabilitation following stabilization.   Follow-up:  Mr. Edwards was asked to follow-up after one month. He was educated on stroke symptoms  medication adherence  lifestyle modifications including diet and exercise  and the importance of regular check-ups. Primary prevention measures such as anticoagulant therapy for the atrial fibrillation and statin therapy for the hypercholesterolemia were also emphasized. Recommendations for engaging a dietitian and smoking cessation services were offered.   Prognosis:  Going ahead  consistent management of his comorbidities and a commitment to rehabilitation are crucial to Mr. Edwards preventing stroke recurrence and improving his quality of life. With the patient’s understanding and co-operation to modify lifestyle factors  the prognosis would be seen as cautiously optimistic.

Patient Abstract:  The subject of this case report is a 75-year-old Hispanic male  Mr. X  who has presented himself with an ischemic stroke. He was brought in by his daughter after recognizing the classic symptoms of a stroke: unilateral facial drooping  sudden confusion and slurred speech.   Patient History:  Mr. X is a retired construction worker  lives with his older daughter  and is a widower for the last 10 years. He is a former smoker with a 40 pack-year history and ceased smoking 15 years ago. He does not consume alcohol or use illicit drugs.  Mr. X has a significant medical history. He has been battling hypertension for more than 20 years  managed with Lisinopril. He was also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 10 years ago  managed on Metformin  and hypercholesterolemia being controlled with the help of Atorvastatin. His mother and grandmother both died due to stroke; hence  there is a notable family history of cerebrovascular accidents. He is allergic to Sulfa drugs.  Clinical Findings:  Upon arrival  initial physical assessment disclosed left-sided weakness  slurred speech  and facial drooping. His initial Blood Pressure was 188/92 mmHg  heart rate was 89 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation was 96% in room air. A neurological exam reported a score of 16 on the National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale. Besides that  other systemic examinations were non-contributory.  Laboratory reports showed high blood sugar levels (225mg/dL)  a slightly elevated BUN-Creatinine ratio  and a marginally increased platelet count. An ECG demonstrated sinus rhythm with left ventricular hypertrophy. Urgent CT scan of the brain confirmed a right middle cerebral artery territory ischemic stroke.  Treatment:  After the diagnosis  he was immediately given aspirin and IV tissue Plasminogen Activator (tPA) therapy was started as per the hospital's stroke protocol. He was started on insulin to control the hyperglycemia. Blood pressure was closely monitored  and no active intervention was initially required for hypertension as his symptoms were suggestive of stroke due to thrombotic occlusion  rather than hemorrhage.  Outcome and Follow up:  After 5 days of hospital admission  he was discharged to a rehabilitation service as his condition had stabilized. His Diabetes  Hypertension  and cholesterol are being monitored and optimization of these factors is ordered to minimize the risk of stroke recurrence. It is recommended for Mr. X to join a comprehensive stroke rehabilitation program and he and his family are scheduled for genetics counseling due to his family history.  Conclusion:  Over the course of this report  it has become clear that Mr. X’s lifestyle and medical history played a significant role in his current condition. The underlying hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus could have contributed to his stroke. This emphasizes the importance of the management of these risk factors to prevent stroke. Regular follow-ups and rehabilitation are crucial in his case to enhance recovery and prevent recurrence.

Title: Stroke in a Patient with Uncontrolled Hypertension and Type II Diabetes: A Case Report  Patient Information:  The patient  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department on the morning of February 23rd  2023. He lives with his wife in their family home  is a retired engineer and an active smoker with a 40 pack-year history. The patient denied any alcohol or illicit drug use. His family history is significant  with his father having died of a stroke at age 73  and his mother having suffered from hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).  Clinical Findings:  The patient was brought to the hospital by emergency medical services (EMS) after his wife found him confused and with the right-sided weakness. At the time of presentation  the patient was responsive but disoriented. His speech was slurred  and there was notable weakness and reduced sensation on his right side. The patient’s initial blood pressure was 185/110 mmHg  heart rate was at 88 bpm  respiratory rate was 18 breaths per minute  temperature was 98.1 degrees Fahrenheit and oxygen saturation was 98% at room air.  History of Present Illness:  The patient has a known medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and T2DM  for which he had been prescribed metformin and lisinopril  but admitted to irregular medication use due to financial constraints. The symptoms indicative of neurologic dysfunctions were noticed by his wife on the morning of his presentation at the emergency department  approximately three hours before arrival.  Diagnostic Assessment:  A complete blood count  coagulation profile  kidney function  and cardiac markers were within normal limits except for high glucose levels and further evaluation showed A1C level at 9.2%  suggesting uncontrolled diabetes. An initial non-contrast head CT scan was quickly performed  revealing a left-sided middle cerebral artery (MCA) ischemic stroke.   Therapeutic Interventions:  Following acute stroke protocol  the patient was immediately started on aspirin (325 mg) and high-dose atorvastatin (80 mg). Given the patient's arrival within the window period (3.5 hours from onset of symptoms)  he was eligible for tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) administration  which was subsequently given.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  After tPA administration  the patient was admitted to the stroke unit for further management and observation. An MRI scan on day 2 confirmed the presence of infarct within the territory of the left MCA. Despite this  his neurologic condition improved significantly over the next week  which can be attributed to early thrombolytic therapy. The patient was advised to control his hypertension and diabetes with appropriate medications to prevent any future strokes.  Discussion:  This case underscores the importance of early recognition and treatment of stroke in the setting of significant risk factors such as uncontrolled hypertension and T2DM. It also highlights the need for adequate patient education regarding consistent use of medication in managing chronic conditions to prevent severe consequences  such as a stroke.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   Mr. J. Smith  Male  aged 65 years. He is a retired elementary school teacher presenting as Caucasian. He is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol. He resides in a suburban area with his wife. He doesn’t have any known genetic disorders or familial history of stroke.  Presenting complaints:   The patient was brought into the emergency department (ED) by his wife after he woke up with severe left facial droop and slurred speech. His wife also reported that he had experienced difficulty in moving his left arm and demonstrated unsteady walk.  Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM)  which are poorly controlled due to irregular follow-ups. He has been taking Metformin 500mg twice daily for DM and Losartan 25mg daily for hypertension. Despite the medications  his blood glucose and pressure levels haven't been efficiently managed. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and is being treated with atorvastatin. His other medical history includes a digestive disorder (Gastroesophageal reflux disease  diagnosed 10 years ago).  Clinical Findings:   Clinical examination indicated left hemiparesis  loss of facial muscle tonus on the left side  and difficulties with fine motor skills in the left hand. In addition  slurred speech  difficulty swallowing  and weakness in left arm and leg were noticed. He did not show any signs of cognitive impairment during the initial assessment.  Diagnostic Assessment:   Computed Tomography scan revealed a right middle cerebral artery infarct. Blood investigations suggested elevated glucose and lipid levels. ECG (Electrocardiogram) detected no abnormalities.  Current Condition and Prognosis:   Mr. Smith has been admitted to the Stroke Unit for active monitoring and management. His prognosis is expected to be favorable with intensive physiotherapy  speech therapy  and appropriate changes in diet and medications. Regular consultations with a neurologist and cardiologist are recommended. Medications for DM and hypertension will be reviewed.  Next Steps:   Aggressive management of his hypertension and DM along with support for lifestyle modifications is crucial to mitigate the risk of further strokes. Regular check-ups  diet control  cessation of alcohol  and medication compliance along with the management of hyperlipidemia are recommended.   Conclusion:   This case emphasizes the risk of stroke in patients with uncontrolled hypertension and DM. Effective management and regular follow-up are key in preventing life-threatening complications associated with stroke. Education on the importance of adherence to medication and lifestyle changes is necessary to reduce the risk of stroke recurrence in similar patients.

Patient Profile  Patient Name: [Redacted for Privacy] Gender: Female Age: 72 Race: Caucasian Marital Status: Widow Occupation: Retired Nurse   Presenting to the emergency department  the patient was noted experiencing acute onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking  which began approximately 2 hours prior to her arrival. She expressed that she was previously in her usual state of health  with no recent falls  injuries  illnesses  or changes in her medication regimen.  Past Medical History  The patient's medical history includes hypertension (HTN) and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM)  which are both under control with medications. She does not have a history of cardiac disease. She has never smoked and her alcohol consumption is minimal. She has a history of stroke almost a decade ago but fully recovered with no residual deficits. Her family history is significant for stroke in her father and brother.  Clinical Findings  Upon physical examination  the patient was found to have facial asymmetry with a drooping right corner of the mouth. She scored 3 on the National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) for the right arm and the right leg. Her speech was noted to be slurred but she was oriented to time  place  and person.   Neurologic examination revealed right-sided hemiparesis and decreased sensation along the right side of the body. Patient's pulse was regular  blood pressure was 145/90 mmHg  and oxygen saturation was at 97% on room air. She also had pinpoint pupils bilaterally and a diminished gag reflex.  Treatments and Outcomes  An urgent non-contrast CT of her head was performed  which showed a hyperdense left middle cerebral artery indicative of an acute thrombus. The patient was deemed a candidate for thrombolysis and thrombectomy  and she was promptly treated with intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)  followed by a successful endovascular clot retrieval.  Post-treatment  the patient depicted significant improvement on the NIHSS  reducing to a 1 in her right arm and leg in less than 24 hours. She was admitted to the stroke unit for further management and close neurological observation. After participating in a stroke recovery program  which included physical therapy and occupational therapy  she was transferred to a rehabilitation center.  Conclusion  This case study demonstrates the necessary vigilance and immediate action needed for stroke patients. It also showcases the value of intravenous tPA and endovascular approaches in acute ischemic stroke. The patient showed an excellent response to both interventions and therapy methods  which facilitated her progress towards rehabilitation.

Patient Information and History:  Mr. X  a 65-year-old Caucasian man  was brought into the emergency department by his wife on the afternoon of January 5  2023  presenting with abrupt onset severe headache  confusion  right-sided weakness  and slurred speech that had commenced about two hours before arriving at the hospital. Besides these primary symptoms  his wife also reported that he experienced loss of balance and trouble with walking. The patient was a retired mechanical engineer  living with his wife and was active  performing many of his daily tasks independently.   Mr. X had a significant past medical history. He was a former smoker with a 30-pack per year history but quit ten years ago. He was known to have hypertension for the last 15 years  managed on Amlodipine 5mg daily  but had often been non-compliant with his medications. He also had Type 2 diabetes mellitus  well-controlled with Metformin 500mg twice daily for five years  and the most recent HbA1c was 6.8%  three months ago. There was no known history of cardiac disease or peripheral vascular disease. Neither did he have any known allergies. His father had died from a myocardial infarction at age 68 and his maternal grandfather had suffered a stroke at age 72. He is a moderate drinker but denies any illicit drug use.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  Mr. X was conscious but not oriented to time  place  or person. His Glasgow Coma Scale was 14/15  showing difficulty in obeying commands. His blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg  pulse 89 beats per minute  regular  respiratory rate 20 per minute  and body temperature of 37.2°C. His speech was slurred (dysarthria). Neurological examination indicated right-sided hemiparesis (power 2/5)  right-sided facial droop  and dysphagia. The remaining cranial nerves were normal. Cerebellar signs were present  including inability to perform rapid alternating movements and difficulty with heel-to-shin test.  Diagnostic Assessment:  With the high suspicion of stroke  Mr. X was quickly transferred for a CT scan  which revealed an ischemic stroke in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery. Carotid Doppler ultrasound was also performed and it showed 70% stenosis of the left internal carotid artery.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The clinical manifestations and imaging confirmation of ischemic stroke led to a prompt decision to administer intravenous thrombolytic therapy (Alteplase)  which was started 3 hours post-stroke onset. His hypertension was treated urgently with intravenous labetalol  and subsequently managed with the addition of Lisinopril to his regular antihypertensive medication.  Follow‐up and Outcome:  Following the treatment  Mr. X was admitted to the stroke ward. He showed signs of gradual improvement over the following week. His power on the right side improved (power 4/5)  and his speech became clearer. Rehabilitation therapy was initiated with physiotherapy  speech therapy  and occupational therapy. He was started on long-term antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel) and statins to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke. Upon discharge  he was counseled on the importance of medication compliance and lifestyle modification  including regular exercise  maintaining a healthy diet  and moderate alcohol consumption. In addition  outpatient neurology  physical and rehabilitation medicine  and primary care follow-ups were arranged.  Learning Points:  This case illustrates the importance of prompt recognition and management of stroke to minimize infarct size and maximize recovery. It also serves as a reminder of the critical role of modifiable risk factors  such as hypertension and medication compliance  in the occurrence and management of stroke.

Patient Information:  The patient is a 78-year-old Caucasian male who resides in and is a retired teacher. He is married and living with his wife. His primary language is English  and he does not smoke  drink  or use recreational drugs. The patient has a medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus; both conditions are fairly controlled with prescribed medications. He also has a family history of stroke as his father had one at 76.  Presenting Complaint and Examination Findings:  The patient was admitted to the hospital due to a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and speech difficulties that started about 2 hours before his arrival. On examination  he appeared conscious and oriented  vital signs were stable  pulse: 88/min regular  BP: 160/90 mmHg  Respiratory rate: 16 breaths/min and SpO2: 98% on room air. Neurological examination showed right-sided facial droop  dysarthria  right arm and leg drifting downwards on extended outstretch- indicative of right-sided hemiparesis. He had no sensory loss and visual fields were intact.  Investigations:  A rapid blood glucose test was done immediately to rule out hypoglycemia which was normal. An urgent non-contrast cranial computed tomography (CT) scan was done and showed a left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory infarct. Complete blood count revealed slightly elevated white blood cells (13 000 /cu.mm) and normal hemoglobin and platelet levels. Coagulation profile  including PT  APTT  and INR  were within normal limits. ECG showed normal sinus rhythm and cardiac enzymes were normal. The patient’s cholesterol profile results revealed elevated levels of LDL cholesterol (145 mg/dL) with normal HDL levels.   Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical presentation  examination findings  and imaging results  a conclusion for acute ischemic stroke involving the left middle cerebral artery territory was made.   Management:  The patient was immediately started on IV Alteplase as Thrombolysis  given his presentation was within the time window of 4.5 hours after the onset of symptoms. His blood pressure was managed with IV antihypertensives to maintain it below 180/105 mmHg. An aspirin was started 24 hours after alteplase administration. His diabetes was managed with insulin and diet regulation. LDL was managed with statins.   Condition at Discharge:  After a two-week stay in the hospital  the patient showed significant recovery with decreased right-sided weakness and better-formed speech. He was discharged with prescriptions for low-dose aspirin and statins. Furthermore  referrals to follow up in outpatient rehabilitation services  for physical therapy and speech therapy  were made to aid in his recovery.  Follow-Up:  The patient was scheduled for a follow-up visit with a neurologist in one month to assess his recovery progress and monitor his stroke risk factors. Also  a referral was made to a diabetes specialist and to a dietitian to optimize his diabetic control  diet and to provide education for secondary stroke prevention. Regular follow-up plans every 3 months with the primary care provider and every 6 months with a neurologist were decided for continually monitoring of his condition.

Case Report - Ischemic Stroke  [Patient Initials: H.D.]  Demographics:  H.D. is a 67-year-old Caucasian male. He is retired and lives with his wife. H.D. used to be a regular smoker but quit 12 years back. He occasionally consumes alcohol  mainly during social gatherings. The patient has been dealing with obesity (BMI: 30.3 kg/m2) for over a decade and leads a sedentary lifestyle.  Medical History:  H.D. has a history of hypertension and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 6 years ago. He is currently on oral hypoglycemic agents and antihypertensive medication. H.D. has been fairly stable despite his comorbidities  with regular physician follow-ups every three months. He had no known allergies and no previous surgeries.  Presenting Concerns:  H.D. presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty in speaking  which started approximately 3 hours prior to arrival. There were no associated symptoms such as headache  vomiting  seizures  or loss of consciousness.  Examination Findings:  Physical examination revealed a well-nourished individual with a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg. Neurological examination showed expressive aphasia  left-sided hemiparesis with a power of 3/5  and left-sided neglect. Heart sounds were normal  and chest examination showed no abnormalities. The rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.  Investigations:  Blood tests showed a slightly raised HbA1c at 8.1% and mild elevation in total cholesterol at 204 mg/dl. An urgent non-contrast CT scan of the head showed a hyperdense middle cerebral artery sign  suggesting an acute ischemic stroke. The ECG and chest x-ray findings were normal.  Management and Outcome:  H.D. was managed according to the acute stroke pathway. He was given intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) within the therapeutic window of 4.5 hours. Aspirin was started 24 hours after thrombolysis. Concurrently  H.D.'s diabetes and hypertension were also stringently managed.  Physiotherapy was also initiated for motor recovery. H.D. demonstrated significant improvement in his motor power over a few weeks. Speech and language therapy were beneficial in managing his speech difficulties.  Conclusion:  H.D.'s case represents a typical scenario of an elderly patient with multiple comorbidities  presenting with acute ischemic stroke. It highlights the essential role of rapid identification and management of stroke  along with stringent control of risk factors  to optimize the recovery. Further  it emphasizes the importance of multidisciplinary care in managing post-stroke disabilities.

Patient Description:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  a retired teacher residing in the urban area of New York. He is a known case of Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which have been controlled over the past ten years with medications. He is a nonsmoker and doesn't consume alcohol. He lives with his wife and also has a family history of stroke  with his father and one of his paternal uncles both having experienced an episode in their late 60s.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presented to the emergency department with acute onset right-sided weakness and difficulty in speech that began approximately one hour prior to arrival. He was alert but seemed confused.  Clinical Findings and Concerning Symptoms:  On examination  the patient had a blood pressure of 165/95 mm Hg  pulse rate of 78 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute  with a temperature of 98.6°F. Neurological examination revealed a right-sided hemiplegia and expressive aphasia. His pupils were equal and reactive to light. There were no signs of meningeal irritation. There was no history of recent trauma or infection  chest pain  palpitations  or other symptoms suggestive of a cardiovascular event.  Diagnostic Focus:  As the patient presented with symptoms indicative of a stroke  an emergency CT scan was ordered which showed an infarct in the left middle cerebral artery territory consistent with the symptoms. Due to the rapid presentation to the hospital (<3 hours from the onset of symptoms) and after thorough investigations to rule out bleeding or any contraindications  the patient was considered a candidate for thrombolytic therapy. His blood sugar was slightly elevated and HbA1c confirmed poorly controlled diabetes. ECG did not show any abnormal rhythm.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was administered thrombolysis with IV alteplase as per standard protocol. He was also started on a more rigorous regimen for his blood pressure and blood sugar control. He was further evaluated by physiotherapy and speech therapy. Consults for cardiology  endocrinology  and nutrition were placed.  Follow-up:  The patient's stay at the hospital lasted ten days. He showed improvement in his right-sided motor function and speech. His blood pressure and glycemic control were improving with the new regimen. He was discharged with stringent follow-up plans involving the continuation of medication  regular monitoring of blood pressure and blood glucose  dietary modifications  physiotherapy  and speech therapy.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of rapid identification and treatment in acute stroke cases. At the same time  it underscores the significance of stringent control and management of chronic diseases like hypertension and diabetes  which are established risk factors for stroke. Patient education about their disease  prompt treatment adherence  and regular follow-ups are vital for prevention of such life-threatening episodes.

Case Report: Cerebrovascular Accident (Stroke)   Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old African-American male named Mr. Johnson  currently residing in the downtown area of Washington DC. He is a retired school teacher  an active smoker and his past medical history reports hypertension and atrial fibrillation which he has been inconsistent with medication.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Johnson was brought in by his daughter on March 10  2021  as she noticed sudden onset of aphasia (difficulty in speaking) and right-sided weakness when she visited him in the morning. The patient seemed conscious and alert but had difficulty in understanding and communicating.  Clinical Findings: Initial physical examination revealed the patient was afebrile  blood pressure hypertensive at 170/95 mmHg  heart rate irregularly irregular at 97 bpm  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air. He showed signs of right-sided hemiparesis and expressive aphasia. The rest of the examination - cardiovascular  respiratory  gastrointestinal  and musculoskeletal systems were unremarkable.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  The CT scan of the brain showed a left-sided acute ischemic stroke. Electrocardiogram (EKG) confirmed atrial fibrillation. The lab tests showed slightly raised HbA1c and LDL cholesterol level.   Therapeutic Focus and Assessment: The stroke team was consulted and tPA (tissue plasminogen activator) was given within 3 hours of symptom onset  for thrombolysis. He was admitted to the stroke unit for further management. Subsequent management included anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation  hypertension control  and statin therapy. Speech therapy was initiated for his aphasia. His active smoking status was addressed and cessation counseling provided.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  Gradual improvement was evident in Mr.Johnson's expressive aphasia and right-sided hemiparesis over the course of his stay. After spending 15 days in rehabilitation  he was discharged home on long-term anticoagulation  antihypertensive  and statin therapy  with outpatient physiotherapy and speech therapy continuation advised. His hypertension and atrial fibrillation were better controlled and the family was quite compliant.  Lessons learned:  Stroke risk is considerably higher in patients with atrial fibrillation and hypertension  especially if they are smokers and non-compliant with their medications. Immediate treatment with thrombolytic-therapy can significantly improve the outcome. A multidisciplinary approach is essential in the rehabilitation of stroke patients. Compliance with outpatient follow-up and therapy are also crucial.   Patient Consent:  Informed consent for including relevant clinical information in this case report was given by the patient's daughter.

Patient Case Report: Stroke  I. Introduction:  This case report highlights a 67-year-old African American male who presented with symptoms consistent with stroke.  II. Identification:  The patient is a retired software engineer  known as Mr. B  who resides with his wife in the suburbs of Detroit  Michigan. He is a non-smoker and a social drinker  reports a sedentary lifestyle  and has a BMI of 29. Mr. B has a history of hypertension  type II diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. He has no known allergies and takes Metformin 500mg twice daily  Simvastatin 40mg daily  and Lisinopril 10mg daily.  III. Chief Complaint:  Mr. B's wife brought him to the ER after he suddenly developed difficulty talking  decreased right-side facial movement  and weakness in his right arm and leg. She reported the symptoms started suddenly during breakfast and worsened within the hour  prompting her to bring him to the hospital.  IV. History:  Mr. B's past medical history includes diagnosed hypertension for approximately 20 years  type II diabetes for 10 years  and hyperlipidemia for 15 years. There are no previous hospitalizations or surgeries.   V. Family History:   The patient’s father had a stroke at age 72 and died from complications a few years later. His mother died at age 75 from heart disease. He has one sister who is a type II diabetic.  VI. Clinical Examination:  Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate of 88 beats per minute  temperature 36.8°C. He had dysarthria  right-sided facial palsy  and hemiparesis. His orientation  memory  and other cognitive functions were intact. The Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) was 15.   VII. Investigative Studies:  Initial labs showed elevated blood glucose (280 mg/dL)  high total cholesterol (220 mg/dL)  and HbA1c of 7.9%. A non-contrast CT scan of the head demonstrated a left-middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarction.  ECG did not show any signs of atrial fibrillation or acute ischemic changes.  VIII. Diagnosis:  Mr. B was diagnosed with acute ischemic stroke on a background of uncontrolled hypertension  type II diabetes  and hyperlipidemia.  IX. Treatment:  Mr. B received thrombolytic therapy with intravenous alteplase within the 4.5-hour time window from symptom onset. Later  he was admitted to the stroke unit for further management which included a statin  antiplatelet therapy  insulin regimen for glycemic control  intensified antihypertensive treatment  and physical therapy.  X. Conclusion:  Long-standing hypertension and poorly managed diabetes and hyperlipidemia identified the patient as a stroke risk. Screening and appropriate management of these risk factors are necessary in all patients of this demographic.  XI. Follow-up:  Mr. B was discharged home and referred to the stroke clinic for regular follow-ups and adjustments of his drug regimen. Rehabilitation services  diet counseling  and patient education were also implemented to facilitate his recovery and secondary stroke prevention. Management of lifestyle changes will be crucial in reducing the recurrence of stroke.

Case Report: Acute Ischemic Stroke in a 57 Year-Old Male Patient  Patient Information:   The patient is a 57 year-old Caucasian male  who lives in suburban New Jersey  USA. He is a former smoker with a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been managed effectively with daily medication (Lisinopril 10 mg for hypertension  Atorvastatin 20 mg for hyperlipidemia). The patient is a software engineer by profession and leads a sedentary lifestyle with moderate alcohol consumption.  Presenting Issue:    The patient presented at the emergency department complaining of sudden acute weakness in his left arm and leg and slurred speech. His symptoms started abruptly one hour before he arrived at the ED. There does not seem to be a specific trigger for the symptoms.   Clinical Findings:   Upon emergency examination  the National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) was calculated to be 6 (moderate stroke). He had obvious facial asymmetry with weakness on the left side of the face and body. His speech was slightly slurred. Sensory examination was unremarkable. Gait could not be assessed due to the patient's inability to stand or walk unsupported.  Diagnostic Assessment:   An immediate computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain was performed and revealed an early ischemic change in the right cerebral hemisphere. An electrocardiogram (EKG) and blood tests were performed. EKG showed normal sinus rhythm and blood tests showed an elevated cholesterol level.
