Therapeutic Intervention:   The patient was immediately treated with Alteplase  a recombinant tissue Plasminogen Activator (rtPA) - the standard thrombolytic agent for acute ischemic stroke. Because of the patient’s early presentation to the hospital (within 60 minutes) from onset of symptoms  he qualified for such treatment. His blood pressure was controlled with additional dosages of Lisinopril.   Follow- Up And Outcomes:   The patient was admitted to the stroke unit for further monitoring. Over the next 48 hours  his leg strength improved and his speech became clearer. His dysarthria and hemiplegia continued to improve over the next several days. He was transferred to inpatient rehabilitation on day five post-stroke. After three weeks of rehabilitation  he showed significant motor skills recovery and was discharged home with outpatient physical and speech therapy. His antihypertensive and lipid-lowering therapy was continued and he was also started on antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin 81mg/day).  Patient's Perspective:   The patient is thankful that he received timely medical intervention  and is aware that his lifestyle choices have played a role in his current health condition. He has expressed an eagerness to improve his lifestyle  particularly diet and exercise.  This case highlights the importance of timely intervention in ischemic stroke  along with the continued need for education about disease prevention and lifestyle modifications to mitigate risk factors.

Patient Information  Mr. Edward Ashton is a 62-year-old Caucasian male. He currently resides in Boston  Massachusetts  and is retired from his job as an accountant. He has been married for 37 years and has three adult children. His primary language is English.  Presenting Complaint  The patient was admitted to the emergency department of the hospital with symptoms of acute weakness on his right side  slurred speech  and facial droop. His wife reports that the symptoms had a sudden onset while they were having breakfast at home.  Clinical History  Mr. Ashton has a significant medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes  which have been managed with oral antihypertensives and antidiabetic agents for the last 18 years. He has never smoked but reports that he consumes alcohol socially  maybe two drinks per week. Mr. Ashton admits to living a sedentary lifestyle and lacking a strict dietary regimen.  Investigations  Immediate assessments included an MRI brain scan  which revealed a large left middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarction. He also underwent a Digital Subtraction Angiogram (DSA) that indicated blockage in the left MCA. His blood glucose level measured a high of 245 mg/dL and blood pressure was recorded at 175/95 mmHg on admission. Hemograms  electrocardiogram  lipid profile  and other routine blood investigations were within normal ranges.  Diagnosis  Based on the clinical presentation and imaging studies  Mr. Ashton was diagnosed with an Ischemic stroke.  Treatment Plan  The patient was not eligible for thrombolytic therapy due to the duration of his symptoms before arrival. He was promptly started on broad-spectrum antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin)  statin-based lipid-lowering therapy (Atorvastatin)  and continued on his antihypertensives and antidiabetic medications. In addition  insulin therapy was initiated to better manage his diabetes. The stroke affected his language and motor skills  and therefore he was referred to speech  occupational  and physiotherapies as part of his recovery.  Patient Progress  Mr. Ashton remained in the hospital for a week and was discharged once his vital signs and blood glucose levels were stable. He was given a follow-up appointment with a stroke specialist for further consultation and management.  Prognosis  The patient's overall prognosis depends primarily on his commitment to managing his lifestyle  namely adopting a more active lifestyle and diet overhaul under professional guidance. His risk of recurrent stroke  as with many stroke survivors  will depend on how well he adheres to his prescribed medications and lifestyle modifications.  This case highlights the importance of timely management of risk factors (hypertension and diabetes) and swift action during signs of stroke to hopefully prevent or mitigate consequences.

Case Report: Stroke in a 68-year-old Female Patient   Patient Information  The patient  Ms. J  is a 68-year-old Caucasian woman living in a suburban community in Miami  Florida  who is retired and lives alone. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia; both conditions have been managed with appropriate medication. She stopped smoking more than 10 years ago but has a smoking history of 25 pack-years. She has a moderate daily alcohol consumption of 1-2 units. Besides hypertension and hyperlipidemia  her medical history also includes osteoarthritis and type II diabetes mellitus. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease in her late father  who died of myocardial infarction at the age of 76.  Presenting Complaint  Ms. J was found disoriented and confused at her home by her neighbor  who then contacted emergency services. Upon EMS arrival  the patient was conscious with slurred speech and right-sided weakness (hemiplegia). It was also noted that the patient was not able to communicate verbally  while comprehension was comparatively preserved  consistent with expressive aphasia.  Clinical Findings  Upon assessment in the Emergency Department  her blood pressure was elevated at 170/95 mmHg. A CT scan of her brain confirmed an ischemic stroke in the distribution of the left middle cerebral artery. Electrocardiogram (ECG) indicating sinus rhythm. Routine blood work revealed elevated HbA1c and hyperlipidemia. Her Body Mass Index (BMI) was found to be 33  indicating Grade I obesity.  Treatment   The patient was admitted to the stroke unit. As per the American Stroke Association guidelines  tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA) was not administered due to delays in accessing care. She was consequently started on aspirin 300mg daily  a statin  and an increase in her antihypertensive medication was advised. A physiotherapy and speech therapy program was initiated in conjunction to aid recovery.  Outcome and Follow-Up  Following an initial period of rehab and treatment  the patient demonstrated some mild improvements in motor strength (grade 4/5) and slightly better verbal output  although the expressive aphasia improvement was slow. She was kept in rehab for another three weeks where she continued to improve moderately. Medications were regularly reviewed and adjusted to provide best possible care  and the patient was also advised about lifestyle modifications like smoking cessation  weight reduction  dietary modifications  and regular exercise.  Ms. J will continue having regular follow-ups with her primary care provider and rehabilitation team.  Learning Points   Given the patient's history of multiple modifiable risk factors like hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type II diabetes  and obesity  this case emphasizes the significance of adequate control and management of these conditions to prevent vascular events such as a stroke. It also highlights the need to educate patients about recognizing the early signs of stroke and the importance of seeking immediate medical aid.

Patient Profile Report  I. Demographic Information  Patient ID: 82952LB Name: Mr. Johnson  Age: 62 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: African-American Marital Status: Married Occupation: Retired  II. Initial Presentation  Mr. Johnson presented at the emergency department of Hospital ABC on the morning of August 8  with sudden onset of left-sided weakness  dysarthria  and facial droop. Noted by his wife who was with him at the time.  III. Past Medical History  Mr. Johnson has a known history of essential hypertension  controlled Type II Diabetes Mellitus  and hyperlipidemia for which he has regularly taken antihypertensives  metformin  and statins respectively for the past 8 years. He has a 20-year history of tobacco use but quit smoking about 10 years ago  and a social history of alcohol use. Previous medical record showed no known allergies to any medications.  There was no previous history of stroke or transient ischemic attack  and no family history of stroke. There was  however  a family history of Type II Diabetes and Hypertension.  IV. Assessment & Further Examination   On an initial neurological examination  a significant left-sided weakness was noted  and the patient was unable to lift his left arm or leg against gravity. The face was asymmetrical due to left facial weakness as well as sensory loss on left side when tested. Dysarthria was noticed. Patient's Glasgow Coma Scale score was 15/15.  This clearly showed evidence of a right-sided brain lesion  indicating a possible stroke. The patient had a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score of 14  which signified a high probability of significant morbidity and potential mortality.  V. Diagnostic Procedures  An immediate non-contrast computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain was ordered  which revealed a large area of decreased attenuation in the right hemisphere. This result  along with his clinical presentation  confirmed the diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke. The electrocardiogram  as well as the basic metabolic panel  were within normal parameters. The lipid profile showed elevated levels of low-density lipoproteins (LDL).  VI. Conclusion  Mr. Johnson  a 62-year-old retired African-American male with a history of hypertension  controlled diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and a history of tobacco and alcohol use  presented with an acute onset of symptoms indicative of a stroke  with a CT scan confirming a diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke in the right hemisphere. The case calls for an aggressive treatment approach  as well as lifestyle modification counseling upon stabilization and discharge.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mrs. Sarah Max Age: 69  Gender: Female Ethnicity: Asian Occupation: Retired teacher  Presenting Complaint:  Mrs. Max presented at the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. She had also experienced a temporary loss of vision in her right eye that morning.  Medical History: Mrs. Max is a non-smoker with a medical history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Her diabetes has been well-controlled through regular insulin injections and diet. She has hypertension for last 15 years managed by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. She is regularly monitored by her general practitioner for her chronic conditions. She does not drink alcohol. Her family history reveals that her mother had a stroke at an age similar to her own.  Examination: Her blood pressure was 155/95 mmHg  heart rate 88 per minute  respiratory rate 18 per minute  and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Mrs. Max was conscious and alert but had pronounced dysarthria. Neurological examination revealed right-sided homonymous hemianopia  right facial droop  and right-sided hemiparesis (power grade 3 out of 5). Her Glasgow Coma Scale was 15 out of 15.   Investigations: CT (computerized tomography) scan showed an ischemic stroke in the left middle cerebral artery territory. Her blood investigations revealed high sugar levels and slightly elevated cholesterol. Carotid Doppler showed 70% stenosis in her left internal carotid artery. Electrocardiogram and echocardiography were normal.  Management: Mrs. Max was diagnosed with an ischemic stroke. She was managed with intravenous thrombolysis using recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (r-tPA) within the therapeutic window. Her hypertension and hyperglycemia were addressed with intensified therapy.  Outcome: Her symptoms began to improve within 48 hours. After five days in the hospital  she was discharged to a rehabilitation facility with improved right-sided strength and speech. She will continue to be monitored by the general practitioner and neurologist  with regular scheduled visits for physiotherapy  occupational therapy  and speech therapy.  Discussion: Mrs. Max’s case illustrates the importance of rapid identification and management of stroke. Her prognosis has been favorable due to prompt management and the ongoing managing of her diabetes and hypertension. Her rehabilitation will focus on regaining her physical abilities and managing her underlying risk factors.

Patient Information:  A 68-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Case presentation: The patient arrived at the emergency department with symptoms of a clumsy right hand  weakness in the right arm and leg  and slurred speech which started suddenly approximately two hours earlier while watching television. He was brought to the emergency department by his wife. The patient’s past medical history includes hypertension for the past ten years  and controlled diabetes for the past seven years. He was adherent to treatment regimen and has regular follow-ups at the local clinic. He has no history of stroke or TIA  possesses a two-year-old history of ischemic heart disease. His family history reveals that his father experienced a stroke at the age of 72. He quit smoking ten years ago  but during his active smoking years  he smoked approximately one packet of cigarettes per day. He drinks moderately and does not use illicit drugs.  Clinical findings: On initial examination  the patient appeared to be in moderate distress. His vitals upon admission were blood pressure of 180/95mm Hg  heart rate 78 bpm  respiration rate 20 breaths/min  oxygen saturation 95% on room air  and temperature of 36.8°C. Neurological examination revealed dysarthria and right facial droop. Motor strength was 4/5 in the right upper and lower extremities and 5/5 in the left upper and lower extremities.  Timeline: The patient was taken for urgent computerized tomography (CT) of the head. The CT scan revealed a left MCA (middle cerebral artery) infarct. He was evaluated for thrombolytic therapy  but was excluded due to his initial high blood pressure reading.  Diagnostic assessment: Based on the patient's clinical presentation and CT scan  an acute ischemic stroke was diagnosed.  Therapeutic intervention: The patient received aspirin  was started on blood pressure treatment with Labetalol  had his diabetes management adjusted  and was set for physical therapy for weakness on the right side  occupational therapy for hand coordination issues and speech therapy for dysarthria.   Outcome and follow-up: The patient’s hospital course was uneventful and he showed signs of improvement. After a week in the hospital  he was discharged home with rehabilitation services for physical  occupational and speech therapy. Upon outpatient follow-up  his right-sided weakness and dysarthria had greatly improved. His blood pressure was controlled  and he was advised to continue medication  regular clinic follow-ups and physical therapy.  Patient consent: Informed consent was obtained from the participant included in this study.  Conclusion: This is a standard case presentation of a 68-year-old male with a conventional risk factor (hypertension and diabetes) presenting with acute ischemic stroke and improved considerably with management. This case underscores the importance of immediate evaluation and treatment in stroke patients to improve their outcomes and reduce the incidence of long-term disability. Regular follow up  continued medication(for hypertension and diabetes)  and physical therapy are essential for the further improvement of the patient’s condition.

Patient Profile:  Patient Initials: T.J. Age: 74 years old Race: Caucasian Gender: Male Occupation: Retired teacher Residency: Urban  Presenting complaints:  The patient  T.J.  has been brought to the emergency department presenting with sudden onset of facial drooping on the right side  right-sided weakness  and difficulty speaking  which began approximately 2 hours prior to arrival.  Medical History:  T.J. is a known case of type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension for the previous 15 years  which have been partially controlled with Metformin 500 mg twice daily and Lisinopril 10mg daily. He had a history of dyslipidemia as well and was prescribed statins which he has been non-adherent with. There is no history of stroke or any other neurological disorders in the past  and there are no known drug allergies. No notable surgical history was reported.  Family history revealed both his parents had a history of hypertension. His father had a heart attack at the age of 63 and his mother had a stroke at the age of 72.  T.J is a former smoker and quit smoking 20 years ago. He has a past history of moderate alcohol consumption but stopped 5 years ago. He does not undertake regular physical activity and follows a mostly sedentary lifestyle.  Pertinent Findings:  On examination  T.J. appeared conscious but anxious. Vital signs were recorded as BP - 160/90 mmHg  Pulse -85/min. irregular  Respiratory rate -16/min  Temperature- 37°C  and SpO2 - 97% on room air. Physically  he was overweight with a BMI of 27.  Neurologically  there was evidence of facial drooping on the right side  motor power was 2/5 in the right upper and lower limbs  normal power on the left side of the body. Speech was slurred. The rest of the systemic examination did not reveal any abnormal findings.  Marcinski score was calculated to be 12.  Plan:  A CT scan was done immediately that showed an area of hypodensity in the left middle cerebral artery region  suggestive of an ischemic stroke. Lab results highlighted an elevated fasting blood sugar level and lipid profile. The EKG showed signs of left ventricular hypertrophy but no acute changes.  Management:  T.J. met the criteria for the administration of intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)  which was given immediately. His blood pressure was managed with additional anti-hypertensive agents. His hyperglycemia was managed with insulin.   Follow-up and Prognosis:   T.J. will be closely monitored in the stroke unit. He will be scheduled for an MRI to further assess the extent of his stroke. Following stabilization and recovery  T.J. will be referred for rehabilitative therapy  including physical and speech therapy  as needed.   Education on lifestyle modifications including dietary habits  importance of physical activity  adherence to medication especially statins  and regular monitoring of blood pressure and glucose will be emphasized. Long-term management will involve managing his diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia with appropriate therapeutic interventions.   The prognosis will depend significantly on T.J.'s response to physical and speech therapy  and control of comorbid conditions. Early intervention and strict control of diabetes and hypertension can lead to a better prognosis.

Patient Description:  Ms. S.F.  a 70-year-old Caucasian female  was admitted to the facility following an acute ischemic stroke. She had a medical background notable for hypertension  Type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypercholesterolemia.  Clinical Findings:  The patient experienced sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking that started less than 24 hours prior to her admission. On arrival  her blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate 78 bpm  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 96% on room air. Her neurological examination revealed a moderate left hemiparesis  left facial drooping  dysarthria  and left-side neglect. The patient's National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score was 13.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  An immediate non-contrast CT scan of the brain showed no hemorrhage or established infarction. Subsequent MRI confirmed an acute right middle cerebral artery territory infarct. Carotid Doppler ultrasound identified a severe right internal carotid artery stenosis at the bifurcation. Blood tests revealed elevated blood glucose levels and a low-density lipoprotein cholesterol level of 140 mg/dL.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment:  Intravenous alteplase therapy was administered within 4 hours of the symptom onset. The patient's hypertension was initially managed with IV labetalol and later transitioned to oral medications. Glycemic control was achieved with insulin. High potency statin therapy was initiated to manage her hypercholesterolemia. After a week of medical stabilization and monitoring  the patient subsequently underwent a successful right carotid endarterectomy.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  Following her surgery  Ms. S.F. was enrolled in a robust rehabilitation program including physical therapy  occupational therapy  and speech and language therapy. A 4-week follow-up showed a significant improvement in her speech and strength on the left side. Her NIHSS score reduced to 3. Her blood pressure and glucose levels were well controlled  and her lipid profile showed significant improvement.  Patient Perspective:  Throughout her course of treatment  Ms. S.F. showed determination and positive spirits. She expressed relief and satisfaction with the noticeable improvement in her health and wellbeing.  Lessons Learned:  This patient’s case signifies the importance of quick recognition and rapid management of stroke cases  and the crucial role of rehabilitation in mitigating stroke-associated disabilities. It stresses the need for efficient management of underlying risk factors  like hypertension  diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia  in preventing stroke recurrence.

Patient Profile: Patient Mr. J.M. is a 67-year-old male residing in Queens  New York. A retired bus driver  he lives with his wife and has three adult children. He has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which  he has been irregular on medication.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. J.M. was brought to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in speaking which started while he was in the washroom early in the morning. It is reported that Mr. JM has not experienced any similar events in the past.  Clinical Findings: Upon evaluation  the patient seemed mildly distressed. Preliminary neurological examination revealed right hemiparesis and expressive dysphasia  while other systems did not reveal any abnormality. His blood pressure was noted to be 160/100 mmHg. Orientation to time  place  and person was intact.   Diagnostic Assessment and Intervention: An immediate non-contrast CT brain was done  which revealed an infarct in the left middle cerebral artery territory  consistent with acute ischemic stroke. His blood work including complete blood count  liver function test  kidney function test  sugar level  electrolytes were all within normal limits. His lipid profile revealed increased levels of LDL. ECG showed left ventricular hypertrophy  and echocardiography showed no abnormalities.  The patient was admitted to the stroke unit  where intravenous thrombolysis could not be initiated due to the time window. He was started on antiplatelets  statins  and antihypertensives. His hypertension and hyperlipidemia management were readjusted and he was plans made to monitor him regularly to ensure compliance. A multi-pronged rehabilitation program involving physiotherapy  occupational therapy  and speech therapy was initiated efficiently.  Discussion: The case presented is a typical example of an ischemic stroke secondary to uncontrolled hypertension and dyslipidemia. The situation underscores the importance of regular medication intake in patients with hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The absence of any previous similar event also highlights the sudden onset nature of strokes and the need for immediate medical attention.  Diagnosis: Acute Ischemic Stroke secondary to uncontrolled Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia.  Patient Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this case report.

Patient Details:   Name: GR (full name not disclosed for privacy) Gender: Female Age: 60 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Teacher  Presenting Complaint:  Patient GR  a 60-year-old retired teacher  presented with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  slurred speech and a sudden  severe headache. She was brought to the hospital by her daughter who noticed these symptoms.  Past Medical History:  She is known to have hypertension and type II Diabetes Mellitus for which she was on oral antihypertensive drugs and metformin respectively. She was compliant with her medications and regularly visiting her family physician for follow-up. There was no history of smoking or alcohol consumption. She doesn’t have any known drug allergies. She was otherwise leading an active life with regular morning walks and yoga practice.  Family History:  Her parents died in their late eighties and had a history of hypertension. Her elder brother died due to a stroke in his sixties.   Presenting Issue:  Her initial Blood Pressure was 160/100 mmHg  Heart rate was 90 bpm  random blood sugar was 210 mg/dl. Her physical examination revealed right hemiparesis and expressive dysphasia. Gaze was deviated towards the left. There was no sign of any external injury or trauma.   Investigation:  Immediate Non-Contrast CT scan of the brain was performed which revealed a hypodensity involving left middle cerebral artery territory suggestive of an acute ischemic stroke.   Management and Outcome:  She was started on intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA) within the therapeutic window  following the standards of acute ischemic stroke management. Simultaneously The National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score was 14 on admission indicating moderate severity.  Her blood pressure and glucose levels were effectively managed. Physical therapy was initiated once her vitals stabilized. During her hospital stay  she showed gradual improvement  with her right-side strength improving slightly and her speech becoming clearer.  She received tailored rehabilitation  including physiotherapy  occupational therapy  and speech therapy for the duration of her hospital stay. Her treatment is likely to continue on an outpatient basis. Before discharge  her family was educated about the importance of medication adherence  dietary modification  and lifestyle changes.   Conclusion:  The case demonstrates the crucial role of immediate medical attention  swift diagnosis  and early initiation of therapy in the outcome of ischemic stroke patients.

Patient Profile:  Name: Ms. K Age: 65 years old Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired School Teacher  Presenting Complaint: Ms. K was brought to the emergency department presenting with a sudden loss of strength and numbness in her right arm and leg  trouble speaking and understanding speech  drooping of the right side of her face  severe headache  dizziness  and disturbed balance.  Medical History: Ms. K has a significant past medical history including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type II diabetes mellitus  and atrial fibrillation. She had been relatively well-controlled on a regimen of medications including metformin  warfarin  losartan  and atorvastatin. She has no known allergies to medication.  She is a former smoker with a history of 20 pack-years but quit 15 years ago. She occasionally consumes alcohol with no reported history of substance misuse. No history of inherited diseases is present in the family. She is widowed and lives alone with her pet dog.   Clinical Findings and Investigations: On examination  Ms K had an elevated blood pressure at 160/95mmHg  irregularly irregular heart rhythm  and other signs consistent with right-sided hemiplegia. Her Glasgow Coma Scale was scored at 14/15. Neurological assessment found a reduction in power in the right arm and leg (3/5). Speech was slurred although comprehension appeared intact.  The patient underwent computed tomography (CT) of the brain  which revealed an occlusion in the middle cerebral artery indicative of an ischemic stroke. In addition  electrocardiogram indicated atrial fibrillation  and blood analysis showed elevated blood glucose and cholesterol levels.  Management and Outcome: Ms K was immediately administered intravenous thrombolysis (alteplase) within the accepted 3-hour window after the onset of symptoms  and subsequently transferred to the stroke unit. She was monitored closely for signs of aggressive blood pressure lowering and changes in neurological function.  Her anticoagulation therapy was reviewed since she had been taking warfarin but still developed a stroke. Her diabetes and hyperlipidaemia management strategies were also reconsidered.  Ms K required rehabilitation including physical  occupational and speech therapies. She made reasonable progress over subsequent weeks with some residual right-sided weakness. Upon discharge  adjustment of her home situation was necessary due to her mobility limitations and her family was engaged to help ensure continued therapy and care.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the complexity of managing stroke in a patient with several comorbidities. It underscores the urgency of implementing prompt intervention upon recognition of stroke symptoms and the need for continual adjustments in the management of chronic disease in patients who have suffered a stroke.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Jones  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  currently living in Seattle  Washington  USA.  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of severe headache and difficulty speaking.  History of Present Illness: The patient reports experiencing a sudden  severe headache followed by difficulty in speaking while watching television at home. Upon arrival at the hospital  the patient also exhibited confusion and drooping facial features on the right side. He denies any history of severe headaches  seizures or transient ischemic attacks (TIAs).  Past Medical History: Mr. Jones was previously diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been managing both conditions with medications namely lisinopril and metformin respectively. The patient is a former smoker but quit 15 years ago and has a 20 pack-year smoking history. No history of alcohol or substance abuse.   Family History: The patient's mother suffered from a stroke at age 77  and his father died of a myocardial infarction at age 70.   Examination: Upon examination  the patient appeared alert but anxious. His vital statistics were within normal range: Blood pressure – 140/85 mmHg  pulse – 80 beats per minute  temperature – 98.6 F  and respiration - 16 breaths per minute. Neurological examination revealed expressive aphasia and hemiparesis of his right arm and leg.  Investigation: A CT scan of the brain was immediately ordered  which revealed an acute ischemic stroke in the middle cerebral artery territory on the left side. Blood tests showed elevated glucose levels and otherwise normal CBC  thyroid profile  and electrolytes.  Impression/Diagnosis: Acute ischemic stroke.  Treatment: The patient was immediately given aspirin and admitted to the ICU where IV tPA was started within the therapeutic window. Long-term treatment with anticoagulants and statins was discussed and planned.  Prognosis: Prognosis is guarded considering the existing comorbidities. Comprehensive rehabilitation services have been recommended.  Follow Up: A follow-up appointment is scheduled in 4 weeks to assess post-stroke recovery  regulate the anticoagulant and statin therapy doses and to check glucose and cholesterol levels.  This case emphasizes the importance of early recognition and intervention in case of stroke to limit the extent of brain injury and disability. The patient's hypertension and diabetes  along with a strong family history  underlines the relevance of managing chronic medical conditions to prevent severe illnesses like stroke.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Atkins Age: 72 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher Location: Ohio  USA  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Atkins presented at the emergency department with sudden onset severe headache  altered speech  right-sided weakness  and poor coordination. There was no history of recent trauma  fever  alcohol or drug abuse.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Atkins was previously diagnosed with hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been on medication for both conditions for the last 10 years. Additionally  he has a history of smoking 1 pack per day for approximately 40 years  but quit smoking 5 years ago. He also has a family history of stroke on his mother's side. His regular medications include Amlodipine 10mg for his hypertension and Metformin 500mg for diabetes.  Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  his blood pressure was elevated at 195/110 mmHg. Neurological examination revealed severe dysarthria  right central facial palsy  right hemiparesis  and ataxia of right limbs. His blood glucose was 220mg/dl. He also had a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score of 14 on arrival  indicating severe neurological deficit.  Investigations:  An emergent CT scan head was done which revealed a large left middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarct. The diagnosis of an acute ischemic stroke was made. His lipid profile showed elevated LDL cholesterol levels. An ECG revealed left ventricular hypertrophy but no arrhythmia.  Treatment:  Considering his high blood pressure  he was administered intravenous antihypertensive medications. He was also given intravenous thrombolytic therapy (tissue plasminogen activator) within the therapeutic window since he presented within 4 hours of stroke onset. His diabetes management was reviewed and adjusted. The patient was admitted to the stroke unit for close monitoring due to his severe symptoms.  Follow-up:  Given his ongoing right-sided paralysis  Mr. Atkins was referred to a comprehensive rehabilitation program which included physiotherapy  occupational therapy and speech therapy after his condition stabilized. Lifestyle modification education was given to him and his family to prevent stroke in the future  including controlling his blood pressure and managing his diabetes  dietary changes  and increasing physical activity. He was also started on secondary prevention measures  including antiplatelet therapy (clopidogrel)  a statin (atorvastatin) and continued on his antihypertensive medication regimen.  In summary  Mr. Atkins is a 72-year-old male with a background of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are major risk factors for stroke. His case serves to highlight the importance of prompt identification and management of stroke symptoms and the importance of strict control of vascular risk factors to prevent the devastating consequences of stroke.

Case Report  Patient Information: Mr. J  a 67-year-old African-American male  presented at the emergency department with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and slurred speech. He is a retired engineer  married with three grown-up children and resides in Tampa  Florida. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus and admits to being a heavy smoker for a bout 35 years.  Presenting Problem: Mr. J complained of waking up feeling 'off-balance' and noticed trouble moving his left arm and leg. He also found it difficult to speak clearly and his wife noticed his face was drooping on one side.   Medical History: His medical records reveal a consistent history of poorly managed hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus over the past decade. He does not have any history of myocardial infarction  cerebral diseases  or family history of stroke or heart diseases. He quit smoking two years ago  but had smoked heavily (one to two packs a day) for more than thirty years. He occasionally consumes alcohol and does not use illicit drugs. He is not currently on any anti-platelet drugs or anticoagulants. A history of non-compliance to medications was also noted.  Examinations and Investigations: A neurological examination revealed dysarthria and profound left-sided hemiparesis. He had a score of 2 on the National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS)  indicating a likely damaging stroke. His blood pressure was 185/95 mmHg  and random blood sugar was 180 mg/dL. ECG did not reveal any atrial fibrillation or any other abnormality. A CT scan performed upon admission demonstrated a right middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarction.   Management: His vital signs were stabilized  and an intravenous line for fluid administration was secured. With a diagnosis of ischemic stroke  he was administered recombinant tissue Plasminogen Activator (rtPA) within the three-hour window period from symptom onset. His blood pressure and sugar levels were monitored and controlled with medications. He was advised complete bed rest and started on a low salt  low sugar diet.  Following thrombolysis  he was moved to the stroke unit where he will be closely monitored for improvements or indications of complications like intracranial hemorrhages.   Outcomes and Follow-up: Plans for a comprehensive rehabilitation strategy  involving physical and occupational therapy  have been made. Mr. J will be instructed on lifestyle modifications including dietary changes  increased physical activity  and strict management of hypertension and diabetes. Regular follow-up visits and monitoring of vital parameters are scheduled.  This case emphasizes the importance of early identification and management of risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  and smoking in the prevention of stroke. It also underscores the urgency in recognizing the symptoms of stroke and seeking immediate medical attention.

Patient Case Report: Cerebral Stroke  Patient Information Demographics: 63-year old  Caucasian male  retired software engineer.  Residential information: Lives in the suburban area of Manchester  England.  Smoking status: Has a history of 30 pack-years. Alcohol intake: Drinks alcohol occasionally.  Presenting Complaint: The patient attended to the emergency department with acute right-sided weakness and dysarthria.   Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. No known allergies were reported.  Family History: The mother died of a stroke at 67  and his father had angina.   Physical Examination:  The patient appeared distressed and hypertensive with a blood pressure recorded at 175/95. The patient demonstrated a clearly notable right-sided hemiparesis and slight facial droop. His speech was slurred though he seemed aware and observant of the situation.  Investigations:  - Bedside glucose: elevated - 9.5 mmol/l. - CT head showed an early ischemic change in the area of the left middle cerebral artery. - ECG showed no abnormalities. - Lipid profile: cholesterol - 7 mmol/l  LDL - 4.9 mmol/l  HDL - 1.5 mmol/l - Full blood count  urea  and electrolytes were within normal limits.  Diagnosis/Impression: Given the sudden onset of right-sided weakness  dysarthria  facial droop  and imaging results  the patient was diagnosed with an ischemic stroke.   Treatment: He was immediately given a thrombolytic drug - alteplase  to break up the clot and restore blood flow to the affected region of the brain. His blood pressure was managed with antihypertensives.  Follow up and Outcome:  The patient was admitted to the stroke unit for close monitoring  further investigations  and rehabilitation. His symptoms slightly improved over the next 48 hours. He was started on low-dose aspirin and a statin for secondary prevention. The patient will require prolonged physiotherapy  occupational therapy  and followed by a professional stroke recovery team.  Conclusion: This case highlights the imperative need for prompt medical attention in stroke cases to ensure good outcomes. In addition  it underscores the significance of good control of risk factors - hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia  to prevent recurrent vascular events.

Title: Acute Ischemic Stroke in an Elderly Female Patient with Hypertension and Diabetes Mellitus: A Case Study   Patient Information:   The patient is a 78-year-old Caucasian female  commonly residing in the United States  New York City. She lives alone and is highly independent for her daily living activities.  Chief complaints:  The patient presented at the emergency department with acute sudden onset of right-sided weakness  speech difficulties  and facial drooping that started around two hours prior to her arrival.  History of Present Illness:  On presentation  the patient appeared alert but visibly distressed. She was experiencing severe difficulty moving her right side  slurred speech  and facial asymmetry. She noticed these symptoms while preparing breakfast and immediately called 911.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with oral metformin  and hypertension  managed with lisinopril. She was diagnosed with these conditions around 15 years ago. She also reported having high cholesterol for which she takes a daily dose of atorvastatin. There is no known history of any cardiac illnesses or atrial fibrillation. She had not reported any similar episodes in the past.  Investigations:  Initial assessment via a non-contrast CT scan revealed an acute left middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarction. A complete blood count  blood glucose  and coagulation profile were done immediately and results were within normal limits except for elevated blood sugar levels. ECG showed normal sinus rhythm with no evidence of acute myocardial infarction or atrial fibrillation. MRI of the brain confirmed the acute ischemic stroke.  Management:  The patient was immediately administered intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) within 3 hours of symptom onset after ensuring no contraindications. Her blood sugar levels were monitored and managed. Following that  she was transferred to the stroke unit for further care. She was started on aspirin  a statin and an antihypertensives to manage her risk factors. The patient was then subjected to rehabilitation therapy.  Outcome and Follow-up:  The patient demonstrated significant improvement in her mobility and speech during her hospital stay. She was discharged home after 2 weeks and was continued on aspirin  a statin  antihypertensives  and her usual diabetic medications. She was also prescribed to continue physical and speech therapy as an outpatient service. The patient was recommended regular follow-up appointments in the stroke clinic.  Learning Points:  This case underlines the high importance of a speedy diagnosis and management in acute stroke to reduce subsequent disability. It also highlights the need for continuous medical management and follow-up in patients with diabetes and hypertension due to their increased risk of developing a stroke.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. Rakesh Sharma Age: 64 years Sex: Male Ethnicity: South Asian Profession: Retired Engineer Residence: Mumbai  India  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Rakesh Sharma was brought to the hospital by his wife after she found him suddenly weak on his right side  having difficulty in speaking  and with the right side of his face drooping.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension for the past 15 years and is on regular medication (Lisinopril 10 mg). The patient also has type 2 diabetes mellitus for around 10 years and is on oral hypoglycemic drugs (Metformin 500 mg). He also has a history of Ischemic heart disease and had undergone angioplasty 5 years ago. He reports no known drug allergies. He has a 30 pack per year smoking history  but quit tobacco use about a year ago  and reports drinking alcohol socially.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 190/110 mm Hg  a pulse rate of 98 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per min. Neurological assessment revealed right-sided hemiparesis  facial droop  and speech slurring. The National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score was calculated to be 14  indicating a moderate to severe stroke.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Brain CT scan was ordered immediately which revealed an acute infarct in the distribution of the left middle cerebral artery. The laboratory investigations revealed a blood sugar level of 250 mg/dl and a total cholesterol of 240 mg/dl. Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) was 7.6%  indicating poor control of diabetes.  Therapeutic Management:  As his symptoms started within three hours of presentation  the patient was administered intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) after explaining the potential benefits and risks to the patient and his family. His blood pressure was managed with labetalol and nitroglycerin. His diabetes was managed with subcutaneous insulin therapy.  Outcome:  Post-thrombolytic therapy  the patient's right-sided weakness improved partially. He was referred to a neurologist for further management and was advised to follow a low salt  low cholesterol diet and continue his medication for hypertension and diabetes. A follow-up was scheduled for the patient in 1 week’s time  and rehabilitation was organized for gait training.  This case illustrates the importance of early recognition and management of stroke  particularly in patients with high-risk factors like hypertension  diabetes  and previous cardiovascular disease. The role of lifestyle changes and stringent control of hypertension and diabetes to prevent stroke cannot be overemphasized.

Case Report: A 60-year-old Male with a Stroke  Presenting Patient: The subject of this case report presents a 60-year-old Caucasian male with complaints of sudden weakness on the right side of the body  confusion  loss of balance  and slurred speech. These symptoms began approximately 3 hours before presenting to the Emergency Department of the hospital. The patient was accompanied by his spouse who verified the onset of symptoms and provided additional medical history.  Past Medical History: Per the history as gathered from the spouse  the patient possesses an extensive medical history. He is a known case of Type-II diabetes mellitus for which he has been taking medication for about 15 years. Additionally  he has been hypertensive for the past 10 years  without any incidents of hypertensive crisis. He has been on antihypertensive medications for the same. He had a history of smoking (20 cigarettes/day for approximately 35 years  quit 5 years ago). An ex-alcoholic  he has been sober for the past 10 years. There were no incidents of transient ischemic attacks in the past. His father had suffered a stroke at age 75.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appeared conscious but was visibly distressed and speech was dysarthric. Motor examination revealed right hemiparesis. The patient’s right arm motor strength was graded 3/5 and the right leg motor strength was graded 2/5. Sensory examination showed neglect like behavior for right side. Normal findings were demonstrated on examination of the cranial nerves. The patient scored a 12 on the National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS).  Diagnostic Assessment: An emergency non-contrast CT scan of the brain was performed which ruled out hemorrhagic stroke.  MRI scan of the brain confirmed an acute ischemic stroke involving the distribution of the left middle cerebral artery. ECG revealed a normal sinus rhythm. Blood tests revealed persistent hyperglycemia but no other abnormal findings.  Treatment: The patient was treated with intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA)  as he reported within the optimal time frame for thrombolysis. Blood sugar levels were controlled with medications. Physical and occupational therapy were initiated.   Conclusion: This case illustrates the importance of rapid recognition and treatment of symptoms indicative of stroke  especially in patients with significant risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  and a history of smoking. This case also substantiates early intervention via thrombolysis in eligible patients  which can result in significantly better outcomes. The patient’s progress will be carefully monitored  and further reports will be made accordingly.

Patient Information:  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male named John Doe  currently residing in New Jersey. He is a retired teacher and lives with his wife. He doesn't have any known drug or food allergies. He is a former smoker but he quit smoking 20 years ago. He reports occasionally consuming alcohol. His normal activity level is roughly sedentary due to his age  with minor exercises such as walks around the neighborhood.  Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. He has been on oral medication (Metformin) for diabetes and amlodipine for hypertension for the last 10 years. His blood pressure and glucose levels have been relatively controlled with prescribed medication and lifestyle modifications.   There is a family medical history of heart disease  as his father had a heart attack at the age of 68. His brother was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease in his early 60s. The patient has regular body check-ups and screening for heart conditions due to his family history and individual risk factors.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe was brought to the hospital with a sudden onset of slurred speech  right-sided facial droop  and right arm weakness. His wife noticed these symptoms manifest while they were having breakfast  and she called an ambulance immediately.  Examination and Investigation:  Upon examination  Mr. Doe was conscious and coherent but had difficulty in speech with clear dysarthria. His vitals were checked: Blood pressure was 180/100 mmHg  pulse 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  and Oxygen saturation was 96% on room air. His Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) was 14/15 (E4V4M6).  An urgent CT scan was ordered which revealed an occlusion in the left middle cerebral artery suggestive of an acute ischemic stroke.  Treatment and Monitor:  Treatment was initiated immediately with intravenous administration of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) considering the timeline. He was admitted to the stroke unit for close monitoring. Over the course of hospitalization  he was put on an intensive rehabilitation program to recover from the stroke's physical impacts. His medications for hypertension were reviewed and adjusted. The need for stricter control of diabetes was emphasized.  Outcome:  Mr. Doe's condition gradually improved over his stay at the hospital. His speech clarity improved considerably  and he regained some strength in the right arm  although some weakness persisted. After being discharged  he was referred to an outpatient rehabilitation program and follow-up care was scheduled  adjusting his diabetes and hypertension medicines as per new needs.  This case emphasizes the need for early recognition of stroke symptoms and immediate intervention which can significantly improve the patient's outcome. It also highlights the requirement for an active approach towards management of chronic conditions like hypertension and diabetes that are risk factors for stroke.

Case Report:  Patient Description:  The patient is a 66-year-old Caucasian male. He resides in New York and has been a lifetime nonsmoker. He lives alone and is a retired engineer. He has a past medical history notable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes  which have been managed with amlodipine 5 mg once daily and metformin 500 mg twice daily respectively for the past 5 years. His functional status prior to the incident has been independent  living alone without any home services. He has not suffered from any allergies and adheres to a balanced diet. Further  he is not known to consume any alcohol or use any illicit substances.  Chief Complaint and History of Present Illness:  The patient was brought in by Emergency Medical Services (EMS) to the emergency department (ED) with complaints of sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech that were first noticed by a neighbor visiting him. The symptoms started approximately 4 hours prior to his arrival at the hospital.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  the patient was awake  alert  and oriented to person  place  and time. Vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 165/95 mm Hg  pulse of 78 beats/min  temperature of 98.7 degrees Fahrenheit  and a respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min. His speech was dysarthric  and the right corner of his mouth was drooping.  Neuro exam revealed right-sided hemiparesis with a power of 2/5 in the right upper and lower extremities and normal power of 5/5 in the left upper and lower extremities. Babinski sign was positive on the right side  and the patient also showed signs of dysphagia.  Investigations:  A non-contrast computed tomography (CT) scan of the head was immediately performed  which showed a left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory infarction  consistent with the physical examination findings. His random blood glucose was 200 mg/dL. Other basic labs including CBC  BMP  LFTs  coagulation profile  cardiac enzymes were within normal limits.  Diagnosis:  With these clinical findings and investigations  a diagnosis of ischemic stroke was established.  Treatment:  Since the patient arrived outside of the therapeutic window for thrombolytic therapy  he was started on secondary prevention and supportive treatment as per the clinical guidelines. This included aspirin 81 mg daily  a statin  and medications to control his blood pressure and blood sugar levels.  The patient was admitted to the stroke unit for close monitoring and rehabilitation was initiated to help improve his physical function. His progress has been satisfactory  though he continues to have some limitations on his right side.  This case is a classic example of an ischemic stroke heavily influenced by traditional risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes. It once again emphasizes the need for better control of these risk factors to prevent such severe outcomes.

Patient Profile:  Full Name: Ms. Margaret Stewart Age: 72 years Sex: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation/Profession: Retired school teacher.   Presenting complaint: Loss of balance and coordination  difficulty in speaking and understanding speech  severe headache and unilateral numbness and weakness.  Past Medical History: Patient has a known history of untreated hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past 15 years. She is also reported to have had frequent transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) and atrial fibrillation over the past year. No history of diabetes  smoking  or alcohol abuse.  Family History: Patient's father and elder brother had coronary artery disease. Mother died of a stroke at the age of 76.  Clinical findings: Neurological examination revealed facial droop on the left side  weakened grip strength and reduced sensation on the left side of her body. Speech was slurred and patient was unable to accurately repeat phrases spoken to her. Her blood pressure reading was 180/95 mmHg.  Diagnostic assessment: A computed tomography (CT) scan was immediately conducted which showed a thromboembolic block in her right middle cerebral artery  confirming the diagnosis of Acute Ischemic Stroke.   Patient's laboratory results were as follows:  - Fasting Blood Glucose was 95 mg/dL  - Total Cholesterol was 280 mg/dL  - High density lipoprotein was 35 mg/dL  - Low density lipoprotein was 180 mg/dL  - Triglyceride level was 250 mg/dL  Therapeutic intervention: Based on the 'time-last-seen-well' and the CT findings  patient was evaluated as a candidate for intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). Treatment was initiated promptly reducing the immediate risk for widespread ischemic brain damage. The patient was then admitted to the Stroke Unit for continuing care. Medical management included a hypertensive emergency regimen to gradually lower her blood pressure levels  lipid-lowering treatment (statins)  and anticoagulant therapy (Warfarin) for her atrial fibrillation.  Follow-up and outcomes: Post-therapeutic interventions  the patient showed improvement in her grip strength and facial muscle control  though some difficulties in sensation and speech remained. An interdisciplinary focus on physiotherapy  occupational therapy  and speech therapy was prescribed. She was also encouraged in a strict regimen of lifestyle modifications  comprising regular exercise  diet modifications  and medication adherence for managing her co-morbid conditions.  Patient's consent: Obtained  This clinical case underlines the well-known connection between untreated hypertension  hyperlipidemia  atrial fibrillation  and subsequent risk of ischemic stroke. As such  it stresses the importance of optimizing blood pressure control  cholesterol levels  and anticoagulant therapy in patients with these risk factors to prevent devastating neurological consequences.

Title: An Uncommon Presentation of a Stroke in a Woman with a History of Hypertension and Hyperlipidaemia  Introduction: Mrs. Elizabeth Wilson  a 72-year-old Caucasian woman  residing in New York was brought to the Emergency Department (ED) due to a sudden onset of Left-sided body weakness and difficulty in understanding and speaking.  Demographic Information: Name: Elizabeth Wilson Age: 72  Sex: Female Occupation: Retired Residence: New York  Medical History: 1. Hypertension: Diagnosed 16 years ago  medication - Losartan 50 mg daily 2. Hyperlipidaemia: Diagnosed 10 years ago  medication - Atorvastatin 80 mg daily  No history of diabetes or heart disease. She was a non-smoker and a non-alcoholic. She had a history of being sedentary and overweight.  Clinical Features: On examination  she was fully oriented but showed signs of dysarthria (difficulty in articulate speech) and dysphasia (difficulty understanding spoken language). There was a motor deficit in the left side of the body  including face and arm as well as sensory loss.   Investigations: Neuroimaging by Computerized tomography (CT) revealed an Ischemic stroke  owing to a right Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) occlusion.  Management: Thrombolytic therapy (Alteplase 100mg IV) was initiated promptly  within the ""golden hour."" The patient was then admitted to the Neuro intensive care unit (ICU) for further management. Her hypertension was controlled  and a low cholesterol diet was advised to manage her hyperlipidemia. She was scheduled to start a comprehensive rehabilitation program.  Follow-Up: At a 3-month follow-up  Mrs. Wilson made significant improvements with moderate residual left-sided weakness  managed by ongoing physiotherapy. Her speech had improved as well  with slight difficulty remaining in sentence construction.  Discussion: Prompt treatment initiation in Mrs. Wilson led to considerable recovery  emphasizing the importance of early recognition and management in Ischemic stroke patients.  Conclusion: Stroke prevention strategies in older patients  especially those with chronic diseases like hypertension and hyperlipidaemia  are crucial. It's noteworthy that preventive measures  early recognition  and intervention can significantly improve stroke outcomes. Regular monitoring and follow-ups in such patients are essential to ensure adherence to therapeutic strategies  and any deviations should prompt immediate revision of the treatment plan.   Key learning points:  1. Importance of early recognition and management of stroke.  2. Role of thrombolytic therapy in early management.  3. Importance of regular follow-ups for stroke patients.

Case Report: Patient Profile: - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 64 years old - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Navy Officer - Current Residence: Albany  New York  Medical History: - Hypertension: Yes  diagnosed six years ago - Diabetes: Yes  diagnosed three years ago - History of Smoking: Yes  quit 10 years ago - Alcohol Consumption: Moderate - Family History of Cardiovascular Disease: Father had a stroke aged 70  brother died of a heart attack aged 62  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Doe was brought in by his wife  who noticed sudden onset of weakness in the left side of his body at around 7 am. The patient reported no headache  vertigo or loss of consciousness. No history of seizures  migraine  or any systemic disease is reported.   Examination: Upon examination  he was alert but visibly anxious. His speech was slurred. Physical examination revealed a left-sided facial droop and significant motor weakness in the left upper and lower limbs. His blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg  pulse was 80 bpm  regular and full  and respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute.   Laboratory Investigations: An immediate CT scan of the brain was performed  which showed the presence of an acute infarct in the right middle cerebral artery territory. Blood tests and lipid profile were done  showing elevated blood sugars and LDL cholesterol.   Treatment: The patient was admitted to the stroke unit. The emergency department initiated IV thrombolytic therapy with rt-PA  within three hours of symptom onset.   Outcome: The patient improved gradually over a period of days. His speech began to clear and by day 6 he displayed significant reduction of motor weakness.   Follow Up and Maintenance: Mr. Doe was referred to Physiotherapy for supportive care and rehabilitation. He was prescribed antiplatelet drugs  statins and antihypertensives  with strict instructions about diet maintenance and regular exercise. The patient is scheduled to have regular follow-ups and monitoring of blood pressure  cholesterol  and glucose levels 2 weeks post-discharge.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and intervention in the management of stroke. Prompt administration of thrombolytic therapy can significantly improve outcomes  underlining the need for public education about the early signs of stroke and the necessity for urgent treatment.

Case Report: Stroke in a 68-Year-Old Male with Hypertension  Patient Information The patient is a 68-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack year history and a social drinker. He is retired and lives with his wife. His maternal grandmother had a stroke at the age of 75.  Chief Complaint  The patient was brought to the Emergency Department by an ambulance after experiencing sudden slurred speech  weakness on the right side of his body  and difficulties in maintaining balance while walking.  Clinical Findings On examination  the patient was alert but demonstrated expressive aphasia. Vital signs were stable. Neurologic examination indicated right-sided hemiparesis  right facial droop  and ataxic gait. Initial blood tests displayed a slightly elevated blood sugar level of 170 mg/dL and cholesterol 220 mg/dL. Blood pressure was elevated at 170/100 mmHg.  Diagnostic Assessment A non-contrast CT scan of the patient’s head revealed a left-sided acute ischemic stroke. The EKG showed normal sinus rhythm. Carotid Doppler ultrasound found a 60% stenosis in the left carotid artery. MRI confirmed the presence of the stroke in the distribution of the Left Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA).  Therapeutic Intervention The patient was deemed to be beyond the window for thrombolytic therapy. He was started on aspirin (81 mg daily)  atorvastatin for cholesterol control  and insulin sliding scale was initiated. An antihypertensive drug  lisinopril  was started to control his blood pressure. The patient underwent occupational and physical therapy to address hemiparesis and difficulties with balance.  Follow-up and Outcomes  The patient's strength improved modestly with rehabilitation and he regained partial function on the right side over a period of six weeks. He was discharged to his home with continuing outpatient physical and occupational therapy. His blood pressure  blood glucose  and cholesterol levels were better managed with medication and diet control.  Patient Perspective The patient was thankful for his wife's quick response and expressed motivation to continue with his rehabilitative therapies to regain strength. He stated he now understands the need to better manage his risk factors to prevent another stroke.   Informed consent: The patient mentioned above in the case report has given his informed consent for the case report to be published.   Discussion  This case underscores the importance of risk factor management including blood pressure  cholesterol  and glucose in the context of stroke. Despite a history of hypertension and diabetes  the patient's poor control over these factors potentially led to the cerebrovascular event. This case also highlights the importance of early recognition and management of stroke symptoms to prevent lasting neurologic damage.  Clinical pearls  1. Secondary prevention strategies are vital in patients who have already had a stroke. 2. Stroke symptoms should be evaluated immediately due to the limited window for intervention that can significantly reduce long-term morbidity.   Keywords: Stroke  Hypertension  Diabetes  Rehabilitative therapy  Prevention strategies.

Case Report: Acute Ischemic Stroke   Patient Demographic Information   Mr. L is a 72-year-old Caucasian male from a suburban town in the United States. He is a retired engineer  married  with two adult children. Mr. L is physically active and has no history of smoking or alcohol abuse. His diet is mainly of mixed western origin.  Past Medical History   The patient has a documented history of hypertension and type-2 diabetes  diagnosed about 15 years ago but has been under control with consistent use of prescribed medication. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia for 10 years.   Clinical Scenario   Mr. L reported a sudden onset of symptoms including speech slurring  confusion  one-sided weakness and facial droop on awakening in the morning. He was immediately taken to the local Emergency Department.   Clinical Evaluation   Upon arrival at the emergency  physicians performed a neurological exam and found significant alteration in his mental status  his speech was slurred  and he showed a facial droop on the left side. Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 155/95 mmHg  pulse rate of 78 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute  and temperature was normal.   The patient’s coordination was affected on the left side  experiencing left arm drift and decreased strength in the left arm and leg. Glasgow coma scale was found to be E4V4M6. No signs of trauma or infection were evident. His blood glucose levels were slightly elevated. No alcohol or narcotics were detected in the system.   Medical Investigations   With suspicions of Stroke  CT head without contrast examination was ordered immediately  which revealed early signs of acute right middle cerebral artery (MCA) ischemic stroke. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed ischemic infarct involving right MCA territory. No signs of hemorrhage were visible.   Management and Outcome   The patient was treated according to the guidelines for acute ischemic stroke with intravenous administration of recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA). He was admitted to the Stroke Unit for further management where his blood pressure and blood glucose levels were closely monitored and controlled. After a week  the patient showed considerable improvement in his symptoms although mild weakness in his left arm persisted. He was referred to rehabilitative therapy to regain strength and control on his left side.   Conclusion   This case highlights the importance of prompt recognition and treatment of acute ischemic stroke symptoms. A well-coordinated and multidisciplinary approach was imperative to the rehabilitation and recovery of the patient.

Patient Profile:  Name: [Confidential] Gender: Male Age: 58-years-old Race: Caucasian Occupation: Engineer Date of admission: 25th November  2021 Location: Ohio  USA  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented with sudden onset severe headache  right-sided weakness with difficulty speaking.  Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been taking medication over the past decade. He has been non-compliant to his prescribed diet and exercise regimens. He is a smoker with a 30-pack year history and is also a social drinker.   Examination:  An initial physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 170/100 mm Hg. The patient appeared alert but had difficulty with speech. A neurological examination showed that his power was grade 2/5 on the right side of the body. Cranial nerve function was normal except for facial weakness on the right side. Sensation was intact.  Investigations: Laboratory investigations were within normal limit though lipid profile was slightly elevated. A non-contrast computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain was performed urgently  which showed a hyperdense region in the left middle cerebral artery indicating an acute ischemic stroke.  Management:  The patient was immediately administered intravenous thrombolytics  as he was within the therapeutic window of 4.5 hours from stroke onset. He was admitted to the stroke unit for further monitoring and management.   Course and Outcome: Despite early intervention  the patient's right-sided weakness did not diminish initially. He was referred for urgent speech and physical therapy. After a week  the patient showed some improvements in his strength (power of 3/5) though speech remained slurred. He was discharged with prescriptions for antiplatelet  statins and antihypertensive therapy with a strict caution on lifestyle modifications. He was also scheduled for regular outpatient follow-ups.  Summary:  This case highlights the consequences of non-compliance to lifestyle modifications and medical therapy in a hypertensive and hyperlipidemic patient leading to stroke. Early recognition of symptoms and appropriate medical intervention helped reduce the severity of post-stroke morbidity but complete recovery is expected to be slow. This supports the need for continuous health promotion and awareness about stroke symptoms for timely intervention.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. RJ Age: 68  Gender: Male  Race: Caucasian   Background: Mr. RJ presented himself at the Stroke Specialty Clinic with symptoms suggestive of a stroke. He is a retired engineer living with his wife and has two grown-up children who live out of state. He has a history of high blood pressure for the past 15 years and high cholesterol for 10 years. Mr. RJ is a former smoking and reported drinking alcohol occasionally. His mother had a history of stroke and died from its complication at the age of 79.  Clinical Presentation: Mr. RJ came into the clinic complaining of sudden onset of weakness and numbness on his right side  loss of balance  difficulty in speaking  dizziness  blurred vision in his left eye  and a severe headache. All these symptoms emerged around 3 hours prior to him reporting to the clinic. His wife reported that Mr. RJ also seemed to be disoriented and was demonstrating garbled speech immediately preceding their decision to rush to the clinic.  Examination and Tests: Vital signs revealed a high blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg. Neurological examination showed right-sided hemiparesis. His Glasgow Coma Scale was 14/15 and NIHSS was calculated to be 12 points. Upon radiological intervention with an urgent CT brain scan  an acute ischemic stroke was identified in his left middle cerebral artery region.  Management: Following the diagnosis  Mr. RJ was started on intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA)  within the therapeutic window. After obtaining consent from his wife and full discussion of the risks  he was transferred to neurosurgical intervention for thrombectomy  which was successful. He was then admitted into the Stroke Unit for further monitoring and treatment.  Over time  he showed significant improvement with respect to his neurological deficits. His blood pressure and cholesterol levels were brought under control with ongoing medication. He was discharged two weeks later with a recommendation for physical and occupational therapy and prescribed a rehabilitation program to aid in his recovery.  Follow-up: Upon follow-up after a month  Mr. RJ was doing well and showed significant improvement in his right-sided strength  balance  and speech. His rehabilitation program was continued and prescribed further follow-up.  NOTE: This is a generalized construction of a Stroke Case Report. In real clinical settings  the details can vary vastly based on multiple factors such as other comorbid conditions  variation in presentation  and hospital-specific protocols.

Case Report: Ischemic Stroke in a 68-Year-Old Male  Patient Information:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  who lives with his wife in a rural setting but within reasonable proximity to major medical facilities. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol in moderation. He has no personal or family history of psychiatric disorders and enjoys a good relationship with his family and social network. His primary language is English  and he is generally very active and cognitively intact.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which are both controlled with appropriate diet  regular physical activity  oral antihypertensive  and hypoglycemic agents. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia  currently managed with statin therapy. The patient was diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) 10 years ago but has largely been asymptomatic. He has no history of any major surgeries or health complications. He has been on Aspirin 81mg for primary cardiovascular prevention following his diagnosis of hypertension and diabetes.  Presenting Symptoms:  The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden-onset right-sided weakness  difficulty speaking  and facial drooping. The symptoms started abruptly approximately 45 minutes prior to his arrival at the hospital. There was no headache  seizure  loss of consciousness  or preceding trauma.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient was alert but showed clear signs of expressive aphasia. His vital signs were as follows: blood pressure 150/90 mmHg  pulse 108 bpm  respiratory rate 20 bpm  oxygen saturation 97% on room air  and temperature 98F. Neurological examination revealed right-sided hemiplegia  right facial droop  and dysarthria. The rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Immediate non-contrast computed tomography (CT) of the brain was carried out  showing early signs of an ischemic stroke  specifically an infarct involving the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory. Lab investigations including Complete Blood Count  Electrolytes  Renal Function Tests  Liver Function Tests  and Coagulation Profile were all within normal limits. The EKG revealed normal sinus rhythm and cardiac enzymes were negative.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately evaluated by the stroke team and began intravenous (IV) tissue Plasminogen Activator (tPA). He was transferred to the Stroke Unit for further management and monitoring.  Follow Up: After 24 hours of drug initiation  the patient's speech showed mild improvement. Physiotherapy was initiated for right-sided weakness. Rehabilitation continues with promising prospects of recovery. His antihypertensive medications and glycemic control will be reviewed in follow-up stroke clinics and necessary adjustments will be made to optimize secondary prevention of stroke.  Conclusion:  Prompt intervention and management allow for the improved prognosis of this patient after suffering an ischemic stroke. It is important in such medical cases to maintain impeccable control of the patient's chronic conditions like hypertension  type-2 Diabetes Mellitus  and hyperlipidemia to prevent complications such as stroke.

Case Report:  Patient: Mr. John Smith  Date of Birth: 04/30/1940  Gender: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Accountant  Presenting Problem:  92-year-old male patient with initially unnoticed left-side weakness  altered speech  and confusion. He was found later by his son  with whom he lives. The son brought him to the emergency department immediately upon recognizing the symptoms as stroke-related.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a documented history of hypertension for the last fifteen years  managed with medication  regular check-ups  and lifestyle adjustments. He has Type 2 diabetes  controlled with diet and oral medication for ten years. The patient had a Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI) at age 85  with subsequent successful Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) to the left anterior descending artery. He has mild chronic renal disease due to his diabetic history. The patient denies smoking and alcohol use but reports occasionally indulging in high-sodium and sugary foods despite his condition.   Emergency Department Assessment:  Initial NIH stroke scale score was 12  suggesting moderate to severe stroke. A cerebral CT scan demonstrated an acute right middle cerebral artery thrombus. There was no evidence of hemorrhage. Neurology was consulted  and after appraisal of the situation and consultation with the patient’s son  thrombolysis was arranged.  Management and Outcome:  The patient underwent thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) within the 3 hour window of onset of symptoms. Post thrombolysis  there was considerable improvement in the patient’s left-sided weakness and his speech. NIH Stroke Score post-24 hours of thrombolysis had reduced to 4 suggesting minor stroke risk. Patient was admitted for further observation and management.   He was discharged after 7 days and referred for regular physiotherapy and occupational therapy sessions. A proper diet plan was provided to the patient's family. His antihypertensive medications were adjusted  and he was started on low-dose aspirin for secondary prevention of stroke.   Follow Up:  Patient remains stable upon follow-up over the next six months. Although he still has minor weakness in his left side  his speech and cognition have returned to near norm  and his condition remains stable.   Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of early recognition and intervention in cases of stroke  in order to maximize the likelihood of recovery. It also highlights the importance of rigorous management of risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  and diet control in older patients with a history of cardiovascular disease.

Case Report:  Patient Profile:  Name: Mrs. Jane Doe Age: 68 years  Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian  Residential Location: Miami  Florida  Case Presentation:  The patient  Mrs. Jane Doe  has been admitted to the emergency department presenting with acute-onset confusion  right-sided weakness  and expressive aphasia. She also complained of headache and vertigo.  Medical History:  Mrs. Doe has a notable past medical history that includes controlled hypertension for a decade  type 2 diabetes mellitus for which she takes metformin  and hyperlipidemia treated with atorvastatin. She has past surgical history of total knee replacement for osteoarthritis 5 years ago.  She is a non-smoker and denies recreational drug use but indulged in social alcohol use.   Her family history is significant for stroke  as her mother had a stroke at the age of 72.
