Neurological Examination:  Her neurological examination revealed impaired orientation and expressive aphasia. The motor exam showed right-sided hemiparesis. Sensory examination was intact  and cranial nerve testing was unremarkable except for mild dysarthria.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Computed Tomography (CT) and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) of the brain were performed which showed a hyperintense area in the distribution of the left middle cerebral artery  confirming an acute ischemic stroke.   An Electrocardiogram (ECG) was conducted which showed normal sinus rhythm and no abnormalities.  Treatment:  The patient presented approximately 3 hours after the onset of symptoms and was evaluated as a candidate for thrombolytic therapy. After assessing her overall clinical condition  intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) was administered.   Outcome and Follow-Up:  After 24 hours  her symptoms showed significant improvement. The right-sided weakness ameliorated  and her expressive aphasia improved. She was transferred to the stroke rehabilitation unit and weaned off the rtPA. Per protocol  she was started on aspirin  a statin and antihypertensive medications.   During outpatient follow-up after six weeks  she demonstrated further improvement in her physical condition and was advised to adopt a healthier lifestyle  including low salt and low sugar diet  regular exercise  regular blood pressure checks and continued medication compliance.  Summary:  This case emphasized the importance of rapid evaluation and treatment in patients presenting with stroke symptoms. A timely multidisciplinary approach involving emergency clinicians  neurologists  radiologists  and pharmacists led to a favourable result in Mrs. Doe’s case.

Patient Information:  Mr. A  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presented at the hospital suffering from sudden onset dizziness  blurred vision  difficulty speaking  and weakness on the right side of his body that started about 2 hours prior.  Past medical history:  The patient has been known to have hypertension and hypercholesterolemia for the last 15 years. He has been on a regimen of Lisinopril 10 mg once daily for hypertension and simvastatin 20 mg once daily for high cholesterol. Despite these interventions  the patient has been mostly non-compliant with medication administration and follow-ups. He is a smoker  smoking approximately half a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years. He leads a fairly sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity and a diet rich in saturated fats. There is a history of stroke in his family  with his father having suffered a similar incident at a similar age.  Current assessment:  On examination  the right side of his face was drooping and he was unable to smile evenly. His speech was slurred and he was unable to raise his right arm. His blood pressure was elevated at 180/100 and his heart rate was irregular. The patient's body mass index calculated to 28 (overweight range). Fasting blood glucose was high  indicating possible undiagnosed diabetes. The initial CT scan showed a hypodense area in the left MCA (middle cerebral artery) indicative of an ischemic lesion  which suggests he had an acute ischemic stroke.  Treatment & Recovery Plan:  The patient was administered intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)  a clot-busting medication  within a therapeutic time window. He was subsequently admitted to the stroke unit for continuous monitoring and care. Antiplatelet  antihypertensive drugs  statins  and oral anti-diabetic medications were prescribed alongside lifestyle modifications including stop smoking  balanced diet and regular physical activities. He was also referred to occupational and physical therapy for rehabilitating the right-sided weakness and speech therapy for the speech impairment.  Patient education:  Education was provided about maintaining a healthy lifestyle helps to prevent further strokes. The patient was educated about the significance of medication compliance  regular follow-ups  smoking cessation  eating a diet low in saturated fat and cholesterol  and regular exercise. He was also taught to recognize the signs and symptoms of a stroke  so that he can obtain immediate medical attention if necessary.  The patient reported a better understanding of his condition and an improved willingness to comply with medical advice and lifestyle changes. He was scheduled for follow-up appointments at regular intervals in the neurology clinic to monitor his progress and management.

Patient Information:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  an ex-smoker who quit the habit 20 years ago. His past medical history highlights hypertension and diabetes mellitus type II  for which he has been receiving treatment for the past 10 years. The patient is also known to have hyperlipidemia  and there is a family history of strokes. He is a retired engineer with a less active lifestyle and a BMI of 29  hence falls under the overweight category.  Case Presentation:  On the morning of the presentation  the patient was found in a compromised state by his wife  having difficulty in speaking and a droop on the left side of his face. He was rushed to the emergency department with locomotor difficulties along with mild confusion. His symptoms had started almost an hour prior to his presentation to the hospital.  Clinical Findings:  Upon initial examination  the patient's vital signs were stable  with BP: 160/100 mmHg. Neurological examination revealed moderate left-sided weakness (4/5 upper limb  3/5 lower limb)  left facial droop  and dysarthria. He had no visual field cuts or sensory impairments.  Diagnosis:  An emergency CT brain was conducted and showed signs of acute ischemic stroke on the right middle cerebral artery territory. His blood reports highlighted elevated sugar levels and increased LDL-cholesterol. His ECG  although had signs of left ventricular hypertrophy  showed no signs of arrhythmias. The clinical picture and radiological findings were consistent with an acute right MCA stroke.  Treatment:  The patient was immediately given a systemic thrombolytic  recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA)  considering the time of onset of symptoms. He was counseled about the benefits and risks of the procedure. His blood pressure was monitored and managed effectively with antihypertensives. Glycemic control was achieved with insulin.  After ensuring stability  he was transferred to the stroke unit for further recovery and rehabilitation. An integrated approach involving physiotherapy and speech therapy was also initiated. He was started on antiplatelet therapy and statins after discussing the benefits and risks with the patient and his caretakers.  Outcome and Follow-up:  The patient showed a marked improvement after the treatment. His speech improved significantly  and he could move his left limbs more freely. He was discharged after two weeks with a significantly improved NIHSS score. He has been scheduled for regular follow-ups at the stroke unit and for further management of his hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia.  Learning Points:  This case report underlines the necessity of early recognition and prompt treatment of stroke to prevent long-term disability. It also reaffirms the importance of managing risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia in preventing stroke. Equally importantly  it reinstates how an integrated rehabilitation approach can significantly improve quality of life post-stroke.

Case Report Title: Acute Ischemic Stroke in a Middle-Aged Female With Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia  Patient Information: Jane Doe  a 52-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency department with symptoms suggestive of acute stroke. She had a significant past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia but was otherwise in good health. She is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol sparingly  and leads a moderately active lifestyle.   Chief Complaints: The patient complained of sudden onset of vertigo  altered coordination  slurred speech  right-sided weakness  and facial droop that started approximately 2 hours before arrival at the hospital.  Medical History:  Ms. Doe has been diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past seven years. She has been under medication (Lisinopril for hypertension and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia) along with healthy lifestyle modifications. No history of similar episodes or neurological diseases in the past. No family history of strokes  heart diseases  or other major illnesses. Regular health check-ups revealed controlled blood pressure and cholesterol levels until the last follow-up three months ago.  Clinical Findings:  Upon arrival  she was alert but oriented to person only. Vital signs were stable  blood pressure 170/100 mmHg  heart rate 90/min  respiratory rate 16/min  and temperature 98.6°F. On examination  she was found to have right-sided facial drooping  slurred speech  and diminished power in the right upper and the lower limb. Neurological evaluation indicated right Babinski sign positive. Gait was not assessed due to weakness.  Diagnostic Assessment: A complete blood count  coagulation profile  and chemical analysis were within normal limits. ECG showed normal sinus rhythm. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain was done immediately  which revealed an ischemic stroke in the left middle cerebral artery territory. Carotid Doppler revealed plaque in the left internal carotid artery  suggesting a probable source for thromboembolization.  Therapeutic Intervention: She received intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA) approximately 2.5 hours after the onset of her symptoms. Antiplatelet  antihypertensive  and medication for hyperlipidemia was adjusted according to the situation.  Follow-up and Outcomes: After being admitted to the ICU  the patient showed subtle improvements over the next few days. Her speech started improving  and her motor power slightly increased. The patient was transferred to a stroke rehabilitation center after two weeks in the hospital. On follow up at six months  the patient had made substantial progress in physical and speech therapy  although residual right-sided weakness persisted.   Patient Perspective: The patient was initially anxious and distressed by the acute symptoms but expressed gratitude for the timely medical care and intervention received.   Informed Consent: Informed consent was taken for her emergency management and further necessary procedures.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of early recognition  time-sensitive management in ischemic stroke  and the long-term management of modifiable risk factors like hypertension and hyperlipidemia. It also underscores the importance of a multidisciplinary approach  involving emergency physicians  neurologists  radiologists  and rehabilitation specialists for maximum patient recovery.

Patient Details  Age: 74 Name: Anonymous Sex: Male Race/Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Retired school teacher  Presenting Symptoms  The patient visited the emergency room reporting sudden onset of difficulty in speaking and understanding speech  coupled with right-sided numbness and weakness. He also reported having a severe headache and loss of balance.  Past Medical History  The patient has a past medical history that includes high blood pressure  controlled by prescribed medication (Lisinopril 10mg)  and type 2 diabetes controlled by diet and Metformin 500mg twice daily. The patient is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago and does not consume alcohol. There is a familial history of stroke in the patient's family. His late mother succumbed to an ischemic stroke at the age of 78. His older sibling also had a stroke at the age of 70.  The patient reported good compliance with his medications and described his diabetes and blood pressure as well-controlled. He reported regular exercise in the form of daily walks and denied any illicit drug use.  The Case  Within 30 minutes of arrival to the hospital  the patient was diagnosed with ischemic stroke through a rapid assessment: physical examination  complete blood count  plasma glucose level  CT scan  and MRI of the brain. The results from the brain scans indicated the occlusion of the middle cerebral artery on the left side of the brain.  In accordance with stroke guidelines  the patient was administered IV alteplase. His symptoms of aphasia and right-side weakness significantly improved after the infusion. After stabilization  he was admitted to the stroke unit for further management.  Management of Case  The patient's hypertension  diabetes  diet  and lifestyle were managed as part of his in-patient stay and ongoing recovery plan. An antiplatelet drug  aspirin  was started in addition to his regular medication regimen. On a follow-up visit a week later  the patient showed significant improvement with only mild residual weakness in the right upper limb.   The patient was referred to physiotherapy for rehabilitation and strength building exercises. A dietitian provided counseling and worked out a diabetic-friendly diet plan to help maintain blood glucose levels. The patient was also offered counseling for coping with stress and adapting to lifestyle changes post-stroke.  The family members were provided education and advice regarding the patient's dietary habits  daily exercise  medication  and regular check-ups.  In conclusion  timely intervention and adherence to stroke guidelines led to the successful management of an ischemic stroke in this 74-year-old male patient.

Title: Recurrent Ischemic Stroke in a Hypertensive and Diabetic Elderly Patient   Demographics & Patient Information:   Patient A.B.  a 75-year-old female  is a resident at a local nursing home and primarily of Caucasian ethnicity. She is a retired school teacher and her family's medical history includes an incidence of stroke in her late father.  Past Medical History:  The patient is a known case of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) for the last 15 years  managed with metformin 500mg twice daily. She has also been diagnosed with primary hypertension eight years ago  managed with amlodipine 5mg daily. She’s also known to have chronic kidney disease (CKD) but has not yet required hemodialysis. Previous yet pertinent medical history includes no allergies or known drug intolerances.   Presenting Complaint:  The patient was rushed to the Emergency Department after she was found aphasic and right-side paralytic by the nursing home staff. On examination  her blood pressure was 170/90mmHg  heart rate was 96 beats/minute  and random blood sugar was 210mg/dl. She was conscious  alert but disoriented to time  place  and person.   Clinical Findings:  Neurological examination revealed global aphasia  right hemiplegia  and right-sided facial droop. Eye examination showed dilated and non-reactive pupils. The rest of her physical examination was unremarkable.   Diagnoses:  An immediate CT scan of the head demonstrated an acute infarction in the left middle cerebral artery territory  confirming an ischemic stroke. Electrocardiogram (ECG) was suggestive of left ventricular hypertrophy. Some lab reports such as increased HbA1c and elevated creatinine also confirmed her known diagnoses of uncontrolled diabetes and chronic kidney disease respectively.  Therapeutic Intervention and Follow-up:  The patient was admitted to the stroke unit where she received intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) within the therapeutic window followed by aspirin (325 mg) and clopidogrel (75 mg) as secondary prophylaxis against recurrent stroke. Her hypertension was managed with labetalol infusion. She had intermittent monitoring of her blood sugar levels  which were managed with insulin regimen.   She showed signs of improvement throughout her stay and was eventually discharged after 3 weeks. A rehabilitation plan  involving physiotherapy and occupational therapy  was established to improve her mobility and daily living activities. Her medication regimen was also reviewed  with the dosage of metformin being increased to 1000mg twice daily  and hypertension managed with amlodipine 10mg daily. The patient was advised on regular follow-ups with her primary caregiver and a multidisciplinary team including the neurologist  endocrinologist  and nephrologist to monitor and manage her comorbid conditions concurrently.  Summary:  This case report underlines the challenges of managing a stroke patient with multiple comorbidities  emphasizing the importance of a multidisciplinary approach and stringent control of modifiable risk factors such as blood pressure and blood glucose levels for optimal outcomes. The necessity of regular patient follow-ups and revisions in medication dosage also forms a part of comprehensive patient care.

Title: Acute Ischemic Stroke in a 49-year-old Male with History of Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia  Introduction: A 49-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with new-onset right-sided weakness and difficulty with speech. The patient has a significant past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and is currently taking Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension and Atorvastatin 40mg daily for hyperlipidemia. He has a smoking history of one pack per day for 20 years and is an occasional alcohol drinker.  Case presentation: The patient was brought into the emergency department by his wife  who found him slumped on the floor of their living room. He was demonstrating facial droop  slurring of speech  and right-sided motor weakness. Initial vital signs showed his blood pressure was 160/110  heart rate was 90 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation was 95% on room air. His weight was 230 pounds with a height of 6 feet.  He was alert but confused during examination and exhibited signs of aphasia. The right-sided motor weakness was confirmed via physical examination. The National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) was utilized  and the patient’s score was 17  indicating severe stroke.  Laboratory results revealed elevated LDL cholesterol levels (160 mg/dL) and elevated total cholesterol levels (240 mg/dL). CT scan of the head was performed promptly  which revealed an acute left hemisphere ischemic stroke.  Management and Outcome: Based on the clinical presentation and the guidelines  an intravenous thrombolytic therapy with alteplase was initiated immediately. The patient was admitted to the stroke unit for further monitoring and care.  With physical and speech therapy  the patient showed gradual improvement over the following days. After extensive care  including medications and rehabilitation  the patient’s right-sided motor strength had significant recovery  and his speech was improved. On discharge  he was referred for outpatient rehabilitation services and advised to quit smoking  limit alcohol intake  and follow a healthy diet to manage his hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Conclusion: This case highlights the critical role of immediate recognition and treatment of ischemic stroke in patients with concurrent comorbidities like hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Lifestyle modifications and strict control of risk factors are imperative for effective secondary prevention of recurrent strokes.

Case Report  Patient Information: Mr. X  73-year-old  Caucasian male  retired engineer  Chief Complaint: Acute onset of speech difficulty and right-sided weakness   Presenting Illness: Mr. X was brought to the emergency department by his daughter after she found him with slurred speech and difficulty moving his right side. These symptoms began roughly 3 hours before hospital arrival. The patient reported a severe headache prior to the onset. There is no history of trauma  falls  or loss of consciousness.   Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago and has been on medication (ACE inhibitor). He also has type 2 diabetes under control with metformin for about 5 years. He has hyperlipidemia for which he takes a statin. He is a former smoker (stopped 20 years ago) and consumes alcohol occasionally.   Family History: His father died of a myocardial infarction in his seventies and his mother had a history of stroke in her late sixties.  Physical Examination: On arrival  patient was alert but not oriented to time  place  or person. He had a blood pressure of 170/95 mm Hg  pulse 92 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  temperature of 37°C  and an oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Neurologic examination revealed a facial droop on the right side  decreased power (2/5) in the right upper and lower limbs and dysarthria. He had a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score of 12.  Investigations: His blood glucose level was slightly elevated. Other bloodwork  including CBC  electrolytes  kidney and liver function were within the normal range. EKG showed regular sinus rhythm without ischemic changes. Non-contrast CT scan of the brain confirmed a left hemisphere ischemic stroke.   Diagnosis: Based on clinical and radiological findings  Mr. X was diagnosed with acute ischemic stroke.  Treatment: Intravenous thrombolysis with alteplase was administered within the therapeutic window. He was later started on Aspirin  Statin and continued his antihypertensive medications.   Current Condition: Following treatment  his power showed slight improvement (3/5)  but he continues to struggle with speech. He was referred to a rehabilitation center for physiotherapy and speech therapy. His condition is stable.  This case underlines the importance of immediate medical attention in the neuronal ""golden hour "" for optimal recovery post-stroke. As well as reinforcing the crucial role of strict control of modifiable risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia for prevention of such life-threatening events.

Patient Information:  The patient is a 73-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired teacher  living with his wife in the suburban area of Chicago  Illinois. He is a non-smoker but has a history of moderate alcohol consumption.  Chief Complaint:  The patient was brought into the hospital with complaints of severe headache and sudden onset of right-sided weakness. He also reported slurred speech and difficulty understanding language (both spoken and written) for the past two hours.  Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago and has maintained relatively good glycemic control with Metformin. He has a 5-year history of Hypertension  controlled with a combination of Losartan and Atenolol. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia and has been taking Atorvastatin for the past 2 years. The patient has never had a stroke before. His father died at the age of 75 from a stroke while his mother died at 80 due to heart disease.   Physical Examination:  Upon presentation  the patient exhibited facial droop on the right side  and his gaze was fixed to the left. Neurological assessment revealed motor strength of 3/5 in the right upper and lower extremities  and normal motor strength 5/5 in the left upper and lower extremities. The patient's speech was slurred  although he was alert and oriented.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An urgent brain CT scan was conducted  and the results indicated an acute  left middle cerebral artery stroke. An ECG was normal  and the blood pressure was 155/90 mmHg. Fasting plasma glucose was elevated at 10.5 mmol/L  and HbA1c was 7.4%. Lipid profile was as follows: Total cholesterol 200 mg/dl  HDL 52 mg/dl  LDL 120 mg/dl  and triglycerides 178 mg/dl.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was evaluated for intravenous thrombolysis  to which he was amenable. As he presented within the therapeutic window and there were no contraindications (e.g.  recent surgery  bleeding disorders  etc.)  recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA) was administered. The patient was admitted to the stroke unit for monitoring  and necessary supportive treatment was initiated.   Follow-up:  Despite the initial treatment  the patient has been left with significant right-sided weakness and expressive dysphasia. A Multi-disciplinary team that includes physiotherapists  occupational therapists and speech  and language therapists have been involved in his care. The patient is currently undergoing physical and speech therapy  showing gradual progress. He has been advised to continue with his medications for hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. A consultation with a dietitian was done to discuss a diet plan to control the patient’s comorbidities better. He was advised to limit alcohol intake. The patient's family was also educated about stroke  its potential causes  and ways to minimize the risk of recurrence.    This case illustrates the importance of rapid diagnosis and intervention in acute stroke situations. Despite the residual sequelae  early intervention with thrombolysis potentially prevented further devastating consequences in this patient.

Case Report: Cerebrovascular Accident in a 59-year-old Male Patient  1. Patient Information:  The patient is a 59-year-old Caucasian male  with a past history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. He is a retired office worker and has smoked a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years  and drinks alcohol socially. The patient lives alone and has two adult daughters.  2. Chief Complaint:  He visited the emergency department complaining of sudden onset right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking.   3. History of Present Illness:  The symptoms began 2 hours prior to his arrival at the hospital. The patient experienced sudden-onset right-sided weakness and speech difficulty. There was no history of trauma or loss of consciousness. He did not experience severe headache  chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations.  4. Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus 10 years ago. His medications include Metformin 500mg twice daily  Lisinopril 10mg daily  and Atorvastatin 20mg nightly. He has been inconsistent with utilizing healthcare services and medication compliance. His records reveal that his blood pressure and blood glucose levels have been poorly controlled over the past two years.  5. Physical Examination:  On examination  blood pressure was 180/95 mmHg  heart rate 80 bpm  respirations 16 per minute  and temperature 36.8°C. Neurological exam revealed right hemiparesis  facial droop  and expressive aphasia. No other abnormalities were noted.   6. Diagnostic Assessment:  A non-contrast CT scan of the head was performed promptly  showing a hyperdense area in the left middle cerebral artery territory suggestive of an acute ischemic stroke. Further diagnostic work-up including ECG and blood tests were ordered to evaluate the underlying cause and severity of the stroke.   7. Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was admitted to the stroke unit. He was eligible for thrombolysis within the 3-hour window from the onset of symptoms  and was started on tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) after obtaining written informed consent. Simultaneously  his blood pressure was tightly controlled with continuous infusion of antihypertensive agents. He was also started on Aspirin 300mg daily and Atorvastatin 40mg twice daily.   8. Follow-Up and Outcomes:  Over the following days  his neurological symptoms improved. He was discharged home after a 9-day hospitalization  and referred to physical and speech therapy. A stroke prevention program including smoking cessation  regular exercise and a diet plan for controlling blood pressure and blood glucose was provided.   The patient was scheduled for regular check-ups to monitor his blood pressure  blood glucose levels and to ensure appropriate medication adherence. His family was educated regarding stroke signs and symptoms  emergency measures  and the importance of regular follow-up and medication compliance.  This case emphasizes the need for early recognition and prompt management of ischemic stroke  lifestyle modifications and meticulous management of risk factors in patients with hypertension and diabetes to prevent debilitating complications.

Patient Profile:   Gender: Male Age: 68 years old Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Presenting Concerns:  The patient reported sudden-onset weakness on the right side of his body and difficulty in verbal communication a few hours ago  and was immediately taken to the emergency department for examination. He also complained about a severe headache that started concurrently with the above-mentioned symptoms.  Medical History:  The patient mentions a history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 15 years. He is also a chronic smoker  with a history of smoking nearly a pack a day for more than 40 years. His other conditions include hyperlipidemia for which he has been on medication. His father suffered a cerebrovascular accident (stroke) at the age of 72 and passed away due to the complications. There is no history of diabetes or other chronic diseases.   Clinical Findings:  On examination  his blood pressure was recorded as 180/100 mmHg. His heart rate was slightly accelerated (tachycardic)  with a noticeable irregular rhythm. Neurological examination revealed expressive aphasia (trouble in speaking or finding words) and right-sided hemiparesis (weakness on one side of the body). The rest of the examination was non-contributory.  Diagnostic Assessment:  A CT scan of the head delivered an image showing an area of low attenuation in the left hemisphere  primarily affecting the middle cerebral artery region  indicative of an ischemic stroke. Blood tests showed slightly elevated cholesterol levels and a random blood sugar within normal limits. An EKG confirmed an arrhythmia.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Given his presentation and the time of stroke onset  the patient was eligible for thrombolysis therapy. He was promptly started on IV Alteplase. Index of suspicion for a cardio-embolic source was high due to his heart arrhythmia - the patient was started on anticoagulants. His antihypertensive therapy was optimized.   Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient's strength on his right side  as well as his speech  markedly improved after the infusion. He was later referred to a rehabilitation center for further management of his residual deficits.  This case highlights the importance of rapid identification and management of stroke  emphasizing on the importance of vascular risk factors such as hypertension  smoking  and hyperlipidemia. The irregular heart rhythms detected indicate a probable underlying arrhythmia such as atrial fibrillation which should be confirmed in the follow-up outpatient setting.

Case Report   Patient Information:   • Name: Mrs. X (Name concealed due to privacy matters) • Age: 67  • Sex: Female  • Occupation: Retired teacher  • Ethnicity: Caucasian  • Marital Status: Widowed • Chief complaint: Sudden weakness and numbness on the right side of the body  Medical History:   Mrs. X has a significant medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which she has been on medication for around 15 years. She is also a chronic smoker and remains to consume about half a pack per day for 35 years. Further  she had diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes 10 years ago  and for this  she has been on oral hypoglycemic agents.   Case Description:   On 12th March 2021  Mrs. X was brought to the emergency department as she was experiencing sudden weakness on the right side of her body including the face  arms  and legs  also it was difficult for her to speak. She had been fine until an hour before coming to the hospital when she developed these symptoms while having breakfast. The daughter who accompanied her stated that Mrs. X had not been taking her hypertension medications properly for a few days.   On presentation to the hospital  Mrs. X was dysarthric and had right-sided facial droop. Her blood pressure was noted to be 190/100 mmHg. On neurological examination  there was noted to be right-sided hemiparesis  with the power of 2/5 in her right upper and lower limbs. A CT scan revealed left middle cerebral artery infarction.  Management and Follow-up:  She was given intravenous rt-PA (recombinant tissue plasminogen activator) as a part of the thrombolysis treatment as she reached the hospital within the treatment window. Later  an individual care plan was developed including physiotherapy and speech and language therapy. She was placed on aspirin and statins. Her hypertension medication was upgraded.   Over the next several weeks of her hospital stay  she displayed slow but steady improvement in her motor function with the continued assistance of physiotherapy. Unfortunately  her speech showed only minimal improvement. She was counseled regarding lifestyle modifications including her smoking habit and dietary changes.   The patient was discharged in a medically stable condition but continues to return for outpatient physiotherapy and neurological follow-ups. She was advised to adhere to her medication schedule and to closely monitor her signs and symptoms of stroke in the future.  Conclusion:  This case serves to emphasize the importance of compliance to hypertension medication and lifestyle modifications in a patient with risk factors for stroke.

Case Report:  Patient Information  Mr. S  a 68-year-old African-American male  presented to the emergency department with acute onset of left-sided weakness  slurred speech  and facial droop consistent with a possible stroke.  Medical History  Mr. S has a significant medical history relevant to this presentation. Known cases include hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypercholesterolemia. He had been a smoker for about 35 years before quitting fifteen years ago. He has a family history of cerebrovascular disease  with his father having succumbed to a stroke at the age of 72 years.  Presentation  The patient was initially seen at a regional hospital but was transferred due to the requirement of a comprehensive stroke centre. At the time of admission  Mr. S reported that he woke up from sleep with symptoms lasting about an hour  which improved initially then worsened.  On initial examination  Mr. S had a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score of 10  characterized by left-sided facial weakness  left-sided hemiplegia  dysarthria  and some confusion. An emergent CT scan was performed which excluded the possibility of haemorrhage but demonstrated early signs of ischemia in the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory.  Management   An intravenous tPA  the clot-busting therapy  was avoided because of the uncertainty concerning when the symptoms initially began (as the patient woke up with the symptoms  and it was well beyond 4.5 hours when he presented). Mr. S was scheduled for emergent neurointervention (thrombectomy). Unfortunately  angiography confirmed complete occlusion of the right MCA  but there was no substantial penumbra  indicating maximum brain damage had already taken place. Hence  no mechanical thrombectomy was performed.  Outcome and Follow-up  Despite early detection and correct initial steps  Mr. S's stroke had major consequences. He was later transferred to the stroke unit  where he was commenced on antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin)  Statins for his hypercholesterolemia  and strict blood pressure and blood glucose controls were managed for his hypertension and diabetes respectively.  During the hospital stay  Mr. S received rehabilitative services  including physiotherapy  speech and occupational therapy. After a period of two weeks  there was a modest improvement in his condition  with residual left-sided weakness and mild issues with speech.  Following this  Mr. S was discharged to a rehabilitation center for continued recovery and stroke management. He will continue acquiring medical treatment for his underlying chronic medical conditions and will remain in outpatient follow-up care.  Learning Points: 1) Time is brain in acute stroke management – earlier intervention leads to better outcomes. 2) Rehabilitation after stroke can be a lengthy process and involves a multidisciplinary approach.  This case illustrates the devastating effect of pre-existing conditions  which increase the risk of severe stroke despite aggressive management.

Title: Acute Ischemic Stroke in a 54-Year-old Hypertensive Female  I. Demographic Information Name: Patient X Age: 54 Sex: Female Occupation: School teacher  II. Presenting Complaints  The patient was brought to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset left-sided weakness  difficulty in speaking and drooping of the left side of her face. The deficits were noticed about 3 hours post waking up in the morning.   III. Past Medical History Patient reported having been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 15 years. However  compliance to antihypertensive therapy had been inconsistent. Her blood pressure recordings over the last year ranged from 140/90 mm Hg to 180/110 mm Hg. She has no known history of diabetes  hyperlipidemia  or any other chronic illnesses. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. There is no significant family history of stroke. She has no known allergies to drugs or foods.   IV. Clinical Examination On examination  the patient appeared conscious but not oriented. Her speech was slurred. Her blood pressure on arrival was 170/100 mm Hg. The neurological examination revealed a left-sided facial droop  motor power of 2/5 in the left upper and lower extremities  and a slight impairment in touch and pain sensation on the same side. Cardiovascular examination showed rhythm regular without murmurs. Chest was clear on auscultation.  V. Diagnostic Assessment Based on her symptoms and signs  a clinical diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke was suspected. Urgent brain CT scan was performed and disclosed a right middle cerebral artery infarct. ECG and Carotid ultrasound were normal. Routine blood examinations including a complete hhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhemogram  serum electrolytes  renal function tests  liver function tests  and lipid profile were sent. Lipid profile revealed an elevated LDL level.  VI. Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was immediately started on intravenous thrombolytic therapy given that she was within the window period. She was also given aspirin 300mg loading dose then 75mg daily  atorvastatin 80mg daily  and her antihypertensive medications were reviewed and adjusted.   VII. Outcome and Follow-Up  Over the subsequent week  the patient's speech improved significantly  and her motor strength also showed mild improvement. She was discharged with prescriptions for aspirin  atorvastatin  and antihypertensives along with referrals to a speech therapist and physiotherapist. She was also educated about the importance of adherence to antihypertensive therapy and lifestyle modifications including a healthy diet and regular exercise to control her blood pressure and reduce her risk of recurrent strokes. Occupational therapy was recommended for improving her ability to perform daily activities.  VIII. Discussion This case highlights the risks associated with poorly controlled hypertension leading to complicating conditions such as an ischemic stroke. Early detection  immediate treatment  and appropriate rehabilitation were key elements for this patient's journey. Education on lifestyle modifications and regular follow-ups are critical in preventing recurrent strokes in such vulnerable patients.

Patient Profile  Patient Initials: A.G. Sex: Male Age: 63 Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired School Teacher  Case Report  Mr. A.G.  a 63-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden-onset weakness in the right side of his body and difficulty speaking. He was previously healthy and rarely sought medical attention. His medical history included hypertension  for which he had been sporadically taking antihypertensive medication. He has a 20-year history of smoking and moderate alcohol consumption. His mother had suffered a similar event in her late sixties due to atherosclerosis.  On examination  Mr. A.G. was found to have right-sided hemiparesis and facial droop. His speech was unclear and he seemed to have difficulty understanding simple commands  suggesting expressive and receptive dysphasia. His vital signs showed an elevated blood pressure of 170/98 mmHg. The rest of his physical examination was unremarkable. No immediate life-threatening conditions were identified  and it was suspected that Mr. A.G. had suffered an ischemic stroke.   He was rushed for a CT scan  which confirmed the presence of an acute ischemic lesion in his left middle cerebral artery territory. The patient's lab tests reported slightly elevated cholesterol levels but other values (including glucose  kidney function tests  and Complete Blood Count (CBC)) were within normal ranges.  Mr. A.G. was immediately started on intravenous thrombolytic therapy within the therapeutic window of 4.5 hours from the onset of symptoms. His blood pressure was closely monitored and antihypertensive medications were started to bring his blood pressure down to a safer level. After 72 hours  his symptoms improved slightly; his speech began to improve and the right-sided weakness was less profound than at initial presentation. He was transferred to the Stroke Rehabilitation Unit after a week in the Acute Stroke Unit for further recovery and to begin physical therapy.  This case highlights the importance of early recognition and treatment in ischemic stroke  as well as careful management of modifiable risk factors like hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and smoking  all of which were present in Mr. A.G.'s case. Despite his sporadic adherence to medication  rapid administration of thrombolysis seemed to have prevented severe disability in Mr. A.G.   Moreover  this case underscores the importance of acute rehabilitative therapy in improving prognosis and functional outcome after an ischemic stroke. Continuing assessments are to be done for Mr. A.G. as he undergoes active effective rehabilitation in the Stroke Rehabilitation Unit.  Patient Consent: Obtained.

Title: A Case Report of Acute Ischemic Stroke in a 68-year-old Diabetic patient  Patient Information:  The patient is a 68-year-old African American male who resides in a suburban neighborhood. He has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type 2 diabetes  and had a previous myocardial infarction 8 years ago. He is a former smoker but quit 7 years ago. The patient discloses moderate alcohol consumption and a lack of regular physical activity.  Clinical Findings:  Presenting to the emergency department with a sudden onset severe headache  left side weakness  slurred speech  and confusion. His alertness varied and he had a hard time following commands. On examination  his blood pressure was high at 179/95 mmHg  pulse 88 bpm  and respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute. The patient was immediately rushed to have a Non-Contrast CT scan of the head  which revealed an acute ischemic stroke in the right middle cerebral artery distribution.  Timeline:  The patient last felt normal approximately 12 hours prior to presentation. Initial stroke symptoms began acutely  with maximal severity at onset.   Diagnostic Assessment:  The patient’s National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score on admission was 22  indicating severe stroke. His blood glucose was measured at 250 mg/dL  elevated but expected for his diabetic condition. Fasting lipid profile showed total cholesterol 272 mg/dL  with LDL of 180 mg/dL  triglycerides 275 mg/dL  and HDL 35 mg/dL. His HbA1c was 8.0% suggesting poorly controlled diabetes.  Therapeutic Interventions:  Given that the patient's last known normal was outside the therapeutic window for thrombolysis and thrombectomy  he received conservative medical management. This involved blood pressure control with antihypertensives  secondary stroke prevention with dual antiplatelet (Aspirin and Clopidogrel)  statin therapy to control his elevated cholesterol levels  and tighter glucose management with adjustments in his diabetes medications.  Follow-up and outcomes:  After a week in the hospital  the patient showed some slight improvement  with NIHSS score dropping to 17. However  his left-side weakness was significant enough to limit his daily activities. He was discharged in a stable condition with a referral to physical and occupational therapy for continuing rehabilitation. His long-term prognosis remains uncertain.  Patient Perspective:  The patient voiced concern over his significant physical limitations and his ability to live independently in the future. He expresses frustration over his failure to adhere to lifestyle changes and medications previously prescribed for his pre-existing conditions.  Take-Away Lessons:  This case highlights the importance of primary prevention strategies and treatment compliance in patients with multiple risk factors for stroke. It supports the need for aggressive management of illnesses like hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes to potentially prevent devastating consequences like a stroke. It further emphasizes the role of lifestyle modification  routine follow-up  and patient education in chronic disease management.

Case Report: Stroke in a 63-year-old Male  Patient Information: The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of left-sided weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty in maintaining balance.  Patient Medical History: He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  all of which are controlled with medications. His medication regimen includes Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. He has no allergies. The patient is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history but quit 10 years ago. There is no history of illicit drug use and alcohol use is minimal. No history of previous stroke or transient ischemic attacks. His family history is notable for a father who had an ischemic stroke in his late 70s.  Physical Examination: Initial physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 170/102 mmHg  a pulse rate of 86 beats per minute  and a temporal body temperature of 37°C. Neurologically he was conscious but had dysarthria  left sided facial droop  gaze palsy and loss of power in left upper and lower limbs with power of 2/5. His speech was slurred with impaired comprehension and repetition  consistent with expressive dysphasia.  Investigations: An immediate computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain was performed  which did not show any hemorrhage. However  it showed early signs of ischemic infarction in the region supplied by the right middle cerebral artery. ECG demonstrated sinus rhythm with left ventricular hypertrophy. Lab reports revealed slightly elevated fasting blood glucose levels and a raised total cholesterol of 7.0 mmol/L.  Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with an acute ischemic stroke due to right middle cerebral artery (MCA) occlusion.  Management and Progress: Following emergency department assessment and a diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke  the patient was given intravenous thrombolytic therapy (alteplase) within a 3 hours window of symptom onset. Blood pressure was managed within the recommended range using antihypertensives. Lipid-lowering and glucose-controlling drugs were continued. He was admitted to the stroke unit for further management and monitoring.  During hospitalization  the patient received physiotherapy and speech-language therapy. The patient showed signs of improvement over time  with a slow return of function in the left upper and lower limbs. His expressive dysphasia improved.   After a period of hospitalization and rehabilitation  he was discharged to continue his recovery at home. He was educated about the importance of medication adherence  maintaining a healthy diet  regular physical activity  and follow-up outpatient appointments.   Follow-up and Outcomes: At a follow-up appointment six weeks later  the patient continued to improve. He had residual mild weakness in the left side but was able to perform daily activities independently. His speech was more fluent with occasional word-finding difficulties.  Teaching points: This case underscores the importance of timely recognition and treatment of acute ischemic stroke  as well as the contribution of vascular risk factors such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes in the development of stroke. It highlights the critical role of comprehensive rehabilitation for recovery after stroke and the value of controlling cardiovascular risk factors for secondary prevention.

Title: Acute Ischemic Stroke in a Female Patient with History of Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Introduction:  Presenting a case of a 68-year-old African American female with a medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension (HTN)  type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM)  and hyperlipidemia presenting with acute ischemic stroke.  Patient Information:  Ms. B is a retired school teacher  non-smoker  known to drink moderate amounts of alcohol socially  living alone. She has a history of poor medication adherence due to forgetfulness and financial constraints.  Clinical Findings:  Ms. B was brought to the emergency department (ED) after being discovered by a neighbor unresponsive with evidence of right-sided weakness. She had last been seen well approximately 12 hours before being found. Upon arrival  she was stuporous but rousable to painful stimuli with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 8. She exhibited right hemiparesis and aphasia.   She had a blood pressure of 180/95 mmHg  heart rate of 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation of 98% on room air  and had a random blood glucose level of 240 mg/dL.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Immediate brain imaging with computed tomography (CT) scan demonstrated a large area of diminished attenuation in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery compatible with acute infarction. No hemorrhage was seen. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed left ventricular hypertrophy with no acute ischemic changes. Carotid Doppler ultrasound revealed moderate stenosis of left internal carotid artery.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was beyond the therapeutic window for thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). Therefore  the patient was started on aspirin  atorvastatin  and a high-dose statin. She was also admitted to the stroke unit for intensive blood pressure control  tight glycemic management  and neurologic monitoring. Physiotherapy and speech therapy consultations were made for rehabilitation planning.  Outcome and Follow-up:  Over the course of her hospital stay  the patient's neurological deficits persisted. She remained hemiparetic and aphasic. Her blood pressure and blood sugars were brought under control. After a week  she was transferred to a rehabilitation facility for continued physiotherapy and speech therapy.  Disclosure Statement:  Permission has been obtained from the patient to publish details about her case for the purpose of medical education and knowledge enhancement. All possible effort has been made to conceal the identity of the patient.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of good control of risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes in the prevention of major complications like stroke. It also emphasizes the significance of timely medical attention in cases of acute stroke where interventions like thrombolysis can drastically improve outcomes.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. Jones Age: 68 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Accountant Residence: New York City  NY  USA  Chief Complaint:  The patient was brought in by his daughter with a complaint of sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty in speech.  History of Present Illness:  Mr. Jones's symptoms started approximately six hours before arriving at the emergency department. Initially  he complained of a sudden headache. Subsequently  his daughter noticed a drooping of the right side of his face  weak right hand grip  and his speech became slightly slurred.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension: being managed with a diuretic and an ACE-inhibitor. 2. Diabetes Mellitus Type 2: controlled with a daily dose of metformin. 3. Moderate Alcohol user: drinks whiskey occasionally. 4. Tobacco user: 20 cigarettes/day for over 40 years. No history of drug abuse. 5. No significant surgical or family history.  Physical Examination:  Vitals: Blood Pressure: 160/90 mmHg  Pulse: 92 bpm  Respiratory Rate: 22 breaths/min  Temp: 98.6 F/ 37 C  Oxygen Saturation: 96%  Physical exam was significant for facial droop on the right side  decreased strength in the right upper and lower extremities  and slurred speech. Otherwise  the remaining of the physical examination was normal.  Investigations:  Immediate CT scan of the head was performed  which indicated a left middle cerebral artery ischemic stroke. Complete blood count  metabolic panel  and coagulation screen were within normal limits. His HbA1c was slightly elevated indicating poor control over his diabetes.  Management:  Mr. Jones was immediately initiated on IV rtPA (altepase) for acute stroke treatment given that he was within the therapeutic window. After the stroke team's evaluation  he was admitted to the hospital stroke unit for further management. He was also referred to a speech therapist and physiotherapist for addressing his speech and motor deficits respectively.  Prognosis:  Mr. Jones's prognosis is uncertain at this moment. It largely depends on his responsiveness to treatment and rehabilitation process in future.  Plan:  Long-term management will include aggressive blood pressure and diabetes control  discontinuation of smoking  decrease in alcohol intake  and secondary stroke prevention strategies. Also  Mr. Jones will need regular follow-ups with his primary care doctor  endocrinologist  and neurologist  and continue rehab therapy to regain his strength and speech.  Please note that patient information including names and locations are fictitious for this example case study.

Patient Case Report: Stroke   Patient Background Information  The patient is a 70-year-old right-handed Caucasian male  living in an urban setting. He is a retired production engineer  with a history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes a day for 50 years and occasional alcohol consumption. He has a significant family history of heart disease  both parents dying of myocardial infarctions in their early 70s. The patient's past medical history entails a diagnosis of hypertension and hyperlipidemia 15 years ago  and he's been on atenolol (50 mg/day)  and simvastatin (20mg/day) respectively.   Clinical Presentation  The patient was brought to the emergency room after his neighbour found him in a confused state with the inability to use his left limbs. He reported noticing symptoms the evening before  with sudden weakness in his left arm and leg  issues with balance  and trouble with speech and comprehension. The patient also reported a severe headache  visual disturbances  dizziness  but no loss of consciousness  seizures  or incontinence. No acute respiratory symptoms were reported. The patient denied any recent history of trauma or falls  infection  new medications  or illicit drug use.  Physical Examination upon Arrival  On examination  the patient appeared to be in moderate distress. Vital signs exposed a heart rate of 78 bpm  respiratory rate of 16 breaths/min  blood pressure reading of 165/90 mm Hg  oxygen saturation of 96% on room air  and a temperature of 37.2°C. The cardiac evaluation revealed regular rhythm with no audible murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Neurological examination showed a global aphasia (non-fluent aphasia with comprehension deficits)  right gaze preference  left facial droop  left upper motor neuron pattern weakness (4/5 strength in the left upper and lower extremities)  sensory loss to all modalities on the left side of the body  and a diminished left brachioradialis reflex.   Investigations and Diagnosis  The examination findings provoked a probable diagnosis of ischemic stroke. A CT scan of the head was immediately conducted  which revealed a right-middle cerebral artery infarction. An Echocardiogram illustrated no pathological findings  excluding the hypothesis of a cardiac origin of an embolic stroke. Furthermore  blood tests including complete blood count  coagulation factors  lipids and glucose were within normal limits. The final conclusive diagnosis was right middle cerebral artery ischemic stroke.   Treatment and Follow-up  Considering the time of symptom onset and presentation  the patient was not a candidate for thrombolytic therapy. Management was mainly supportive with constant monitoring  secondary stroke prevention measures  and rehabilitation. After stabilizing  he was referred to physiotherapy  occupational therapy  and speech therapy. Neurologists with expertise in stroke managed his care during the hospital stay with cooperation from the primary care team  nursing personnel  physiotherapy  and speech therapy services. The patient has shown slow  but consistent signs of recovery.

Patient's Name: Mr. George Becker  Sex: Male  Age: 66 years   Ethnicity: Caucasian  Address: 127 Austin Street  Riverside  California   Presenting Complaint: Sudden onset of weakness on the right side of the body and difficulty with speech.   Date of Onset: (Week prior to hospitalization)  Background: The patient called an ambulance after awakening from sleep with the presenting complaints. The patient lives alone  and it was established that he likely spent approximately 30 minutes from when he awoke to when he called for help.  Past medical history: Mr. Becker has a history of hypertension for which he takes Amlodipine 10mg daily. He was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes seven years ago and is compliant with his medication  Metformin 1000mg twice daily. He has no know allergies. He stopped smoking fifteen years ago and takes alcohol occasionally. There is no known family history of stroke.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient was conscious  alert but had noticeable difficulty with speech. His vitals were as follows: blood pressure 190/95mmHg  heart rate 85 bpm  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 98% on room air  and temperature of 98.6°F.  Neurological examination showed ocular deviation to the left  right-sided facial droop  decreased power 2/5 in the right upper limb and 3/5 in the right lower limb (on a scale of 0 to 5 with 5 being normal). Sensation was intact.  Investigations: Laboratory investigations showed mildly elevated HbA1c (8.2%) indicating non-optimal glycemic control. Lipid profile was unremarkable. Complete blood count  renal and liver functions were within normal limits. The electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed a normal sinus rhythm with no acute ischemic changes.   A non-contrast head CT scan was performed urgently  which showed left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory infarct. No bleeds were identified.  Diagnosis: Based on the clinical presentation and radiologic findings  the diagnosis of ischemic stroke was made (left MCA territory).  Treatment: Treatment was initiated promptly with aspirin  325 mg orally  stat. Due to the delay in presentation  the patient was not eligible for thrombolytic therapy. He was also started on atorvastatin 80 mg and continued on his standard medications.   Rehabilitation: The patient was referred to physical therapy for motor rehabilitation and a speech-language pathologist for speech therapy.   The patient's condition is being closely monitored  and he is responding well to therapy.    Next Follow-up: 1 month from discharge date.

Patient Identifier: Case 001-SR  Background: A 62-year-old African male was admitted to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe headache  right-side weakness  and slurred speech  indicating a likelihood of cerebrovascular event.  Clinical Features: The episode started abruptly an hour before he was brought to the hospital. His headache was reported to be of high intensity  localized at the occipital region and was without any precipitating factor. He also complained of sporadic vertigo  diplopia  and difficulty swallowing. Initial Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was 14/15 (E4V4M6).  Patient History: He is a known case of hypertension for the past ten years and is on regular antihypertensive medication (Enalapril 5mg once daily). The patient also has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for seven years and is on oral hypoglycemic drugs (Metformin). He had a history of smoking 20 cigarettes a day for 40 years and is a moderate alcohol consumer but has no history of illicit drug use. There is no history of similar episodes  seizure  trauma  or loss of consciousness. No known drug allergies were reported.   Examination and Tests:  On examination  he was fully conscious  oriented but had motor aphasia. Blood pressure was 170/95 mmHg  pulse 85 beats per minute  regular and temperature 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit. Neurological examination revealed right hemiplegia  right facial palsy  dysarthria  and dysphagia. Rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.  An urgent CT scan of the head was performed which revealed an acute infarct in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery.  Management: The patient was immediately commenced on Asprin (300mg) and Atorvastatin (20mg). Glycemic control was optimized. Physiotherapy was initiated for limb weakness.  Outcome:  His condition stabilized over a week with a gradual decrease in headache intensity and a mild improvement of motor aphasia. The patient was discharged 10 days later and was advised regular check-ups and adherence to the prescribed medications and lifestyle modifications.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of immediate medical attention and management in acute cerebrovascular events to prevent severe disability and improve the outcome. The patient's lifestyle habits and medical history of hypertension and diabetes present as risk factors reiterating the significance of primary prevention strategies in stroke patients at risk.

Case Report:  Patient Profile: Mr. John Peterson  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  residing in Pasadena  California  presented to the emergency room with symptoms suggestive of a stroke. He lives with his wife who is his primary caregiver.  Medical History: Mr. Peterson has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which have been under control with medication for the past 15 years. He has been relatively compliant with his prescribed medication regimen  including lisinopril 10 mg for hypertension and metformin 500 mg for his diabetes. He has no known allergies. The patient is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  and only consumes alcohol occasionally during social gatherings. His family history is notable for a father who had a stroke at the age of 65 and a mother who also had diabetes.  Presentation: On arrival  Mr. Peterson displayed signs of acute neurological dysfunction. He presented with sudden onset of left-sided weakness  facial drooping  slurred speech  and difficulty walking. His initial vitals showed a blood pressure of 180/90 mmHg  heart rate of 90 bpm  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and an oxygen saturation level of 93% in room air.  Investigation: Neurological examination indicated a score of 15/15 on the Glasgow Coma Scale. The National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score was 14  indicating a moderate-severe stroke. An immediate non-contrast CT head scan did not show any evidence of a hemorrhagic stroke. A blood analysis indicated elevated blood glucose levels at 225 mg/dl and other laboratory values were within normal ranges. An ECG showed normal sinus rhythm.  Management: Mr. Peterson was diagnosed with an ischemic stroke. Clot-busting therapy with intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) was immediately initiated within the therapeutic window of 3 hours of symptom onset. He was also started on aspirin 100mg and atorvastatin 40mg to prevent further clotting. His blood pressure was managed with continued lisinopril use and an additional prescription of amlodipine. His blood glucose levels were regulated with an adjusted dose of metformin.  Outcome: Mr. Peterson was admitted to the neurology ward for further monitoring. He showed progressive improvement in clinical symptoms over the course of his admission. His blood pressure and blood glucose levels stabilized with medication  and his left-side weakness showed a significant reduction. He was scheduled for physiotherapy sessions for his residual motor impairments. He demonstrated understanding of the importance of adhering to his medication regimen strictly and of making necessary lifestyle modifications. Mr. Peterson will continue to have routine check-ups in the neurology outpatient clinic.  In conclusion  this case emphasizes the importance of early recognition and management of stroke symptoms  showing a positive patient outcome resulting from immediate medical intervention within the therapeutic window.

Patient Information: Mr. K. Adams  60-year-old Caucasian male  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of slurred speech  right arm weakness and confusion  Presenting Illness: The patient  Mr. K. Adams  presented to the emergency room accompanied by his wife  after an abrupt manifestation of slurred speech  weakness of right arm and a sense of disorientation. He also reported experiencing a severe headache which started the night before.  Past Medical History: Mr. Adams has a ten-year history of hypertension and five-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Both conditions were being managed by medications i.e.  amlodipine 10mg daily for hypertension and metformin 1000mg twice daily for diabetes. His blood pressure levels and blood sugars have occasionally been found to be in the higher bracket over the past year. He is a former smoker  having quit three years prior  but does have a drinking history (moderate - 7-14 units per week). There is no history of any other significant illness or surgery in the past. Additionally  there is no known allergy to any medication. There is a family history of stroke in his father at the age of 68 years.  Physical Examination: The patient was alert but appeared anxious and confused. His vital signs were: blood pressure 180/95 mm Hg  pulse rate 80 bpm  regular & breathing cleanly at 16 breaths/min  temperature 98.6°F. Neurological exam revealed dysarthria  facial droop on the right side  right arm drift suggestive of right side weakness (NIH Stroke Score of 5). The rest of his systemic examination was unremarkable.  Investigation Findings: Laboratory tests showed an elevated blood sugar of 250mg/dL  HbA1C of 8.5% and raised LDL cholesterol 160mg/dL. The EKG was normal  but CT scan of his brain revealed the presence of an acute left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory infarct. Carotid doppler showed 60% stenosis on both sides. His echocardiography was normal with an ejection fraction of 60%.  Diagnosis: The patient was thus diagnosed with an acute ischemic stroke (Left MCA territory)  secondary to poorly managed hypertension and uncontrolled diabetes.  Management: The patient missed the opportunity for thrombolysis as he presented 5 hours after the onset of symptoms. He was started on aspirin  a statin  and antihypertensives. His diabetic medications were reviewed and optimised. The patient was also referred to a physiotherapist for early rehabilitation.  This case accentuates the importance of optimal control of hypertension and diabetes in reducing the risk of preventive conditions like stroke. It also emphasizes the importance of a timely presentation to the hospital following the onset of acute neurological symptoms as it can make a major difference in the outcome of the patient.

Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 69-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department of our facility.  Chief Complaint: The patient reports a sudden onset of slurred speech  weakness in the right upper and lower extremities  and difficulty swallowing that started hours before his arrival.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He also has hyperlipidemia and obstructive sleep apnea. He has a 40-pack year history of smoking  but quit approximately ten years ago. He does not consume alcohol. He denies any history of illicit drug use.  Physical Examination: Upon arrival  his vital signs were stable but the neurological examination revealed right-sided facial droop  motor weakness  and mild dysarthria. The patient scored 12 on the NIH Stroke Scale. The remaining systemic examinations were unremarkable except for the presence of a bruit over the right carotid artery.  Diagnostic Assessment: Laboratory investigations including complete blood count  blood chemistry  fasting lipid profile  and coagulation tests were within normal range except for the elevated blood sugars and HbA1C confirming poor glycemic control. Computerized tomography (CT) scan of the head revealed a left middle cerebral artery territory infarction. A duplex ultrasound of the carotid artery demonstrated significant stenosis of the right internal carotid artery.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was promptly treated with intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) within the therapeutic window. The patient was admitted to the stroke unit where a multidisciplinary team was involved in his care. This included initiating aggressive management of his risk factors  blood pressure  and blood glucose levels.  Follow-up and Outcomes: His symptoms of dysarthria and right-sided weakness started showing signs of gradual improvement within days. He was kept under observation for 72 hours  and no complications were observed. As per hospital protocol  a rehabilitation therapist evaluated Mr. John and he was scheduled for regular physiotherapy with an aim to improve motor function.   The patient was discharged after a week in stable condition with appointments for follow-ups in neurology  endocrinology and physiotherapy. The importance of medication adherence  lifestyle modification  and regular follow-up visits was reinforced to the patient upon discharge.  Learning Points: This case highlights the importance of immediate recognition and intervention in acute stroke cases. It further emphasizes the need for aggressive management of risk factors  especially in patients with multiple comorbidities like diabetes and hypertension which can substantially increase the risk of ischemic stroke. This patient’s case will encourage healthcare professionals to consistently communicate and educate patients on the significant role of risk modification and medication compliance in reducing stroke recurrence.

Title: Ischemic stroke in a 68-year-old Caucasian Female with a History of Hypertension and Diabetes  Case Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. The symptoms started an hour prior to her arrival at the hospital. Her son  who accompanied her  reported that she was unable to lift her right arm and her speech was slurred.  Past Medical History:  The patient is known to have a 15-year history of type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and hypertension  which had been controlled with medication. She has been on Metformin 500mg twice daily and Lisinopril 10mg once daily. The patient has a 10-pack year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. She is allergic to Penicillin  which is known to cause a rash.  Family History:  The family history is notable for a father who had a myocardial infarction at age 65 and a mother with hypertension and type 2 diabetes.   Assessment:  On examination in the ED  her blood pressure was 168/92 mmHg  heart rate was 88 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 18 breaths per minute  temperature was 36.7 °C  and oxygen saturation was 98% on room air. The NIH stroke scale was used to assess the level of impairment  and she scored a 14  suggestive of moderate to severe ischemic stroke.  Imaging:  A CT scan of her brain shows an infarct in the left middle cerebral artery. No intracranial hemorrhage was identified. An echocardiogram showed left ventricular hypertrophy  but there were no other structural abnormalities or evidence of thrombus. An EKG showed normal sinus rhythm.  Subsequent Management:  She was given tPA (tissue plasminogen activator) within three hours of her symptom onset  as she met eligibility criteria for thrombolytic therapy. After the administration of tPA  she was carefully monitored for potential complications. The patient was admitted to the stroke unit for further management.  Plans for further management include:  1. Attempt to identify the etiology of stroke  including investigations for potential cardiac sources of embolism  2. Control of risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes 3. Occupational and physical therapy to facilitate rehabilitation 4. Preventive measures such as antiplatelet therapy and statin therapy  subject to the results of investigations 5. Education about the signs of stroke and importance of seeking immediate treatment  Patient education regarding lifestyle alterations including physical activity  diet adjustments  and medication compliance will be an essential part of her treatment plan. Her existing medication regimen will be reviewed and revised  as necessary  based on the results of ongoing investigations.  Follow Up:  The patient will be followed up as an outpatient with regular assessments of her recovery and control of risk factors  repeat neuroimaging remains an option based on her recovery.  Discussion:  This case illustrates the importance of quick recognition and early intervention in patients presenting with acute ischemic strokes  as well as aggressive control of risk factors in patients with established vascular diseases.

Title: Middle-Cerebral Artery Ischemic stroke in Hypertensive and Diabetic Patient  Case Presentation:  Patient Information: A 66-year-old African-American male presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and speech difficulties dating to approximately three hours from the presentation.  Clinical findings: On physical examination  the patient was alert and oriented but had acute aphasia along with right-sided hemiparesis. Vital signs indicated blood pressure of 185/105 mm Hg. The NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score was calculated at 14  suggesting a severe stroke.   Diagnostic Assessment: His medical history was remarkable for hypertension  type II diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. Laboratory findings revealed a random blood sugar of 268 mg/dL. An EKG test demonstrated sinus rhythm. An emergent non-enhanced CT scan of the head showed a left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory acute ischemic stroke. No evidence of hemorrhagic transformation was noted.   Therapeutic Intervention: As his symptoms commenced within the prior three hours  he was eligible for intravenous thrombolytics. Intravenous alteplase (rtPA) was initiated at a dose of 0.9 mg/kg  with a limit of 90 mg - 10% infused as a bolus and the rest over 60 minutes.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient was admitted to the Stroke Unit for close monitoring and standard post-thrombolytic care. His wife was educated to detect and report any unusual changes in the patient's condition. After 48 hours  the patient's speech improved gradually  and his right-sided weakness began to enhance as well. Blood pressure was managed according to post-thrombolytic protocols  and glucose levels were monitored and controlled. After a week of care  the patient was discharged home with moderate neurological deficits and advised on control and management of diabetes and hypertension  and the importance of medication adherence.  Conclusion: This case underscores the critical role of identifying stroke promptly and addressing associated modifiable risk factors such as diabetes and hypertension. Early administration of intravenous alteplase has been instrumental in improving the patient's outcome despite the presence of multiple comorbidities. It is also important to measure and communicate the values of medication adherence and lifestyle modification to patients  thus reducing the risk of stroke recurrence.

Title: Ischemic Stroke in a Middle-Aged Male with a History of Hypertension and Diabetes Mellitus: A Case Report  Patient Information:  The patient is a 54-year-old African-American male who is a resident of New York  United States.  Chief Complaint: The patient presented at the hospital with a complaint of sudden weakness on the right side of the body and difficulty speaking  which persisted for three hours before he arrived at the emergency department.   History of Present Illness:  The patient reported that he had woken up feeling tired as usual but while getting ready for work  he suddenly experienced weakness on the right side of his body. He also noticed difficulty in speaking and immediately called for an ambulance.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a 10-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. He had been prescribed anti-hypertensive drugs and insulin but adherence to the prescribed medication has been poor. The patient is a smoker with a 30 pack-year smoking history and is also a regular consumer of alcohol  averaging one drink per day. He has no known drug allergies and is not taking any other forms of medication. The patient also reported that his father died at the age of 62 due to a stroke.  Physical Examination: Upon arrival  the patient was conscious and oriented but showed signs of dysarthria. He had a blood pressure of 190/110 mmHg  pulse of 88 bpm  respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. His neurological examination revealed right-sided hemiparesis and facial droop.   Diagnostic Assessment: An initial CT scan revealed no acute hemorrhagic changes and no signs of mass effect. Subsequent MRI imaging  however  revealed a left middle cerebral artery distribution infarct confirming the diagnosis of a left ischemic stroke. Blood tests showed elevated blood glucose and HbA1c levels  indicating poor control of his diabetes. ECG was done which did not indicate any arrhythmia.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately treated with IV alteplase for thrombolysis along with aspirin in a monitored environment. His blood pressure was carefully controlled with intravenous antihypertensive treatment. Measures were taken to control his elevated blood glucose levels.   Follow Up and Outcomes:  During his hospital stay  the patient's speech improved   yet right-sided weakness persisted  albeit to a lesser extent. He was referred to a rehabilitation team for physical therapy and was discharged with a regimen of aspirin  a statin  antihypertensive  and antidiabetic medication. A strict plan to control his blood pressure and blood glucose was instructed. Complete cessation of smoking and alcohol consumption was also advised.   Patient Consent:  Informed patient consent was obtained for the treatment provided and will be kept on file.
