In conclusion  this case report highlights the significance of proper management of classic risk factors for stroke such as uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Moreover  it underscores the need for patient education regarding medication adherence  lifestyle modifications  and recognizing early signs of stroke for better prognosis.

CASE REPORT  Patient Profile: ID: Case Report #239 Sex: Male Age: 69 years old Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer Location: Clearwater  Florida  Presenting Complaint: The patient was brought to the emergency department with symptoms of sudden numbness and weakness of the left side of the body  dizziness  and difficulty in speaking and understanding speech.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia for which he has been on treatment for the past 10 years. He also has a history of smoking 1 pack per day for 30 years but quit 5 years ago. There is no record of any previous stroke or transient ischemic attack. He had an appendectomy at age 20 and a total knee replacement at age 62 due to severe arthritis. There is no report of any allergies.   Family History: His father died at 70 of a myocardial infarction and mother suffers from Alzheimer’s disease. He has one elder sister who is alive and healthy.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg  pulse 90/min regular  resp rate 20/min. Neurological examination revealed left-sided facial droop  left-sided weakness (muscle power 3/5 in the upper and lower limb)  and dysarthria. Other systems examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment: ECG did not show any ischemic changes. Blood tests  including lipid profile  blood glucose  and complete blood counts  were all performed and found to be within normal range except for elevated blood sugar and cholesterol. CT scan of the head showed a right middle cerebral artery territory infarct.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was diagnosed with an ischemic stroke and was started on IV thrombolysis within the window period. He was also managed for his hypertension and diabetes. A speech therapist was involved in his management.   Follow-Up and Outcome: The patient made a good recovery over the next week with improvement in his dysarthria and left-sided weakness. He was discharged and advised to adhere to a low salt  low cholesterol diet  regular physical activity  and strict blood pressure and blood sugar control. He was scheduled for a follow-up after one month.   Patient Consent:  Obtained  This case highlights the importance of early recognition and treatment of stroke  especially in those with risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  and a history of smoking. Further  there is a need for aggressive management of risk factors to prevent recurrent stroke.

Title: Acute Ischemic Stroke in a 67-year-old Male with Hypertension – A Case Report  Patient Information: A 67-year-old African-American male  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset confusion  sudden weakness in the right arm  slurred speech  and difficulty walking  History of Present Illness: According to the patient's family  there had been no prior warning signs. His symptoms precipitously occurred while he was having breakfast.   Medical History: He has had an established history of hypertension for 20 years. The patient's blood pressure has often been poorly controlled as he is non-compliant with his anti-hypertensive medication. He has no history of diabetes  atrial fibrillation or any other cardioembolic source. He is a non-smoker and refrains from alcohol.  Physical Examination: The patient was awake  alert  but exhibited signs of dysarthria. A neurological examination indicated right hemiparesis - exhibiting weakness on the right side of the body with facial droop. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment: An urgent non-contrast CT scan of the brain demonstrated an area of hypodensity in the distribution of the left middle cerebral artery suggestive of acute ischemic stroke. Labs including complete blood counts  electrolyte panel  liver and renal function tests  lipid profile  coagulation profile were essentially within normal limits  except for elevated blood pressure levels (185/96 mmHg).  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was given intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) as he presented to hospital within the therapeutic window for thrombolysis (within 4.5 hours of symptom onset). He was then started on aspirin 300mg and atorvastatin 80mg daily. His hypertension was managed with oral medication to maintain systolic pressure below 140mmHg.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Progressive improvement was seen in the patient's motor functions over the next few days. A rehabilitation program  including physical and occupational therapy  was arranged. Upon discharge  antihypertensives were re-adjusted and he was counselled about the essentialness of drug compliance for secondary stroke prevention.  Patient Perspective: The patient was grateful for the therapeutic outcome and expressed his resolve to adhere to medication and lifestyle changes to prevent a recurrence of stroke.  Key Learning Points: 1. Hypertension is a significant risk factor for stroke. 2. Importance of timely intervention in the management of acute ischemic stroke  including the short therapeutic window for thrombolysis. 3. Role of rehabilitation in recovering from stroke. 4. Importance of adherence to medication and lifestyle modification for secondary stroke prevention.   Contributors: This report was prepared by Dr. [Name]  the attending physician for the case. Reviewed by Dr. [Name]  Neurology Department Head.   Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for the anonymous reporting of this case.

Patient Information:  Mr. Abel  a 65-year-old African-American male  was brought into the emergency department from his home by his wife after showing signs consistent with a stroke.  Chief Complaint:  Sudden onset of slurred speech  weakness in the right arm and leg  and difficulty walking.  History of Present Illness:  The patient was in his usual state of health until three hours prior to his arrival at the emergency department. His wife informed the physician that Mr. Abel had been gardening when he started to slurred his speech and had difficulty raising his right arm. Upon noticing this  she helped him into their house where he fell due to weakness in his right leg. There was no loss of consciousness  no seizures  no sudden and severe headache  and no febrile illness. He phoned the doctor once he realized that he was unable to walk.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Abel has been on long-term medication for hypertension for the past ten years. He's a known diabetic for seven years and keeps his blood sugar level under control through a combination of insulin shots and oral medication. He's also been regularly taking statins for 5 years due to borderline high cholesterol level. He has a history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit nine years ago. He drinks alcohol socially. His last routine check-up was six months ago  and his vitals  ECG  and blood tests were all normal.  Family History:  Both of his parents had died from stroke; his mother at the age of 68 and father at the age of 70. The patient has one sibling  a brother who is healthy.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  Mr. Abel was conscious but anxious. His blood pressure was 175/95mmHg  pulse was 84 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 16 breaths per minute  and temperature was 98.1℉. Physical findings reveal right-sided facial weakness  dysarthria  right-sided hemiparesis  and hemisensory loss.  Investigations:  Lab tests including complete blood count  electrolyte levels  glucose  coagulation profile  and lipid profile were obtained. A non-contrast CT scan of the head was immediately performed which showed a left middle cerebral artery territory infarct. ECG showed normal sinus rhythm.  Diagnosis:  Based on the history  physical exam  and imaging findings  the patient was diagnosed with an acute ischemic stroke.  Treatment:  Mr. Abel was treated initially with IV normal saline and antihypertensives to control his blood pressure. As there were no contraindications  he was further treated using thrombolytic therapy (intravenous rt-PA)  within the recommended time frame. Afterward  he was admitted to the stroke unit where he was closely monitored and underwent a comprehensive management for secondary prevention of stroke which includes risk factor modification  use of antiplatelet  and statin therapy.  Follow-ups and Prognosis:  Mr. Abel requires continuous physiotherapy for his right-sided weakness and regular follow ups with a neurologist to monitor his condition. Prognosis in this situation is guarded as he responded well to the initial therapy  but long term outcome depends on the impact of the subsequent rehabilitation and control of his risk factors.

Patient Information:  Mr. Joseph  a 65-year-old male  Caucasian ethnicity  retired teacher  resident of Texas was admitted to the hospital with stroke symptoms on March 10th  2022.  Patient's Past Medical History:  Before the stroke  the patient existed hypertension for 10 years and Type II Diabetes for 15 years. His blood pressure and blood glucose level control had been inconsistent. He was on Amlodipine  Lisinopril  Metformin  and Sitagliptin for his hypertension and diabetes. He has no history of surgery or any other pre-existing disease. He has no known drug allergies. He is an occasional drinker and has quit smoking for the past ten years. There is a history of stroke in his paternal lineage.  Chief Complaints:  Mr. Joseph arrived at the hospital with difficulty speaking and loss of balance. The symptoms started suddenly about two hours before arrival. The patient was immediately taken into the Emergency Department of the hospital due to his symptoms.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient was alert and oriented but seemed distressed due to his inability to speak clearly. His Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) was 11 (E4V1M6). His vitals were Pulse 88 bpm  BP 180/100mm Hg  and SpO2 95% on room air. On neurological examination  there was weakness in his right upper and lower limbs along with facial droop on the right side.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  An urgent CT scan was done  revealing an acute left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territorial infarct  which explained the right-sided weakness and speech difficulty. The blood test showed slightly elevated blood glucose and a high level of LDL-C  despite the fact that the remaining numbers were within the normal range. His EKG did not show signs of cardiac ischemia.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous Alteplase after careful consideration of the risk versus the benefit of an ischemic stroke thrombolysis. Along with that  his anti-hypertensive was optimized to bring the BP under control and statin therapy was initiated for elevated LDL-C levels.  Follow-Up and Outcome:  After a couple of days of treatment  Mr. Joseph showed some improvements. His speech became clearer  and the weakness of his right limbs also started showing slight improvements. He was discharged with anticoagulant and statin prescriptions and was given appointments for regular follow-ups and physical and speech therapy sessions.   Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of speedy diagnosis and management in improving patient outcomes in stroke patients. It also underscores the need for aggressive management of risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes to prevent recurrent strokes.

Patient Information Name: [Redacted for privacy reasons] Age: 67 years old Sex: Male Race: African American Occupation: Retired Engineer Presenting Clinic: [Redacted for privacy reasons]  Case History Mr. [Redacted] presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-side weakness  difficulty in speaking  and numbness in the right arm. His wife mentioned he had been in his usual state of health until the earlier part of the day when they noted the abnormalities.  The patient was a non-smoker  consumed alcohol moderately  had a history of poorly controlled hypertension and diabetes mellitus  and had a family history of stroke. His medications included Metformin for his type 2 diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. He admitted to occasional lapses in medication compliance. He had no known allergies to foods or drugs.  On physical examination  the patient was conscious but had noticeable difficulty in speech (both in articulation and comprehension). His vital signs were stable albeit with a mildly elevated blood pressure (155/95 mmHg). Neurological examination revealed a right-side facial droop  mild dysarthria  and significant weakness in the right upper and lower limbs. Sensations were markedly reduced on the right side of his body.  Investigations  A quick non-contrast CT scan of his brain was ordered  which showed a hypo-dense area in the region of the left middle cerebral artery  indicative of an ischemic stroke. His ECG showed normal sinus rhythm and his laboratory tests revealed poorly controlled diabetes with an elevated HBA1c of 9.7%  but were otherwise within normal limits.   Management  Given that Mr. [Redacted] arrival was within the timeframe for thrombolysis  he was promptly given intravenous administration of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). His stroke was determined to be of significant severity  warranting admission to the stroke unit for further management and investigation.  Concurrently  his blood pressure was intensively managed and his diabetes was brought under control with insulin. His dosage of Lisinopril was increased and a new anticoagulant medicine was prescribed.  Outcomes and Follow-Up  The patient's condition notably improved over his hospital stay. After a week  he was discharged with much improved strength in his right limbs and speech  although some mild deficits remained. He was referred to speech and physical therapy for continuing rehabilitation.  An aggressive risk factor modification was sought with proper glycemic and blood pressure control. He was educated about the importance of medication compliance and lifestyle adjustments including proper diet  regular exercise and reducing alcohol consumption.  Conclusion  This case emphasized the importance of early recognition of stroke symptoms and immediate medical intervention in limiting the damage caused by a stroke. Primary prevention with effective control of blood pressure and diabetes is crucial in lowering the risk of stroke especially in high-risk individuals. Regular follow-ups and adherence to therapeutic interventions are likewise necessities for a better outcome.  (Information regarding the patient's background and diagnosis has been anonymized for privacy purposes.)

Patient Information:  Mr. S  an 65-year-old African-American male  Presenting complaints:  Patient was rushed to the ER department after being found unconscious.  Past Medical History:  Mr. S has had a history of uncontrolled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus which have been poorly managed throughout the years due to non-compliance with medication. A five-year history of tobacco smoking is also recorded  with an average of 10-15 cigarettes per day. There is no previous history of stroke or heart disease. However  he has an extensive family history of chronic conditions like diabetes  hypertension  and stroke.  Clinical Findings:  On examination in the ER  his Glasgow Coma Scale score was 11/15 (E3  V3  M5). His Blood Pressure was significantly elevated at 180/110 mmHg and his pulse rate was 80 beats per minute. Neurological examination revealed right-sided hemiparesis and facial droop. His language was garbled and he seemed confused indicating possible dysphasia.  Diagnostic Assessment: An emergent CT scan of the brain confirmed the presence of a left middle cerebral artery territory infarction. Blood investigations showed random blood glucose concentration of 220 mg/dL while HbA1c was at 9%. These values point towards uncontrolled diabetes. His lipid profile was also deranged with high LDL and total cholesterol levels.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately managed with intravenous thrombolytic therapy (tPA) within the therapeutic window. His blood pressure was tackled with IV antihypertensive and his blood glucose levels were controlled using insulin therapy.  Follow-up and Outcomes: He was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit for close monitoring. His speech improved and he regained some strength on his right side over two weeks of intensive physiotherapy. He was discharged with oral antiplatelets for stroke secondary prevention and antihypertensive drugs  alongside strict glycemic control measures. A detailed rehabilitation  lifestyle modification  and follow-up program were instituted.  Patient's Perspective: The patient understood his current health state and importance of medication adherence  adding that he now realizes the seriousness of his chronic health conditions and the consequences they bear.   Teaching Points: This case underlines the importance of proper management of chronic diseases like hypertension and diabetes and the strong influence of modifiable risk factors like smoking on stroke risk. It reaffirms that vigilance and prompt treatment in acute stroke can alter the course of the disease improving patient outcomes.

Patient Information:  Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 65 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. John Smith was admitted to the hospital emergency room with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking that started around three hours prior to his admission.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  which he has been managing with oral antihypertensive and hypoglycemic medications for the past decade. He also has hyperlipidemia and takes a statin medication for it. There is no documented history of any strokes or TIAs before this. Mr. Smith is a non-smoker but drinks socially. He has no known drug allergies.  Clinical Examination:  On initial examination  Mr. Smith was alert and able to follow commands but was noticeably dysarthric. His vital signs were stable except for an elevated blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg. Neurological examination revealed moderate left facial drooping  significant left-sided motor weakness  and sensory loss. His left upper and lower limbs scored 2/5 on the muscle strength test.   His reflexes were found to be brisk on the affected side  but Babinski's sign was absent. He also demonstrated mild dysphagia. His cranial nerve examination revealed no other abnormalities. There were no signs of neck stiffness or any other meningeal sign. His cardiovascular examination revealed an irregular pulse  suggesting possible atrial fibrillation. Rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.  Investigations:  A computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain was urgently performed which revealed an early infarction in the right middle cerebral artery territory. His Electrocardiogram suggested atrial fibrillation. A subsequent carotid Doppler study revealed no significant stenosis in carotid arteries. His blood tests including fasting glucose  HbA1c  lipids  and routine hematologic parameters were within the range of his known baseline.  Treatment:  Based on clinical features and investigation findings  a diagnosis of ischemic stroke was made. Since Mr. Smith presented within the therapeutic window of 3 hours for thrombolysis  he was immediately commenced on intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) following all necessary precautions. His hypertension was aggressively managed. He was also started on anticoagulant treatment for atrial fibrillation.  Outcome and Follow-Up:  With sustained rehabilitation and medication  Mr. Smith demonstrated significant improvement in dysarthria and motor strength over a period of a few weeks. He was discharged with a plan to continue physiotherapy and speech therapy. His current medications include aspirin  a statin  an oral anticoagulant  his antihypertensive  and hypoglycemic drugs.  Although secondary prevention with hyperlipidemia and blood pressure control would be necessary  the chief concern moving forward is to manage his atrial fibrillation to prevent further thromboembolic events.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of prompt recognition and treatment of acute strokes. It also reflects the role of managing chronic conditions like hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes mellitus  and atrial fibrillation for the prevention of such serious and potentially debilitating conditions.

Patient Information: Mr. J. is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department with right-sided facial droop  difficulty speaking  and right-sided weakness which began 50 minutes prior to presentation.  Clinical Findings: Upon arrival  Mr. J. was immediately evaluated. His blood pressure was found to be 160/90mmHg  pulse rate was 80 beats per minute and regular  temperature was 36.8°C  respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 98% on room air. His speech was slurred and he exhibited a pronounced droop on the right side of the face  as well as weakness in his right arm and right leg. Neurological examination including mental state examination revealed impaired sensation on the right side of the body. Pupil dilation was normal and examinations of the cranial nerves were unremarkable.   Past Medical History: Mr. J. has a known medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he was prescribed amlodipine and atorvastatin respectively. Additionally  he is a former smoker  having quit twenty years ago and denies any drug or alcohol use. He has no known family history of ischemic stroke or clotting disorders.  Diagnosis and Therapy: Given the rapid onset of symptoms and examination findings  a presumptive diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke was made. A neurological consultant was involved immediately and the patient was sent for an urgent computed tomography (CT) scan of the head  which did not show any evidence of hemorrhage. He was subsequently assessed to be a suitable candidate for thrombolysis. Within 90 minutes of arrival  the patient was administered intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (IV tPA).  Outcome and Follow-up: Mr. J. was admitted to the stroke unit for further management and observation. Over the initial 24 hours  his symptoms of right-sided facial droop and arm weakness improved significantly. His speech also improved although remained slightly slurred. A repeat CT scan at 24 hours was unchanged. Further investigations including ECG and carotid doppler ultrasound did not reveal the source of the embolism. The patient was discharged on aspirin and statin therapy. He was also referred for outpatient speech and physical therapy. At his one-month follow-up visit  Mr. J. made significant recovery  with slight residual slurred speech being the only observable deficit.  In conclusion  this case illustrates the importance of early presentation  diagnosis  and intervention in minimizing the long-term sequelae of acute ischemic stroke. This patient's outcomes were likely improved as a direct result of these key factors.

Patient Information  Mr. George Smith  a Caucasian man aged 71 years  residing in Pittsburgh  Pennsylvania presented to the hospital.   Cheif Complaint  Sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty in speech.  History of Present Illness  The symptoms started about 3 hours prior to arrival at the emergency department. He was doing his regular morning walk when he suddenly felt weakness on the left side of his body. He tried to call his wife but noticed that his speech was slurred.  Demographics  Mr. Smith is retired  a lifelong non-smoker with occasional alcohol consumption. He used to work as a factory worker involving mild physical exertion. There is no known family history of stroke.   Past Medical History  He has a history of hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus which are reasonably well controlled with medication. He is currently on Metformin 500mg twice daily for his diabetes and Amlodipine 5mg once daily for hypertension. He has neither allergy history nor a history of surgery in the past.  Review of Systems  Other than the current neurological disturbances  Mr. Smith denied experiencing any chest pain  shortness of breath  or palpitations. His bowel and bladder habits have been normal. He had lost about 4 pounds of weight in the past month  but he attributed it to his new diet plan.   Physical Examination  On examination  Mr. Smith was conscious and oriented but had slurred speech. He had a blood pressure of 180/95 mmHg  a pulse rate of 85 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 per minute  and a normal temperature. His neurological examination showed left-sided hemiparesis. There was no sensory loss. The cranial nerve examination was remarkable for facial droop on the left side. Examination of the cardiovascular  respiratory  and gastrointestinal systems were unremarkable.  Summary  This is a case of a 71-year-old male patient with sudden left-sided hemiparesis and dysarthria. His past medical history of hypertension and diabetes increases the chances of cerebrovascular accident or stroke. The absence of any sensory loss or other neurological signs  fortunately  suggests a potentially less severe stroke. However  his high baseline blood pressure is concerning and will need urgent management to prevent further complications. He was admitted and further investigated to confirm the diagnosis and treatment plan.

Patient Information:   Mr. John Doe  a 67-year-old Caucasian male was brought to the emergency department with complaints of a sudden onset of severe headache  right-side weakness and difficulty in speech. He has a stable job as an engineer  married with two children  and is a non-smoker. His history indicates occasional alcohol consumption on social events and no use of illicit drugs. He lives in an urban area and has a well-balanced diet. His family history indicates father with heart disease and mother with diabetes.  Clinical Findings:   On physical examination  Mr. John Doe was noticeably asymmetric with the right side of his face drooping. He presented with right-sided hemiparesis and expressive aphasia. His Glasgow Coma scale was 13/15 (E:4 V:4 M:5). His vital signs on presentation were within normal range except for high blood pressure (160/100mmHg).  Diagnostic Assessment:   The initial CT scan performed was indicative of a left middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarction  but showed no evidence for hemorrhage or mass effect. A complete blood count  renal function test  blood glucose  serum electrolytes and lipid profile were performed  which were all within normal range except for raised serum cholesterol level (250 mg/dL). He was also positive for carotid artery disease on duplex ultrasound.  Therapeutic Intervention:   As the patient was brought to the hospital four hours after the symptoms occurred  he was ruled out for thrombolytic therapy due to exceeded time limit. He was initiated on antiplatelets  statins  and blood pressure-lowering medications. Along with medical management  he was also given physiotherapy for motor recovery.  Follow-up and Outcomes:   The patient spent one week in the hospital during which he showed slow but steady improvement in his symptoms. His BP and cholesterol were brought under control and maintained. Upon discharge  he was scheduled for regular follow-ups with neurology  physiotherapy  and an outpatient medical management plan was given to control hypertension and hypercholesterolemia.  Patient Perspective:  Mr. John Doe recognized the need for lifestyle changes to mitigate the risk of a secondary stroke and is committed to comply with medical recommendations  regular follow-ups and physiotherapy sessions.  Teaching Points:  This case highlights the importance of patient's timely arrival to the hospital for potential eligibility for thrombolytic therapy  which could significantly affect the patient’s prognosis. Moreover  it emphasizes on the need for stroke awareness to recognize the symptoms and seek immediate professional help. Also  it demonstrates the role of proper medical management and therapy in reducing the risk of recurrent stroke and improving patient outcome.

Case Report  Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. Jones  Gender: Male Age: 68-years-old Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher Living Situation: Lives with wife in a single-story home  Physical Characteristics: Non-smoker  moderately active  BMI within the healthy range (under 25)   Family History: Father died of a myocardial infarction at 72  mother still alive but suffered a stroke at 65   Chief Complaint:   Mr. Jones presented to the emergency department with acute onset of right-sided weakness and speech disturbance. He was brought in by his wife who noticed a sudden change in his speech and movement during their morning breakfast.  Presenting Symptoms:  - Right-sided weakness (hemiparesis) - Slurred speech (dysarthria) - Facial droop  Health History:  Known Hypertensive for the past 15 years  on medication with Lisinopril and Amlodipine and also managing with dietary restrictions and moderate exercise. Has a diagnosis of type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 10 years  under medication with Metformin. Mr. Jones also has a history of Hyperlipidemia  controlled with Atorvastatin. Last routine check-up was two months ago  in which his blood pressure  glucose levels  and cholesterol parameters were within therapeutic control limits.   Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  he was conscious with a BP of 155/90 mmHg  pulse rate 80/min  and respiratory rate 18/min. Neurological examination revealed right-sided hemiparesis  motor aphasia  and facial droop on the right side.  Investigations:  A CT scan of the brain revealed a large ischemic stroke in the area supplied by the left MCA (Middle Cerebral Artery). His ECG showed no abnormalities. Blood investigations showed a mildly elevated glucose level of 160 mg/dl and a cholesterol level of 220 mg/dL.   Diagnosis:   Acute ischemic stroke in the left MCA region.  Treatment:  Mr. Jones was immediately started on an intravenous dose of Alteplase  a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA)  the standard treatment for acute ischemic stroke if given within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. His blood pressure was managed to keep it below hypertensive emergency levels. He was also started on Aspirin after 24 hours of tPA treatment.  Outcome and Follow-up:  Mr. Jones responded well to the treatment and showed a progressive reduction in symptoms. His motor skills improved and his speech became progressively more coherent over the following weeks with the help of physical and speech therapy. He continues to be under strict medical observation and physiotherapy for complete functional recovery.  Summary:  This case highlights the crucial role of immediate recognition and treatment of stroke for reducing the severity of symptoms and improving the patient's quality of life. The patient's history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia could have likely been contributing factors to his stroke. Thus  this case emphasizes the importance of routine checks and stringent control of these conditions.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old African-American male was brought to the Emergency Department (ED) by his wife for sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking that began approximately two hours prior to his arrival in the ED.  Patient Information:  Name: Mr. John Smith  Age: 68-years-old  Sex: Male  Race: African-American  Occupation: Retired Banker  Marital Status: Married  Smoker: No  Alcohol: Social Drinkers  Living Situation: Lives with wife  Demographics:  Mr. Smith lives with his wife in a suburban neighborhood. He is a retired banker  who enjoys reading books and playing golf during his spare time. He is a non-smoker and a social drinker.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has been diagnosed with hypertension over the last 10 years. He was also recently diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 3 years ago. He has been taking Lisinopril for his hypertension and metformin for his diabetes. Mr. Smith has a family history of stroke  with his mother having suffered one at the age of 74.  Clinical Findings:  On arrival to the ED  the patient was found to be alert and oriented to person  place  and time. However  he was having difficulty forming coherent sentences. His vital signs were considered stable: Blood Pressure - 170/90 mm Hg  Pulse Rate - 98 beats/min  Respiratory Rate – 12 breaths/min  and Body Temperature - 99°F. Neurological examination revealed right-sided facial droop  right upper and lower-extremity weakness with a power of 3/5  and slurred speech. No sensory abnormalities were detected.  Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical examination and the sudden onset of the symptoms  a preliminary diagnosis of an ischemic stroke was made.  Clinical Course:  The patient was immediately taken for a CT scan  in order to confirm the diagnosis of a stroke and to rule out a hemorrhagic stroke. The CT scan confirmed the radios of an ischemic stroke on the left cerebral hemisphere without any signs of hemorrhaging.  Treatment:  In accordance with the acute stroke care pathway  the patient was immediately started on intravenous Alteplase (tissue plasminogen activator)  within the therapeutic window of 4.5 hours from the onset of symptoms.   Outcome:  The patient responded well to the treatment. At a 7-day follow-up visit  he was noted to have improved in his speech and motor strength but still exhibited mild dysarthria and right-sided weakness. He was referred to physical therapy and a speech-language pathologist for further management.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of early recognition and timely treatment of an ischemic stroke  to reduce the risk of long-term disability. It also underscores the role of managing risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes  in the prevention of a stroke  particularly in patients with a family history.

Patient Information:  -Mr. J  a 72-year-old  Non-Hispanic Caucasian male -Currently retired  previously worked as an accountant  -Resides in a suburban area with his wife -Non-smoker and non-alcoholic -Family History: Father suffered from stroke at age 75  Mother had hypertension.   Presenting Complaint: The patient's wife reports that Mr. J suddenly complained of a headache and feeling dizzy. There was a sudden weakness in the right side of his torso and an inability to move it. His speech was also abnormal. The incident occurred while they were having dinner.  History of Present Illness: According to the patient's wife  Mr. J has been generally well until the sudden onset of severe headache and dizziness. Prior to severe condition  there were episodes of lightheadedness and difficulty in balancing  which Mr. J dismissed as signs of growing age. No history of trauma or falls. They reached hospital within the ""Golden Hour"" of stroke onset.  Past Medical History: -Mr. J is a known diabetic for the past 15 years and is on oral hypoglycemic agents.  -He was diagnosed with hypertension 8 years ago  for which he is on medication.  -There were no previous incidences of stroke or transient ischemic attacks.  -Other comorbid conditions include benign prostatic hyperplasia and osteoarthritis.  Physical Examination on arrival: The patient was conscious and alert. Upon neurological assessment  it was noted a weakness in the right arm and leg  and the right side of the face drooped. Speech was slurred  and patient struggled to articulate some words. Pupils were equal and reactive to light. Glasgow Coma Scale was 14/15.  Investigations: CT scan of the brain was ordered immediately which confirmed an ischemic stroke in the left middle cerebral artery territory.   Other investigations like complete blood count  renal function  liver enzymes  lipid profile  and HbA1c were carried out  which showed less controlled diabetes and high cholesterol levels. An EKG was also performed which was non-specific.   Conclusions: The patient was diagnosed with ischemic stroke  secondary to poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension. Treatment began immediately using an IV thrombolytic (clot-busting) medicine  after discussing the potential benefits and risks with family members. The blood sugar level and blood pressure were also medically managed.   Plan: The patient was referred to a neurosurgeon for evaluation of potential surgical intervention if necessary. Later  he will be evaluated by an occupational and physical therapist for assessment of rehabilitation needs. The wife was counseled on the importance of medication adherence  and they were provided with a list of stroke warning signs and advised to seek immediate medical attention should these signs appear. Mr. J was also recommended to adjust his diet  control his blood sugar levels and blood pressure  and participate in regular physical activity  such as walking. A revisit check-up was scheduled in two weeks.

Case Report: Acute Ischemic Stroke in a 65-Year-Old Male with Hypertension  Patient Information: A 65-year-old Hispanic male was brought to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty in speech.  Presenting concerns: The patient also reported experiencing a sudden severe headache  dizziness  and a change in vision. He initially disregarded the symptoms thinking it might be due to tiredness but called emergency services when he experienced difficulty in moving his left arm and leg.  Medical History: The patient has a known medical history of hypertension which is well controlled by Lisinopril 10 mg once daily and Amlodipine 5mg once daily. He also reported a history of smoking 10 cigarettes per day for the past 30 years and excessive alcohol consumption on weekends. The patient does not have any known allergies. There is no family history of stroke  but his mother has a history of coronary artery disease. He is not diabetic.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient was found to have slight facial drooping on the left side with noticeable slurring of speech. His BP was 170/90 mmHg and pulse 88 beats per minute. He showed clear signs of left hemiparesis. His National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score was 16.  Diagnostic Tests: A non-contrast CT scan of the head was performed which showed a right-sided middle cerebral artery (MCA) infarct suggestive of ischemic stroke. Electrocardiogram (EKG) showed sinus rhythm with no arrhythmia. Blood test showed a normal blood and platelet count. Lipid profile showed a slight increase in LDL cholesterol levels.  Therapeutic Intervention: Given the severity of symptoms and patient's presentation within 3 hours from the onset of symptoms  he was an eligible candidate for thrombolysis. The patient and his family were informed about the risks and benefits of thrombolysis. After obtaining consent  IV Alteplase (rt-PA) was administered. The patient's blood pressure was controlled utilizing intravenous antihypertensives.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Twenty-four hours later  the patient's symptoms had significantly improved with a reduced NIHSS score of 5. The patient had no major complications from the thrombolysis. A follow-up CT scan showed a decrease in the size of the ischemic region. He was referred to a rehabilitation service for speech and physiotherapy and has shown good progress to date. His blood pressure was well managed with his usual medication and he has been advised to quit smoking and limit alcohol.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of recognizing stroke symptoms  early diagnosis  and initiation of appropriate treatment in patients with cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension  smoking  and alcohol consumption. It also stresses upon the need for primary preventive measures and lifestyle modifications in patients at risk.

Title: Basilar Artery Occlusion Stroke in a 76-Year-Old Male with Hypertension: A Case Report   Patient Information:   The patient is a 76-year-old Caucasian male  a retired electrician living in a suburban community  with a medical history significant for long-standing hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol moderately.  Case Presentation:  The patient was brought to the emergency room by his son  who found him at home with sudden-onset right-sided weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty maintaining balance.Symptoms began approximately two hours prior to arrival at the ER.  Clinical Findings:   On physical examination  the patient was awake  oriented  and cooperative  but displayed signs of facial asymmetry with drooping on the right side. Speech was slow and slurred. Motor examination revealed right-sided hemiplegia. His blood pressure was elevated at 180/90 mmHg  other vital signs were within normal limits. Fingerstick glucose was elevated at 200 mg/dL.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An immediate non-contrast computed tomography (CT) scan of the head revealed a hypodense region within the distribution of the basilar artery  suggestive of acute stroke. Accompanying CT angiography revealed occlusion of the basilar artery. Blood tests demonstrated poorly controlled diabetes with an HbA1c of 8.2%.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Thrombolysis was initiated within the standard time window using intravenous alteplase (rtPA). Despite this  the patient's symptoms did not significantly improve  prompting emergent mechanical thrombectomy. Post-procedure  his symptoms improved markedly.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  The post-stroke physical therapy and rehabilitation program was initiated. At follow-up  one month later  the patient was bottling some residual right-sided weakness but was making steady progress with rehabilitation.   Patient Perspective:   The patient was grateful for the quick diagnosis and intervention that potentially saved his life. He expressed renewed commitment to manage his hypertension and diabetes and minimise his risk for future strokes.   Conclusions:  This case emphasizes the impact of aggressive emergency management of basilar artery occlusions  underscoring the importance of rapid diagnosis  immediate thrombolytic therapy  and  if necessary  mechanical thrombectomy. It additionally highlights the relevance of routine chronic disease management in patients with type 2 diabetes and hypertension to reduce the risk of severe complications such as stroke.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaints: New onset left-sided weakness and confusion.  Presenting Problems: The patient was brought to the ER by his wife  Mrs. Elizabeth Smith around 2:00 PM as he suddenly developed weakness on the left side of his body and started slurring his speech. He was also disoriented in time and place. There was no history of loss of consciousness  fall  headache  trauma  seizure  or incontinence of urine or feces.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith was a known hypertensive and type 2 diabetic for the past 15 years. He was also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia 10 years ago. He is a non-smoker but has a history of moderate alcohol intake.  Medications: He was routinely taking Metformin 500mg twice daily after meals  Amlodipine 5mg once daily  and Atorvastatin 20mg once daily at night.  Family History: His father succumbed to a heart attack at the age of 71  and his paternal uncle had a history of Stroke.  Social History: Mr. Smith is a retired accountant  lives with his wife  who also serves as his primary caregiver. He is financially stable and has a good social support system.  Examination: Upon physical examination  Mr. Smith was found alert but appeared confused. He exhibited signs of left-sided hemiparesis and expressive aphasia. His blood pressure was 170/96mmHg  pulse rate 88 bpm  respiratory rate 18 breaths/min  and temperature 98.8°F. Neurological examination revealed left hemiparesis and the increased tone of the left-sided limbs. His reflexes were brisk on the left side with extensor plantar response.  Investigation Reports: 1. Blood report indicated HbA1c: 8.5%  elevated LDL levels of 160 mg/dl. 2. Non-contrast CT brain showed a right-sided middle cerebral artery territory infarct. 3. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed normal sinus rhythm.  Diagnosis: Right Middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory ischemic stroke.  Management: His blood pressure was carefully managed  and he was given a thrombolytic (Alteplase). His antihypertensive was adjusted with the addition of Lisinopril  and a dual antiplatelet (Aspirin and Clopidogrel) was started. Statins were upgraded to high-intensity statin therapy. His blood glucose levels were managed with the continuation of Metformin and lifestyle modifications. He was counselled about his condition and prognosis. He was referred to speech and physical therapy for rehabilitation.  Conclusion: The case highlights the outcome of long-term poorly managed hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia leading to a complicated condition such as ischemic stroke. Early recognition  aggressive management  and correctable risk factor control are key components in the management and prevention of further complications and strokes.  Patient Confidentiality: This case report maintains the patient's anonymity following the Declaration of Helsinki guidelines.

Case Report  Patient Information Mr. O.A.  a 72-year-old male patient of Caucasian ethnicity  presented to the hospital suffering from acute confusion and difficulties with speech and coordination. The patient lives in a suburban region and works as a retired engineer. He was referred by his primary care physician after he experienced sudden-onset right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. The patient is a non-smoker and his alcohol consumption is moderate.  Past Medical History Mr. O.A. has a significant medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been taking medications for both conditions for the last 12 years  which include Lisinopril 10 mg daily and Atorvastatin 20 mg daily respectively. He has also been pre-diagnosed with type 2 diabetes  which has been controlled by Metformin 1000 mg twice daily for about 9 years.   Apart from the above-mentioned conditions  the patient has also undergone an appendectomy in his thirties. There was no significant family history of stroke or atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Mr. O.A. has attended regular follow-up visits for the management of his conditions. The control of hypertension and diabetes was relatively good  and lipid levels were within normal range. The patient has no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings On presentation  the patient was alert but oriented to person and place only. Physical examination revealed a BP of 152/88 mmHg and a heart rate of 98 bpm. The patient also presented with sudden-onset right-sided weakness and motor aphasia  indicative of a left-sided stroke. A high-resolution computed tomography (CT) scan of the brain was performed  revealing an area of focal hypodensity in the left middle cerebral artery (LMCA) territory that suggested an ischemic stroke.  Diagnostic Assessment  Mr. O.A. underwent a series of diagnostic tests including a complete blood count  and tests for coagulation profile  lipid profile  electrolytes  liver and kidney function. All came back within normal limits except for an elevated cholesterol level. A chest x-ray showed no acute disease. An electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed atrial fibrillation  a common cause of embolic stroke.   Therapeutic Intervention & Follow-Up Mr. O.A. received thrombolytic therapy within the early hours following his stroke onset  after he had been adequately anticoagulated. Simultaneously  his diabetes and hypertension were managed to keep his BP <140/90 mmHg and glucose levels <10 mmol/L. He was also started on aspirin daily to prevent further strokes  a Statin for his high cholesterol and a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) to address the atrial fibrillation.  In the weeks following his discharge  Mr. O.A. progressed favorably with physical therapy  occupational therapy and speech-language pathology input  which helped to improve his right-side strength and speech difficulty. Regular follow-ups were scheduled with his primary care physician for the management of co-morbidities and to monitor his recovery post-stroke.  Outcome Post-therapeutic intervention  there was a significant improvement in Mr. O.A.'s health. His motor skills and speech improved  and his condition stabilized  thereby improving his overall quality of life. His co-morbidities are well-managed through medication and regular follow-up visits.

Patient Information:   Mr. Terry Brown  a 69-year-old Caucasian male  retired school teacher  non-smoker  residing in Melbourne  Australia. The patient is married with two children. He has a past medical history of high blood pressure and hyperlipidemia. He has been on medication (ACE inhibitors and statins) for these conditions for approximately 5 years. There was no history of acute or chronic illness or previous surgical interventions. Mr. Brown is a moderate drinker  and he does not smoke.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Brown presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset of right-sided weakness  difficulty in speech  and extreme headache. These symptoms started approximately two hours before arrival at the hospital. No loss of consciousness or convulsions were reported.   Clinical Findings:  On assessment  Mr. Brown appeared conscious and cooperative but had apparent difficulty in comprehending and responding needs. He looked disoriented  with a slight slurring of speech. Initial vital signs were recorded as follows: blood pressure of 160/90mmHg  heart rate of 94 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Neurological evaluation revealed a decreased power in the right upper and lower limbs.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  An immediate CT scan of the brain was ordered which demonstrated an area of low attenuation consistent with an acute ischaemic stroke in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery. Blood tests revealed that his lipid profile was considerably raised. His random blood glucose level was within a normal range. All other routine laboratory tests were also within normal limits.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Given the clinical and radiological evidence of acute ischaemic stroke and within the window period for treatment  Mr. Brown was administered an intravenous thrombolytic agent. His hypertension was managed with antihypertensive drugs. He was transferred to a specialized stroke unit for further management and rehabilitation.   Follow Up and Outcomes:  After 1 week of episode and with the appropriate medical and rehabilitative care  the patient showed significant improvement in his symptoms. His speech got much better  and his right-sided weakness reduced considerably. Mr. Brown is scheduled for regular outpatient physical rehabilitation and clinical follow-up.  Patient Perspective:  Mr. Brown expressed his gratitude for the timely care he received at the hospital. He displays a positive outlook and commitment towards follow-up treatments and lifestyle modifications.  This case highlights the importance of immediate recognition and management of stroke  as timely treatment significantly improves the outcome. It also emphasizes the need for regular monitoring and control of risk factors such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia to prevent stroke. The role of easy access to rehabilitative care post-stroke could not be more stressed.

Title: Acute Ischemic Stroke in a Hypertensive  Diabetic Male Patient  Patient Information  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  currently living alone with some assistance from a home care nurse in Dallas  Texas. He is a retired mechanical engineer and a non-smoker. His only known allergies are Penicillin and Shellfish. He is 5'8"" tall  weighs 200 lbs  and has a BMI of 30.4  indicating obesity. His previous medical history includes uncontrolled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 10 years  Hypertension for 15 years and a history of transient ischemic attacks (TIA) 2 years ago. He has been prescribed Metformin 500mg twice daily for his diabetes and Lisinopril 20mg once daily for hypertension.   Chief Complaint:   The patient was brought to the emergency department due to the sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech that started around two hours prior to admission.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  blood pressure was 190/100 mmHg  heart rate 92 beats per minute  and pulse oximetry read 96% on room air. Neurological examination revealed right-sided hemiparesis and expressive aphasia. He scored 14 out of 15 on the GCS (Glasgow Coma Scale)  and 3 in the NIHSS (National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale).  Diagnostic Assessments:  An urgent non-contrast-enhanced CT scan was carried out  revealing an area suggestive of a left middle cerebral artery infarct. Laboratory investigations revealed a random blood sugar of 210 mg/dl and HbA1c of 8.5%. Further tests like lipid profile  kidney function  and liver function tests were within normal limits. The ECG reported a normal sinus rhythm.  Treatment:  The patient was treated with intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA) within the therapeutic window. His blood pressure was controlled with labetalol injection. He was closely monitored in the stroke unit and managed as per guidelines.  Outcome:  The patient's symptoms partially resolved after 72 hours  and he was later discharged on antiplatelets  higher dose of antihypertensive  and directions to optimize his diabetic control were given. He is presently in rehabilitation therapy to recover from the residual weakness.  Discussion:  This case emboldens the significant link between chronic conditions such as hypertension  diabetes  and increased risk of stroke. It also highlights the invaluable role of risk factor control in preventing ischemic stroke.  Informed Consent:  Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.

Patient Information:  Mr. J.W. is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired  a non-smoker  with a moderate alcohol consumption pattern  residing in East Baton Rouge  Louisiana.   Initial Presentation:  Mr. J.W. presented to the outpatient clinic with complaints of sudden onset weakness on the right side of his body and slurred speech that began about four hours prior. He also mentioned transient episodes of dizziness and blurred vision over the past week. He denied any headache  seizure  or loss of consciousness.   Past Medical History:  Mr. J.W.'s past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both under good control with medication. He was diagnosed with atlantoaxial instability about ten years ago and was managed conservatively. No history of stroke or major surgeries was reported. He has a family history of stroke: his father suffered from a stroke at the age of 75.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  the patient appeared conscious  but mildly disoriented. Speech was dysarthric. Neurological examination revealed moderate right-sided hemiplegia and right facial droop. No sensory deficit observed.   Differential Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical features and history  a differential diagnosis of ischemic stroke was considered. Other less likely possibilities included transient ischemic attack and intracranial lesion.  Investigations:  An urgent non-contrast CT Head was done  which revealed an area of decreased attenuation in the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory  indicative of an acute ischemic infarct. The carotid Doppler showed significant stenosis in the left internal carotid artery. His lab results revealed normal complete blood count  serum glucose  kidney and liver function tests  and lipid profile except for mildly elevated triglycerides.   Management:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)  within the 4.5-hour window period of stroke. Also  he was administered a loading dose of aspirin. His blood pressure and glucose levels were constantly monitored and managed.  Outcome and Follow-up:  Mr. J.W’s condition improved gradually over one month with physiotherapy and rehabilitation. He experienced significant improvement in speech and motor strength on follow-up visits. He was counseled on lifestyle modification  adherence to his antiplatelet medication  control of diabetes  and hypertension  and recommended for regular outpatient follow-up every 3 months.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of accurate and timely diagnosis of an ischemic stroke allowing the administration of intravenous tPA  which significantly improved the patient's health outcome. It also emphasizes the significance of vascular risk factor management in preventing a repeat stroke.

Case Report - Ischemic Stroke   I. Patient Information  Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old African American male  retired military veteran  presently residing in Plano  Texas. He lives with his wife and was admitted to the Stroke Unit at HCA Houston Healthcare Medical Center on 29th August 2021.  II. Chief Complaint  The patient was brought to the Emergency Department (ED) by his wife due to a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech  which his wife noticed when he tried to stand up from the couch  and he fell.   III. Past Medical History  Mr. Johnson has a medical history of hypertension  Type-2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He was diagnosed and started on medications for these conditions about ten years ago. He used to smoke a pack a day for 30 years and quit smoking approximately five years ago. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. He is allergic to penicillin.  IV. Physical Examination  On examination  the patient was conscious  oriented to time  place  and person but had a noticeable speech disorder  motor aphasia. There were no signs of sensory aphasia. His blood pressure was 160/95 mmHg  pulse was 90 beats per minute  and his BMI was around 30  indicating obesity. He showed signs of right-sided hemiparesis with weakness more severe in the upper limb than the lower. His speech was dysarthric with sino-nasal speech. Right facial weakness was present.   V. Current Clinical Diagnosis  Based on the patient's history  clinical presentation  and physical examination  an ischemic stroke is highly suspected.  VI. Laboratory and Imaging  His labs on admission reveal an elevated blood sugar level at 210mg/dl while HbA1c level was 7.8%. CT brain scan showed a hypodense area in the left middle cerebral artery territory suggestive of a left hemispherical ischemic stroke.  VII. Treatment & Follow Up   The patient was given an intravenous thrombolytic following a quick assessment by the hospital's stroke team and obtaining consent from the immediate family. Subsequent treatment included dual antiplatelet therapy and intensified control of his blood sugars and blood pressure. He was enrolled in physical therapy and occupational therapy as part of his rehabilitation program.    Patient’s wife was updated on medication adjustments and the importance of medication adherence. Arrangements were made for monthly telehealth follow-ups to monitor progress in stroke rehabilitation. The importance of regular control of blood sugar  blood pressure  and healthy lifestyle modifications were discussed. Given the high risk for recurrent stroke and other cardiovascular complications  referrals to cardiology and endocrinology were provided for long-term management.  This case underscores the need for public awareness about stroke symptoms and the requirement for coordinated medical services providing rapid diagnosis and treatment. Furthermore  it highlights the need for optimizing primary prevention measures in patients with established cerebrovascular disease.

Case Report: Acute Ischemic Stroke in a 67-year-old Male Patient   Evaluating Physician: Dr. XYZ  Patient Profile: The patient  Mr. A  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  residing in B city  presented himself to the Emergency department on August 29  2021  with the complaint of sudden weakness on his right side and difficulty with speech.   Past Medical History: Mr. A has a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension for 10 years and type 2 diabetes mellitus for 7 years. He also has a history of heavy cigarette smoking for the past 40 years and a past familial history of stroke. His other past pertinent medical history includes hyperlipidemia and atrial fibrillation  for which he has been on sporadic anticoagulation.  Presenting Symptoms: During the initial evaluation  Mr. A reported that he suddenly developed weakness on his right side  accompanied by numbness and difficulty speaking and understanding speech. These symptoms occurred while he was having breakfast.   Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed that Mr. A's blood pressure was 190/95 mmHg  pulse was irregularly irregular  and his glucose level was slightly elevated. On neurological examination  he was found to have dysarthria  right facial droop  and right-sided hemiparesis with a noticeable drift of his right arm. His NIH stroke scale was calculated to be 12  which is suggestive of moderate to severe stroke.  Diagnosis and Treatment:  The CT scan of the head revealed a significant left middle cerebral artery clot leading to an acute ischemic stroke. He was immediately given IV tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) within the therapeutic window of 4.5 hours post the onset of symptoms.   Intravenous heparin was started for his atrial fibrillation. An echocardiogram revealed atrial enlargement but no clot. His carotid ultrasound did not show significant stenosis.   Training and lifestyle changes were recommended for better control of his blood pressure  blood sugar  cholesterol  and to quit smoking.   Follow-up and Prognosis: Mr. A showed improvement in his symptoms after the thrombolytic therapy with improved power in the right upper and lower limbs. He will continue to receive speech and occupational therapy for residual dysarthria and arm weakness.  He has been scheduled for a follow-up with the neurologist and cardiologist to monitor his progress closely and make medication adjustments if necessary. Emphasize was given on vigilant control of blood pressure and strict adherence to anticoagulation to prevent recurrent strokes.  This case emphasizes the need for running an immediate diagnostic test and early initiation of reperfusion therapy in acute stroke  particularly in patients with risk factors  to prevent long-term disability. The importance of strict control of risk factors for secondary prevention has also been highlighted.

Case Report  Patient Information  Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 67 Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Presenting Complaint  The patient presented to the emergency department on November 6th with sudden onset of left-side weakness  slurred speech and difficulty walking.  Medical History  The patient has a past medical history significant for:  - Hypertension  diagnosed about twelve years ago. He is currently on Lisinopril 20 mg orally daily. - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  diagnosed ten years ago  currently managed with Metformin 500 mg twice daily. - Hypercholesterolemia  diagnosed eight years ago  managed with Atorvastatin 20mg orally daily. - He also has a history of smoking approximately one pack of cigarettes per day for the last forty five years.  Clinical Findings  Initial physical examination revealed:  - Rightward deviation of the eyes - Weakness of the left upper and lower extremities (Grade 3/5) - Slurred speech - Unequal pulse volume between the right and left radial arteries - Blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg - Blood glucose level of 200 mg/dl  Investigations  - Brain MRI indicated a right middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke. - EKG displayed left ventricular hypertrophy  consistent with his history of hypertension. - Carotid ultrasound showed significant stenosis of the right internal carotid artery. - Total cholesterol of 240 mg/dl  LDL 160 mg/dl  HDL 35 mg/dL and triglycerides 200mg/dl. - HbA1c was 7.5%  indicating poor control of diabetes.  Diagnosis  The clinical signs and symptoms together with the imaging studies led to the diagnosis of ischemic stroke due to occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery  likely secondary to severe carotid artery stenosis.  Treatment  The patient was not within the therapeutic window for thrombolytic therapy. Therefore  he was treated conservatively with:  - Dual antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin and Clopidogrel)  - Strict control of his blood pressure - Continuation of his existing Atorvastatin for lowering his cholesterol levels - Insulin therapy for better control of his blood glucose levels.  Prognosis  The patient showed gradual improvement over the next few weeks with physical therapy  also considering the multiple interventions aimed to reduce the further risk of stroke. It was recommended that he quit smoking  maintain a healthy diet and adopt a regular exercise regimen.  Follow-up  Mr. Smith will need regular follow up with his primary care physician and neurologist to monitor his response to treatment and adjust medications as needed. The importance of medication adherence was emphasized to prevent further vascular events. Long-term physical and some degree of speech therapy may be required depending on the patient's recovery.

Patient Information  - Identity: Mr. M - Age: 66 years - Gender: Male - Country of origin: United States - Occupation: Retired engineer  Presenting Complaint  The patient presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech that had started a few hours prior to hospital admission.  Past Medical History  Mr. M has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both of which have been managed with medication for the past 10 years. He is a former smoker having quit 15 years ago but admits to consuming alcohol regularly. His father passed away after suffering from a stroke at 68 years of age. The patient had been on angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and statins for his hypertension and hypercholesterolemia respectively.   Clinical Examination  Physical examination revealed an awake  alert patient with right-sided facial droop. Patient had right-sided hemiparesis (muscular weakness on one side of the body)  along with dysarthria (slurred or slow speech). His vitals on admission were: Blood pressure - 170/90 mmHg  Pulse rate - 86 beats per minute  regular  Respiratory rate - 18 breaths per minute  Oxygen saturation - 95% on room air  Body Mass Index - 28 kg/m^2.  Investigations  A non-contrast CT scan of the brain was ordered  which revealed an area of hypodensity in the left middle cerebral artery territory  suggesting acute ischemic stroke. His blood workup included a complete blood count  coagulation profile  electrolytes  cardiac enzymes  lipid profile and HbA1c. All test results were within normal limits  except for elevated LDL cholesterol levels and HbA1c indicating poor management of his hypercholesterolemia and a previously undiagnosed diabetes.  Diagnosis  Based on clinical examination  history and imaging findings  the patient was diagnosed with acute ischemic stroke.  Treatment  Mr. M was administered tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) within the therapeutic window. He was moved to the stroke care unit for further management including antiplatelet therapy  initiation of insulin therapy for his diabetes  continuation of his antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medications  and physical therapy was planned for the next day.  Discussion:   This case demonstrates the importance of managing risk factors like hypertension  hypercholesterolemia and undiagnosed diabetes to prevent the occurrence of stroke. Given the family history of stroke in the patient's father  the need for regular health checks and lifestyle modifications  including diet and exercise  cannot be overemphasized. Despite the suddenness of symptoms  rapid medical intervention helped to manage this patient's condition most effectively  minimizing potential long-term damage.

Patient Report:   Demographics: Mr. Kumar  a 67-year-old male  of Asian Indian descent  retired engineer  nonsmoker  resides in an urban setting with his wife.  Chief Complaint:  Patient was brought in after he complained of sudden and severe headache. His family also reported noticeable droopiness in the left area of his mouth.  Medical History:  The patient has a significant medical history that includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was diagnosed with these conditions about 10 years back and has been managing them with medication. Hypertension has been reasonably well controlled overall  and his blood glucose levels have been variable. Lipid profile reveals elevated total cholesterol levels. The patient has no known allergies to medications. However  he shares a family history of cerebrovascular accidents. His father suffered a stroke at the age of 72.  Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  the patient’s blood pressure was 170/105 mmHg  pulse 94 bpm  respiration rate 21 breaths per minute  and temperature of 36.8°C. His body mass index (BMI) indicated obesity. Neurological examination revealed facial asymmetry  left-sided weakness  and slurred  non-fluent speech with a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score of 12. The rest of the physical examination appeared normal.  Investigations and Diagnosis: The patient was promptly sent for a CT scan  which showed an area of hypodensity in the right middle cerebral artery territory indicating an acute infarct. The CT angiogram revealed occlusion of the right M1 segment  which further indicated an ischemic stroke. Hematological investigations were within range considering his medical history and type of condition.  Treatment Strategy: Mr. Kumar was immediately given a tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) within the 3 hours of his symptom onset. He was encouraged for dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  statin therapy alongside continuation of his existing medications for hypertension and diabetes. A further referral to speech and physical therapists was made for his left-sided hemiparesis and aphasia.  This case scenario brings into light the detrimental effects of unrecognized and untreated hypertension and diabetes  coupled with a sedentary lifestyle leading to obesity  which could significantly enhance the risk of cerebral ischemia or stroke among elders. It emphasizes the importance of regular health checkup  disease management  and lifestyle modifications for the prevention from such potentially disabling and life-threatening conditions like stroke.

Case Report:  Patient Profile: Mr. John Doe  a 67-year-old Caucasian male retired engineer  is admitted to our hospital presenting symptoms of possible stroke. The patient lives with his wife in the suburbs and has a 20-year history of hypertension and type-2 diabetes  which is controlled by medication. He quit smoking 15 years back  has a sedentary lifestyle  and significant family history of strokes with his father having a stroke at the age of 72.  Presenting Symptoms: Early in the morning  Mr. Doe experienced sudden weakness in his right arm and leg  slurred speech  and difficulty in maintaining balance. His wife noticed these symptoms and immediately contacted emergency services.  View Clinical & Medical History: He was diagnosed with hypertension and type-2 diabetes 20 years ago and is under medication for both conditions. His medications include Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. He quit smoking 15 years back but continues to drink alcohol socially. Mr. Doe's father suffered a stroke which brings a risk factor of genetics into consideration. He had his last complete physical examination six months back  with all reports being within acceptable regions.  Present Medical Examination Findings: Upon physical examination  the patient appeared alert but anxious. Neurologic examination showed weakness in the right upper and lower extremities. His speech was slurred  and he had trouble understanding verbal instructions. His blood pressure was found to be 170/100 mmHg and his blood glucose level was 190 mg/dl  which are significantly above normal ranges. Brain MRI indicated acute ischemic stroke.  Treatment & Follow-up: Mr. Doe was immediately started on IV thrombolytics (Alteplase) after ruling out contraindications. Alongside  adjustments were made to his antihypertensive therapy to better control his blood pressure and avoid further complications. His diabetic medications were also reviewed and adjusted to optimize his blood glucose levels.   The patient was counseled about lifestyle modifications including diet and importance of regular physical activity  and regular follow-ups were scheduled to monitor health status and alterations in treatment strategies if needed.  His family was informed  educated about stroke  related care  signs of stroke reoccurrence  and modification in lifestyle to influence better prognosis. The patient was receptive to the advice and treatment and showed commitment towards physicians' plan to manage his conditions.  In summary  Mr. Doe's history with hypertension  type-2 diabetes  lifestyle  and family genetics predisposed him to an ischemic stroke. His rapid evaluation and immediate intervention reflect a positive prognosis. Regular follow-ups and better control of his current conditions would be key in preventing reoccurrence.

Patient Profile: Mr. John Doe  a 70-year-old African American male residing in New York  NY  who is retired from an administrative job. He is a widower living with his daughter and two grandchildren.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe was brought to the hospital after his daughter noticed sudden onset of the left-sided weakness  difficulty in speech  and loss of balance.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe is a known hypertensive and has been dealing with uncontrolled high blood pressure for the last ten years  managed with oral antihypertensive medications. He also has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and ischemic heart disease. He has occasional episodes of atrial fibrillation for which he is on an oral anticoagulant. The patient already uses a hearing aid due to age-related hearing loss.  Social History:  He is a lifelong non-smoker and denies usage of illicit drugs. Mr. Doe used to consume alcohol moderately but has abstained for the past five years. His diet is high in salt and fat  and he is sedentary with limited exercise.  Family History:  Mr. Doe’s father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 67  and his paternal uncle had a stroke at the age of 70. His mother was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and died due to its complications.  Examination and Investigations: On neurological examination  Mr. Doe demonstrated facial droop  left-sided hemiparesis  and dysarthria. His National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score was noted as 12. Blood pressure was elevated at 180/95 mm Hg. Blood reports revealed a poorly controlled blood sugar level with raised HbA1c. His lipid profile was also deranged with high LDL cholesterol. An urgent CT scan of his head showed a right-sided acute middle cerebral artery infarction.  Treatment and Follow-up: Mr. Doe was immediately administered intravenous thrombolytic therapy under the stroke protocol. He was admitted to the ICU for further management  which included maintaining physiological parameters within normal range  controlling hypertension and diabetes  and preventing further complications. He was also given physiotherapy sessions to prevent bed sores and improve the return of function in his left side.  Discussion: Mr. Doe’s case shows the importance of managing modifiable risk factors for a stroke  such as hypertension  diabetes  atrial fibrillation  and a sedentary lifestyle. Along with acute therapeutic interventions  his long-term plan should focus on lifestyle modifications  compliance with medications  regular check-ups  and family education to prevent recurrence and complications.

Name: John Smith Age: 68  Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher Marital Status: Married Residence: Queens  NY  Chief Complaint: The patient was brought to the Emergency Department by his wife after he developed right-sided weakness and difficulty in speaking.  History of Present Illness: Mr. Smith was in his usual state of health until this morning when he woke up with sudden weakness in his right arm and leg. The patient also noticed difficulty in speaking and understanding others. His wife reported that there were no convulsions  loss of consciousness  headache  or visual disturbances. She also mentioned that they recently had a Christmas dinner where Mr. Smith had consumed ham  wine  and several other foods with higher-than-normal sodium and cholesterol content.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has been diagnosed with hypertension for the last 7 years  which is well controlled with medication (Lisinopril). He also has high cholesterol  which has been managed with diet and statins; however  he has been less compliant with his diet during the holiday season. He does not have diabetes mellitus but does possess a history of smoking (about one pack per day for the last 40 years). He had quit smoking two years ago.  Family History: The patient’s father died of heart disease in his 70s  and his mother had a history of hypertension and stroke before she passed away at the age of 78. He has two siblings: a brother with coronary artery disease and a sister who is in good health.  Clinical Examination: On examination  Mr. Smith has a regular heart rhythm  blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  impaired speech  right facial droop  right-sided hemiparesis  and hypoesthesia.   Diagnosis: Based on the clinical presentation and the sudden onset of symptoms  an acute ischemic stroke was suspected.  Treatment: Mr. Smith was immediately given a tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)  a intravenous drug used to dissolve blood clots and restore blood flow to the brain. He was also given medication to lower his blood pressure. A CT scan of his head was ordered  and physical therapy was planned post-procedure.  Prognosis: Mr. Smith's prognosis largely depends on his post-stroke treatment and how well he adheres to his medication and recovery plan  which includes lifestyle changes  such as a healthier diet  regular exercise  and abstaining from smoking and excessive alcohol consumption.  Discussion: The case highlights the importance of strict adherence to antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medications  especially among older adults with a history of smoking and a familial predisposition to cardiovascular diseases.

Patient Presentation:  A Chinese female  67 years old  known as Mrs. Lin  was brought to the emergency department of our hospital because of a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech.
