The patient was reportedly in her usual state of health until two hours prior to the ED visit when she experienced sudden weakness in her right arm and leg and soon noticed difficulty speaking  which caused her family to call for an ambulance immediately.   Mrs. Lin’s past medical history is positive for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. All conditions are relatively well managed with medication  including Lisinopril  Simvastatin  and Metformin respectively. She does not have any history of heart disease or previous strokes. Mrs. Lin also had a 10-year smoking history  a pack a day  but quit 12 years ago. She denied alcohol usage. Mrs. Lin lives with her husband who is also her primary caregiver and is a retired bank employee.   Family history reveals her mother died from myocardial infarction at age 64  and father died from prostate cancer at age 75. An older brother died of stroke at 65 years of age.   On physical examination  Mrs. Lin was conscious but had clear difficulty speaking. Her blood pressure was slightly elevated (160/90 mmHg)  and other vital signs were within normal limits. Neurologic examination revealed global aphasia and right hemiparesis. The rest of the physical exams were unremarkable  including heart and lung exams.   Lab reports showed slightly elevated blood sugar levels and HbA1c levels  indicative of suboptimally controlled Type 2 diabetes. Lipid profile showed elevated LDL and total cholesterol levels. EKG did not show any arrhythmia. A CT scan of the brain revealed an area of ischemia in the left hemisphere  suggesting a stroke  which correlated with her right-sided symptoms.  In conclusion  Mrs. Lin presents with typical signs and symptoms of an acute stroke  likely due to her complex past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and history of smoking. She requires urgent medical attention with thrombolytic treatment  provided that there are no contra-indications  along with aggressive secondary prevention measures to prevent further complications. Early rehabilitation and good blood pressure and glucose control also form the pillars of her long-term management. Mrs. Lin's case underscores the importance of timely identification and management of stroke risk factors.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 74-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. X  recently diagnosed with an Ischemic stroke. He resides in uptown Chicago  Illinois  and is retired  previously working as a helicopter engineer.   Past Medical History: Mr. X has a significant history of hypertension for the past 14 years and Type II Diabetes. Additionally  he's been on treatment for hyperlipidemia for the last 5 years. He is also identified to have atrial fibrillation  diagnosed about two years ago  for which he takes anticoagulant medication. He's a former smoker who quit five years ago and has a moderate-to-severe alcohol consumption history.   Family History: Mr. X's father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 67  and his mother died of complications from diabetes. Both his older brothers are alive-one with coronary artery disease and the other diagnosed with diabetes. No family history of strokes has been reported.  Present Illness: Mr. X was brought to the hospital following sudden onset of slurred speech  weakness in his right side  and confusion. The symptoms started while he was having breakfast with his wife  who immediately called the Emergency Medical Services (EMS). There was no loss of consciousness reported. On arrival at the hospital  a CT scan revealed an occlusion in the left middle cerebral artery  confirming an ischemic stroke.  Examination: Upon examination  Mr. X was alert but slightly disoriented. His BP was 160/90 mmHg  and blood glucose was 180 mg/dl. A neurological examination revealed mild aphasia  right-sided facial droop  and reduced motor strength (3/5) in his right upper and lower extremities.  Treatment: Mr. X was unable to receive thrombolytic therapy  as he arrived at the hospital after the recommended timeframe. The attending neurologist decided to administer antiplatelet therapy while closely monitoring his atrial fibrillation. Dietary and lifestyle modifications were also recommended.  The combination of advanced age  unmanaged hypertension  diabetes  atrial fibrillation  and history of smoking increases Mr. X's risk of experiencing recurrent stroke. Therefore  strict adherence to management plans and regular health checks will be of utmost importance in Mr.X's journey towards recovery and improved quality of life.  Plan: The plan for Mr. X includes strict blood pressure and blood sugar management  occupational and physiotherapy for motor recovery  regular cardiology and neurology follow-ups  and dietary changes. His wife will receive training to assist with his ongoing care  including managing his eating habits and medications.   In essence  the overall objective of the healthcare team is to provide holistic and continuous care to Mr. X  ensuring prompt management of any complications  and preventing recurrent stroke episodes. It will also be important to provide psychological support and promote lifestyle changes for improved overall health.

Case Presentation:  Subject Information:  Mr. Johnson  a 67-year-old African-American male  is seen in the emergency department of a community hospital. His current address is Downtown  Chicago  where he has been residing for over 30 years. He is a retired engineer  married  with three adult children. He has a known smoking history of 30 years but quit about 15 years ago. He does not consume alcohol and follows a vegetarian diet.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Johnson was brought in by his wife after experiencing sudden weakness in his right side  slurred speech and headache which started approximately 3 hours earlier in the morning.   Past Medical History:  He has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he is currently on medication (Lisinopril 10 mg daily and Atorvastatin 20 mg nightly). Mr. Johnson had been compliant with his medication. He has no known drug allergies. Alongside  he has a background of obesity (BMI: 30.7). There is no history of any surgeries.  Family History: Both his parents are deceased. His father had a history of hypertension and had suffered a stroke at the age of 72. His mother was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and chronic kidney disease.  Examination and Evaluation: Upon physical exam  Mr. Johnson exhibited right-sided hemiparesis and facial drooping on the right side. His speech was slurred. His blood pressure was measured to be 170/95mmHg. His BMI was calculated to be 30.7 kg/m2. He scored 12 on NIH stroke scale (NIHSS).  Preliminary Diagnostic Evaluation: Initial CT scan did not show any hemorrhage but showed early ischemic changes. The CBC  serum glucose  renal function tests  and lipid profile are ordered and pending.  Treatment:  He was started on a dose of IV Alteplase due to the absence of hemorrhage and his presentation being within the therapeutic window.  Conclusion: Based on his presenting symptoms  history  and initial investigations  Mr. Johnson is diagnosed with an acute ischemic stroke. Mr. Johnson's age  race  gender  personal medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  obesity  and significant family history predisposes him to an increased risk of stroke. His case also highlights the importance of maintaining blood pressure and lipids within the normal range to prevent such debilitating conditions. His case is quite classic  and he would benefit from a stroke rehabilitation program.   Discussion about the management of other modifiable risk factors  such as obesity  is critical in preventing recurrent strokes and improving Mr. Johnson's long-term prognosis.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is Mr. Richard Harrison  a 68-year-old African-American male who was brought to the emergency department of our hospital by his wife following an episode of severe headache and sudden weakness on the right side of his body. His wife reported that he also had difficulty speaking.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Harrison was diagnosed with hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus 6 years ago. He was prescribed medication but reported non-compliance with the treatment.  Family History:  Richard has a family history of heart disease and stroke. His father had a fatal heart attack at 72 years old and his sister had a stroke at 65 years old.   Social History:  Richard has been a regular smoker for the last 40 years and consumes alcohol occasionally. He is currently retired and lives with his wife. He has a moderately active lifestyle.  Vital Signs & Physical Findings: Upon admission  his blood pressure was 180/110 mmHg  heart rate 88 beats/minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation 95% at room air. Physical examination revealed that he has right-sided weakness and facial asymmetry. Speech was affected  evidenced by garbled words.  Investigations:  An immediate CT scan delivered evidence of an acute ischemic stroke on the left cerebral hemisphere correlating to his right-sided symptoms. His blood glucose level was 220mg/dl  total cholesterol 250mg/dl  and LDL cholesterol 180mg/dl  all indicating poor control.  Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical symptoms  physical findings  and imaging results  Mr. Harrison was diagnosed with an acute ischemic stroke.  Discussion:  Given the patient's history of hypertension  diabetes  smoking habit  non-compliance to medication  and family history of stroke and heart disease  Mr. Harrison demonstrates several significant risk factors for stroke. These lifestyle factors and comorbid conditions likely contributed to the development of his stroke.  Plan:  He was started on thrombolytic therapy with IV alteplase for acute management of his stroke. His hypertension and diabetes were managed accordingly. An interdisciplinary approach involving neurologists  nurses  physiotherapists  dietitians  and  importantly  a psychologist was suggested for the rehabilitation and secondary prevention. His wife is involved in the care plan  especially on home care and medication compliance.  Note:  Mr. Harrison's case underscores the importance of proactive management of modifiable risk factors for stroke  particularly in patients with existing comorbid conditions. Regular monitoring  encouragement of medication compliance  and emphasis on healthier lifestyle choices are integral aspects of preventing such events.

Patient Identification: Mr. Z  a 62-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: Slurred speech and weakness on the right side of body noted by his wife about 2 hours before reaching the hospital.  History of Present Illness: According to Mr. Z's wife  he appeared normal during breakfast. However  around 10 A.M.  he started to speak incoherently and appeared to have difficulty using his right arm. The patient was initially confused and then gradually became alert with fluctuating lucidity.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension for 10 years  type 2 diabetes for 5 years  and elevated cholesterol levels. He also has a 20 pack-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago.  Medications: Mr. Z regularly takes Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Simvastatin for high cholesterol.  Family History: His father had a stroke at 65 and died of heart disease at 70. His mother had type 2 diabetes and died of breast cancer at 73. One elder brother is alive and diagnosed with hypertension and diabetes. His younger sister is healthy.  Social History: Mr. Z is married with 2 adult children. He has retired from an office job and spends lots of his time gardening  which is his recreational activity. He does not consume alcohol.  Physical examination: On examination  Mr. Z was conscious but had slurred speech. His pupils were equal and reactive. Cardiac examination revealed no pathological murmurs. His right-sided body showed weakness  with a power of 3/5. His sensation was reduced on the right side  but proprioception was retained. Right-sided Babinski sign was also positive.  Clinical Reasoning: Given his age  medical history  clinical presentation  and physical examination findings  Mr. Z's diagnosis is highly suggestive of an ischemic stroke affecting his left cerebral hemisphere.  Investigations: A CT scan was immediately obtained  which confirmed an ischemic stroke in the left middle cerebral artery zone. Further lab work showed HbA1c at 7.8%  elevated LDL cholesterol  and normal kidney function.  Management Plan and Follow-up: Mr. Z was handed over to the stroke team  who administered thrombolytic therapy within the therapeutic window. His medications were reviewed. Metformin  Lisinopril  and Simvastatin were continued. Aspirin was added for its antiplatelet effect. His diet was modified by a dietitian in consultation with an endocrinologist to control his diabetes and cholesterol better. Mr. Z will start physiotherapy as soon as he is stable. He will be followed up with the neurology team on discharge with plans for further rehabilitation based on his response to the initial therapies.  This case aims to demonstrate the importance of timely intervention and a multidisciplinary approach in managing a patient with a stroke  particularly when the patient has multiple pre-existing comorbid conditions.

Patient Presentation: Patient Information and Demographics: Mr. James Smith  a 65-year-old African-American male  retired Army veteran  is married with 3 children and 6 grandchildren.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a known history of hypertension  managed with Lisinopril  and hyperlipidemia  controlled with Simvastatin. He is a non-smoker but heavily consumes alcohol  one whiskey bottle daily  for the past 35 years. His BMI is 29.2.   Family History: Both his parents had suffered from hypertension  and his father  deceased  experienced a stroke at the age of 70.   Chief Complaint: Mr. Smith was brought to the ER by his wife who found him in bed  not being able to move his right limbs and slurring his speech. His wife noticed the symptoms upon waking up. He was last seen normal before they went to bed at around 10 pm.   Clinical Examination: On examination  he was alert but had dysarthria. His right facial muscle was drooping  and he had a noticeable right-sided weakness in both upper and lower limbs with a power of 2/5. His blood pressure on arrival was 170/95 mm Hg. Additionally  a minor right-sided neglect was noted.   Investigations: Laboratory screening tests reasserted his high blood pressure  normal blood glucose  and an elevated cholesterol level. An emergent non-contrast CT scan of the head was ordered to rule out a hemorrhagic stroke  which revealed no clear signs of hemorrhage but indicated early ischemic changes  pointing towards an ischemic stroke.  Management: Intravenous thrombolytic therapy was given to Mr. Smith within three hours of the confirmed onset of symptoms after ensuring there are no contraindications. His hypertension was controlled using Nitroglycerine infusion.   Discussion: The management of Mr. Smith's case aligns with the updated guidelines for early management of acute ischemic stroke unless hemorrhage is suspected. Early reperfusion strategy through thrombolysis is the definitive therapy for acute ischemic stroke and has been initiated in this case appropriately.   Long-term management involving secondary prevention strategies  including intensive control of his hypertension with antihypertensives  addressing his alcohol issues  promoting a healthier lifestyle  and addition of antiplatelet agents  would be necessary to decrease the risk of recurrent stroke. Rehabilitation services would also be necessary to maximize his functional recovery. Regular monitoring via routine follow-ups is also critical.   Prognosis: Prognosis largely depends on how well Mr. Smith responds to the initial therapy and how much he could improve with rehabilitation. His long-term outcome can also depend on how well his risk factors are managed  including hypertension and alcohol consumption.

Patient Information: Mr. James Parker  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer from Manchester  UK. Lives with his wife and has three adult children. He is a non-smoker and occasional drinker. He has a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases  as his father died of a heart attack at the age of 72 and his older brother had a stroke at age 65.   Past Medical History: Mr. Parker was diagnosed with high blood pressure and Type 2 diabetes approximately 10 years ago  both of which are controlled on medication. He also has a history of high cholesterol and had a mild myocardial infarction 4 years ago.  Presenting Issue: Mr. Parker was brought to the Emergency Room after his wife noticed sudden weakness on his right side  slurred speech  and facial drooping. Upon presentation  these stroke-like symptoms were present and onset was said to be about 3 hours prior.  Investigations: An immediate CT scan was performed which showed an ischemic stroke. His glucose levels were elevated at 180 mg/dl blood and blood pressure was approximately 165/95 mmHg. Electrocardiography showed arrhythmias consistent with previous myocardial infarction.  Plan: Mr. Parker was immediately treated with Alteplase (tPA)  an intravenous thrombolytic agent  as per the guidelines for early management of acute ischemic stroke within the 4.5 hours window. He was then admitted to the Stroke Unit for further observation and management. His current medication regimen for hypertension  diabetes  and cholesterol was optimized  and he was started on secondary prevention measures for stroke.  Outlook and Recommendations: Prognostically  it is anticipated that Mr. Parker may suffer some residual disability due to the stroke. Rehabilitation services (occupational  speech  physical therapy) have been consulted for appropriate assessment and assistance. Proper control of his hypertension  diabetes and statin therapy for hypercholesterolemia will be essential moving forward. He is also recommended for a consultation for anticoagulation in light of the stroke. Patient education on a diet  drug regimen  and lifestyle modifications  like incorporating exercise  will be essential components of his management.   Overall  this case emphasizes the importance of managing chronic diseases in preventing complications such as stroke  and a multi-disciplinary approach in post-stroke recovery.

Title: Diagnosed Stroke in a 63 Year Old Caucasian Male   Patient Profile: Mr. Johnson  a 63-year old Caucasian male  presented with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and slurred speech. He is a resident of Oakville  Canada  living independently with his spouse and retired from a clerical job.   Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has been suffering from Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and has been on Metformin for the past 10 years. Two years ago  he was diagnosed with hypertension under treatment with a daily dose of Ramipril 2.5mg.   Family History: Mr. Johnson's family history includes his father having suffered from a stroke at the age of 70 and his mother dying due to myocardial infarction around the same age. From his three siblings  one brother aged 67 has been diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and another brother aged 65 with atherosclerosis.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Johnson complained of a sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty in speech which lasted for a couple of hours. He also reported trouble positioning his left arm and leg properly. His wife noted some changes in his face  such as left side facial drooping.   Clinical Findings: On examination  Mr. Johnson had a blood pressure reading of 160/90mmHg and a high blood sugar level of 240mg/dl. His National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) was documented as 12  indicating a moderate level of stroke. His Glasgow Coma Scale results were 14/15  suggesting a potentially serious impairment.  Investigations: Computed Topography (CT) scan of the brain was conducted  revealing a clot in the right middle cerebral artery. Blood report showed elevated triglyceride levels and a slightly high cholesterol level. His HbA1c was 8%.  Diagnosis and Treatment: Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with an acute ischaemic stroke. He was immediately started on intravenous recombinant tissue Plasminogen Activator (rt-PA)  the standard treatment for a patient presenting with acute ischaemic stroke symptoms within a 4.5-hour window. In addition to this  his antihypertensive medication was adjusted  and a statin was added to his prescription for cholesterol management.  Prognosis: Given Mr. Johnson's response to the initial treatment  the prognosis is cautiously optimistic  although careful monitoring is essential due to his diabetic status. Rehabilitation therapy began for his left side weakness  and significant improvement is expected with intensive therapy and good glycemic control.  This case highlights the importance of immediate medical attention in stroke management and the complex care necessary for patients with multiple comorbidities like diabetes and hypertension. It also demonstrates the increased risk of stroke patients with a family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Ethical issues:  Patient confidentiality was maintained throughout the process. The patient's consent was taken before starting any new medication or procedure.

Patient Information: Mr. Jones  a 68-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department with signs of a suspected stroke. He had an observed sudden onset of slurred speech  right-sided arm weakness  and facial drooping while at home with his wife.  Past Medical History: He has a documented history of hypertension  which has been difficult to manage despite being on Lisinopril and Amlodipine. Additionally  he is a Type 2 diabetic controlled with Metformin. He was also treated for high cholesterol levels and prescribed Atorvastatin. He has a 30-pack year history of smoking. He denies any previous episodes of transient ischemic attacks or strokes.  Family History: Both his father and older brother had fatal strokes in their early 70s  and his mother passed away due to complications related to diabetes. None of his four children have reported any major health concerns so far.  Social History: Mr. Jones is a retired mechanical engineer. He quit smoking 10 years ago and has been living a fairly healthy lifestyle since then  including regular exercises and a balanced diet. He occasionally consumes alcohol but only in moderation.  Physical Exam: The patient was alert but showed signs of aphasia. Blood pressure recorded was 180/95 mm Hg. Motor strength in the left upper extremity was intact  but right upper extremity showed significant weakness. Facial drooping was observed on the right side. The remainder of the exam was within normal limits.  Diagnostic Findings: A non-contrast CT head scan was immediately ordered and revealed an acute infarction in the left middle cerebral artery territory. His fasting blood sugar level and lipid profile were found to be significantly high. A CT angiography was recommended to further establish the diagnosis.  Radiologic Findings: In accordance with the CT scan  radiologists noted an area of decreased attenuation involving the cortex and subcortex of the left MCA distribution. This predicted large vessel occlusion and confirmed that Mr. Jones had experienced an ischemic stroke.  Treatment Plan: Mr. Jones was immediately administered aspirin and admitted to the stroke unit. As he arrived beyond the thrombolysis window  mechanical thrombectomy was considered. Anti-hypertensive treatment was adjusted to bring his blood pressure under control. A strict regimen for his diabetes and cholesterol was also put in place  alongside intensive physical therapy.  Anticipated Outcome: Early intervention and intensive care would likely result in an improved outcome  although Mr. Jones' chances of full recovery are inhibited by his medical history and late presentation. Blood pressure and blood sugar control  along with a rehabilitation program  would be instrumental in mitigating the risk of recurrent stroke. The patient and his family were also educated about stroke symptoms and the importance of early reporting to optimize the prognosis.    This case highlights the serious consequences of uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes  emphasizing the importance of primary and secondary prevention in high-risk individuals. It also underscores the significance of early detection and timely treatment of stroke symptoms to minimize disability and improve survival rates.

Patient Presentation  Our patient is Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male residing in the suburbs of New York. He has been recently diagnosed with an ischemic stroke. Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  conditions he has been managing for the past 20 years. As a former smoker  his nicotine dependence is significant  and it is worth noting that he quit smoking only five years ago after smoking one pack per day for 40 years. He also consumes alcohol moderately.  Mr. Doe works as an accountant and has a relatively sedentary lifestyle. On the family front  his father suffered a stroke at the age of 72 and passed away due to complications. His paternal grandfather also had cardiovascular disease. His mother has type 2 diabetes and is living in a care home due to age-related frailty. Meanwhile  his two younger sisters are alive and healthy.  Mr. Doe was brought to the ER by an ambulance  after his coworker called 911 when he was found unconscious at his desk. Upon arrival  he had a Glasgow Coma Scale of 12 and was vitally stable. His blood pressure was 180/95 mmHg; heart rate  87 beats per minute; and respiratory rate  16 breaths per minute. Given his medical background and presenting symptoms  a stroke was suspected.  An immediate CT scan confirmed an ischemic infarct in his right middle cerebral artery region. An EKG found no abnormalities  and blood tests revealed elevated blood glucose levels and high LDL cholesterol. He was quickly administered tPA (Tissue Plasminogen Activator) within the window period. He was then shifted to the stroke unit for further care. His medication  including antihypertensive drugs and statins  is being reviewed and adjusted accordingly.     Mr. Doe's prognosis is presently uncertain. His recovery will probably require occupational and physical therapy due to left-sided weakness noted by the Neurologist. Consideration is being given to initiate a formal smoking cessation and diet modification program to mitigate future health risk factors. His case exemplifies the significant stroke risk factors associated with older age  male gender  hypertension  type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia  smoking  and family history. His lifestyle habits  sedentarism  stress-related occupation  and moderate alcohol consumption further compound the risk.

Patient Profile:   Mr. James Moore is a 68-year-old Caucasian male and a retired engineer living with his wife. He has been a patient in our medical facility for two years.   Medical History:   In 2003  James was diagnosed with Stage II hypertension and has been on low-dose aspirin therapy and ACE inhibitors since the diagnosis. He has also managed to keep his blood pressure under control with regular check-ups and medication. James has a 35 year history of smoking  having started at age 20 but quit recently after a persistent cough and chronic bronchitis. Despite these conditions  he has never been on oxygen therapy. His cholesterol level is slightly above normal  but he has refused to take statins.   Recent Health Complaints:   On 10th July  James began to feel sudden weakness on his right side and difficulty in speaking. His wife noticed his face drooping and immediately called 911. He was rushed to the hospital where further tests  including a CT scan  indicated an ischemic stroke on the left side of his brain.   Family History:   Both his parents died in their late 70s owing to cardiac disease. His elder brother was diagnosed with stroke five years ago  at the age of 70  and made a full recovery. His 66 year-old younger sister is currently living with diabetes but under excellent control.    Current Diagnosis:  Based on his symptoms  medical history and the neuroimaging results  Mr. Moore has been diagnosed with acute left-sided ischemic stroke. It's likely his smoking history  hypertension and high cholesterol may have contributed towards his high risk factor for stroke. The stroke has affected his ability to speak and motor function on the right side  including in his leg and arm.   Treatment Plan:  With his consent  we have begun administering a tPA (tissue plasminogen activator) to help dissolve the clot and restore blood flow to the brain. We have also started him on occupational therapy and speech therapy to help manage the current symptoms. He will require ongoing monitoring to ensure his safety  manage any potential complications  and assess for any recovery.   Given his smoking history and existing health conditions  continued management for his hypertension and high cholesterol will be needed  along with counselling for lifestyle modifications including a balanced diet  regular exercise  smoking cessation  and regular check-ups.   Discussion with Family:   The prognosis and treatment plan has been discussed with Mr. Moore and his wife  and they both seem to be understanding and cooperative. They have been alerted about the risks of a second milder or more severe stroke  and the need for continuous close monitoring and follow-up appointments.

Patient Presentation:   Name: Mr. John Doe  Age/ Gender: 65 years old  Male  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Teacher   Presenting Complaint: Mr. Doe has presented with symptoms in line with a stroke  including the sudden onset of one-sided weakness  confusion  difficulty speaking and understanding  trouble seeing in one or both eyes  and sudden severe headache with no known cause.   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  both of which have been managed with medication for the past ten years. He is a former smoker who quit 15 years ago and occasionally consumes alcohol. Mr. Doe also has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus that has been controlled with oral hypoglycemics. Recently  there’s been an erratic control of blood pressure  as evidenced by his medical records.  Family History: There is a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases. Both parents suffered from hypertension. His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 years  and his mother had a stroke in her late 60s but survived.  Physical Assessment: On examination  Mr. Doe showed the upper and lower right-sided weakness  difficulty in speech articulation and facial drooping on the right side. His cardiovascular examination revealed no abnormalities  and the respirator rate and oxygen saturation were recorded as normal. The blood pressure reading was elevated.  Investigations: A CT Scan was conducted  indicating that Mr. Doe had suffered an ischemic stroke. Blood tests showed a higher-than-normal blood glucose level and increased cholesterol levels.   Diagnosis: Based on his symptoms  physical examination  and CT Scan result  Mr. Doe was diagnosed with an acute ischemic stroke. His hypertension  high cholesterol  history of diabetes  and family history of cardiovascular disease confirm him as a high-risk patient.   Management: The patient was provided with immediate medical care  and a specialist team was immediately activated to manage his acute stroke condition. Thrombolytic therapy was initiated as per guidelines  and secondary stroke prevention measures were conducted.  Prognosis: With immediate medical intervention and management  the prognosis is cautiously optimistic. However  he will likely require rigorous physical and occupational therapy for his recovery.  The case of Mr. Doe highlights the importance of understanding the risk factors associated with stroke and the need for regular monitoring and control of these factors. It is crucial to educate such patients and their families about adhering to a healthy lifestyle  taking prescribed medications  and maintaining regular follow-ups to prevent recurrent strokes.

Patient Profile:  Ms. Alma Jenkins is a 68-year-old African American woman who resides in Boston  Massachusetts. She is a retired school teacher and widowed with two children  both living out of state.   Presenting Complaint:  Ms. Jenkins was brought to the hospital by her neighbor  who found her on the floor partially paralyzed on her right side. Upon examination  she was disoriented  aphasic  and showed signs of hemiparesis.   Medical History:  Ms. Jenkins has hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both managed with medications. She underwent a hysterectomy at the age of 45. Her latest physical examination was a year ago  wherein her health was generally good  but she was advised to lose some weight (current BMI 27 kg/m2). Her lipid panel was slightly elevated with an LDL of 140 mg/dl and an HDL of 35 mg/dl.  Family History:  Her father died of a stroke at the age of 68. Her mother is currently living and at the age of 87  she suffers from Parkinson’s disease. She has a younger brother with no known health issues.   Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  Ms. Jenkins' blood pressure was found to be 160/95 mmHg. The NIH Stroke Scale was 11  indicating moderate severity. Neurological examination showed right-sided weakness and expressive aphasia. Her random blood sugar was slightly elevated at 145mg/dL.  Diagnostic Evaluation:  A non-contrast CT head did not show hemorrhage  but an MRI brain revealed a left middle cerebral artery territory infarct. A subsequent echocardiogram did not show any cardiac source of the embolus  and the carotid ultrasound did not reveal any significant stenosis. Further workup for hypercoagulable state was negative.  Treatment:  Ms. Jenkins was promptly given tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) after securing non-hemorrhagic infarction on CT head within 3 hours of symptom onset. Her hypertension was controlled with antihypertensive medications  and her blood glucose levels were managed via insulin therapy.  Current Status:  Ms. Jenkins is currently in the stroke unit under close observation and her condition is stable. She will be referred to a speech therapist for her aphasia and physiotherapy for motor dysfunction. Her children have been informed about her condition and are traveling down to support her recovery.   Plan:  Once her condition stabilizes  Ms. Jenkins will be discharged home with home rehabilitation services. Part of her discharge plan includes optimizing control of her hypertension  diabetes  and dyslipidemia along with other stroke secondary prevention strategies. Smoking cessation (she was a former smoker)  regular physical activity  and healthy diet are strongly advised.  Discussant:  Stroke is a leading cause of adult disability. Ms. Jenkins is at high risk due to her African American ethnicity  age  hypertension  diabetes  and dyslipidemia. It is crucial to manage these risk factors aggressively to prevent recurrent ischemic stroke or other vascular events. Long-term  she will need comprehensive post-stroke care including access to rehabilitation  secondary prevention  and social support services. Regular follow-up is also vital for managing treatment plans and ensuring compliance.

Patient Profile:  Mr. A is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  who resides in a suburban community with his wife. He was brought to the emergency department (ED) by his wife on 1st March who noted a sudden onset of left side body weakness and slurred speech when he woke up from a nap. The patient denies any head injury  seizure  or loss of consciousness.  Past Medical History:  Mr. A has a history of chronic hypertension for the past 10 years  managed with Hydrochlorothiazide  and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 5 years  managed with Metformin. Although diligent about his medications  the patient has a history of uncontrolled blood pressure and sugar levels. There is no previous history of strokes or transient ischemic attacks (TIA). He had a coronary artery bypass graft surgery 4 years ago.  Social History:  Mr. A smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally. He has a sedentary lifestyle and a high intake of salty and high-cholesterol foods.  Family History:  His father had a stroke at the age of 77 and passed away; his mother died at 90 from heart failure. Mr. A has two brothers  one diagnosed with hypertension  and another diagnosed with Diabetes Mellitus and hypertension.  Examination:  On arrival at the ED  the patient was alert but appeared anxious. Physical examination revealed slurred speech  right facial droop  and weakness in the right upper and lower extremities. His blood pressure was 160/95 mmHg  heart rate 85/min  temperature 98.6 F  and BMI 28. Neurological examination confirmed decreased muscle strength in right limbs.  Diagnostic Findings:  Initial laboratory investigations were non-specific. CT scan of brain showed early signs suggestive of left middle cerebral artery territory infarct. Blood glucose level was 220mg/dl and HbA1c was 8.5%. EKG showed normal sinus rhythm with previous myocardial infarct.  Action Plan:  Mr. A was diagnosed with an ischemic stroke. He was admitted to the stroke unit. His HCTZ was replaced with a combination of Lisinopril and Amlodipine; the dose of Metformin was also increased. He was started on aspirin and referred to a physiotherapist for rehabilitation. Health advice was provided concerning dietary habits and physical exercise.  Prognosis:  With appropriate control of his risk factors (hypertension  diabetes  and sedentary lifestyle)  Mr. A's prognosis can be improved  but his risk for recurrent strokes remains high due to his age and previous heart condition.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of risk factor control in preventing strokes. More aggressive blood pressure and blood sugar control  along with lifestyle modifications  can help prevent stroke in high-risk individuals like Mr. A.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 72-year-old African American male  presenting with symptoms consistent with a stroke. He was brought to the ER by his wife  who reported that he was having difficulty speaking and walking  along with a left-sided facial droop. The onset of these symptoms occurred approximately two hours prior to arrival at the hospital.   Past medical history includes hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and hypercholesterolemia. Patient has a history of tobacco use - 1 pack per day for 40 years  but quit ten years ago. Alcohol usage is denied  and there's no history of illicit drugs. He is under medication for his chronic diseases - lisinopril for hypertension  metformin for diabetes  and atorvastatin for cholesterol. He adheres to his medications but admits his diet behavior doesn't always follow diabetic guidelines.   Complete demographics: Mr. Doe is a retired auto mechanic  living with his wife in a suburban area. He immigrated from Nigeria when he was in his 30s and has a moderate financial situation. He is an active member of a local church and enjoys gardening.   Family history reveals that his father passed away due to a myocardial infarction at 68  while his mother passed due to breast cancer at age 70. He has two older brothers  one of whom had a stroke at age 75  and the other is currently living with a diagnosis of Parkinson's disease.   A clinical examination reveals blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg  irregular pulse  blood sugar level of 200 mg/dL  and elevated cholesterol. Neurological examination indicated left hemiparesis  and a positive Babinski sign on the left foot.  A head CT scan has confirmed the diagnosis of right side ischaemic stroke. The patient was given a tissue plasminogen activator immediately following the CT scan to break up the clot causing the stroke.   Considering the identified risk factors  namely advanced age  history of hypertension  diabetes  dyslipidemia  family history of stroke  and previous smoking habit  this case represents a typical stroke case. The treatment was promptly initiated and Mr. Doe is currently stable but continues to be monitored closely for any further developments. Ongoing care will involve rehabilitation  management of associated medical conditions  and measures for secondary prevention of stroke and overall lifestyle modification advisement.

Patient Information:   Name: Mr. J. Smith Age: 66 Sex: Male Race: African-American Occupation: Retired engineer  Chief Complaint:  ""Sudden weakness in the right side of the body and difficulty in speaking.""  Medical History: Mr. Smith has a 10-year history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. He is a former smoker  having quit two years ago after a 30-year history of a pack a day. He has a BMI of 28  indicative of being overweight. There is no known history of cancer  TB  or other serious conditions. He is under medications for hypertension (Losartan 50mg/day) and diabetes (Metformin 500mg twice a day).  Family History: His father died at the age of 74 due to myocardial infarction  and his mother died at the age of 77 due to complications of diabetes. One older brother  aged 68  suffers from hypertension. No family history of stroke.  Present Illness: Mr. Smith was found by his wife in bed with marked difficulties in moving and talking. He was immediately brought to the hospital. Initial assessment noted a drooping on one side of his face  his speech was slurred  and he had weakness in his right arm and leg. Emergency CT scan confirmed an ischemic stroke.  Physical Examination: Mr. Smith is conscious but shows signs of distress. The significant physical findings include: weakness and reduced sensation on the right side of the body  Slurred speech  BP: 180/100 mmHg  Pulse 88bpm  RR 20bpm. Neurological examination confirmed right hemiplegia.  Treatment: Mr. Smith was immediately treated with tissue plasminogen activator to dissolve the blood clot. He was transferred to the stroke unit for further management  which will include antiplatelets  strict BP monitoring and control  managing his diabetes  physiotherapy  and speech therapy.  Prognosis: Given the prompt treatment and Mr. Smith's relatively good health prior to the stroke  the prognosis is cautiously optimistic. However  Mr. Smith's lifestyle modifications are necessary to prevent recurrent strokes  such as regular exercise  a carefully controlled diet  cessation of alcohol  and strict control of diabetes and hypertension.  Follow-Up: Mr. Smith has been scheduled for follow-ups in the outpatient stroke clinic. After discharge  he will have several follow-ups with rehabilitation  internal medicine  neurology and may need potential consults for neuropsychiatry due to significant changes in daily life following a stroke.

Patient Information: Mr. Smith  a 68-year-old African-American male.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Smith experienced sudden onset weakness in his right arm and leg along with slurred speech while he was having tea in the morning. He was immediately brought to the hospital by his wife.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith is a known hypertensive for the past 10 years and type 2 diabetic for the past five years. He is also a smoker (30 pack-years). He had a myocardial infarction seven years ago and has been on aspirin and statins since then.  Family History: Both of Mr. Smith's parents had hypertension. His father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 65. His brother  70  survived a stroke three years ago.  History of Present Illness: Upon experiencing the symptoms  Mr. Smith sought immediate medical attention. His symptoms progressively worsened over one hour  affecting his ability to walk and speak coherently.  Vital Signs: BP – 170/98 mm Hg  Pulse – 88/min and irregular  Respiratory rate – 18/min.  Physical Examination: Mr. Smith looked acutely sick. His speech was slurred. Motor examination revealed right-sided hemiplegia. His gait was unstable. The rest of the neurological examination demonstrated left gaze preference  conjugate deviation of the eyes towards the left  and homonymous right hemianopsia.  Investigations: Blood tests: His Hemoglobin A1c was 8.2% indicating poorly controlled diabetes. Lipid profile showed elevated LDL cholesterol levels. His kidney function tests revealed moderately impaired renal function. Imaging: CT of the head was performed immediately  which revealed a dense left middle cerebral artery sign without hemorrhage or mass effect  implying an acute ischemic stroke.   Diagnosis: Based on the history  clinical findings  and CT scan results  Mr. Smith was diagnosed with an acute left middle cerebral artery ischemic stroke.  Plan: He was considered for thrombolysis with IV alteplase  as he was within the therapeutic window (less than 4.5 hours from symptom onset). He was admitted to the stroke unit for further medical management and monitoring. His blood pressure and sugar levels were closely monitored and controlled. Secondary preventive measures were initiated  including statins  antiplatelet  and antihypertensive medications. He was also seen by the multidisciplinary team  including physiotherapy and speech and language team  and his wife was educated about the changes in diet and lifestyle necessary for his recovery and preventing stroke recurrence.  Prognosis: He has a high risk of recurrent stroke or other vascular events  given his past medical history  age  and current lifestyle. Strict adherence to medical therapy and lifestyle modifications will play a crucial role in his overall prognosis.

Patient's Profile: The patient is a 75-year-old African-American male  Mr. X. He is married with 3 grown-up children. He's a retired military veteran and a retired high school mathematics teacher.  Present Illness: Mr. X has been admitted to the ER with a diagnosis of right hemispheric ischemic stroke dating back to six hours ago. His symptoms included sudden weakness in the left side of his body  slurred speech  and severe headache. The family mentioned that they noticed Mr. X's left face drooping at breakfast and he seemed less interactive than usual.  Medical History: Mr. X has had a medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes  both under control with medications. He was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago and diabetes 10 years ago. He has a passive smoking history as his wife used to smoke  but she quit 5 years back. He also has mild obesity but does exercise regularly.  Medication History: - Lisinopril 10mg | Daily | Morning - Metformin 500mg | Twice Daily  Family History: His father died of a heart attack  and his mother died of old age. His elder sister is battling breast cancer  and his younger brother had a stroke at the age of 79.  Discussion: The right hemispheric stroke likely occurred due to his longstanding hypertension and diabetes. His family history of cardiovascular disease and his passive smoking exposure may have contributed to his elevated risk for stroke.  Investigations: Mr. X was taken for a CT scan immediately which confirmed the diagnosis of right hemispheric ischemic stroke and ruled out hemorrhagic stroke.  Treatment Plan: The treatment plan for Mr. X includes tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) as it is within the therapeutic window of 4.5 hours. Dual antiplatelets aspirin and clopidogrel have been started  his blood pressure is closely monitored  the stabilization of his blood sugar is ongoing  and he will be started on statins once clinically stable.  Goals: The recovery goals for Mr. X include achieving functional independence  maintaining stable vital signs  preventing secondary complications  and reducing the risk of another stroke in the future.    Plan for Follow-up: Regular follow-ups will be scheduled with a neurologist  and Mr. X will be referred to a physiotherapist and nutritionist to assist in the recovery process and manage modifiable risk factors for stroke.  Conclusion: Given his medical history of hypertension and diabetes  Mr. X's stroke risk was substantially elevated. The immediate challenge is to manage his acute stroke  but modifications in lifestyle and medication could be invaluable in reducing the risk of future similar events.

Patient Case Presentation: Stroke  Brief Summary: Mr. A  is a 70-year old African American male who presented to the emergency room with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty with speech starting about 2 hours prior to admission.  Medical History: Mr. A has a history of well controlled hypertension  type 2 diabetes and hyperlipidemiawith medications  i.e.  Metformin 500mg twice daily  Lisinopril 10mg daily  and Atorvastatin 20mg at bedtime. He had an MI 6 years ago resulting in a cardiac stent placement. His last check-ups with the cardiologist and endocrinologist were about a month ago.  Social History: Mr. A is a retired engineer and lives with his wife in a suburban area. He quit smoking 15 years ago and has one or two standard drinks on holidays and special occasions.  Family History: His mother had ischemic stroke in her late 60s and his father had a history of heart disease and passed away from myocardial infarction in his early 70s. His elder sister is dealing with hypertension and type 2 diabetes  and a younger brother has no known illnesses.  Physical Examination: - Vitals: BP 150/90 mmHg  pulse 82bpm  RR 18 breaths/min  temperature 98.2F - General appearance: Acute distress due to physical weakness. - Neurological exam: Right-sided facial droop  speech slurring  and difficulty in right arm and leg movement  intact sensation.    Result / Investigation: CT scan was performed immediately which ruled out hemorrhagic stroke. However  it was consistent with ischemic stroke. EKG showed no significant abnormalities. Fasting blood glucose was slightly elevated.  Management and Plan: The patient was admitted to the stroke unit. He was given intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) because he was within the therapeutic window. An antiplatelet therapy was initiated and he was also started on statin therapy. Over the next 72 hours  his symptoms improved mildly. A decision regarding the excellent prognosis of physical therapy versus further supportive care was discussed. The influence of hypertension  diabetes  and family history were discussed in emphasizing the need for strict control of these comorbidities.  This case presentation represents an individual with multiple risk factors  including age  race  hypertension  diabetes  and a family history of similar conditions. The management of such patients requires not just the acute treatment of the stroke but also a keen focus on managing these risk factors long-term. Additionally  social support is highlighted as crucial for Mr. A in managing his chronic diseases and preventing further strokes.

Patient Information: Mr. Samuel  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented with sudden weakness on the left side of his body  difficulty in speaking  and a drooping face  raising strong clinical suspicion of a stroke. He was brought to the Emergency Department by his family. His symptoms started whilst he was watching television at home.  Past Medical History: Mr. Samuel has a history of hypertension and type-2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled by medication. He quit smoking ten years ago but had a 15 pack-year history prior to cessation. He reported occasional alcohol use in moderate quantities. He had suffered a transient ischemic attack (TIA) two years prior  from which he made a full recovery.  Family History: There is a strong family history of heart disease and stroke. His father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 71  and his mother had a history of stroke in her late 60s. His older sister also suffers from hypertension and type-2 diabetes.  Examination: Physical examination displayed facial droop on the left side  hemiparesis  and slurred speech. A neurological examination identified decreased sensation and motor function on his left side  with a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale score of 12. His vitals showed a blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg  pulse 80 beats per minute  and blood glucose level of 180 mg/dL.  Investigations: CT scan of the head showed an infarct in the right middle cerebral artery region  indicating an ischemic stroke. Electrocardiograph showed regular sinus rhythm. Complete blood count  serum electrolyte levels  renal function  and lipid profiles were requested.  Management: Mr. Samuel was immediately started on intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)  following confirmation of the ischemic stroke and within the therapeutic window of 4.5 hours. His hypertension was managed according to the current guidelines for acute stroke management. His diabetes was controlled with an insulin regimen.  Outcomes and Follow up:  His symptoms improved considerably over the next 48 hours. He was then referred to rehabilitation services to regain full function. His medications were reviewed and optimized to prevent future strokes. Comprehensive health education regarding necessary lifestyle modifications accompanied the discharge plan. He was scheduled for a follow-up appointment with the neurologist and a referral for speech therapy was organized.  Summary: This is a case of an elderly patient with multiple risk factors  including hypertension  diabetes  personal history of TIA  and family history of cardiovascular diseases  who presented with an acute ischemic stroke. It emphasizes the importance of rapid diagnosis and treatment in minimizing neurological damage and supports the need for long-term prevention strategies for individuals with high-risk profiles for stroke.

Patient Case Presentation: Stroke  Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  was presented to the emergency department on 20th November 2022 with complaints of sudden onset of numbness on the right side of the body  slurred speech  and difficulty in walking.   Past Medical History: The patient has a known case of Hypertension and Type II Diabetes for the past ten years  maintained on Metformin (1000mg twice daily) and Lisinopril (10mg daily). He also has hyperlipidemia treated with Simvastatin (20mg daily).  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Doe experienced a sudden onset of severe headache  weakness on his right-side body  and speech disturbances while at home. He was immediately brought to the hospital.  Clinical Findings: On examination  Mr. Doe was conscious  his blood pressure was elevated at 170/95 mmHg  and pulse 82 beats/minute  regular. Neurological examination showed right facial droop  arm drift to the right side  and slurred speech. He scored 8 on NIHSS (National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale)  indicating moderate stroke. CT scan showed an infarct in the left middle cerebral artery region  confirming an ischemic stroke.  Family History: His father died at the age of 70 from a heart attack  and his mother  now 87  has a history of hypertension and diabetes. His older brother had an ischemic stroke at the age of 68.  Social History: Mr. Doe is a former smoker; he quit 15 years ago. He is a retired engineer  living with his wife. He does not drink alcohol and enjoys a moderately active lifestyle enjoying regular walks and gardening.  Management & Follow-up: Mr. Doe was immediately started on Aspirin (325 mg orally) and admitted for close monitoring and further treatment  including blood pressure management and diabetes control. Physiotherapy for motor rehabilitation was scheduled. Education regarding diet modification  physical activities  and medication obedience was given to the patient and his wife.  Outcome: Mr. Doe's condition remained stable throughout his hospital stay. Upon discharge  subsequent follow-ups were organized with internal medicine for his hypertension and diabetes management  dietary for his meals plan  and physiotherapy for his ongoing rehabilitation.  In summary  Mr. Doe's stroke is likely secondary to his uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes. This case highlights the importance of adequate control of chronic medical conditions to prevent severe complications like stroke.

Case Presentation   Demographics: Mr. J. Smith  a 67-year-old Caucasian male who resides in suburban Chicago  Illinois  was brought to the emergency department.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith reported the sudden onset of severe headache  slurred speech  right-sided weakness starting about an hour ago which was noticed by his wife. He has no history of trauma or fall. No sign of seizure activity was noted.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a known history of Hypertension for 10 years and Type II Diabetes Mellitus for 7 years  both of which are well-controlled with medications (Lisinopril for Hypertension and Metformin for Diabetes).   Social History: Mr. Smith is a retired mechanic  a non-smoker  and his alcohol consumption is limited to social occasions.   Family History: His father died at the age of 78 from ischemic heart disease  and his mother passed away at age 86 due to complications of Alzheimer's disease. One of his three siblings had a stroke in his late 70s.   Physical Exam:  On presentation  his blood pressure was 160/95 mmHg  pulse 96/minute  BMI 28. His neurological examination revealed that he had dysarthria (difficulty in speech)  facial droop on the right side  arm drift and leg weakness on the right side  consistent with signs of stroke. Other physical examinations were unremarkable.  Investigations: Emergency CT scan of the brain showed an area of reduced blood flow in the left middle cerebral artery distribution which is suggestive of an acute ischemic stroke. Blood glucose level was slightly elevated but within the acceptable range for patients with diabetes. His ECG showed normal sinus rhythm.   Management: After a consultation with the hospital’s stroke team  it was decided to initiate intravenous thrombolytic therapy (tPA). He was also started on antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin) and a statin (Atorvastatin) to manage his underlying risk factors. His blood pressure and blood glucose levels are regularly monitored and managed according to the guidelines. He was subsequently referred for physical and speech therapy.  Prognosis: The prognosis will depend on the size and location of the stroke  the time of initiation of treatment  and the patient's compliance with medication and therapy. Stroke rehabilitation can help him regain his independence.  Summary: Mr. Smith is a 67-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes who presented with acute onset of headache  right-sided weakness  and slurred speech consistent with a left-sided ischemic stroke. His management included emergency thrombolytic therapy  initiation of risk factor control with antiplatelet and statin therapy  and referral for rehab services.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John Doe  who was admitted to the hospital following complaints of severe headache  sudden drowsiness  confusion  and difficulty in speaking and understanding words.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension controlled with medication for the past 10 years. His BMI is 29.1  indicative of overweight but not obesity. He had been a smoker for 40 years but quit 2 years ago. He admits to consuming alcohol socially but not excessively. Previously  he suffered from a minor ischemic stroke 4 years ago from which he recovered with minimal complications. There was no history of diabetes  heart disease  or cholesterol disorders.  Demographics:  Mr. Doe recently retired from his work as a civil engineer. He lives with his wife in the suburban parts of the city. Both children live out of state but visit frequently. He leads an inactive lifestyle and has a diet rich in processed foods.  Family History:  His father died from a myocardial infarction at 70  and his mother had a cerebrovascular accident at 78. His older sister is living with type II diabetes. There is a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Clinical Examination:  Physical examination showed left-side facial droop and hemiparesis. His speech was slurred  and he had difficulty finding the right words. His Blood Pressure was considerably high at 180/100 mmHg. A complete blood count  coagulation profile  electrolytes  kidney function  liver function  cardiac enzymes  and cholesterol levels were asked for.  Diagnosis:  Given his symptoms  past medical history  family history  and physical examination  he was diagnosed with a probable stroke -- specifically right hemisphere ischemic stroke. An emergency CT scan was ordered to confirm.   The stroke team initiated immediate stroke management protocol. They also involved a dietician for dietary recommendations and a physiotherapist for post-stroke rehabilitation.  Follow-Up:  A follow-up appointment was scheduled for Mr. Doe  a week after his discharge. His vitals were consistently monitored while he was in the hospital. Cardiology and Neurology specialists were also brought on board for consultation. The hospital's social worker was asked to co-ordinate with Mr. Doe's wife regarding post-discharge care and lifestyle changes.  This incident underlines the importance of focusing on primary prevention -control of hypertension  smoking cessation  and a balanced diet- especially in patients with family history of cerebrovascular and cardiovascular diseases.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information:  Mr. John Doe is a 70-year-old African-American male with a medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. He lives at home with his wife and they have two adult children. He retired five years ago with a previous lifetime occupation as a truck driver.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Doe presented at the ER complaining of sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking which lasted for approximately 2-3 hours before he sought medical attention.  Past Medical History: He was diagnosed with hypertension at the age of 50 and type 2 diabetes at the age of 55. He has been on medication since then  including Metformin  Lisinopril  and Simvastatin. He also had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 5 years ago. Apart from this  there are no other significant illnesses. He is allergic to penicillins.   Social History: Mr. Doe is a former 20 pack-year smoker who quit 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally  with an average intake of one to two standard drinks per week. He is moderately active  enjoys gardening but admits to a diet high in sodium and carbohydrates.  Family History: His father died of myocardial infarction in his early sixties while his mother is alive with Alzheimer's disease. One of his brothers had a stroke in his late fifties. There is no known family history of malignancy.  Examination Findings:  On physical examination  he was alert and oriented. Vitals were stable. Neurological examination showed right-sided hemiparesis and expressive aphasia. Cardiac  respiratory and abdominal examination was unremarkable.  Investigations: CT brain revealed an ischemic stroke in the left middle cerebral artery territory consistent with his right-sided symptoms. Blood tests showed elevated blood glucose levels and slightly raised cholesterol.  Impression: Mr. Doe has likely suffered an acute ischemic stroke secondary to uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia  and has a background of a previous TIA.  Plan: Mr. Doe was immediately started on Aspirin  a statin was added to his current regimen  and his antihypertensive medication was updated. He was admitted to the stroke unit for close monitoring and was further evaluated by a neurologist. The plan is to consider thrombolysis if suitable and to work with the therapy team for early rehabilitation. Dietary and lifestyle changes will be discussed with him and his family. His diabetes regimen may also need revision based on his elevated blood glucose levels.

Patient Case Presentation: Mr. Smith  Case Profile:  Mr. Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male diagnosed with a stroke. He lives with his wife in a suburban neighborhood and is a retired mechanical engineer. He is non-smoker but moderate alcohol consumer. He was brought to the emergency department with acute onset weakness in right side of the body and slurred speech.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years  which are well-controlled with medication. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia 5 years ago and follows a regimen of statin therapy. His medications include Metformin for diabetes  Amlodipine for hypertension and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. He had an uncomplicated appendectomy at the age of 25  with no other surgical history. Mr. Smith's weight is within normal range  however  he leads a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity.   Family History:  Mr. Smith's father died at the age of 75 from cardiovascular disease  while his mother passed away at 80 from a stroke. He has two siblings- an older brother with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation and a younger sister in good health.  Clinical Findings:  Upon examination  Mr. Smith was conscious but had slight difficulty in understanding commands. His blood pressure was 145/90 mmHg and blood sugar was 135 mg/dL. Neurological examination revealed right-sided hemiparesis with a power grade of 3/5. Right-sided facial droop was present with a mild slurring of speech  but no significant sensory impairment observed.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  A CT scan showed an area of infarction in the left middle cerebral artery territory  confirming the diagnosis of ischemic stroke. An EKG did not detect any atrial fibrillation.  Management Plan: Management included an immediate initiation of thrombolytic therapy under the Stroke protocol  strict glucose  and blood pressure control. Mr. Smith was further referred to physiotherapy and occupational therapy for rehabilitation. Furthermore  lifestyle modifications and modification of current medication plan were also addressed with the patient and his family.  This case underscores the importance of regular health checks  lifestyle modifications  and medication adherence in high-risk individuals. The patient  Mr. Smith  had established and well-controlled comorbid conditions  yet suffered a stroke. Thus  proactive medical management with lifestyle modification can potentially prevent such debilitating outcomes.

Patient Profile:   John Doe  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  was brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of weakness in the right side of his body and slurred speech.   Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a medical history significant for hypertension and diabetes type II  which have been managed with medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension and Metformin 1000mg two times a day for diabetes). He quit smoking ten years ago  following a 30-year pack-a-day habit. He denied drug and alcohol use and reported adherence to his prescribed medications.  Family History:   Mr. Doe shared that his father had a stroke at the age of 67. His mother has diabetes  and his older brother was diagnosed with hypertension and coronary artery disease.  Presenting Illness:  On presentation  Mr. Doe displayed noticeable right-sided hemiparesis and dysarthria  prominent symptoms that suggested a cerebrovascular accident/stroke. His blood pressure was elevated at 160/95mmHg  and the blood glucose level was recorded at 220mg/dl.   Diagnostic Assessment:  An urgent non-contrast CT scan was performed  showing an area of reduced attenuation in the left middle cerebral artery territory  indicative of an acute ischemic stroke. Other tests  including EKG and blood tests  were largely unremarkable. His cholesterol level was slightly above the normal range.  Management:  The patient was admitted to the stroke unit for further management  which included initiation of antiplatelet therapy with aspirin  along with aggressive blood pressure control and management of hyperglycemia. Physiotherapy and speech therapy consultations were also arranged to address his right-sided weakness and speech difficulties.   This case serves as an important reminder of the role of modifiable risk factors – namely hypertension  hyperglycemia  and smoking – in the development of stroke. Attention to the prevention  early detection  and control of these risk factors is essential in minimizing stroke morbidity and mortality.

Case Presentation  Patient Information:  Mr. John Doe  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  visited the emergency department due to sudden-onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech. He is a retired engineer  lives with his wife  and has two adult children.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe was diagnosed with hypertension six years ago and type 2 diabetes mellitus three years ago  for which he takes Amlodipine and Metformin respectively. He had an appendectomy at age 30  and no other surgical history was reported.   Family History:  His father passed away at 67 due to myocardial infarction. His mother  now 96  is living with Alzheimer's disease. His older sister died at 59 due to breast cancer  and a younger brother  currently 68  was diagnosed with stroke 2 years ago.   Presenting Situation:  The patient woke up feeling fine  had his breakfast  and was about to go on his morning walk when he felt dizzy and weak in his right arm and leg. His speech became slurred  and his wife noticed the right side of his face drooping. Recognizing these were potential signs of a stroke  his wife immediately called for an ambulance. It was around 8.30 AM. His last known normal was around 7:30 AM.  Clinical Examination:  Primary examination found him alert  disoriented in time  right-sided facial droop  dysarthria  and right-sided hemiparesis (4/5 power in right upper and lower limb). His vitals were stable - BP 165/85 mmHg  HR 74/min  RR 14/min  Temp 98.2°F  and Oxygen saturation 96%.  Inpatient Treatment:  Per the NIH Stroke Scale  his score was 8  indicative of moderate stroke. Immediate CT scan showed no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage. With his medical history and presentation  it was decided to initiate intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA). The Patient and wife were explained about the procedure and process. An informed consent was taken for it.  Treatment outcomes:  Post-treatment  his symptoms significantly improved  with speech returning to normal and a minor right-sided weakness remaining. Stroke was diagnosed as due to small vessel disease caused by uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes.   Long-term Plans:  A multidisciplinary team  including a dietitian  speech therapist  and physiotherapist  was organized to work with the patient during his recovery period. After stabilization  efforts were made to optimize his glycemic control and blood pressure. Dietary changes  medication adjustments  and a strict follow-up schedule were put in place. Their two adult children were given a comprehensive explanation and trained regarding the signs  risks of stroke  and the importance of controlling hypertension and diabetes to prevent the recurrence of stroke. The family support for the patient during recovery was emphasized.

Patient Profile: Name: Mrs. Elizabeth Morgan  Age: 70 years  Sex: Female Race: Caucasian Marital Status: Widowed Occupation: Retired nurse  Presenting Symptoms: Mrs. Elizabeth was brought to the emergency department owing to sudden speech difficulty  right-sided weakness  facial droop and trouble with balance that lasted for about an hour.  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension: She has been diagnosed with hypertension for the last 10 years and takes Lisinopril daily. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 8 years ago. She's on Metformin. 3. Dyslipidemia: She takes Atorvastatin daily since diagnosed 7 years ago.  Family History: 1. Father died at 72 due to myocardial infarction 2. Mother died at 85 from old age 3. No family history of stroke  but her older brother was diagnosed with high blood pressure and heart disease in his 60s.  Social History: Mrs. Elizabeth is a retired nurse who lives alone. She quit smoking 20 years ago and drinks occasionally. She follows a balanced diet and walks daily  but mentions not being active on other forms of exercise.  Clinical Findings: On examination  there was evidence of right-sided hemiparesis and she scored 15 on the NIH stroke scale  indicative of moderate severity stroke. Her speech was slurred but comprehensible. No other abnormalities were detected on systemic examination.  Investigations: CT scan of the head confirmed an acute ischemic stroke in the left middle cerebral artery region. MRI further confirmed this.  Treatment: She was provided emergency stroke care. As she presented within the timeframe  thrombolysis was performed using intravenous alteplase. During her admission  blood sugar and blood pressure were closely monitored and controlled.  Progress: Post-treatment  her symptoms have marginally improved. However  she is currently undergoing physical and speech therapy.  Future Plans:  She will need ongoing physical  occupational  and speech therapy. Given the presence of multiple risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  she will be under close medical follow-ups with modifications in her current treatment regimen.   Summary: This case presents a 70 y/o female patient who developed an acute ischemic stroke likely secondary to known longstanding multiple vascular risk factors. Prompt diagnosis and timely treatment have induced some improvements  but she continues to require concerted multidisciplinary rehabilitation efforts. Her clinical journey underscores the importance of aggressive risk factor management in prevention of cerebrovascular events.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who recently presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden  severe headache accompanied by confusion  sudden weakness in his left limbs  and difficulty speaking. His wife reported that he had previous episodes of transient visual disturbances  but they were never severe enough to seek medical help. These symptoms occurred suddenly approximately two hours prior to coming to the emergency department. Mr. Doe also reported having a history of high blood pressure and hyperlipidemia.   Past Medical History  Mr. Doe is a known patient of Hypertension for the past ten years  which is controlled by taking Lisinopril 10mg daily. In addition  he was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia five years ago  which is managed by a combination of statin therapy (Atorvastatin 20 mg daily) and a balanced diet.  Family History:  According to Mr. Doe  there is a strong family history of hypertension on the paternal side and heart disease on his maternal side. His father died from a stroke at the age of 75 and two of his elder siblings are established cardiac patients.  Social History:  Mr. Doe is a retired accountant who lives with his wife. He has been a smoker for the past 30 years with an average of 20 cigarettes per day  consumes alcohol occasionally and leads a mostly sedentary lifestyle.  Examination:  On arrival  Mr. Doe's blood pressure was elevated at 170/95 mm Hg. Neurological examination was consistent with the left-sided hemispheric syndrome. His speech was slurred and he presented with left-sided facial droop and significant muscle weakness in the left upper and lower extremities.  Investigations:  CT scan of the head was promptly performed  which revealed evidence of a fresh right MCA territory infarct  thereby confirming the diagnosis of ischemic stroke. Blood tests came back showing an elevated cholesterol profile  consistent with his previous diagnosis of hyperlipidaemia.  Management:  Mr. Doe was admitted to the Stroke Unit  where he was started on a conservative treatment regimen including intravenous thrombolysis with a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator. His blood pressure was managed with parenteral antihypertensives to ensure it remained within an acceptable range. He was also referred to the Rehabilitation department for physiotherapy and occupational therapy.  In conclusion  Mr. Doe’s stroke likely results from his uncontrolled hypertension and atherosclerotic disease due to hyperlipidaemia  exacerbating his risk factors of age  genetic predisposition  smoking and a sedentary lifestyle. His case highlights the importance of lifestyle modification  strict control of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and smoking cessation  which could potentially have reduced his risk of stroke.

Case Presentation:  Patient Information: Ms. Rosemary Donovan  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness  facial drooping and difficulty in speech. She lives alone but was brought in by her neighbor who found her in this state. She denied any headache  loss of vision  vertigo  chest pain  or shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: Rosemary has been hypertensive for the past ten years and also was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus five years ago. She is on antihypertensive medication and oral hypoglycemic drugs. She had a minor myocardial infarction 3 years ago and received angioplasty with stent placement in the left anterior descending artery. She is a former smoker  quit 5 years back and has a history of occasional alcohol use. She has no known allergies.   Family History: Deceased father had hypertension and mother had heart disease. Her older brother died from stroke at the age of 72. Younger sister diagnosed with diabetes.  Clinical Examination: On physical examination  patient was conscious but disoriented to time and place. There was noticeable right facial drooping. Motor examination showed right hemiparesis. Her speech was slurred. Her blood pressure was recorded as 170/95mmHg  pulse rate was 82 beats/min and regular  respirations were 18/min  and body temperature was 98.2°F.  Diagnostic Findings:  An emergency CT scan of the head was ordered  which revealed a left middle cerebral artery territory infarct. Her blood glucose level was 200 mg/dL  and other laboratory test results showed no significant abnormality.  Treatment and Management: Rosemary meets the criteria for thrombolysis  if not contraindicated; hence  she will be moved to the stroke unit for thrombolysis with Alteplase (IV rt-PA) within the therapeutic window. Antihypertensive therapy will also be optimized to manage blood pressure levels. She will also require a consultation from the physiotherapy team and the dietitian team. Her family members will be educated on the condition and rehabilitation process and ensure she adheres to her medication.  This case highlights the impact of multiple risk factors including hypertension  diabetes  heart disease  older age  and family history of stroke that culminated in Rosemary's stroke. Modification of risk factors and strict control of hypertension and blood sugar are key to anticipation and prevention of such events.    Disposition:  Hospital admission to the stroke unit with plans for possible thrombolytic therapy pending final review of the contraindications. She will be evaluated for possible rehabilitation needs such as speech pathology for her dysarthria and physical therapy for her right-side weakness.
