He also reported blurred vision in his right eye  difficulty in maintaining balance  and trouble in speaking clearly. He noted that these symptoms started about 1 hour prior to coming to the hospital. He denied any chest pain or shortness of breath.  Final Note:  This case involves a typical risk factor scenario for ischemic stroke  with a hypertensive  hyperlipidemic  former smoker presenting with typical neurologic signs of a stroke. The case serves to focus the training around rapid stroke identification  risk identification  urgent management needs  and overview of typical primary care measures aimed at stroke prevention. Students should use this case to learn about the importance of timely care in case of stroke and understand the potential underlying factors that could lead to a similar experience in other patients.

Case Title: Acute Ischemic Stroke in an Elderly Female Patient   Patient's Information: The patient is a 75-year-old African-American female  Mrs. M  living in a suburban neighborhood. She is a retired school librarian. She is a non-smoker and has an occasional alcohol use.   Past Medical History: The patient has a diagnosed history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus which are managed by medications. There is no known history of stroke in her family.  Key Complaints: Mrs. M was brought into the Emergency Department by her daughter because she woke up and found her mother having problems with her speech  and noticed a facial droop on the right side. Her daughter noted that her mother was completely fine before going to bed the previous night.  According to the daughter  Mrs. M has been experiencing occasional headaches and fatigue for the past few weeks. Mrs. M mentioned about some visual troubles a few days ago  but assumed it was due to her age. On the morning of admission  she complained about difficulty in finding words but denied any symptoms of headache  dizziness  or chest pain.-

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. X is a 65-year-old Hispanic male  who resides in the suburban area of the city. He is a retired engineer  married with five grandchildren. He is an occasional alcoholic and has been a moderate smoker for the past 40 years.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a documented history of hypertension for the last 10 years and type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed five years back. Both conditions are presently managed with medications. He has been non-compliant with lifestyle changes and follow-up care. He supposes himself very much healthy and had not been reporting any symptoms. There is no known allergy to any medication.   Chief Complaints:  Mr. X presented to the Emergency Department with abrupt onset of severe headache described as 'the worst headache of his life'  associated with vomiting and blurring of vision. His wife has noticed a peculiar change in his speech and asymmetry of his face that alarmed them to visit the hospital at once.  Physical Examination:  Upon arrival in ED  he was alert but confused about time and place. He exhibits a significant weakness on the right side of his body  stammering speech  and facial droop. His blood pressure was found elevated (BP - 190/110 mm Hg). Other vital signs were within normal ranges.  This comprehensive patient background information should be the basis for instructing students on recognizing and understanding the signs and symptoms of stroke given the patient's demographic  risk factors (hypertension  diabetes  smoking)  the sudden onset of symptoms  and characteristic physical presentation.

Case Report: Acute Stroke  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Johnson  Age: 65 years Sex: Male Race: African American Occupation: Retired high school teacher Living situation: Lives alone  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension – Diagnosed 15 years ago  irregularly taking prescribed antihypertensives. 2. Type II diabetes mellitus – Diagnosed 10 years ago  managed with metformin and lifestyle modification. 3. Hyperlipidemia – Diagnosed 5 years ago  refused to take statins due to perceived side effects. 4. Previous transient ischemic attack (TIA) – Occurred 2 years ago  left him with minor residual right-sided weakness. 5. Smoker – 20 cigarettes per day for the last 40 years. 6. Alcohol – Moderately heavy drinker (4–5 drinks per night).  Key Complaints: Mr. Johnson was brought in by a neighbor who found him slumped down on his armchair when she came for a visit. He was apparently well until approximately 7 hours ago when he developed sudden onset left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. She reported that he looked confused and his face appeared asymmetrical.  The patient could not directly communicate his complaints. However  a few hours before the presentation  he reportedly told another neighbor that he was experiencing a headache and felt unusually tired. No reported seizures  trauma  loss of consciousness  or fever. His bowel and bladder habits had been normal.   Make sure students consider key aspects of the patient's history (longstanding hypertension  diabetes  smoking  previous TIA) and the symptomatology pointing towards a possible ischemic stroke when discussing differential diagnoses  investigation  and management options. It's crucial to teach the importance of timely stroke identification and treatment.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. James Peterson  a 68-year-old African-American male  initially reported to the emergency department. The patient was a retired banker  living with his wife in the suburban part of the city.   Past Medical History: Mr. Peterson had been diagnosing with hypertension  borderline diabetes  and was a smoker for over 40 years but quit ten years ago.   Presenting complaints: The patient reported experiencing sudden weakness on the right side of his body  slurred speech  and drooping on the right side of his face for approximately two hours. Mr. Peterson's wife also noticed that he was having difficulty walking and was straining to finish his sentences. Mr. Peterson himself was experiencing a headache with a severity of 7 out of 10 on the pain scale. He also exhibited mild confusion. No history of trauma was reported.  Other important information: There was no immediate familial history of stroke. The patient's hypertension was managed with Amlodipine  and his diabetes was diet-controlled. According to his wife  he consistently checked his blood pressure at home  which had been fairly under control. His last reported reading was 145/85 mmHg  and he stated that he'd been sticking to a balanced diet and occasional exercising. He was not under any anticoagulant or anti-platelet medication.  This case has been designed to train medical students about the investigation  diagnosis  and management of ischemic stroke. The history of hypertension  diabetes  and smoking  along with presenting complaints of sudden unilateral weakness  facial drooping  and speech difficulties  almost certainly indicate a stroke. Further investigation of brain imaging  glucose levels  and blood pressure monitoring should affirm this. The prompt management of acute ischemic stroke  including the administration of thrombolytic agents within the therapeutic window  antihypertensive therapy  and secondary preventive measures  can also be explained using this case.

Patient Information:   Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old African American male retired banker  presents to the emergency department accompanied by his wife.  Past Medical History:  He is a known patient of Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for ten years. Patient history reveals no known allergies. He is on Metformin for his diabetes and Amlodipine for hypertension. He is a non-smoker and occasionally consumes alcohol during social gatherings. There is a family history of stroke  with his father having experienced a stroke at the age of 75.  Presenting Complaints:  His wife reports that approximately 2 hours prior to arrival  he suddenly developed a feeling of weakness on the right side of his body  with difficulty in speaking and a facial droop. He denied any preceding headache  recent infections  trauma  seizure  loss of consciousness  or visual changes. He mentions recent stress at his daughter's wedding preparations.  On Examination:  Vitally stable; BP: 160/90 mmHg  PR: 80 bpm  RR:18/min  Temp: 37.5 C. Higher Mental functions unassessable due to dysarthria. Intracranial nerves show right-sided lower motor neuron type facial nerve palsy. Motor system examination reveals right-sided hemiparesis. Medical students should be asked to observe the signs and symptoms and go through some of the medical history to identify the risk factors for stroke.   Plan:   A CT scan of the brain is immediately planned to determine if Mr. Doe is suffering from an ischemic or hemorrhic stroke. Upon confirmation  appropriate management measures should be taken.   The above case scenario will help to understand the importance of history taking  recognize stroke symptoms  prompt emergency measures  and management of common risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes causing stroke. Furthermore  a discussion on the early interventions will underscore the importance of time in stroke management.   Students would be made to understand the 'FAST' acronym which stands for Facial drooping  Arm weakness  Speech difficulties and Time to call the emergency services. They would also be taught about the role of thrombolytics in ischemic stroke and the time window for their administration. The case would also touch on rehabilitation potential and the patient's long-term management and preventive measures following a stroke.

Subject Case: Mrs. Jane Smith  Demographics: - Age: 68 years  - Gender: Female  - Ethnicity: Caucasian  - Occupation: Retired School Teacher - Location: New York City  USA  Past Medical History: Mrs. Smith has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are well-controlled with medications (Losartan 50 mg daily and Rosuvastatin 10 mg daily). She does not have diabetes mellitus or a previous history of cardiac events. She has a 20-pack-year history of smoking but quit 20 years ago. Mrs. Smith has a family history of stroke on her father's side.  Presenting Complaints: Mrs. Smith presented to the emergency department with acute-onset of right-sided weakness  facial droop  and slurred speech that started approximately 2 hours ago. She didn't experience any headache  chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea  or vomiting. She has no difficulty with vision or balance.   Other key complaints include a recent history (2 weeks back) of transient episodes of right arm weakness that resolve spontaneously without any intervention. She disregarded these episodes thinking they might be related to her age.   In the emergency department  her blood pressure is high (170/90 mmHg)  and her blood glucose level is normal. The National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) is 8. The rest of the physical examination is normal without any cardiac murmurs or carotid bruits.    NB: The subsequent steps in management would involve immediate neuroimaging (brain CT without contrast) to rule out hemorrhagic stroke and would then consider thrombolytic therapy depending on the imaging and her eligibility. If indicated  she will be started on tPA (Alteplase) immediately as she came within the window period (4.5 hrs). Stroke is the emergency situation that needs immediate attention. After stabilization  the educational case can discuss stroke risk factors  types of stroke  signs and symptoms  investigations  and finally management and prevention strategies. It would emphasize the importance of correct and fast diagnosis and treatment (""Time is Brain""). Possible short-term and long-term complications could also be discussed.

Patient Information:  - Age: 65 years - Sex: Male - Occupation: Retired Bank Manager - Demographics: African-American  lives with wife  Present Illness:  Presenting Complaints:  - Sudden onset of weakness in the right arm and leg  - Difficulty in speaking with onset same as limb weakness - Mild confusion - No complaint of any headache  vomiting  or altered consciousness  Past Medical History:  The patient is known to be hypertensive for the last 10 years  on irregular treatment. He is also a type 2 diabetic for the last 6 years  currently not well controlled with metformin 500mg twice daily. He quit smoking 5 years ago but was smoking 1 pack per day for 35 years. His father suffered from a stroke at age 68. He has no known drug allergies.   Family History:  Apart from his father who suffered a stroke  there is no other significant family history of any cardiovascular or genetic disease.  Social History:  The patient is retired and lives with his wife. Used to smoke but quit 5 years ago. He has a moderate alcohol intake but no recreational drug use. He is moderately active for his age and enjoys gardening. He also volunteers at a local community center.   Physical Examination:  The patient is conscious & coherent but exhibits mild confusion. He is oriented to time  place  and person. The right nasolabial fold is flattened. He has slurred speech. The tongue deviates to the right on protrusion. His pulse rate - 88 bpm regularly regular  BP -165/95mmhg. There's marked weakness (power 2/5) in his right upper and lower limb but no loss of sensation. Reflexes are normal  plantar reflex is equivocal on the right. No signs of meningeal irritation. Cranial nerve examination reveals no abnormalities aside from the noted tongue deviation. Cardiovascular  respiratory and abdominal examinations are non-contributory.   Further Investigation/Management:  This case is immediately worrisome for a likely stroke  based on complaints and physical findings. Acute management will involve urgent neuroimaging to determine if stroke is ischemic or hemorrhagic  acute management to minimize brain damage  potential thrombolytic therapy depending on imaging results and time from symptom onset  and regular monitoring to identify possible complications. Long-term management would likely involve refining and improving management of his hypertension and diabetes  lifestyle counseling  and possibly anticoagulant therapy or antiplatelet therapy  depending again on the specific results of his investigation.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He has been on medications for his conditions: Lisinopril 20mg daily  Metformin 1000mg twice daily  and Atorvastatin 40mg at bedtime. He has no history of surgery or any allergies. He is a non-smoker and currently lives with his wife. He does not consume alcohol.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Smith presented in the emergency department with sudden onset weakness on the right side of his body  which started about an hour prior to his arrival at the hospital. He further complains of difficulty in speaking and slurring of words. He also mentioned a sudden severe headache which he rated as 8 on a scale of 0 to 10 (0 being no pain and 10 being the worst pain imaginable). His wife also reports noticing the right side of his mouth drooping.   He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness. He has no complaint of loss of vision or double vision.   This case scenario is designed to help medical students understand the clinical presentation of a stroke and highlights the importance of accurate history taking and physical examination in a patient with suspected stroke. This case also emphasizes on the necessity of prompt clinical decision and interventions for patients with stroke.

Patient Information:   - Name: John Wright - Age: 71  - Gender: Male  - Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History:  John has a history of hypertension. He was diagnosed with type II diabetes at the age of 55 but has not managed it well. He also has a history of excessive smoking and alcohol consumption but quit both about a year ago. He takes medication for both  hypertension and diabetes. He has not been consistent with his visits to the doctor. His mother suffered a stroke when she was 67.  Presenting Complaints:  John was brought to the Emergency Department (ED) by his daughter who found him in bed with the right side of his face drooping  slurred speech  and unable to move his right arm and leg. These symptoms had a sudden onset in the early morning while he was asleep. He did not have a headache  vision loss  or difficulty in swallowing but complained of dizziness and was confused about time and place.   In this case scenario  the key learning objectives can revolve around understanding the common risk factors and symptoms associated with stroke  fast action response to stroke symptoms  differential diagnoses  fundamental diagnostic tests  and treatment regimens for stroke.

Patient Case: Acute Stroke   Patient Details:  - Name: Mr. John Doe  - Age: 70 years old  - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian  - Occupation: Retired mechanical engineer  Past Medical History:  - Hypertension: Medication - amlodipine 5 mg daily  - Type 2 diabetes: Controlled by diet  - High cholesterol: Medication - simvastatin 20 mg at night  - No previous history of stroke or other cardiovascular disease  - Non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially  - Family history: Mother had stroke at age 82  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the Emergency Department with his wife. The primary complaints were: - Sudden weakness on right side of body (Around 2 hours duration) - Difficulty in speaking  slurred speech  - Difficulty in understanding what wife was saying  - Complaints of a sharp  splitting headache  - No complaint of chest pain or shortness of breath - No evidence of trauma  - No loss of consciousness   This abrupt onset of neurological symptoms lasted for more than 1 hour  suggesting a possible acute ischemic stroke. His wife notices these symptoms when he was unable to hold his coffee cup and was slurring his words. On arrival at the hospital  the emergency triage team activated the stroke alert  and Mr. Doe was taken for an immediate brain CT scan.

Case Report: Acute Ischemic Stroke  Patient Demographics: Name: William Thompson Age: 66-years-old Sex: Male Occupation: Retired Engineer  Ethnicity: Caucasian Location: Urban  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension present for last 15 years  on medication (Amlodipine 5mg) 2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus for 10 years  currently managed with Metformin 3. Occasional smoking  quit 5 years ago.   Presenting Complaints:  1. Sudden onset weakness in the right side of the body (arm  leg  and half of the face)  for the past 2 hours 2. Difficulty in speech  was unable to say complete words  Narrative Case Details:  Mr. Thompson was brought into the hospital by his wife who reported that while having breakfast  he suddenly experienced an inability to grip his coffee cup and had difficulty speaking clear words. Though he was fully conscious  he could not move the entire right side of his body. His wife also reported a notable droop on the right side of his face  especially noticeable in his facial expression. His symptoms appeared abruptly with no warning signs. Prior to this  he was asymptomatic and was carrying on with his daily activities as usual. He has no history of significant trauma or injury  illicit drug use or recent surgeries.  Conclusion:  Considering the sudden onset of unilateral weakness  drooping of face  and aphasia  an acute ischemic stroke is suspected. Further diagnostic tests including a CT-scan or MRI  lipid panel  echocardiogram  blood glucose levels  and possible carotid ultrasound should be conducted to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other possibilities such as a brain tumor or transient ischemic attack. If diagnosis is confirmed  the patient should be treated immediately with intravenous thrombolytics  if there are no contraindications. Management would then focus on prevention of secondary stroke  rehabilitation  and addressing the risk factors like hypertension and diabetes.

Case Report for Medical Training Program: Cerebrovascular Accident (Stroke)  Patient Information:  - Age: 65-years-old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired Engineer  Chief Complaint:  The patient presented in the Emergency Department complaining of sudden-onset weakness on the right side of his body and difficulty in speech  which started about 2 hours prior.  Past Medical History:  The patient is hypertensive for the past ten years  under treatment with an ACE inhibitor. His compliance with the medication was irregular. The patient also has a history of smoking  with an estimated 30-pack year history. His father passed away due to myocardial infarction at an early age (58 years old).  Family history also reveals chronic diseases  such as Hypertension and Diabetes Mellitus Type 2. Unfortunately  the patient had only rare visits to his primary care physician and lacks regular blood workups.  Physical Examination:  On neurological examination  there was right facial drooping  slurred speech  and right arm drift. The Glasgow Coma Scale was 14/15. Motor strength was 2/5 in the right upper and lower limbs suggesting hemiparesis  with no signs on the left  and intact sensation. His BP was recorded as 180/100 mm HG  and the heart rate was 88 per minute regular.  This case scenario aims to provide students a strong basis on how to approach  evaluate  diagnose  and manage acute ischemic stroke patients. It is also designed to highlight risk factors  including hypertension and smoking. It could also be used to discuss the significance of urgent medical attention and patient's regular follow-up for chronic conditions.

Patient Information:  Name: John Smith Age: 68 years  Gender: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Engineer  Past Medical History: John has a 20-year history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Both have been managed with medication (Metformin for diabetes and Amlodipine for hypertension). He was a pack-a-day smoker for 45 years but quit 5 years ago. He limits alcohol consumption to an occasional glass of wine and has a sedentary lifestyle. He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease - his father suffered a myocardial infarction at age 70  and his mother died from a stroke at age 72.   Presenting Complaints: John was brought to the emergency department by his wife. She reported that he suddenly developed difficulty speaking (appeared to be searching for words and was unable to complete sentences) along with weakness in his right arm and leg while eating dinner at home. The onset was sudden and it persisted  prompting his wife to call for an ambulance. There were no complaints of headache  unconsciousness  chest pain  shortness of breath  or seizures.   Other symptoms:  John complains of slight dizziness and visual disturbances such as blurriness in his left peripheral field of vision since morning. He had attributed it to tiredness earlier but it didn't resolve after a nap.  Overall  the case is constructed to present a likely scenario of an acute ischemic stroke. The following sessions can elaborate on the physical examination  diagnostic tests (like CT/MRI Brain  carotid ultrasound  echocardiogram  blood tests)  further management plans  rehabilitation  and prevention strategies. The case also allows discussion on lifestyle modification  the importance of adhering to medications  and the need for regular check-ups in managing chronic conditions that predispose to such emergencies.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 69 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired schoolteacher Living Situation: Lives with wife in a suburban home  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe was treated for hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past 10 years with daily medication. He quit smoking more than 15 years ago but has a 30-package year history. He is obese with a BMI of 30. He consumes alcohol moderately and has no known drug allergies. His father had cerebrovascular disease and his elder brother is living with coronary artery disease. His medications include 50mg Atenolol and 10mg Atorvastatin daily.   Key Complaints:  Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset difficulty speaking and right-sided weakness which started 3 hours prior to arrival. His symptoms were witnessed by his wife who immediately called for medical help. There is no associated headache  seizures  loss of consciousness  nausea or vomiting  chest pain  or dyspnea. He denies any recent trauma  fever  travel  sick contacts  or changes in medication.  Summary:  Mr. John Doe  a 69-year-old male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and obesity  presents with sudden onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech. His risk factors include his age  gender  familial history of cerebrovascular disease  and personal history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking  and obesity. Given his sudden onset neurological symptoms  the leading differential diagnosis would be an acute ischemic stroke. This case emphasizes the timeliness of diagnosis and management of a potential stroke.

Patient Case Report: Stroke  Patient Information: Name: Mr. Thompson Age: 65 Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Complete Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson is a smoker with history of hypertension  type II diabetes  and high cholesterol levels. He has a record of ignoring medication compliance and lifestyle modifications. He was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation last year. His mother died of an ischemic stroke at the age of 72.  Key Presenting Complaints: Mr. Thompson was brought to the emergency room by his wife who found him slumped on the floor. He exhibited the following symptoms upon initial examination:  1. Facial weakness: His wife had noticed that the left side of his face looked uneven  showing asymmetry while smiling. 2. Arm weakness: He had trouble lifting his left arm. 3. Speech difficulties: His speech was slurred and incomprehensible  unable to complete full sentences. 4. Confusion and disorientation: He was unable to name his location or accurately recall current events.  5. Headache: He complained about an abrupt  severe headache  unlike any headache he had previously experienced.  Thus  based on the presenting complaints  suspicion of stroke was raised and relevant procedures were initiated promptly. His case provides significant teaching material for management and prevention of stroke  emphasizing the critical role of prompt recognition of symptoms  efficient clinical examination  timely investigations and intervention  as well as the importance of preventive measures and lifestyle modifications.

Case Report: Acute Ischemic Stroke  Patient Demographics:  - Age: 68 years old  - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Sex: Male - Occupation: Retired engineer - Smoking Status: Non-smoker - Alcohol Usage: Moderate - Physical Activity: Sedentary  Past Medical History:  The patient has a significant past medical history of hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus  both of which have been managed for the last 10 years with medication. Family history shows that his father died of a stroke at the age of 72. Patient is also overweight with a BMI of 30.  Key Complaints:  The patient was brought to the emergency department by his wife after she found him in the bathroom with difficulty speaking and right side weakness. His wife reported that he was fine when they went to bed around 11 PM  but when she woke up at 7 AM to find him  he was in that state.  The patient was reportedly conscious but seemed confused and had difficulties finding his words. He appeared scared and frustrated. His wife also reported that he had complained of a severe headache the night before but simply took an aspirin and went to bed. He did not report or show signs of any seizures  fever  infection  recent head injury  or similar significant health events.  Physical examination at the emergency department demonstrated right facial droop  aphasia  and right-sided hemiparesis  suggesting left hemisphere cerebral pathology. The emergency physician suspected an acute ischemic stroke and immediately ordered a CT scan to confirm the diagnosis while initiating a stroke protocol. His blood pressure upon admission was 180/95 mmHg  and his blood glucose was 143 mg/dL.   This case will take the students through the process of diagnosing  managing  and understanding the implications of a stroke  as well as discussing preventive measures. The importance of timely diagnosis and management in patients with stroke should be emphasized.

Case Report: Ischemic Stroke  Patient Demographics:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 67 years old Sex: Male Occupation: Retired teacher Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has been diagnosed with Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes for the last 15 years. He is a nonsmoker and consumes alcohol moderately. His father suffered a stroke at the age of 70.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-side weakness  slurred speech  and difficulty in understanding speech which started about 2 hours ago. He also reported a mild headache and confusion. There is no history of trauma  fever  or altered consciousness. There was no complaint of chest pain  palpitations  or breathing difficulty.  On examination  he was conscious but had a right-sided facial droop  brisk deep tendon reflexes on the right side  and power of 2/5 in the right upper and lower limb. His speech was slurred. His blood pressure was 160/90 mm Hg and blood glucose was 200 mg/dl. He scored 12 on the National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS).  Based on the symptoms  past medical history  and physical examination  an acute ischemic stroke was suspected in Mr. Doe. The onset time of symptoms was within the window for thrombolysis therapy. Necessary investigations were done to confirm the diagnosis and to rule out any contraindications for thrombolysis. Mr. Doe was managed as per stroke guidelines with acute thrombolytic therapy and supporting measures.  Note: This case scenario emphasizes the need for urgent assessment and management in stroke  and the role of past medical history in determining stroke risk factors. Also  it is essential for students to understand the importance of the time window in managing ischemic stroke cases.

Case Title: Acute Stroke in a Middle-Aged Female  Patient Information:   - Mrs. Cho  a 52-year-old Asian female - Occupation: Elementary school teacher - Marital Status: Married with two children - Smoking: Non-smoker - Alcohol: Social drinker - Exercise: Walks 3 times a week  - Diet: Regular Asian diet with salt below the recommended intake   Past Medical History:  - Hypertension  diagnosed 5 years ago  on medication (Amlodipine 5mg daily) - Gestational diabetes mellitus during second pregnancy  resolved after child delivery - Mother had ischemic stroke at the age of 65  Presenting Complaints:  - Sudden onset of weakness and numbness on the right side of her body - Right facial droop - Slurring of speech - Difficulty in understanding commands  - Started when she was preparing breakfast this morning   Additional Key Information:  - Patient does not take the hypertension medication regularly - She had a headache yesterday but didn't pay much attention  - No prior episodes of TIA or stroke  This case illustrates a common presentation of an acute ischemic stroke. The key features include sudden onset  lateralizing signs suggesting a particular region of brain involvement  and risk factors such as poorly controlled hypertension and positive family history. It provides an excellent learning opportunity to discuss the identification  diagnosis  and management of acute ischemic stroke.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 63 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Retired Engineer  Chief Complaint:  Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset right-sided weakness and difficulty in talking and understanding speech since last 4 hours. He reported having a severe headache with no history of head injury.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a 10-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which he alleges to manage with occasional medication. He is a smoker with a 30-pack year smoking history. He stopped consuming alcohol two years ago. His father died at the age of 67 due to a massive stroke.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination  patient was conscious but appeared anxious and confused. Vital signs revealed blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg  Pulse - 88/min  respiration – 18/min  and an elevated blood glucose level. A strong heartbeat could be heard in both carotid arteries  indicating possible stenosis. Neurological examination revealed right hemiparesis  facial droop  and expressive aphasia.  Goals for the Case:  The aim of this case is to prompt the students to identify warning signs and risk factors for stroke  understand the need for urgent management  distinguish between different types of stroke  identify the need for lifestyle modification in patients with chronic disease like hypertension and diabetes  and understand the importance of patient education in preventing recurrent strokes.

Case Report:  Patient's Information: - Name: Mr. John Thompson - Age: 62 years old - Sex: Male - Occupation: Retired Accountant - Race: Caucasian - Location: Urban - Marital Status: Married - Children: Two (both adults)  Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson has a significant past medical history including hypertension for the past twenty-eight years controlled with regular medications. He also has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus ten years ago which is currently managed by metformin and insulin injections. He is a former smoker who quit 15 years ago but admits to being a social drinker. There has been no previous history of a stroke or a transient ischemic attack. There has also been no similar illness in the family. No known drug allergies.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Thompson presented to the emergency department with the sudden onset of symptoms that started a few hours ago in the morning. These included:  1. The right-sided weakness of the body  2. Trouble speaking and slurring of words 3. Felt unsteady while trying to walk 4. Sudden loss of vision in his left eye 5. Severe headache.   His wife also noticed a slight droop on the right side of his face and he did not consume his morning coffee which he is usually regular with. He had no complaints of chest pain  palpitations  or shortness of breath.   This case would lead us to consider the possibility of a stroke in Mr. Thompson  prioritizing assessments and interventions important for stroke patients. Students should learn about the immediate medical response needed  the importance of a quick CT scan  how to watch for and manage potential complications  and the ongoing care and rehab needed for stroke victims.

Patient Case: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 68 years old Sex: Male Race: African American Occupation: Retired teacher Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension managed with Lisinopril 20mg daily  Type II Diabetes Mellitus managed with Metformin 1000mg twice a day and has been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia for which he takes Atorvastatin 40mg daily. He quit smoking ten years ago. He occasionally consumes alcohol. His father had a stroke at the age of 58.  Presenting complaint: Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with sudden-onset slurred speech  right-sided facial drooping  and weakness in his right arm beginning approximately 1.5 hours prior to arrival.   He stated that he was watching television when he felt a sudden weakness in his right arm and was unable to pick up his coffee mug. He also complained of difficulty speaking and upon looking in the mirror noticed that the right side of his face appeared to be drooping. There is no history of headache  vomiting  or loss of consciousness.  Physical examination findings: Vitals: Blood Pressure - 160/90 mmHg  Pulse Rate - 88 beats/min  Respiratory Rate - 16 breaths per minute  Temperature - 98.6°F  Oxygen Saturation - 98% on room air Neuro: Conscious but displaying clear signs of right-sided facial drooping  slurred speech  and right arm weakness. Other neurological examination findings unremarkable. Cardiovascular: Rhythmic heart sounds  no murmur.  Respiratory: Clear and equal breath sounds bilaterally.  This case provides key symptoms of an acute stroke  suitable to guide the students through the approach to stroke diagnosis  investigation  and management  as well as discussion about risk factors and prevention strategies.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mrs. Smith Age: 72 Sex: Female Race: Caucasian Residency: Urban  living alone  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension (20 years) 2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus (10 years) 3. Hyperlipidemia (15 years) 4. Myocardial infarction (5 years ago) 5. Former smoker (35 pack-years)  Key Complaints: Mrs. Smith arrived at the emergency department (ED) with complaints of sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking that started approximately 2 hours ago. She also reported feeling a sharp headache  difficulty understanding simple conversations and maintaining balance. Mrs. Smith's neighbor who accompanied her mentioned that Mrs. Smith's mouth seemed to droop on the right side and she could barely use her right arm  which were uncharacteristic for her.  In ED  the physical examination revealed Mrs. Smith's blood pressure was 160/95 mmHg and her blood glucose was elevated at 215 mg/dL. She was conscious but notable was her speech  which was garbled  and she failed to follow simple instructions. Neurological examination identified right-sided facial droop  right-sided hemiparesis (4/5 strength)  and expressive dysphasia. The rest of her physical examination was unremarkable.

Case Report:   Patient Information:   Mr. John Stevens  a Caucasian male aged 67  retired construction worker  presented himself to the Emergency Department (ED). He is a non-smoker and moderate alcohol user. He does not have any known allergies.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Stevens has a known history of hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus for which he takes amlodipine 5mg daily and metformin 500mg twice daily  respectively. His BMI is 31.0 kg/m²  suggestive of obesity. He also has a family history of stroke in his father who died at the age of 70.  Chief Complaint:   The patient came with a chief complaint of sudden onset weakness on the right side of his body and troubles with speech  which was noticed by his wife. These symptoms started about an hour ago while he was reading a newspaper at home. His wife also mentioned some deviation of the mouth towards his left side.  Primary Examination:   On arrival  the patient was conscious but anxious. His vitals were: Blood Pressure- 170/95 mmHg  Pulse-98 bpm  Respiratory rate- 22/minute  Oxygen saturation- 96% on room air  Temperature- 98.6 °F.   Neurological exam revealed signs consistent with a stroke such as reduced muscle strength (power of 3/5) in the right arm and leg  facial droop on the right side  and slurred speech. The patient's NIH Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score was calculated as 8  indicating moderate stroke.   These multiple aspects need to be considered in the subsequent management plan for Mr. Stevens. He is immediately sent for an emergency CT scan  and r-tPA and antiplatelet therapy are being considered while awaiting the scan results.

Patient Information:   Mr. Ali  a 65-year-old male from an urban area. He is a retired banker  married with three grown children. He has a history of smoking one pack per day for approximately 30 years. He lives with his wife and is financially stable.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Ali has a history of uncontrolled hypertension and elevated lipids but has been non-compliant with medications. His last recorded blood pressure at a community health check two months ago was 160/95 mmHg  and his cholesterol was 250 mg/dL. He also has a history of Type II Diabetes mellitus  controlled with metformin. His father died of a stroke at the age of 70.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Ali presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided body weakness  difficulty speaking  and facial droop noted by his wife  two hours prior to the presentation. His wife also noted that Mr. Ali seemed confused and had trouble walking before she brought him to the hospital.  On initial examination:   Mr. Ali is conscious  alert  and oriented but exhibits clear signs of difficulty in speaking and understanding. His blood pressure on presentation is 175/100 mmHg  pulse rate 90/min  respiratory rate 20/min  and temperature is 36.9 degrees Celsius. Neurological examination reveals right-sided hemiplegia and facial drooping on the right side. He also has a noticeable speech difficulty (dysarthria).   Key Learning Points:  The case can be used to discuss the following issues:  1. The urgency required in the assessment and management of stroke. 2. Traditionally recognized risk factors for stroke  like hypertension  diabetes  and smoking. 3. Recognizing stroke symptoms. 4. The importance of public education to present early to the hospital on noticing signs of a stroke. 5. How chronic disease non-compliance increases susceptibility to severe health conditions. 6. Possible long-term complications and rehabilitation needs post-stroke. 7. The impact of family history in the risk of stroke.   The students should essentially be able to understand the complexity of managing a patient suffering from a stroke from this case.

Case Study: Stroke Management  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Arnold Douglas  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired mechanic  living in suburban Chicago.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Douglas is diagnosed with hypertension  type II diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. He has been a smoker for 40 years and consumes moderate amounts of alcohol. His father had a stroke at the age of 73.  Key Complaints:  Early morning  Mr. Douglas was found by his wife having difficulty speaking (slurred speech) and drooping on the left side of his face  and was unable to lift his left arm. His wife reported that he was fine when he went to bed the previous night. The onset was sudden and without any warning signs. He wasn't in any pain but appeared scared due to his inability to articulate or move properly. He did not exhibit loss of consciousness or convulsions.  Further information: On examination  his blood pressure was recorded at 180/100 mmHg. He was alert but visibly distressed. His speech was slurred and hard to understand. A noticeable left-sided facial droop was present.  Please note: The primary objective of this exercise is to help students understand the symptoms and risk factors associated with stroke  the importance of time (the 'golden hour') in stroke treatment  and the general approach to managing such a patient.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   Mr. Smith  a 70-year-old Hispanic male  a retired construction worker living with his wife in a suburban setting. He is a former smoker and has been sober for the last 20 years.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a 10 year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are managed with oral medications. He also has hyperlipidemia and a family history of ischemic strokes. No history of surgery or allergies.  Chief Complaints:  Mr. Smith presented to the emergency department with his wife. He complained of sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech for the last two hours. His wife added that he also had difficulty walking and appeared to lose balance. No reported episodes of seizures  vision changes  fever  weight changes  or urinary and bowel incontinence.  The case aims at making students aware of the risk factors that predispose patients to strokes. The students should also focus on the patient's chief complaints which align with the symptoms of a stroke. Appropriate history taking  clinical judgment  and physical examination need to be conducted to confirm the diagnosis and formulate an effective management plan.

Case Report:  Patient Information and Background:  Patient K is a 70-year-old Caucasian man with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is retired  a former smoker  and lives with his wife. He has been largely compliant with medications for his chronic conditions. He neither smokes nor drinks alcohol and has a low- fat diet plan.  Chief Complaints:  The patient came to the emergency department accompanied by his wife  reporting an onset of acute sensorimotor disturbances. His symptoms started three hours prior to his arrival in the hospital. According to his wife  he had been doing the household chores when he suddenly developed difficulty in speaking  alongside numbness and weakness on the right side of his body. He also displayed facial droop to the right side when trying to smile. The patient had no complaints of headache  dizziness  nausea or vomiting. There was no loss of consciousness or trauma preceding the symptoms.   Medical History:  In revealing his past medical history  he confirms that he is hypertensive for 20 years now  under medication  type-2 diabetic episodes for the last 15 years  but mismanaged  and has had elevated cholesterol levels for the past 10 years. He was a smoker for 30 years  but quit smoking a decade ago. He regularly uses antihypertensive drugs  oral hypoglycemic agents  and statins. He reports no known allergies or major surgeries in the past. His family history includes his father dying from a massive heart attack at the age of 68 and his mother dying from complications of diabetes.  This case can be used to discuss the signs and symptoms of stroke  importance of timely diagnosis and management  risk factors  preventive measures  and long-term patient management and rehabilitation. It also provides an opportunity to discuss health literacy and the importance of medication management in chronic diseases.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Name: John Doe Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Retired High School Principal  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension diagnosed 15 years ago  controlled with medication 2. Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 10 years ago  managed with diet  exercise  and medication 3. Hyperlipidemia diagnosed 8 years ago managed with statins 4. Former smoker for 30 years  quit 5 years ago 5. Family history: Father died of ischemic heart disease in his early 70s; mother had a stroke in her late 80s  Key Complaints: The patient came into the ER with his wife in the early morning. He was complaining about sudden onset left-sided weakness and difficulty speaking that began about 2 hours prior to visiting the hospital. His wife also reported that John's face seemed asymmetrical (""his mouth was sliding to one side"") and he was unable to hold his morning coffee cup due to a sudden weakness in his left hand.  Additional symptoms noted: confusion  dizziness  and severe headache. Upon initial evaluation  his blood pressure was noted to be high (178/95 mmHg).  The patient's symptoms point towards the possibility of an acute ischemic stroke and require immediate analysis and management to prevent further neurological damage. As his symptoms fit into the acronym FAST (Face  Arm  Speech  Time)  an integral part of stroke recognition  this case presents a crucial learning opportunity for medical students about the urgency and proper management of stroke cases.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. John Smith is a 68-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired school teacher  a non-smoker and lives with his wife in their own home.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a medical background of hypertension  treated with Amlodipine 5 mg daily  and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  which is diet controlled. He also has a history of Transient Ischemic Attacks (TIAs) roughly two years back  for which he was prescribed low-dose aspirin therapy. He does not have any history of cardiac diseases and denies any drug allergies. There is a family history of heart disease - his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 72.  Presenting Complaints: On the morning of admission  Mr. Smith was found by his wife having difficulty speaking and understanding speech. She noticed the left side of his face appeared to be drooping and he was unable to move his left arm. She promptly called for emergency services. These symptoms persisted continuously  with no noted relief. Also  Mr. Smith complained of a sudden onset of severe headache which he rated 8/10 in terms of severity. He reported no chest pain  shortness of breath  fever  or any other complaints.   On examination  left-sided facial droop  significant dysarthria  and left-sided hemiplegia were observed. Vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 158/98 mmHg  heart rate of 86 bpm  respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute  and saturating 97% on room air.   Upon these findings and medical history  stroke was considered as the primary diagnosis. Urgent neuro-imaging (CT head) and blood tests were ordered while Mr. Smith was being prepped for possible thrombolytic therapy.

Patient Demographics:   Mr. Brown  65-year-old African-American male  married  retired teacher. Non-smoker with a history of moderate alcohol intake  living in a suburban area.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Brown has been diagnosed with hypertension  diabetes mellitus (type II)  and hyperlipidemia. He is on medications - Metformin for diabetes  hydrochlorothiazide  and lisinopril for hypertension  and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. Mr. Brown has a family history of stroke with his mother experiencing one in her late seventies. Mr. Brown has been generally compliant with his medications but admits to occasionally forgetting his antihypertensive medications.   Key Complaints:  Mr. Brown arrives at the emergency department showing signs of acute neurological deficit. He reported that he suddenly faced difficulty in speaking and moving the right side of his body when he was having dinner with his family. His wife also noticed drooping of the right side of his face. They also recount that he seemed slightly confused at the time of the event.   Presenting Symptoms:   - Sudden numbness or weakness in the face  arm  or leg  especially on one side of the body. - Sudden confusion  trouble speaking or understanding. - Sudden trouble seeing in one or both eyes. - Sudden trouble walking  dizziness  or loss of balance or coordination. - Sudden severe headache with no known cause.   Based on the presenting symptoms and past medical history  a stroke is suspected  and immediate steps need to be taken to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate treatment.

Patient Information: A 75-year-old African-American male.   Past Medical History: The patient has a 10-year history of manageable hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medication regimen includes metformin and lisinopril. He has a history of cigarette smoking for 25 years but quit approximately 15 years ago. No known history of any surgical operations or other significant diseases. Lives alone in an urban neighborhood.  Key Complaints: The patient was brought in by paramedics after being found on the floor by a neighbor  experiencing difficulty in speaking  right-sided weakness  and loss of balance. Onset of these symptoms was believed to be an hour prior to hospital arrival according to the neighbor who contacted emergency services. The patient also complained of a severe sudden headache prior to collapse.  Possible Differential Diagnosis: Given his presenting symptoms and risk factors (hypertension  diabetes  elderly  former smoking habit)  learning should focus on stroke as a primary concern. Further investigations will be required to accurately diagnose and plan treatment.

Case Report:  Patient Profile:   Name: Mr. S Age: 65 years Sex: Male Ethnicity: Asian Occupation: Retired school teacher Location: Urban  Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of Hyperlipidemia and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  which has been controlled by oral hypoglycemic therapy for the past ten years. The patient was a smoker  but stopped smoking 5 years ago. He has no family history of stroke.  Chief complaints:   Mr. S was brought to the Emergency Department by a neighbor who found him collapsed at home. The neighbor reported that he seemed suddenly disoriented during a conversation  had slurred speech  and then fell to the ground. He also noticed weakness in the right side of the body. The symptoms began approximately 2 hours prior to arrival at the hospital. No history of headache  loss of consciousness  or incontinence was reported.   Other complaints include difficulty in controlling blood glucose levels in the past month. He also mentioned experiencing transient bouts of blurring of vision in the right eye which were temporary and lasted only for a few minutes and usually occurred during periods of high blood sugar.  Summary:   In this case  Mr. S  a 65-year-old male with a known history of Type II diabetes and hyperlipidemia presents with sudden onset of disorientation  slurred speech  and right-sided weakness  suggestive of a stroke. This paper will further discuss the differential diagnosis  comprehensive management  and rehabilitation process for cerebrovascular accidents  particularly for patients who have underlying chronic diseases.

Patient Information - Demographics: 65-year-old  African-American  Male - Occupation: Retired Electrician - Past Medical History: Hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hyperlipidemia  Obesity (BMI: 32)  No history of smoking/alcohol. - Allergies: No known drug allergies. - Current Medications: Lisinopril for Hypertension  Metformin for Diabetes  Simvastatin for Hyperlipidemia.  Chief Complaint Mr. Jones  the patient  phoned an Emergency Medical Service after waking up and experiencing unusual symptoms. He reported sudden onset of left-sided weakness  difficulty in speaking and understanding speech  worst headache of his life and vision loss in one eye upon waking up from sleep. He also mentioned a recent history of occasional episodes of numbness in the arm and dizziness.   Family Medical History  - Father died of heart disease in his 70s. - Mother is alive and has hypertension and dementia. - Brother died from stomach cancer at 66. - Sister is alive and has hypertension and diabetes.  Presenting Symptoms  - Sudden onset of significant weakness and numbness on the left side of the body. - Difficulty speaking and understanding what others are talking. - Severe headache with no known cause. - Loss of vision in one eye.  Points to ponder  - There are several risk factors for stroke present in this patient: Hypertension  Diabetes  Hyperlipidemia  Obesity  African-American ethnicity  age and family history. - His symptoms also match the classic stroke symptoms - weakness on one side of the body (Hemiparesis)  altered speech (Dysphasia)  severe headache and vision disturbance.  Objective for Medical Students - Basic understanding of Stroke - its types  causes  symptoms and risk factors. - Ability to recognize the importance of early diagnosis and immediate treatment of stroke. - Making appropriate clinical decisions surrounding the management of acute stroke patients. - Develop a comprehensive and logical stroke care plan considering factors such as patient's medical history  presenting symptoms and risk factors. - Familiarize themselves with the latest advancements in stroke management – from primary prevention to rehabilitation. - Ethical considerations in dealing with stroke patients and their families.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  John Doe is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who lives alone. He is 5’10” and weighs 188 pounds. He is retired  formerly working as a truck driver.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe is a known hypertensive and has been on medication for the past 10 years. He was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type 2 around eight years ago  for which he is also receiving treatment. Mr. Doe is a former smoker  having quit smoking cigarettes 15 years ago  after a 30-year history of 1 pack per day.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe presented in the Emergency Department with sudden onset right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking that started around 1.5 hours prior to his arrival. He was having breakfast when he noticed he was spilling his coffee and was unable to hold the cup firmly in his right hand. On trying to call for help  he found his speech was slurred. His neighbor found him struggling and brought him to the hospital.  On Arrival: He appeared conscious but distressed and anxious. His blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg  heart rate 98 bpm  respiratory rate 18 per minute and temperature 36.6°C. His blood glucose level was slightly elevated at 150 mg/dl.  The hospital's stroke team needs to quickly assess Mr. Doe using the National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale to determine the severity of the stroke and guide treatments. He will likely need to undergo imaging tests  such as a CT or MRI  to determine the type and location of the stroke. Speed in both diagnosis and treatment is critical in this case  as the faster the stroke is treated  the better the chances that Mr. Doe will have less damage and disability.

Patient Information  Name: John Thompson  Sex: Male  Age: 65 years  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired engineer  Presenting Complaints:  John presented to the emergency department with his wife who reported changes in her husband  including slurred speech  suddenly being confused  and difficulty moving his right arm and right leg. Symptoms started approximately two hours ago.   Past Medical History:  John has been managed in a primary care setup for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension for the last 10 years. His hypertension was diagnosed during his regular medical check-up and his diabetes during regular screening. Both illnesses have shown good control with medication. His medication regimen includes Metformin 500mg twice daily and Lisinopril 10mg daily. He doesn't smoke but has a 10-year history of moderate alcohol consumption. His father died of a stroke at an age of 70 years.  No known drug allergies and previous surgical procedures.  Foreseeable Learning Objectives:  1. Understand the pathophysiology of stroke and how chronic conditions like hypertension and diabetes act as risk factors. 2. Learn to manage a potential stroke case  including how to perform and interpret relevant clinical examinations  urgent imaging  and other diagnostic procedures. 3. Differentiate between types of stroke and their management options. 4. Identify the importance and strategic approach to acute stroke cases in an emergency setting. 5. Understand the long-term complications and rehabilitation process post-stroke. 6. Learn the importance of educating patients and their families about stroke prevention and health lifestyle modifications.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 72 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Marital Status: Married  Chief Complaints:  Mr. Doe arrived at the ER complaining of a sudden onset of difficulty speaking  weakness on the right side of his body  and a drooping face on the right side. These symptoms started around three hours prior to his hospital arrival. He also reported having experienced a severe headache that was unlike any headache he had ever had before.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension: Diagnosed 10 years ago  poorly controlled due to inconsistent medication adherence. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 8 years ago  reasonably controlled with daily oral hypoglycemics. 3. Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed 5 years ago  currently on statin therapy. 4. Ex-smoker: Smoked 20 cigarettes/day for 40 years  quit 4 years ago. 5. No known history of ischemic heart disease or atrial fibrillation. 6. Previous medical review did not identify any allergies.  Family History: 1. Both parents had hypertension and father died of myocardial infarction. 2. One elder brother died from a stroke  while another elder sister has Type 2 diabetes.  Social History: Mr. Doe lives with his wife and is rather sedentary  occasionally taking walks in the neighborhood. He has a history of high alcohol intake but stopped 4 years ago  the same time he quit smoking.  With the above case  medical students can discuss the potential causes of his stroke  risk factors  crucial investigations  management options  and preventive strategies. They will learn about the importance of recognizing stroke symptoms  timely management  and the implications of lifestyle and chronic illnesses in the disease's outcome.

Case Report for Stroke Education Training  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old African American male with a lifestyle slightly inclined towards sedentarism. He is a retired school teacher  living with his wife. He is a non-smoker  but moderate alcohol drinker. He is also diagnosed with hypertension and Type-2 diabetes.  Past Medical History: The patient has a 10-year history of managed hypertension and Type-2 diabetes mellitus. He has also been clinically obese for the past 15 years. His medication regimen includes Metformin for the diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. There's no family history of stroke  but his father had coronary artery disease. He has been fairly consistent with his medications  though there were occasional lapses when he didn’t take his medications as prescribed. His last routine check-up was 6 months ago.  Key Complaints: The patient was brought to the hospital by his wife after she noticed that he developed a sudden difficulty in speech. The onset was quick while he was having breakfast  and he also had difficulty moving his right arm. She also noticed drooping on the right side of his face when he tried to smile.    When questioned and examined  the patient appeared to understand everything going around him but struggled to articulate his responses. His speech was slurred  and his tongue deviated to the right. His blood pressure was noticed to be 186/95 mm Hg and sugar levels slightly elevated.  These symptoms are highly suggestive of a stroke - a medical emergency where the blood supply to a part of the brain is blocked or reduced. In light of this patient's medical history  a possible diagnosis is ischemic stroke. However  a definitive diagnosis involves medical investigations like a CT/MRI scan for further evaluation. Immediate treatment is essential to minimize brain damage and potential complications.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has been diagnosed with hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus for the last ten years. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago but with a 30 pack-year history. He has a history of occasional alcohol consumption. He does not participate in regular exercise and his diet is high in saturated fats. His father passed away at the age of 70 from a myocardial infarction and his mother had a stroke in her late 70s.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Smith presented to the emergency department in the late evening with complaints of sudden onset of right sided weakness and difficulty in speech which started approximately two hours before his arrival. He also complained of a sudden severe unbearable headache. He stated that he had lost balance and had fallen but had not lost consciousness. He mentioned that he has been not compliant with his hypertension and diabetes medications for the last one week.  Upon examination  his vital signs showed a blood pressure of 180/100 mmHg  a heart rate of 90 beats per minute  and regular respiratory rate. His random blood sugar level was high. His speech was slurred  and he was not able to lift his right arm and leg against gravity.  In conclusion  Mr. Smith’s symptoms and history shows a strong indication towards an acute ischemic stroke  which is triggered by various risk factors like hypertension  diabetes  sedentary lifestyle  and non-compliance to medications. A CT brain imaging and further investigations are required to confirm this diagnosis and initiate the appropriate treatment. Urgency in management is critical due to the time-sensitive nature of potential stroke treatments. This case emphasizes the importance of identifying and managing modifiable risk factors for stroke  as well as understanding the acute presentation and treatment of ischemic stroke.

Patient Profile: Name: John Doe Age: 67 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher  Past Medical History: John Doe has a history of hypertension for the past 15 years. He has been on a calcium channel blocker and a statin for hyperlipidemia for the last 10 years. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history but quit last year. There is no recorded history of diabetes or any neurological issue. He also has a family history of stroke and heart disease - his father had a stroke at the age of 70 and a younger brother had a myocardial infarction at the age of 62.  Current Complaints: Mr. Doe arrived at the Emergency Unit around 2 hours after the onset of sudden left-sided weakness along with difficulty speaking. He also described a mild throbbing headache. Before the symptoms started  he was at home watching television. He didn't lose consciousness but felt sudden dizziness which prompted him to call his neighbor for help.  Upon arrival  his blood pressure was elevated at 170/95 mmHg. He was alert but had dysarthria  left facial droop  and left-sided hemiparesis. A CT-scan without contrast was immediately ordered.   This training case aims to allow medical students to interact with a simulated case of stroke  be able to identify the key signs and symptoms  and understand the importance of rapid response and appropriate initial management. Thereafter  the role of effective continued management and rehabilitation should be discussed in the prevention of further complications following an initial stroke episode.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. Johnson  a 72-year-old African-American male  retired school teacher  presented in the emergency department in the late evening hours.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a significant past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker with a 40 pack-year history who quit 10 years ago. He has no known drug allergies. Current medications include metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. Family history is notable for stroke in his older brother at an early age.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Johnson's wife reported that he suddenly developed difficulty in speaking and was unable to lift his right hand while they were having dinner. He also complained of numbness on the right side of his body  including his arm  leg  and face. On questioning  Mrs. Johnson also mentioned that he had been complaining of intermittent headaches for the past couple of weeks.   On arrival:  Vital signs disclosed blood pressure of 182/95 mm Hg  heart rate of 88 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. He was afebrile. His random blood sugar level was 180 mg/dL. Neurological examination showed right-side facial droop  dysarthria  and significant weakness in lifting his right arm and right leg.   To teach medical students about stroke  this case can be used to focus on recognizing the signs and symptoms of stroke  understanding the role of risk factors  and interpreting imaging and laboratory results to reinforce understanding of stroke evaluation and management. There should be emphasis on the importance of time management in such cases 'time is brain'.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Name: John Doe Age: 72 Years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher  Medical History: John has a medical history of hypertension with limited control  well-managed type 2 diabetes  obesity  and high cholesterol. He also has a 30-year smoking history  although he quit six years ago. No history of any previous stroke or transient ischemic attack. His father had a stroke at 68.  Key Complaints: John was brought into the emergency department by his daughter who noticed sudden onset of speech difficulty and right-sided weakness when they were having lunch together earlier in the day. The daughter reports the patient's face also seemed to droop on the right side. He had no headache  dizziness  or loss of consciousness. The onset of these symptoms was approximately four hours prior to presentation. The patient reported being in his normal state of health prior to the sudden onset of these symptoms.

Case Report: Acute Ischemic Stroke   Patient Demographics: - Patient's Name: John Doe - Age: 68 years old - Sex: Male - Occupation: Retired Engineer - Race: Caucasian  Past Medical History: - Hypertension (diagnosed 18 years ago) - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM  diagnosed 10 years ago) - Hyperlipidemia (diagnosed 10 years ago) - Smoking History: 20 pack-years - No personal or family history of stroke  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the Emergency Department accompanied by his daughter. His primary complaints included:  1. Sudden and severe headache unlike any he had experienced before  which woke him up from sleep early in the morning around 3 AM. 2. Difficulty speaking and understanding speech: His daughter noticed slurred speech and found him to be confused when she visited him in the morning around 9 AM. 3. Trouble walking  dizziness  and loss of balance and coordination. 4. Right-side weakness and tingling sensation  first noticed upon waking up. 5. Blurred vision in the right eye.   The daughter reported that the symptoms had been ongoing for at least 5 hours before reaching the hospital. The patient had been asleep for the 4 hours prior to that  so the maximum time from symptom onset was unknown but could have been up to 9 hours. The patient did not have any fever  chest pain  or difficulty in breathing.  Knowing that the patient’s symptoms and the duration of those symptoms are critical in stroke care  the scenario can be used to teach medical students about the quick assessment and management of potential stroke patients. Precise time of symptom onset is particularly essential as it determines eligibility for various treatments such as IV thrombolysis and endovascular thrombectomy.

Patient Information:  - Age: 67  - Sex: Male  - Occupation: Retired teacher - Marital Status: Married  - Race: Asian   Past Medical History:  - Hypertension for 10 years  - Dyslipidemia for 7 years  - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 5 years   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. K  a 67-year-old retired teacher  came to the emergency department with his wife. His wife reports that he was fine until an hour ago when he suddenly developed slurring of speech. She also noticed that the right side of his face appeared to be drooping. He was trying to get up from the chair  but his right hand and leg seemed weak. He denies headache  chest pain or any episodes of unconsciousness.  Travel history/health behaviors: He is a nonsmoker and does not drink alcohol. He mentions he hasn't been traveling for the past year due to the current pandemic  and their lifestyle has been quite sedentary.   Medication History:  He is on antihypertensive medication  statins for dyslipidemia  and metformin for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus.  Observations and Checkings:  Upon arrival  he was conscious and vitally stable but had evident facial asymmetry. His speech was slurred and difficult to comprehend. His blood pressure was 175/105 mm Hg.   This patient presentation indicates a probable acute ischemic stroke  most likely a left middle cerebral artery territory infarct. It is important to confirm the diagnosis quickly with a head CT scan and begin appropriate treatment  since the timing is essential in the management of stroke.

Patient Information:  Mr. John Smith  67 years old  Caucasian male  retired school teacher who lives with his wife. Current smoker with a history of smoking 20 cigarettes per day for the last 40 years. Regular alcohol consumption of 2-3 glasses of wine per evening.  Past Medical History:  - Hypertension: Diagnosed 10 years ago  undergoing treatment with Lisinopril 20 mg orally once daily.  - Type II Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 6 years ago  managed with Metformin 1000 mg twice a day. - Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed 8 years ago  treated with Simvastatin 20 mg orally once daily at night.   Patient complaints: Mr. Smith came to the emergency department with his wife. His wife reported that he suddenly developed difficulty in speaking and drooping at the right side of the face. She also noted that his right arm appeared weak when he tried to reach for a glass of water  causing it to drop. Mr. Smith seemed confused and told her he was feeling a bit dizzy and experiencing a severe headache. The symptoms all started abruptly about an hour and a half ago without any preceding events or triggers. He has not previously experienced any similar episodes.   Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  patient showed some signs of confusion. Vital signs were as follows: BP- 190/100 mmHg  heart rate - 95 bmp  respiratory rate - 18 bpm  temperature - 98.6 F  and oxygen saturation - 93% on room air. Neurologic exam indicated facial droop on the right side  slurred speech  and right arm drift indicative of muscle weakness. Normal power was observed in the left arm and both legs. Other cranial nerve functions were intact. It was noted that patient could understand spoken language but had difficulty responding appropriately which suggests an expressive aphasia. Sensation was equal in all four limbs. Balance and coordination could not be tested due to the patient's motor deficits. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Clinical Suspicion: Based on the history  clinical findings and abrupt onset of symptoms  the chief suspicion is an acute ischemic stroke.   Next Steps: The patient needs immediate neurologic imaging with noncontrast CT scan of the head and possibly an MRI to confirm the diagnosis of stroke and determine its extent and location. Concurrently  urgent stroke team and neurology consultation should be called for immediate management including possible thrombolysis. In addition  primary causes of stroke such as cardiac sources should be evaluated with an EKG and echocardiogram. Further management would depend on the imaging results and additional diagnostic tests.   Teaching Points: This case reinforces the need for the rapid assessment and management of a stroke  understanding the risk factors  and the importance of thrombolytic therapy. Students should learn the use of stroke scales  stroke syndromes  and appropriate immediate measures in the context of acute stroke.

Case Report: Stroke  Patient Information:  Mr. Johnson  a 72-year-old African-American male residing in the suburban part of San Francisco.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a history of Hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus. His blood pressure and glucose levels are controlled through medications. He has a 30-year history of smoking but quit five years ago. There is also a family history of stroke; his father passed away due to an ischemic stroke at the age of 78.  Key Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Johnson presented to the emergency department by ambulance with primary complaints of sudden onset of right-sided weakness  difficulty in speech and facial drooping that started about one hour ago. He also reported that he experienced a severe headache  which he described as the worse he's ever had.  Additional patient's complaints comprise blurring of vision  difficulty swallowing  and a sudden loss of balance leading to a fall. There's no reported loss of consciousness  seizure  chest pain  or shortness of breath. There are no signs of trauma  bleeding  or any other significant findings in the initial physical examination. The patient also reported that he takes his medications regularly and did so on the day of the event.  The patient's symptoms and medical history suggest a likely acute cerebrovascular accident  commonly known as a stroke  which needs immediate medical assessment and intervention.

Patient Case:     Patient Demographics:  Ms. Louise Juan is a 67-year-old African-American woman with a five-year residence in New York City  living alone and managing her own care.  Past Medical History:  Ms. Juan is known to have hypertension and Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus  both controlled with medications. She has been a non-smoker for the past 20 years but was an active smoker for nearly 25 years prior. She has a sedentary lifestyle and her alcohol consumption is within moderate limits. There has been no major surgeries or hospitalizations in the past. On medication  she is taking Metformin for diabetes and Amlodipine for hypertension.  Key complaints:  Ms. Juan presented to the outpatient department with unraveling symptoms over the past 24 hours featuring interrupted speech  right-sided facial droop  and weakness in her right upper and lower limbs. She also states she experienced a sudden headache  which she describes as “the worst headache of her life”  along with episodes of dizziness and confusion.  Evaluation and Discussion Points:   Students should discuss the possible causes of the symptoms (Stroke vs TIA vs other differential diagnoses)  design a stepwise approach to evaluate the cause (neurological examination  imaging  labs) will discuss plan and management concerning her comorbid conditions.  In this case  it can be suspected that Ms. Juan has experienced either an ischemic stroke or a hemorrhagic stroke  given her abrupt headache and neurological symptoms. This diagnosis can be confirmed with the help of Brain imaging methods (MRI or CT) and blood tests.     Emergency management of the acute stroke including risk and benefits of initiating thrombolytic therapy (if it is an ischemic stroke) should be discussed along with measures to control high blood pressure and blood sugar levels. The need for long-term medication adjustments for hypertension and diabetes could be reviewed as well.   The role of allied health professionals including occupational therapists  physiotherapists  speech and language therapists  and dieticians in the rehabilitation and ongoing care of patients with a stroke should also be deliberated. Additionally  students should also assess and provide for the psychosocial needs of the patient post-stroke  assess risk for further strokes  and implement prevention strategies.   Outpatient follow-up care  including potential needs for home health care or rehabilitation facilities  should also be part of the designed case study. This will include discussions on lifestyle modifications  secondary prevention of strokes  and vaccinations.

Patient Information: Jose Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male  married  retired engineer  non-smoker  light alcohol consumer.  Key Complaints: Mr. Rodriguez visits the emergency department with his wife. He reports symptoms of sudden onset weakness on the right side of his body  difficulty speaking  facial droop  severe headache  and dizziness which started two hours ago.  Past Medical History: Mr. Rodriguez is known to have hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he takes medications regularly. However  he admits to sporadic adherence to medication.
