He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 5 years ago. He has no known allergies. He had an ischemic heart attack 3 years ago and has a family history of stroke  his father having passed away from one at the age of 70. No history of prior surgeries.  Physical Exam:  Alert but anxious  speech dysarthria observed. BP: 160/90 mmHg  Pulse 90/mn irregular  Oxygen saturation 96%  BMI 30. Central neurological deficit with right sided hemiparesis. Cranial nerves revealing facial asymmetry favoring the left side. His speech is slurred and hard to understand. Normal S1 and S2 heart sounds. No abnormal breath sounds.  This case allows students to approach a clinical scenario of a suspected acute stroke. It provides a platform to discuss the importance of time in management of stroke  differential diagnoses  investigations  and intensive treatment options including thrombolytics. Long term care  rehabilitation and secondary prevention could also be covered.

Patient Case:   Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 67-year-old African-American male originally from Austin  Texas  was brought in by his wife to the emergency department.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been inconsistently treated due to lack of consistent medication adherence. Mr. Smith used to be a smoker but quit 10 years ago. He has a family history of stroke  with his deceased mother having experienced stroke in her early seventies.   Key Complaints: Mr. Smith was performing his usual daily activities when his wife noticed his speech started to become slurred. Shortly after  he started to complain about sudden numbness and weakness in the left side of his body  including his arm and leg. He also complained about a sudden  severe headache with no known cause contributing to the discomfort. There was also a mention of seeming difficulty with understanding and performing simple tasks  lack of coordination  dizziness  and blurred vision from his left eye. Of note  Mr. Smith does not drink alcohol or use any illicit substances and he takes no other medications aside from those prescribed for his hypertension and hyperlipidemia.   These symptoms started around 2 hours ago and have shown no improvement. This caused his wife to promptly bring him to the hospital in fear of a potential stroke  given his family history. The symptoms described fit closely with common stroke symptoms requiring immediate medical attention. Stress  possible neglect of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and the patient's background make for a highly probable incidence of stroke.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 70 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Mechanic  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe presents with sudden onset weakness of the right side of his body  slurred speech  and difficulty in maintaining balance that started 3 hours ago.  Past Medical History:  John has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Both conditions are being managed with medication. He used to smoke but quit 15 years ago. His father had a stroke at the age of 78.  Clinic Observation:  On examination  he appears conscious but anxious. His blood pressure is elevated at 165/95 mmHg. A clear lack of coordination and diminished strength in the right side limbs was noticed. His speech seems slurred  and he appears to have difficulty understanding simple commands.  Based on these complaints and findings  a preliminary diagnosis of stroke is considered. Urgent diagnostic procedures like Computerized Tomography (CT) scan or Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) are to be carried out for definitive diagnosis  and necessary management should be initiated as early as possible given the time-sensitive nature of the condition.    Teaching Points:  This case is designed to help medical students: 1. Understand the risk factors (hypertension  diabetes  smoking  family history) and identifying symptoms (weakness on one side of the body  speech difficulties  loss of balance) associated with stroke. 2. Know the importance of time in stroke management - the so-called 'golden hour.' 3. Recognize the need for urgent diagnostic procedures (CT/MRI) and lifestyle modifications in the management of stroke. 4. Improve knowledge about primary and secondary preventive measures in stroke.

Case Report: Cerebrovascular Accident (Stroke)  I. Patient Information  - Name: John Doe - Age: 65 - Sex: Male - Race: African American - Occupation: Retired Mechanical Engineer - Marital Status: Married - Language: English  II. Past Medical History  - Hypertension  diagnosed at age 60  with irregular treatment and control - Type 2 diabetes  diagnosed at age 58  controlled with metformin - Hypercholesterolemia  diagnosed at age 62  controlled with atorvastatin - Tobacco use history  20 pack-years  quit 7 years ago - Alcohol use limited to social occasions - No history of surgeries  III. Review of Systems  - General: Unintentional weight loss over the past couple of years - Cardiovascular: Complaints of irregular heartbeats in the past but no recent complaints - Respiratory: No complaints - Gastrointestinal: No complaints - Endocrine: Diabetes is stabilized - Neurological: No history of seizures or syncope  IV. Presenting Symptoms  John presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset trouble speaking and difficulty understanding speech which began 2 hours ago  accompanied by weakness and numbness of his right arm and leg. He also mentioned difficulty maintaining balance  which made him stumble. He denied any headache  altered vision  dysphagia  facial asymmetry  or chest pain. His wife  sitting beside him  noticed the sudden alteration in his speech and motor skills  which made her bring him to the hospital. John has no family history of stroke.   The objective of this case is to test students' knowledge to recognize  diagnose  and prioritize management of acute ischemic stroke. Further investigation into the case will unravel more details regarding the specific type  source  and underlying cause of stroke and discuss the treatment protocol according to standard guidelines. Teaching points should focus on understanding the importance of time in managing stroke patients (time is brain concept)  knowledge about indicators and risk factors  interpreting results from diagnostic tools like CT/MRI and pharmacological management including thrombolysis.

Case Report  Patient Information: A 68-year-old Hispanic male  a retired construction worker.  Past Medical History: Non-compliant with hypertensive and diabetic medications for the last year  10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  smokes one pack of cigarettes per day for the last 40 years. No previous strokes or heart diseases. He had an appendectomy in his 20s.  Presenting Complaints: Patient's son reports that the father was watching TV when suddenly he started slurring his speech and found difficulty in understanding him. The patient himself noticed a gradual onset of weakness on his right side  particularly in the arm and face. Patient also complains of a mild headache and dizziness. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  abdominal pain  or any other significant symptoms.  This scenario raises a high suspicion for ischemic stroke  most likely caused by the patient's long-standing  uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  and significant smoking history – all major risk factors for stroke. The sudden onset of symptoms with language and motor impairment is very suggestive of a left hemispheric ischemic event. Given this information  it is necessary to assess the patient immediately for further neurological deficits  evaluate symptom onset time  and consider possible thrombolytic therapy based on the patient's overall condition and symptom onset time.   Learning Objectives: 1. Recognize the classic signs and symptoms of an acute ischemic stroke. 2. Understand the importance of rapid assessment  intervention  and management in patients presenting with stroke-like symptoms. 3. Comprehend the major risk factors for stroke  and the importance of proper control and management of these conditions. 4. Learn to communicate empathetically with patients and their relatives during highly stressful situations. 5. Understand the role of thrombolytic therapy in the management of acute ischemic stroke and the factors affecting its administration.

Patient Case: Mr. John Johnson  Demographics:  Age: 68 years  Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer Marital Status: Married Residence: Suburban   Past Medical History:  Mr. John Johnson has a known medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking for 25 years. Family history includes father who suffered a stroke at age 70.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. John Johnson was brought to the emergency department by his spouse. She reported that earlier in the day  he has suddenly developed slurred speech  right side weakness  and difficulty in walking. She also reported that Mr. Johnson was complaining of a severe headache  unusual for him. He initially dismissed these symptoms  but his condition progressively worsened over two hours.   Other noted symptoms also included sudden difficulty in understanding speech  facial paralysis (primarily on the right side)  dizziness  and loss of balance and coordination. There had been no recent trauma or other illness reported. Furthermore  Mr. Johnson did not have any known allergies to medications  and he was currently taking medications including a beta blocker and a statin for his hypertension and hyperlipidemia  respectively.   The motive behind this case is to train medical students to recognize the early signs of a stroke promptly  understand the risk factors  and know the initial steps in managing such a patient in the emergency department.

Patient Profile: - Name: John Doe - Age: 58 years old - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian - Profession: Retired military officer  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe presented with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and difficulty in speech. The episode lasted for approximately an hour without any further progression of symptoms.   Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension  controlled with regular medication for the last 10 years. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the last 7 years  moderate control. 3. History of smoking 1 pack/day for the past 30 years  quit smoking 2 years ago.  Family History: - Father: Expired due to myocardial infarction at 65 years old. - Mother: Diagnosed with stroke at 70 years old  currently 78 and living with related complications.  Drug History:  1. Taking metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes. 2. Amlodipine 10mg  one tablet daily for hypertension.  Allergies: No known drug allergies.  Social History:  Retired military officer and currently works as a security consultant. No history of alcohol or drug misuse. Married with 2 children.  Relevant Review of Systems:  - General: No recent weight loss  fever  or chills. - Cardiovascular: No report of chest pain or palpitations. - Respiratory: No report of cough or shortness of breath. - Neurological: Denies any previous episodes of weakness or difficulty in speech.  The timing and nature of the symptoms raise suspicion of a transient ischemic attack (TIA) or ""mini-stroke"". Comprehensive assessment including neurological examination  blood tests  ECG  and neuroimaging are needed to confirm the diagnosis and plan the treatment. Given his medical and family history  Mr. Doe is at a higher risk for stroke and he should be counseled on risk factor modification.

Case Report - Stroke  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 64 years Gender: Male Ethnicity: African-American Occupation: Retired engineer  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension for the last 10 years  for which he is irregular in taking medications. He has an established history of smoking for 30 years but quit 5 years ago. He also has hyperlipidemia.  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the Emergency Department accompanied by his daughter  stating he woke up from a nap with the sudden onset of weakness of his right arm and leg. He noticed his mouth appeared to be 'drooping' on the right side and his speech was slightly slurred. He states he experienced an intense headache  described as the worst he ever had  with no known triggers  which was accompanied by some mild dizziness and blurred vision. No symptoms of confusion  seizures  nausea  or incontinence were reported. His symptoms began two hours prior to arriving at the hospital. No similar previous episodes were reported by the patient or his family.    [It's a clear-cut case of stroke  high suspicion of ischemic type  given the history of risk factors such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  age  and ethnicity. The sudden onset of symptoms with clear lateralization also indicates a high likelihood of a stroke. The case will continue with investigations ordered (MRI  angiogram  CT scan  etc.)  management initiated including administration of thrombolytic therapy if within window period  controlled lowering of BP  etc.]

Case Study: Stroke  Patient Demographics Sex: Male Age: 68 Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired IT Engineer Residence: Urban area  living alone  Past Medical History: Patient has a known history of hypertension and high cholesterol for the past ten years  controlled with regular medication (amlodipine and atorvastatin respectively). He uses alcohol moderately but doesn't smoke. No history of diabetes or other chronic diseases. No known drug allergies. He's been fairly adherent to prescribed medications and regular follow-up.  Key Complaints: The patient called emergency services after waking up in the morning and finding the left side of his body to be weak. He also reported difficulty speaking and a drooping face on the left side. Additional symptoms he reported include a sudden  severe headache with no known cause  trouble seeing in one or both eyes  and trouble walking due to dizziness  loss of balance  and loss of coordination.  This case report sets the context and foundation for the students to further discuss the clinical evaluation  diagnostics  management  and potential complications of stroke. This also provides a platform to discuss stroke prevention and rehabilitation strategies.

Patient Profile:   Mr. Thomas  a 68-year-old white male  retired factory worker  is brought to the emergency department (ED) by his daughter.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Thomas is a known hypertensive and has type II diabetes mellitus managed principally with lifestyle modifications and medications (insulin). He quit smoking 10 years ago but has a history of smoking one pack a day for almost 30 years. He also has hyperlipidemia. He denies any history of heart disease  but he hasn't undergone a preventive health check-up for the past 3 years. Family history is significant  with his father expiring from an ischemic stroke in his 70s.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Thomas' daughter noticed that her father woke up from his afternoon nap with slurred speech and the right side of his face seemed to be drooping. He also complained about difficulty in moving his right arm. These symptoms have persisted for just over an hour. He is alert and oriented but seems very anxious. He denies headache  but admits difficulty in maintaining balance. He also mentions that he forgot to take his hypertension medicine for the past couple of days.   In addition to the above case  mention that the initial measures in the ED include a quick assessment using the FAST (Face drooping  Arm weakness  Speech difficulties and Time to call emergency) test  maintaining the patient's ABC (airway  breathing  and circulation) and prompt coordination with a neurologist or stroke specialist. Make the students understand that a stroke is a medical emergency and demands immediate treatment. This can help underline the necessity for timely recognition and treatment of a stroke.

Case Report:   Patient Demographics: Name: Patient X Age: 68 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: African-American Occupation: Retired Marital Status: Widower Residence: Urban  Past Medical History: Patient X has been diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past ten years. Compliance with antihypertensive medication and insulin therapy has been inconsistent  as evidenced by elevated blood pressure and HbA1C levels on routine check-ups. He has a 40-year history of smoking but quit five years ago. He has no known allergies but has a family history of stroke and cardiovascular disease.  Key Complaints: Patient X presented to the emergency department with acute onset slurring of speech  right-sided facial droop  and right-sided weakness affecting the arm more than the leg  beginning about 2 hours ago. He complained of a sudden  severe headache prior to these symptoms. He denied experiencing any visual disturbances  seizures  loss of consciousness  chest pain  or shortness of breath. However  he reported difficulty in maintaining balance when he tried to walk. Notably  he was unable to lift his right arm and had a strange sensation on the right side of his body. His speech was difficult to understand  and he appeared quite anxious.  This case report provides an opportunity for medical students to explore the diagnosis  management  and possible complications of stroke. It also emphasizes the importance of knowledge about risk factors and the role of primary prevention in high-risk populations.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 68 years old Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a ten-year history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. He is a former smoker with a 40 pack-year history  but quit about 15 years ago. He has a known history of hypercholesterolemia.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Doe was brought to the emergency by his daughter after he experienced sudden onset of left-sided weakness and slurred speech. The daughter reported that her father complained of severe headache and dizziness about an hour prior to the deterioration in his condition. Additionally  she observed some confusion in him while arranging his morning medications.  Physical Examination: Mr. Doe exhibits facial asymmetry with left-sided weakness. He is alert but has difficulty speaking and understanding language (dysphasia). He shows left-sided neglect and has difficulty moving his left extremities. His vision check reveals some loss in the right visual field of both eyes.  This case study focuses on a hypothetical acute ischemic stroke patient. Students should be encouraged to consider stroke interventions  the importance of 'time is brain'  and consider primary and secondary stroke prevention strategies. The comorbidities will also allow discussion on control and management of diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia.

CASE REPORT:   Demographics: The patient is Mr. John  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  a retired teacher living in the urban area of San Francisco. He is a non-smoker but has a history of mild alcohol consumption.   Past Medical History: John has a history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medications include Metformin and Lisinopril. He also has a family history of cerebrovascular accidents  with his father experiencing a stroke at age 75.  Key Complaints: John presented to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of left-sided facial droop  weakness in the left upper and lower limbs  and noticed difficulty in speech with slurred words. These symptoms started while he was having breakfast approximately 2 hours before arriving at the hospital. His wife who was with him at that time did not notice any loss of consciousness  seizure  headache or dizziness.  The patient denies having chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  or any gastrointestinal symptoms. However  his wife confirms that John has been non-compliant with his prescribed hypertension and diabetes management medication for the past week.   Comments: The symptoms presented by Mr. John are characteristic of a right hemispheric stroke office  most likely an ischemic stroke due to his history of hypertension and non-compliance with medications. As the next step  immediate diagnostic procedures should be implemented  such as physical neurological examination and cerebral imaging (like a CT scan) to confirm the diagnosis  identify the size and location of the stroke  and to implement the appropriate management strategy. If the stroke is confirmed to be ischemic and considering the time since symptom onset  thrombolytic therapy should be evaluated as a treatment option as well. The patient's non-compliance with his chronic disease management needs to be addressed to prevent future similar episodes.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  68-year-old Caucasian male  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes and Hypertension ten years ago. He is a former smoker  having given up the habit 5 years ago. He has a family history of stroke  with his father having suffered a stroke at age 72. He is compliant with his prescribed medication  which includes Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. His last documented check-up was six months ago showing blood pressure and blood sugar levels within acceptable levels under medication.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith is brought to the Emergency Room by his daughter. According to her  he suddenly developed difficulty in speaking (slurred speech)  drooping on one side of his face  and a sudden  severe headache with no apparent cause. He also seems to be having trouble maintaining his balance. The symptoms onset was quick and appeared when he was having breakfast with his family this morning.   These symptoms are indicative of a potential cerebrovascular accident or stroke  which triggers an immediate and urgent response from the medical team. Brain Imaging  neurological assessments  and intervention  as well as management options  are integral parts of the medical care that Mr. Smith requires quickly.

Case Report: Stroke Management for Medical Students  Patient Information: • Demographics - Mr. S. R.  65-year-old Caucasian male.  • Occupation - Recently retired as a business executive. • Residence - Lives alone in an urban setting.  Medical History: • Past Illnesses - Hypertension and Diabetes Mellitus Type II  both controlled with medication. • Surgeries - None. • Allergies - Beta-lactam antibiotics. • Medications - Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension. • Lifestyle - Sedentary lifestyle with moderate alcohol consumption  non-smoker. • Family History - Father died of coronary artery disease  mother had a stroke at 67.  Presenting Complaints: 1. Sudden numbness and weakness on left side of body - face  arm  and leg. 2. Difficulty in speaking and understanding spoken words. 3. Vision problems in one eye - feeling of ""darkening"" in visual field. 4. Trouble walking and maintaining balance  has experienced a recent fall. 5. Severe headache with no known cause.  Please note: These symptoms came on suddenly and have been ongoing for about 2 hours. The patient is in the emergency department. Students are to proceed with the case as if they are part of the healthcare team providing immediate care. This is to see if students can appropriately diagnose the situation  foresee potential complications  and dictate possible treatments/management plans.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 68-year-old African-American male  Occupation: Retired middle school teacher  Living Situation: Lives alone in a suburban area  relies on daughter for transport and buying groceries. Daughter visits twice a week.  Past Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes. He quit smoking 10 years ago but has a 30 pack-year history of smoking prior to quitting. Mr. Smith drinks alcohol moderately. His father died of a stroke at the age of 72.  Presenting Complaints:  - Mr. Smith reports sudden onset of slurred speech  right-sided facial drooping  and weakness on the right side of his body during breakfast. - He attempted to lift his right arm but couldn’t.  - Daughter notes he seemed confused and off-balance when she dropped in for a visit in the morning.   Emergency Medical Services were contacted immediately  and Mr. Smith was transported to the hospital. The symptoms started around an hour prior to the hospital arrival. During transport  blood glucose level measured to rule out hypoglycemia - results were within normal range.   Initial Assessment in Emergency Department: - Vital signs: Blood pressure - 180/95mmHg  Pulse - 82 beats per minute  Respiratory rate - 18 breaths per minute  Temperature - 98.2°F  Oxygen saturation - 98% on room air. - Physical examination reveals Mild right-sided facial droop  Dysarthria  Right arm drift  and Mild confusion. - NIHSS (National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale) score is 8.  This case study is aimed to help medical students understand the recognition  initial assessment  and management principles in a patient presenting with acute ischemic stroke. It also highlights the importance of time sensitivity in stroke management. The vital role of thorough history taking and quick physical examination in deciphering a stroke also becomes evident in this scenario.

Patient Information:   Mr. Robert Smith  a 65 -year-old African-American male  retired bank manager  Background Information and Relevant Social History: Mr. Smith lives with his wife in a suburban setting. He is particularly fond of fatty  fried foods and his diet lacks adequate fruits and vegetables. He smokes half a packet of cigarettes daily and does not engage in any regular physical activity. He has a family history of hypertension and cerebrovascular diseases.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith was diagnosed with hypertension and Hyperlipidemia 10 years ago  for which he has been taking Losartan and Atorvastatin respectively. He has a 15-year history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled on Metformin and Insulin.  Key Complaints: The patient initially presented with sudden onset of unilateral weakness in the right side of his body encountered when he was at home. He also reports difficulties in speaking  slurred speech and numbness in the right side of his face. His wife also noticed that he had a drooping right corner of the mouth. These symptoms started abruptly about 2 hours ago. There is no history of loss of consciousness  seizure  or recent trauma.  In short  the case presentation must focus on eliciting signs of acute cerebrovascular attack (stroke) in a patient with multiple longstanding vascular risk factors  including hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. Evaluation should include a thorough neurologic exam  prompt imaging with Head CT and/or MRI  and exploration of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) eligibility.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mrs. Laura Stevens Age: 68 Gender: Female Ethnicity: African-American  Chief Complaint: ""At around 7:30 am this morning  I started feeling weakness in my right arm and leg. All of a sudden  I also had difficulty speaking properly. It was quite frightening.""  Past Medical History: Mrs. Stevens is a diagnosed hypertensive for the past 12 years. She is also a type 2 diabetic for the past 5 years. Both these conditions have been reasonably well-controlled with medication and lifestyle management. She does not smoke or drink alcohol  but her BMI indicates that she is obese (BMI 32). She had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 3 years ago. Her mother passed away due to a stroke at age 70.  Social History: Mrs. Stevens is widowed and lives with her adult son who works from home. She is largely independent but occasionally requires assistance for certain tasks due to arthritis.  Physical Exam: Mrs. Stevens displays facial asymmetry with the right side of her face drooping. Her speech appears slurred  and she demonstrates difficulty in raising her right arm. Her blood pressure reading is 160/95 mm Hg. Her blood sugar is slightly elevated (fasting blood glucose: 160 mg/dl).  Summary: Mrs. Stevens is a 68-year-old African American female with the hypertensive and diabetic history experiencing sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech. Given her history of TIA  it is possible we might be dealing with an acute stroke case. Immediate intervention and management is necessary.
